column2: The stock market squeaked through with a gain yesterday, thereby making it five winning sessions in a row, while some big-name issues posted impressive advances.

ALBANY, June 4 -- The Senate today passed and sent to the Assembly a bill authorizing the Port of New York Authority to finance and construct high-speed rail links from Kennedy International Airport to Manhattan and from Newark Airport to Newark and its suburban areas.
A cheek twitching, Juan Arias stared at the numbered cubes yesterday as post positions were drawn for today's Belmont Stakes.
It all began when someone decided to try to revive the concept of the Round Table lunches, those informal meetings of conversational wits that have become part of American literary folklore.

GENEVA, June 4 -- Sources close to the European Free Trade Association see as a "very good beginning" for four of its member states the reported plan of European Economic Community officials for a free-trade arrangement with European countries not seeking entry into the Common Market.

As a Philadelphian I feel it necessary to reply to your editorial of May 20 in which you denigrate Frank Rizzo, the victor in the recent Democratic primary for Mayor. What is depressing is not his victory, as you suggest, but the surprising attitude of liberals that the common man is incapable of voting wisely, unless of course the liberals' candidate wins.

HALIFAX, N. S. -- In alliance with Edmund de Rothschild, the British merchant banker, Nova Scotia has begun a new campaign to harness the mighty tides of the Bay of Fundy in order to generate electric power.
OTTAWA, June 4 (AP) -- Canadian and Soviet representatives today signed a contract for the sale of 81.5 million bushels of Canadian wheat to the Soviet Union for approximately $145-million.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 4 (AP) -- Fighting waned then flared again today in the weeklong battle for control of the Vihear Sour Marshes, 15 miles east of Pnompenh. The marshes control the eastern approaches to the capital.
CAIRO, June 4 -- The chief United States diplomat in Cairo, Donald C. Bergus, will fly to Paris Sunday for talks with Secretary of State William P. Rogers on the "current situation in Egypt."

As the Harlem River Consumers Cooperative completed its third year of operation yesterday, its founder said that its success had led it to a position where it was planning to help start 26 similar co-ops.
The Boston Red Sox, Chicago Cubs and Cincinnati Reds staged their own hit parade last night and it was sour music for 13 opposing pitchers.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A high White House official cautioned newsmen today not "to put much store" in reports that President Nixon was displeased that J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, had not invited Commissioner Murphy to a meeting here yesterday to discuss recent police slayings.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., formally divested itself yesterday of its cable television and TV syndication operations by transferrng them to Viacom, Inc., and mailing 3,791,000 shares of Viacom stock to C.B.S. shareholders of record last Dec. 17.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 -- Allied military intelligence officers are paying close attention to the heavy mortar and rocket fire that the enemy has been using since the close of the South Vietnamese thrust against the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos in March.

Our citizenry seem to have reached a consensus on the merits of withdrawing our troops from Vietnam, but this coincidence of opinion should not obscure the differing motivations which have produced it. These differences have already caused major disagreements on how quickly we should withdraw those troops, and soon another issue will emerge to divide our nation.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Federal Government disclosed plans today to impose racial quotas on Federal construction projects in Chicago, after a voluntary equal hiring program there collapsed.

PARIS, June 4 -- The French Government is negotiating with Rolf Liebermann, the internationally known director of the Hamburg Staatsoper, to take over the management of the Paris Opera, it has been learned here.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Justice Department announced plans today for a $7.5-million Federal grant to intensify the prosecution of narcotics cases in New York City.

A group of reform-minded residents of South Brooklyn banded together not long ago to form a political club, the Independent Neighborhood Democrats. As politically aware citizens they were interested in revising national priorities, improving the delivery of municipal services, registering new voters and supporting enlightened candidates. They started by distributing questionnaires testing their neighborhood's sentiment on a broad range of issues.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended May 29 totaled an estimated 16.3 billion ton-miles, 7.6 per cent above the year-earlier week, which included the Memorial Day holiday, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea has often said in recent weeks of intensive activity at Albany that he intended to maintain "orderly procedure" in the usually hectic wind-up days of the legislative session. Almost invariably in the past the closing days have been wild and woolly, with deliberation ignored and unexamined bills swept into law by the carload.

The city's plan to negotiate to buy Yankee Stadium was approved by the City Council yesterday, over the objections of its minority leader, who said that Mayor Lindsay had not told the truth about the plan.

BOSTON, June 4 -- In the bright morning sun that flooded a 28th-floor executive suite at the Sheraton-Boston Hotel, some of America's major booksellers were the guests this week of the McGraw-Hill Book Company for coffee, sweet rolls and sweet talk.
Employes of the Museum of Modern Art voted yesterday to be represented in collective bargaining by the Professional and Administrative Staff Association.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June (UPI) -- Jose Napoles scored an eighth-round knockout over the welterweight champion, Billy Backus, tonight to regain the crown he lost six months ago in Syracuse.
Heavy new buying and a scarcity of sellers sent new crop corn futures prices up yesterday, leading a parade of higher commodity prices on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Recent letters to The Times have opposed extension of the draft, asserted that it can be justified only during a declared war and have, of necessity, urged support of a volunteer army.
Four more major retail chains, including Sears, Roebuck Co., the country's largest, reported yesterday increased sales in May over the 1970 month.

YONKERS, June 4 -- The Martin Tananbaum International, harness racing's l 1/2-mile counterpart of the Belmont Stakes, wound up with Laverne Hanover and Rum Customer giving the Billy Haughton Stable entry a one, two finish at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

TEL AVIV, June 4 -- The Israeli Government announced today that it had uncovered a 10-man Syrian espionage ring in the occupied Golan heights. It said that the ring had been led by Sheik Kamal Assad Kanj, a prominent figure in the Druse community and once a member of the Syrian parliament.
CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, June 4 (UPI) -- Steve Melnyk and Jim Simons won semifinal matches today to line up an all-American final in the 76th British Amateur golf championship.

The Task Force on Child Abuse and Neglect submitted its final, formal report to Mayor Lindsay yesterday amid signs that some of its recommendations are making it easier to deal with child abuse problems.

Dancers and dance companies must reach numerically larger audiences and provide greater service to the general public than in the past if increased government funds in the dance field are to be justified, the Association of American Dance Companies was told during its current annual conference here.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 4 -- for the first time in the history of intercollegiate lacrosse the national championship will be decided by combat tomorrow as Cornell and Maryland meet at Hofstra Stadium in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament final.

OWINGS MILLS, Md. -- A Middle East settlement as envisaged in U.N. Resolution 242 will depend very largely upon the degree of influence the U.S. is willing to apply to persuade Israel that her ultimate survival depends on acceptance by her neighbors and international guarantees, rather than on any specific frontiers secured by continuing military superiority.

TEL AVIV -- With whom will Israel sign peace even assuming the best will in the world on the part of President Sadat? In the twenty-three years of Israel's existence as a state, there have been twenty-six successful revolutions in the Arab countries and at least forty-two unsuccessful revolutions.

Ernie Wilkins, who is better known as a jazz arranger than as a saxophonist, and Chris Woods, who is better known as a jazz saxophonist than as an arranger, have combined both aspects of their talents as co-leaders of a quintet that made its debut yesterday afternoon at the Jazz Center, 57 West 57th Street.
LONDON, June 4 -- The British Overseas Airways Corporation said today that it would suspend its mid-Pacific service Nov. 1 and therefore would no longer stop at San Francisco.
LOS ANGELES, June 4 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan insisted today that he had "paid every tax" he owed.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Six national higher education associations today issued a statement recommending broad changes in policy in the future role of colleges and universities in the Reserve Officers Training Corps.

A team of scientists who drilled sample cores from the bottom of the Pacific Ocean has reported finding evidence of a mysterious but major change that took place around the earth between 50 and 100 million years ago.
Albert Shanker has been reelected for a two-year term as president of the United Federation of Teachers, winning 86 per cent of the vote in a three-man race, the federation announced yesterday.
Gyorgy Lukacs was an eminent philosopher and literary critic, the disputatious creator of a Marxist system of esthetics.

While this has been one of the most bitterly divisive state legislative sessions in years, a small bill emerges on which both majority Republicans and minority Democrats seem to find themselves in warm agreement. This is a politician's bill. It provides for a pay boost.

Palestine awakens again to the conflicting claims of race, religion and government. Both Israelis and Arabs are raking old ashes, stirring smouldering fires and fanning fanaticism. Each side refuses to yield an inch. The Israelis denounce the arming of Arabs by the U.S.S.R. and other bystanders.

A few months ago, 12 of the artists who live and work in Westbeth, the artists' housing development in the West Village, mounted a large exhibition of their work in four sizable galleries adjoining the building's courtyard at 155 Bank Street, between Washington and West Streets.

NEWARK, June 4 -- Samuel Di Feo, a Government witness in the trial of nine Hudson County and Jersey City officials, has been threatened with death if he does not "keep quiet," the United States Attorney's office said today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A university professor who revolted a dozen years ago against conventional woofers and tweeters in high-fidelity sound reproduction was granted a patent this week for his own successful loudspeaker system.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 4 -- The Government of Pakistan appears to be trying to bring some former leading members of the outlawed Awami League of East Pakistan back into the national fold.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, whose unannounced Presidential campaign has been plagued by financial and organizational problems, is again cutting back and realigning his staff.
The election of Matt Meyer, retired Scripps-Howard Newspapers executive, as president and chairman of the Scripps-Howard Foundation was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 5 (UPI) -- Jim Shellenback walked Reggie Jackson with the bases loaded and then threw a wild pitch for another run in the 21st inning this morning to give the Oakland Athletics a 5-3 victory over the Washington Senators in the sixth longest game in American League history.

Some Manhattan stores were still openly selling pirated eight-track cartridge and cassette tape recordings yesterday, despite the raid Thursday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office on 14 other shops accused of selling similar tapes.
ALBANY, June 4 -- Republican and Democratic legislative leaders were reported nearing agreement this evening on a tax package for New York City of at least $500-million.

JUNEAU, Alaska, June 4 (AP) -- Gov. William A. Egan has vetoed a bill that would have given Alaska the earliest Presidential primary in the United States. The bill would have scheduled the election in February of Presidential years.

PARIS, June 4 -- The Government and Parliament prepared this week to take steps toward the new society that Premier Jacques Chaban-Delmas has promised the country. But the country continued to show signs of agitated impatience with its present lot.

British Overseas Airways Corporation said yesterday that it would fly students under 26 years of age between New York and London for $210 round-trip in the peak summer season and $190 during other periods.
The new issue market displayed a mixed performance this week in quiet trading. Only a couple of companies made first public offerings of their common shares.

The Congressional bill to create public service jobs for the unemployed is a constructive response both to the immediate exigencies of the recession and to the long-term needs of unskilled workers. With nearly five million persons out of work, including many recent veterans of Vietnam, the nation has a moral as well as an economic obligation to take effective action to offset the human consequences of a downswing in the business cycle.
All right, you students of logic: which is better, to be precisely wrong or vaguely right?

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The hijacker of a United Air Lines 737 jet who demanded to be flown to Israel was captured at Dulles International Airport tonight when the flight engineer, acting on the advice of a psychiatrist in the control tower, talked the hijacker into giving up his pistol.
The burning of coal around the world may be adding almost as much mercury to the environment as the waste from all industrial processes combined, a University of Miami scientist has reported.

BRUSSELS, June 4 -- Britain was strongly criticized by the Australian Deputy Prime Minister, J. Douglas Anthony, today for the problems caused to Australia by the British bid to join the European Common Market.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 30 -- Along University Road the students are nervous about final examinations, angry about the rugby club's planned tour of South Africa and delighted that the campus film theater will finally show "I Am Curious (Yellow)."

At a time when our systems of dealing with social deviance and dependence seem in perilous disrepair, when courts and jails are in turmoil, welfare snarled, hospitals swollen, and "law and order" become no more than the bully's rallying cry, this diligent work of American social history by a young professor at Columbia casts a little quiet light around it.

For Americans perhaps the most interesting and most startling aspect of the 23d Danish Ballet Festival, which ends in Copenhagen tonight, was the appearance of Bruce Marks, of American Ballet Theater, who made his debut with the Royal Danish Ballet as James in "La Sylphide."
The ingenuity of 18th-century Connecticut cabinetmakers is ably demonstrated in the newly installed furniture galleries at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford.

Patients in the waiting rooms at the West Side Medical Centers, two of the largest methadone-maintenance clinics in the country, voiced fears, sometimes bordering on panic, as they talked yesterday about the Federal Government's order that the clinics be closed.

LAST December -- while relations between the Soviet Union and the United States were strained due to allegations of anti-Semitism in Russia (leading to bombings and other incidents in the U. S. and to the cancellation of the Bolshoi Theater's scheduled U. S. tour) -- a group of 33 American "citizen diplomats" was busily roving and probing the Soviet Union.

The books of this monumental series are travelogues into culinary fairylands, with recipes on the side, where food is always interesting, appetizing, fresh, well-cooked and well-served. They remind me of Disneyland: charming and often irresistible combinations of nostalgia and phantasy, where all is the way we would like it to be, with no nasty surprises lurking around dirty corners.

Can silk survive in a world of man-made fibers? The Queen of Fibers, as it is sometimes called, probably will continue as a viable textile material if it is not priced out of the market. Silk fabrics are still in demand in the realm of high fashion and will be included in many of the couture lines for the fall season.

Four men who were arrested early yesterday in an attempted holdup of a black social club in the Bronx are being investigated in the murder of two city policemen and the wounding of two others last month, an assistant district attorney said last night.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Whenever Democratic Representatives from New York congregate here these days the conversation turns to the latest rumors about what the Republican-controlled Legislature in Albany may be up to in the drawing of the state's new Congressional districts.

Edward W. Carter, the lean, scholarly merchant who bought Bergdorf Goodman last March and who built Broadway-Hale Stores in the last quarter-century into the West's largest retail company, was fortunate in having had several career alternatives.
GREENVALE, L. I. June 5 -- Thousands of students who were graduated from Long Island colleges this week are finding there is little available for them on the job market.
The nation's 5 million unemployed found themselves last week to be pawns in a battle over public service jobs that may provide more work for politicians than it does for the jobless.
AMONG the many courses, workshops and seminars that are being offered to photographers this spring and summer are the following:
SAN DIEGO, June 5 (AP) -- Bob Bailey's tie-breaking single in the two-run sixth inning gave the Montreal Expos a 2-1 triumph over the San Diego Padres today.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, June 5 -- Steve Melnyk, former United States Amateur champion, defeated Jim Simons, 3 and 2, in the 36-hole final today and became the first American since 1967 to win the British Amateur golf championship.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 5 -- Ch. Twin Ponds Plaid Cymry, a 3-year-old Welsh terrier owned by Mrs. Robert D. Clark Jr. of Middleburg, Va., and handled by Peter J. Green of Bowmansville, Pa., won his fourth best in show today.

Madison Square Garden was filled Friday evening with the whine of steel guitars and voices that reflected various reverberations of the twang of the Southern hills. They came from a sampling of Nashville music, bundled together as "Nashville at the Garden."
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 5 -- Cornell won the first National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse championship today, beating Maryland, 12-6, at Hofstra Stadium.

It was eight o'clock on a June morning with the sun shining on the bay, and the women of Sandy-cove were at their household chores or doing their shopping, most of them in their customary attire for summer and winter alike of drab wool and, if they were out of doors, a coarse shawl by way of headgear.
Hell's Kitchen became the site of a fairground yesterday as part of an effort to rejuvenate the seedy West Side section of tenements and brownstones.

And now comes Ellen Liman, a liberated decorator whose do-your-own thing interiors are clearly going to give some people a case of the pip. She advocates dog leashes as window shade pulls, night stands made of orange crates and plastic laundry baskets as chandeliers.

MOSCOW, June 5 -- Reliable diplomatic sources report that the number of Jews permitted to leave the Soviet Union dropped somewhat in May from the April and March figures, but that it still represented a relatively high figure.

Your May 23 report on the request of the presidents of black colleges for greater governmental and philanthropic support calls public attention to an urgent national problem. I write to endorse the request of these educators.
John Dewey High School in Coney Island has become the first in the city to offer Regents credit to students studying marine biology.

James A. Michener, working with a group of researchers and after exhaustive interviewing, has compiled a detailed account of the grim events that ended in the shooting of four students at Kent State University in May, 1970. Each of his book's 559 pages is crammed with evidence, statements, analyses, and most of those pages suggest also a prodigious effort, on Mr. Michener's part, to achieve even-handed treatment of his harrowing material.

WASHINGTON -- When First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was judged guilty of participating in war crimes, a broad element of the public hooted at the justice of an army that brought lieutenants to the dock but wouldn't treat a general that way.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Sal Bando's home run in the second inning and Rick Monday's homer in the fourth helped Jim (Catfish) Hunter and the Oakland Athletics to a 6-1 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

BRIDGE does not distinguish between amateurs and professionals. Tournaments are open to all regardless of the way they earn their living. Inevitably, however, the names best-known to the general public are those of the professionals, particularly those who write books with wide circulation.

Hundreds of municipal workers are being laid off, playgrounds closed and services curtailed as cities large and small across New York State generally report budget crises -- in part attributed to state cutbacks.

THE stock market snapped out of its mild month-long slump last week without the benefit of any rash of bullish news to propel it upward. It nevertheless managed to achieve moderate gains in slightly more active trading.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 5 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority is appealing to private non-profit foundations for a $415,000 grant to help rectify the environmental problems caused by uncontrolled strip mining of Appalachian coal for T.V.A. boilers.

SINCE cigarette companies no longer may advertise on TV, they've decided to back televised tournaments to keep their names before the viewing public. Most of the big sports events already have backers, of course, so the tobacco people are using great imagination to come up with programs to attract a high rating.

CAPE MAY, N. J., June 5 -Four pilots were killed today when their World War II planes were involved in two separate midair collisions during a race at the Cape May County Airport. No one else was hurt.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 (AP) -- Larry Dierker of the Houston Astros posted his fifth consecutive victory and 10th in 11 decisions by defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-1, tonight with ninth-inning help from Fred Gladding.

HAGI, Japan -- Strolling aimlessly in the evening light, I grinned at a band of young boys playing in the street, and was greeted in return by excited shouts: "Gaijin, gaijin!" -- "A foreigner, a foreigner!" It was a sure sign that I had left the tourist trail behind and reached my goal: the "other" Japan.
Economics is a two-way street today for colleges and universities.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 5 -- The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation named today 32 black veterans of the military, including five from the New York area, as recipients of Martin Luther King Jr. Fellowships.
" Cook is most pleased you liked the ragout, sir. You're the finest judge of horseflesh in all of England."

MOSCOW, June 5 -- The Soviet Union reacted cautiously today to yesterday's communique by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that called for further probing of Soviet intentions on the reduction of forces in Central Europe.
LONDON -- Says Bagehot in "The English Constitution":
A polar bear at the Central Park Zoo was shot dead by a policeman yesterday after the animal sank his teeth into the arm of a man who had reached into his cage.

ONE of the most enjoyable exhibitions I have seen in months has turned up with no preliminary fanfare -- and for that matter, no current fanfare -- at the Metropolitan Museum, an institution that seldom misses a chance to flourish its trumpets. Called "Ancient Egyptian Writing," if you can imagine such a thing, the show is most instructive, although to use that word so early in a report is to risk turning the reader off.

LONG BEACH, L. I. June 5 -- Babe Ruth struck out, Joe DiMaggio missed an easy pop fly and Christy Mathewson was hit unmercifully as a softball team of narcotics addicts undergoing a methadone treatment program at the Long Beach Memorial Hospital played a team of local policemen this week.

Your article entitled "Caribbean Black Power" by Wade Greene (Travel section, Feb. 7) requires, I think, some clarification. First, many of your readers do not realize that Tobago is separated from Trinidad not only by 20 miles of water but also by attitudes and ideologies that could hardly be more different.

Nguyen Van Thieu was elected President of South Vietnam in 1967 by only 35 per cent of the vote in an 11-man race. A new election is scheduled for Oct. 3, and Mr. Thieu, according to Saigon reports, would like to make sure his margin is greater this time.
LOS ANGELES, June 5 -- The New York Mets' three-game winning streak ended tonight when they wasted 10 hits and were defeated by the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-0.

Robbin's Rest is not a singles' community and the Ocean Beach ferries do not link up with the train schedules (the latter being a situation which has annoyed and puzzled me for the past six years while renting in Robbin's Rest) -- as was said in the article on summering on Fire Island (Travel section, May 23).

This is in reference to Robert Lipsyte's article in The Times on April 26 entitled "Honest, or Just Another Jive-Dude?" in which a group of black high school athletes said that Manhattan College was one of the easiest colleges in the metropolitan area to get into and also indicated that it was one in which it was hard to get a meaningful education.
CAIRO, June 5 -- Four years ago this morning, antiaircraft guns broke the silence in the desert around Cairo and air-raid sirens wailed throughout the city. War with Israel had begun.

REMEMBER Conrad Rooks? Sure you do: he's that far-out fellow who, four years ago -- at the age of 32 -- wrote, directed and produced "Chappaqua," a partially autobiographical movie that described, in exotic detail, the rehabilitation of a narcotics addict.

TORONTO, June 5 -- In a decision that may influence transportation patterns in other North American cities, the Ontario government vetoed this week a highly controversial expressway, already partly built, to bring commuter cars into downtown Toronto.

ATLANTA, June 5 (UPI) -- Mike Lum reached Ken Holtzman, making his first relief appearance of the season, for a three-run homer with two out in the 11th inning tonight to give the Atlanta Braves a 6-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
A giant of the food industry is attempting to grow even larger.
Joseph Streicher and Louis Herman, two still-active members of the American Stock Exchange, remember when they did their brokerage business outdoors in the middle of Broad Street.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A Potomac River swollen with debris from recent heavy rains has added to the problems suffered by the sensitive sport of unlimited hydroplane racing on the eve of tomorrow's final heat of the President's Cup regatta.

AN exhibition of more than 100 items created by Victor David Brenner, American sculptor and medalist, will open on Saturday -- the centennial of his birth -- at the Chase Manhattan Bank Money Museum, 1254 Avenue of the Americas at 50th Street.

A textile manufacturer determined to become a psycho-analyst, a retailer who has decided to study law and a mother of five who simply wants "to know more" are among 1,200 students with little formal education who are now working for diplomas in the Adult Collegiate Education program at Queens College.

Grazing in the pastures on the 1,000-acre farm of Mrs. Alden V. Reene in Middletown, Delaware 80 Holstein cows, Heloise, a Dorset ewe, and a Tennessee walking horse and her foal. Waddling near the bar are 13 geese.

UPTON, L. I., June 5 -Physicists at Brookhaven National Laboratory are completing installation of a $49-million machine designed to soup up this country's most powerful research tool for studying the inner workings of the atom.
The Transit Authority's express bus service from Manhattan's Upper East Side to Wall Street, now two months old, appears to be a big success.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Six out of 10 Americans now think it was a mistake for the United States to become involved in the Vietnam War, the Gallup Poll reported today.
The Brooklyn Roman Catholic Diocese will undergo a major reorganization this month in an attempt to deal more effectively with the problems of its parishioners at the grass-roots level.

CALCUTTA, India -- If you go sightseeing here and happen to ask your guide about the famous "Black Hole of Calcutta," you will probably be told, according to the official Government line, that there is no such thing and never was. This is not quite true.

Prague is every man's possession, in the same sense as the music of Mozart, the Sistine ceiling, the sonnets of Shakespeare. Its unique beauty has universality; its tortured, tragic history is inseparable from the unresolved fate of Western man.

ATLANTA, June 5 -- With holes cut in his golf cap to give him improvised air-conditioning on this hot, humid day, Gary Player of South Africa moved ahead of Jack Nicklaus to lead the $125,000 Atlanta Golf Classic. "I never get tired," said the Johannesburg professional after he posted a five-under-par 67 for a 54-hole total of 204 and a one-stroke lead.

A 58-year-old pipefitter who works -- of all places -- for a Cincinnati meat packer, has put one over on the nation's professional rose breeders. His rose, named Portrait, is the first "hybridized" by a rank amateur to win an All-American Rose Selections award in that organization's 40-year existence.
There was a cocktail party in one of the more handsome brownstones in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn the other day. But it was no ordinary get-together.

WASHINGTON -- Poll results mean different things to different readers, but to some political buffs Dr. Gallup's latest findings will tend to confirm what John Mitchell said this week at a Republican dinner in Virginia: "You can't beat somebody with nobody and they sure don't have anybody to run against Nixon."
CENTEREACH, L. I., June 5 -- The four telephones in the law offices of Dominic J. Baranello, chairman of the Suffolk County Democratic party, rang continuously this week.

BRUSSELS, June 5, (Reuters) -- The Common Market's Executive Commission announced plans yesterday to stimulate investment and create 300,000 new jobs in depressed farming areas over the next five years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June -- About a day after Doris H. Kearns, a bouncy, 5-foot-4 young woman from Long Island who teaches political science at Harvard, was picked as a White House Fellow under President Johnson four years ago, an article by her appeared in The New Republic under the headline "How to Remove L.B.J. in 1968."

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 5 -- Howard McMichael, at the tiller of his Etchells-22 Class sloop, Kangaroo, was winner of the only long race on Long Island Sound today when a fleet of 89 sailed in a collapsing breeze in the season's sixth Yacht Racing Association championship regatta, conducted by Beach Point Yacht Club.

OTTAWA, June 5 -- Since his recent visit to the Soviet Union, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has spoken so expansively of Canadian friendship with "our neighbor to the north," that he has aroused new questions about his fidelity to the neighbor to the south.

The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of Dec. 6, 1970. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from earlier issues of the Book Review.
ALBANY, June 5 -- An immigration conspiracy charge against New York City's former Relocation Commissioner has been dismissed here.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 6 -- Gen. Duong Van Minh, considered the leading political rival of President Nguyen Van Thieu in the October elections, today publicly criticized South Vietnam's new electoral law.
The nuts and bolts of the problem of the Jamaica Avenue El in Queens, the head of the Woodhaven-Richmond Hills Community Board says, are indeed the line's -- and area's problem.

" The scene of my Nottingham-Derby novels all center around Eastwood, Notts, where I was born. And whoever stands on Walker Street, Eastwood, will see the whole landscape of 'Sons and Lovers' before him -- Underwood in front, the hills of Derbyshire on the left, the woods and hills of Annesley on the right.

Whereas I admire John Brooks's bravery in remounting his motor-assisted bicycle after a nasty spill ("Memoirs of a Bourgeois Hell's Angel in Bermuda," Travel section, May 16), he might want some suggestions for his next visit.
Through a nationwide clean-up campaign executed by Boy Scouts and adult helpers, thousands of miles and acres across the country were reported cleared of litter.

PARIS, June 5 (AP) -- The International Lawn Tennis Federation announced today that three players from the World Championship Tennis group had been suspended for entering the French tournament and then not taking part. They were Tom Okker of the Netherlands, Nicola Pilic of Yugoslavia and Ismael El-Shafei of Egypt.

Among the juvenile-book industry's most coveted awards are the annual Poohlitzer Prizes, or "Winnies," as they are affectionately referred to in the trade. A panel of distinguished critics, editors, librarians and bubblegum vendors will soon announce the prize-winners for this year from the following finalists.

MELVILLE, L. I., June 5 -- Suffolk County will begin to run out of fresh water within 10 years unless a countywide sewer network is built "at a very fast clip," according to a comprehensive report on the county's water resources.
American businessmen may again enter the China trade soon, but they will find that it has changed since Sino-American trade was suspended 20 years ago.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association is sending a team of seven to play in the Griscom Cup matches on Friday at the Brae Burn County Country Club, Newton, Mass.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, June 6 (AP) -- North Vietnamese rockets were reported to have struck the port city of Danang yesterday and heavy fighting was reported near Khesanh in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam.

WHILE the eight Candidates are struggling fiercely in matches to determine who will be his next challenger, world champion Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union waits calmly in the wings. His entrance into the great drama won't come until the spring of 1972, far enough so that his preparations need not yet have swung into high gear.

ALBANY, June 5 -- Democratic legislative leaders assured their party's legislators today that there would be "minimal" layoffs of city workers under the $500-million tax package tentatively agreed on by Governor Rockefeller and Democratic and Republican legislative leaders.

PARIS, June 6 -- Jan Kodes, who is about as well known at Forest Hills as Willie Mays is in Prague, won his second straight men's title at the $95,000 French open tennis championships today. Evonne Goolagoing, a 19-year-old part-abogrigine, won the women's title.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 6 -- Sharp clashes between United States and South Vietnamese forces and North Vietnamese regulars continued today around a Government base high above the main road between Khesanh and Quangtri, with a predawn enemy attack in which 83 North Vietnamese soldiers were killed, according to Government reports.
MOUNT FREEDOM, N. J., June 6 (AP) -- Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, dismissed the Presidential drive of Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. as "insignificant" today.

LONDON, June 6 -- A picture of almost unrelieved gloom for Britain's economic prospects was painted this week by the National Intitute of Economic and Social Research. The institute is Britain's major private agency specializing in short-term forecasts.

Congress is taking a close look at revolutionary consumer legislation designed to provide meaningful Federal income tax deductions in two major areas: college tuition expenses and automobile insurance premiums.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Bill Muncey of Seattle, driving an unlimited hydroplane that had never raced until yesterday, won the President's Cup today for the second year in a row.

ALBANY, June 6 -- A rare attempt to override a Governor's veto failed tonight in the Assembly but touched off bitter protests and angry confrontations on the floor over the tactics of Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 -- Steel producers were trimming their estimates of inventory building last week. With July orders continuing to lag, producers were lopping as much as two million tons off projections of the strike hedge accumulation by Aug. 1.

MOSCOW, June 6 -- The Soyuz 11, the second Soviet ferry craft to take astronauts up to the orbital station Salyut, is commanded by an experienced fighter pilot who has been waiting eight years for his first flight into space. With him are two trained engineers -- one is a novice in the space program, the other is on his second orbital mission in 18 months.

CAIRO, June 6 -- Efforts by the United States for an Israeli pullback from the Suez Canal and reopening of the waterway have regained momentum in the last few days after an interlude of frustration arising from conflicting Egyptian-Israeli conditions.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- One of the pioneers in studying the link between viruses and cancer will be honored tomorrow in Barcelona while scientists throughout the world are moving rapidly toward vindication of his once-unpopular views.

PARIS, June 6 -- The renowned French trainer, Francois Mathet, saddled his fourth French Derby winner in six years today as Mrs. Francois Dupre's bay colt, Rheffic, captured the 130th running of the Chantilly Classic.

ALBANY, June 6 -- The chairmen of the Legislature's two finance committees announced today a supplemental budget of $23.6-million for the 1971-72 fiscal year, the lowest amount sought in seven years.

Recent legislation abolishing rent control on vacant apartments in New York City will have the positive effect of increasing the supply of certain types of housing at the cost of higher rents for new tenants and probable harassment for current dwellers.

In June book reviewers come at us with long lists of books for "summer reading." "Suggestions for Summer Reading." That is how they usually headline these mysterious lists. A man accepts his list without enthusiasm. "Summer reading"? What is the unifying principle behind this inscrutable list?

The Kennecott Copper Corporation in a petition yesterday accused the Federal Trade Commission of responding to political pressure in a recent decision to require Kennecott to divest itself of the Peabody Coal Company.
SANT' ALFIO, Italy, June 7 -- A 200-yard-wide river of lava from Mount Etna pushed to within two and a half miles of this village today, wiping out crops and crushing at least one peasant cottage.

Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that the collapse in Albany on Sunday of a legislative package to provide new subsidies for transit operations would mandate "substantial increases" in the city transit fare Jan. 1.
Radio City Music Hall, better known for its high-kicking Rockettes and its movies, was filled yesterday by rows of mortarboards and purple academic gowns and the strains of Bach and Handel.

ALBANY, June 7 -- As the Legislature again put off adjournment for another day, Governor Rockefeller and legislative leaders prepared today to submit a $525-million New York City tax package to rank-and-file legislators of both parties tomorrow for a test of sentiment and a possible final vote.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 7 -- The Pakistani Government removed from circulation today part of the nation's currency in an effort to check the economic effects of looting from banks in East Pakistan.

Aubrey M. Daniel 3d, the Army prosecutor of Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. who criticized President Nixon for having injected himself into the case, will join the Washington law firm of Edward Bennett Williams this summer.

DUARTE, Calif., June 7 (UPI) -- An Air West DC-9 jetliner disintegrated so completely after colliding with an F-4 Phantom jet and crashing into a mountain that no sizable portion may ever be found, a Federal investigator said today.

Whatever it is that is panache, the New York City Ballet's young dancer and choreographer, John Clifford, has it in trumps. To see him dancing at the New York State Theater in "Stars and Stripes" for the first time on Sunday night, you just know that if that word panache had not existed, we would there and then have had to invent it.

BOSTON -- A national bookstore chain executive's contention that the American public is overwhelmingly uninterested in books, oblivious to literary reviews and must be lured into stores by the kind of garish displays used by supermarkets and gas stations has stirred widespread debate. It has also prompted some self-examination by book publishers who are trying to maintain high literary slandards.

The Federal Reserve appeared to move yesterday to slow down the rate of growth in the nation's supply of money. The central bank, acting the day before its policysetting Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet in Washington, sold Treasury bills for cash, driving rates on longer-term bills up as much as 27/100ths of a percentage point.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 7 (AP) -- The United States command reported today that American troop strength in South Vietnam had been reduced by 4,800 men last week. It also announced that six Marine Corps units totaling 1,240 men would return soon to the United States.

Hundreds of thousands of motorists were trapped in massive traffic jams on the hottest day of the year yesterday when municipal workers opened drawbridges in the city and abandoned trucks on major highways.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 7 -- Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore, who has been widely accused of aiming to tame or throttle the press in his island republic, arrived in Helsinki today to defend his actions before newspaper editors and executives from around the world.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- It's called Compar-A-Buy in Chicago, Valu-Price in Boston, Un 1 Price in Los Angeles, Chek-Mate in Denver, Valu-Chek in Phoenix and Tru-Price in Burlington, Iowa.

Green peppercorns packed in vinegar, juniper berries, Mexican oregano and Chinese five-spice are some of the unusual and hard-to-find items in the new 5th Season line of 82 spices by McCormick Co. Packed in embossed glass jars with label colors in a choice of curry, spice brown and sage green, the spices are available in Bloomingdale's delicacies department and in the gourmet food shop and fifth floor housewares area at Abraham Straus.
A Bedford-Stuyvesant woman said she was forced to continue payments on a $900 used car that broke down three weeks after she bought it.
The troubled Lockheed Aircraft Corporation yesterday announced a profit of $8.3-million, or 73 cents a share, for the quarter ended March 28.

CALCUTTA, India, June 7 (Reuters) -- The number of East Pakistani refugees flooding into India reportedly neared five million today. Cholera in epidemic proportions threatened this squalid capital of West Bengal state.

DURHAM, N. C., June 7 -- "Humanity is above all nations," reads an inscription carved on a stone bench at Duke University. That is an idea to which the nations generally pay more lip service than homage but it received unusual tribute at the university's commencement exercises today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (Reuters) -- The Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System voted unanimously at its March meeting to maintain prevailing money-market conditions "while accommodating any downward movements in long-term rates."

The police have been unsuccessful in their attempt to link two members of the Black Panther party who were captured in a holdup last Saturday to the murder of two policemen in Harlem on May 21, a police source said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- Communist China may be building its first nuclear-powered submarine, the Pentagon said today.
Copper-futures prices, which had been steadily dropping lately, bounded back yesterday in moderately heavy trading on no particularly bullish news.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The eight-year legal battle between the Food and Drug Administration and the Church of Scientology moved into the Federal District Court here today with the Government arguing that counseling methods used by the church constituted a "substantial public hazard."
It was hardly a day for music, but the 207th Street Bridge trilled yesterday like a mechanical canary, apparently delighted to have the day off.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 7 -- Randall P. McIntyre, chairman of the board of trustees of Adelphi University since October, 1970, and vice president of McIntyre Aviation, Inc. of Ronkonkoma, L. I., has been named acting president of the university, effective June 15.
Every available policeman was pressed into service yesterday in an attempt to mitigate the effect of one of the worst traffic tie-ups in the city's history.
The city's Parking Violations Bureau, less than a year old, has come under the scrutiny of the City's Department of Investigation.

The Equity Corporation has elected Robert W. Halliday as chairman replacing Jakob Isbrandtsen, who will remain a director. The company also promoted James W. Hart to senior vice president and chief operating officer; Paul M. Montrone to senior vice president and chief financial officer and Richard N. Daniel to vice president operations. Mr. Halliday is also chairman of the Allied Equities Corporation, a major Equity Corporation shareholder, and of U.S. Natural Resources, Inc.

Don Bies, a touring pro from Seattle, carded a 68, 67 -- 135 yesterday to lead the nation's qualifiers bidding for berths in the United States Open golf championship to be held June 17-20.
The second annual Straw Hat Awards honoring excellence in the American summer theater during 1970 were presented yesterday at the Faberge Town House, 5 West 54th Street.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Secretary of Housing and Urban Development George Romney announced today that he would not revise upward the 7 per cent interest-rate ceiling on Government-backed mortgages on the ground that "underlying" credit conditions did not warrant such an action.

PARIS, June 7 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers today pledged the Administration's determination to maintain and expand a liberal and non-discriminatory world trade system. But he warned that other nations must do their part by accepting their international obligations and applying the rules of trade fairly.

It is a measure of the hostility and distrust between Democrats and Republicans at Albany, between suburban and urban representatives, between inner-borough and outer-borough representatives from New York City that bills providing funds to help defray the costs of operating the city's subways failed to win passage in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- In a stunning reversal, the Senate approved today a $2.7-billion increase in pay for all the military services.

CAIRO, June 8 -- President Sadat, during a visit to the Suez Canal front in the last two days, has reiterated willingness to reinstate a cease-fire with Israel for six months along the canal, but insisted that Egyptian troops must cross to the Eastern shore as part of a plan to open the waterway.

ALBANY, Wednesday, June 9 -- After wrestling for weeks over New York's City's fiscal problems, the Republican-controlled Legislature voted early today to create a temporary state commission to make a sweeping investigation of the present "management, structure, organization and the fiscal and governance practices" of the Lindsay administration.
MOSCOW, June 8 -- The Three Soviet astronauts aboard the assembled Soyuz-Salyut space station settled down to a daily routine today in what had the appearances of becoming a long mission.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 8 -- With Mel Stottlemyre continuing his strong pitching and Danny Cater erupting from his season-long hitting doldrums, the Yankees successfully started their 13-game road trip tonight by defeating the California Angels, 3-0.

Most of the 13,000 members of Local G 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters have probably never driven a truck. Their leader went directly from Hofstra College into the union in 1957, and he has been there since.
New York City is supposed to have the power to overwhelm all its squabbling citizens. Like some great elemental force of nature, it seems as permanent as its great rivers, polluted but irresistible.
Striking municipal workers accepted a settlement formula last night and agreed to end immediately their walkout, which had disrupted the city for the last two days.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. disclosed today that the British Government could cancel its agreement to supply Rolls-Royce engines for the new Lockheed Tristar airbus if Congress did not act by Aug. 8 to provide financial assistance to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.
ALBANY, June 8 -- Earl W. Brydges, the Senate Majority Leder, charged today that the Lindsay administration was at least partly responsible for the "anarchy" in the city.

The Narcotics Control Council selected by Mayor Lindsay to conduct a control study to make heroin easily available to narcotics addicts is composed of distinguished public officials. Unfortunately, not one is a physician. The medical profession views heroin addiction as an illness that is now attaining epidemic proportions.
PARIS, June 8 -- United States officials say that a message from President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt had slightly advanced the prospects for an interim agreement this year on reopening the Suez Canal.
The graduating class at the first commencement exercises at York College was told yesterday that "a movement towards real integration" of the races was taking place in the United States.
NEWARK, June 8 -- The established powers in New Jersey's Democratic and Republican parties won easy victories today in the state's legislative primary elections.

The international money crisis of May has brought to a head the issue of whether the rich industrial nations are headed for greater protectionism and capital controls or for freer trade and flexible exchange rates.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Clark M. Clifford, former Secretary of Defense, said tonight he had reason to believe that the United States could reach an agreement now with North Vietnam to end American involvement in the Indochina war by Dec. 31 and obtain the release of the American prisoners of war by within 30 days.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 8 -- Pakistani citizens, close to panic, tried to crowd into banks today to turn in huge amounts of paper currency suddenly without value as the result of a Government decree last night.

WASHINGTON, June -Georgia State Representative Julian Bond rejected today the idea of a black independent running for President next year and said Negroes instead would enter favorite son candidates in several Democratic state primaries.
ALBANY, June 8 -- Following are highlights of the $525-million New York City tax authorization package for the 1971-72 city fiscal year beginning July 1:

BONN, June 8 -- While Chancellor Willy Brandt expects to cover major East-West problems, including the Berlin issue, when he meets with President Nixon next week, he considers the United States' relations with an expanded European Economic Community as the most vital subject on his Washington agenda.

Futures prices of pork bellies, from which bacon is sliced, fell yesterday in heavy trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Early in the day, prices dropped and their lower levels prompted an acceleration of the buying, causing prices to rise somewhat.
Robert Kotlowitz, who recently resigned as managing editor of Harper's Magazine, will join WNET (Channel 13) next month in the newly created post of executive editor in the programing department.

LONDON, June 8 (AP) -- A miniature portrait was sold for $156,240 today, a price believed to be a world record for such an art work. In 1842 it was brought by a peer for 18 -- the annual wage of his butler.

PARIS -- Twenty-three advanced nations agreed today to try to keep protectionist forces at bay by setting up a special high-level group to study and seek to resolve the growing number of trade problems.

ALBANY, Wednesday, June 9 -- As the State Legislature eased toward adjournment of its 1971 session, the Assembly gave final approval yesterday to a bill permitting New York City to create a housing development corporation with power to raise $700million through the sale of bonds.

State Housing Commissioner Charles J. Urstadt told an overflow meeting of more than 1,000 landlords yesterday that the Legislature that gave them vacancy decontrol could also take it away, and he warned them to use self-control in applying the law.

PRINCETON, N.. J., June 8 -- Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, told graduating seniors this morning that the changes they had witnessed during their undergraduate lives might not seem very shocking several years from now.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, June 9 (Reuters) -- North Vietnamese troops struck hard at Government forces yesterday in a new attempt to seize the marshy eastern approaches to Pnompenh.

The world of East Flatbush in Brooklyn is divided into two kinds of people: those who think that the rubble-strewn vacant lot on the corner of Church Avenue and East 42d Street is a rubblestrewn vacant lot -- and the others.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to its director, J. Edgar Hoover, was at one time recently tapping 47 telephone and has secretly planted at least six microphones for security reasons or to investigate organized crime.
BRISTOL, England, June 8 (UPI) -- Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia upset top-seeded John Newcombe of Austraia, 9-8, 6-4, in the first round of the $48,000 Wills open grass tennis tournament today.
NEW DELHI, June 8--The World Heath Organization announced here today that cholera had spread along the whole of the 1,350-mile West Bengal-East Pakistan border.
Sam McDowell, who had trouble winning at the start of the season and then began winning but lacked control, had few problems in posting his fifth straight victory last night.
LONDON, June 8 -- The Foreign Secretary said today that the responsibility for the refugees flooding into India from East Pakistan "must be assumed by the United Nations."

WASHINGTON, June 8--One year ago, there was talk around Washington that one of the kindest things President Nixon ever did was to relieve Robert H. Finch from the torments of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

The chief of the Consumer Frauds Unit in the United States Attorney's office here warned the Federal Trade Commission yesterday that its proposed new law on installment buying would "not have teeth" unless it was changed to cover a newly widespread consumer swindle called the "specious cash sale."
Glamour stocks sagged again yesterday and this time the general market gave ground amid an atmosphere of investor caution. Declines outnumbered advances by more than a 2-to-1 ratio.
Three separate investigations were under way last night into possible sabotage at several of the bridges closed by a strike of mridge employes early Monday.

A former national bank chairman and four other men have been convicted of fraud and conspiracy to manipulate the price of Hercules Galion Products, Inc., on the American Stock Exchange. The convictions, announced yesterday by United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr., grew out of Federal indictments nearly four years ago during a wide-ranging investigation of a series of alleged manipulations on the Amex.

To the Editor: Councilman Carter Burden's letter (May 11) to the contrary notwithstanding, the one thing that the city administration is doing right is not needlessly spending millions of dollars "to clean up its own facilities," so as to avoid polluting the air.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A senior White House official acknowledged today that he had sharply criticized the coverage of the White House by Dan Rather, a correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, during a breakfast meeting with one of Mr. Rather's superiors.
Dismayed by the continuing number of unsanitary restaurants here, city health officials want to require all eating places to display the "scorecard" of their most recent inspection.

A fire destroyed three abandoned piers on the Hudson River between 66th and 69th Streets yesterday afternoon, sending so much smoke into the air that the West Side Highway had to be closed until 10 P.M.
Voters in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties went to the polls yesterday in the first of two days of balloting on schoolboard membership, school budgets and related matters.

PARIS -- A new speed record for political defection and redefection has perhaps been established by Jozsef Szall, Hungary's senior diplomat, who fled Budapest last autumn, sought asylum in the United States, and has now returned to Europe proclaiming himself a Hungarian patriot and a good "socialist."
I would like to take issue with the opinions of those objecting to the proposed experimental Heroin Maintenance Program on the basis of its supposed failure in England.

TEL AVIV, June 8 -- Israel's Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Haim Bar-Lev, said today that any Egyptian attempt to resume hostilities would "not achieve any strategic objective," so the Arab armies would end up no better off than they are now under the cease-fire.

Canadians occasionally complain about American business infiltration into their country, but it isn't very often that a United States company admits to having over-expanded in the vast Northern country.

COPIAGUE, L. I., June 9 -- Copiague High School, where racial disorders broke out Monday and yesterday, will remain closed tomorrow and will hold classes on Friday only for seniors, Principal Walter G. O'Connell said today.
Arthur Feuerstein, a computer programmer by profession and for a long time now one of America's leading masters, has won the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club with a score of 8 1/2-3 1/2.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Treasury published today its proposed regulations under the recently enacted law requiring new record keeping and reporting of both domestic and international financial transactions.

The Goldman Band will open its 54th season of free Guggenheim Memorial Concerts in city parks at Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center, on June 23. The 180-voice All-City High School Chorus will appear with the 54-piece band in a program played under the direction of Richard Franko Goldman, conductor, and Ainslee Cox, associate conductor.

If Brooklyn seems an unlikely source for a bluegrass group, the Canarsie Bluegrass Boys are not apt to disillusion you. But although the Canarsie musicians offered a relatively pale reflection of their declared musical idiom on Tuesday evening at an al fresco concert on the deck of the Caviare at the South Street Seaport Pier, Fulton Street and East River, they showed a talent that moved in a different direction.

The municipal workers' strikes in New York City in the last few days have offered classic examples of what is wrong with the way in which contemporary Americans are trying to operate their society. It may be the richest and the most advanced technological society in history, but late twentieth-century America is something of a political mess.

MOSCOW, June 9 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin accused the Nixon Administration today of following "an aggressive policy" in foreign affairs that he said was blocking any improvement in Soviet-American relations.

DETROIT, June 9 -- The Ford Motor Company contends that new damage-resistant bumpers on its cars will add $108 to the retail price, apparently far more than car owners would save from lowered insurance rates.

Two of the so-called "Harlem five" -- indicted three years ago for allegedly conspiring "to kill a cop a week" and convicted a month ago of various lesser felony counts of illegal possession of guns and homemade bombs -- were put on five year's probation yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Arnold G. Fraiman.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 (AP) -- A Soviet freighter was seized by four deputy Federal marshals today as security for a $377,000 damage suit. The suit was filed by a Massachusetts company that said Russian trawlers damaged its lobster fishing equipment.

TEL AVIV, June 9 -- The United States has informed Israel that the American passport of Meyer Lansky, the reputed underworld financial leader, is no longer valid for general use and travel, reliable sources said here today.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Senate approved an amendment to the draft bill today that would require the armed forces to identify drug addicts and to offer them treatment and rehabilitation.

Negotiations for the sale of Canonero II are continuing, with Robert Kleberg of the King Ranch, of Texas and Mrs. J Cloyce (Liz) Tippett of the Llangollen Farm of Florida part of a combination dealing with Pedro Baptista, the Venezuelan metals executive who owns the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes.

Residents of Chinatown and of cooperatives near the Brooklyn Bridge expressed opposition before the City Planning Commission yesterday to the proposed erection of a 720-foot tower to house Telephone Company equipment, calling it a "monstrosity" that would change the character of the neighborhood.

JERUSALEM, June 9 -- Several diverse groups of highly skilled Jewish Americans, attracted by the life style of the commune, have asked to establish new settlements in Israel -- not to work the land in the old Zionist tradition, but to pursue scientific research or to build industrial plants.

RYE, N. Y., June 9 -- Jim Knowles of Greenwich, Conn., and William Wright of Clementon, N. J., tied at 150 today in the 67th annual United States Seniors Golf Association championship. They will play off over 18 holes tomorrow morning here at the Apawamis Club for the title.

CLEVELAND, June 9 -- The Nixon Administration called on the electric power industry here today to support its efforts to develop a liquid metal fast-breeder reactor, coal gasification and sulphur oxide control technology.

ALBANY June 9 -- Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, who emerged from the 1971 legislative session as a major political figure in the state, declared in an interview today that the heavy budget-cutting and fiscal retrenchment during the session was not a one-year phenomenon but would continue indefinitely.

Pending construction of galleries to house its collection of primitive art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has initiated a two-year series of four exhibitions of black African sculpture in a converted gallery on the main floor.

More than 70 men are currently under investigation by a special Justice Department task force set up to examine the web of alliances and business dealings of Meyer Lansky, the organized crime leader now living in Israel.
Southwest Forest Industries announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Riegel Paper Corporation in a transaction valued at about $112.3-million.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- After three years of work and an outlay of nearly $250,000, the United States Information Agency is letting a major propaganda film on the Vietnam war slip into oblivion.

WASHINGTON, June 9, (AP) -- WPIX-TV began broadcasting nine public service programs after learning its broadcast license would be challenged, a vice president of the station testified yesterday at a Federal Communications Commission hearing.

It makes me angry to see my taxes go toward either sustaining lives of poverty or, worse, providing incomes for men too lazy to work.

The city found 21,000 members of its police force in violation of the Taylor Law for their walkout last January and announced yesterday that they would be fined two days' pay for each day of absence and placed on probation for a year.

MIAMI, June 9 -- The custody fight over 12-month-old Baby Lenore reached into Florida today, bringing to this hot and humid city the same mix of claims and counterclaims and bitterness and sadness that have accompanied the case in New York since January.
HONG KONG, June 9 (Reuters) -- Rumania urged China today to normalize its relations with the West in the interests of world peace.
MEXICO CITY, June 9 -- Mexico has called a meeting of the world's principal silver producers to consider joint action to increase and stabilize sagging silver prices.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Thursday, June 10 (AP) -- Enemy forces attacking the eastern defenses of Pnompenh reportedly poured rocket and mortar fire yesterday into four Cambodian strongpoints within 12 miles of this capital.

LOS ANGELES, June 9 -- Another episode in the self-destruction of Hollywood took place this week with a Sotheby Parke-Bernet six-session sale of 900 costumes from the film and theatrical costumers Max Berman and Sons, Inc.

MEXICO CITY, June 9 -- The ordinary passenger who asks nothing more than "a safe, comfortable, reliable and moderately priced ride" has been forgotten by the rapid transit industry, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of New York State's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said here today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, supported today President Nixon's conduct of the Vietnam war against charges by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, that Mr. Nixon was timing his policy to help win re-election in 1972.
HELSINKI, June 9 -- Freedom of the press must be subordinated to the special security needs and sensitivities of Singapore, Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said today.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 9 -- Alex Johnson hasn't been in the California Angels' line-up since last Friday. He may never be in the California line-up again -- unless the Angels can't find a team willing to try to solve baseball's No. 1 mystery.

BONN, June 9 -- Allied sources disclosed today that the Big Four ambassadors had virtually completed work on a key element of their proposed agreement on Berlin, an arrangement for access to West Berlin.

The bond market's slump moved into its third day yesterday as prices continued to move downward and interest rates kept climbing.

Two brothers received prison sentences of 20 years to life yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens for murdering a Housing Authority employe by throwing him from the roof of a six-story building.

MONTREAL, June 9 (AP) -- Jean Beliveau, the center and captain of the Montreal Canadiens, considered one of the greatest players of all time, announced his retirement today after 18 seasons.

The nice thing about the piano is that any number up to three, at least, can play it at the same time. This possibility was demonstrated in the Tully Hall Sampler concert given on Tuesday night. A program entitled "Piano Music for One to Six Hands" was performed by John Ryan and Marshall Williamson, pianists of Metropolitan Opera Studio, and Judith Alstadter.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The State Department said today that Israel had violated the 1949 Geneva convention by building large apartment projects in the former Jordanian sector of Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Members of the House Ways and Means Committee told Senator Edmund S. Muskie today that his general revenue-sharing plan was an improvement over President Nixon's. But there was no sign that a committee majority was ready to approve either.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9 -- The head of the United Nations Children's Fund is making a worldwide plea for immediate assistance to refugees from East Pakistan.

ALBANY, June 9 -- Following are the major actions taken by the Legislature during the regular 1971 session, which ended early this morning:

ALBANY, June 9 -- At the request of Governor Rockefeller and Republican leaders here, the Legislature has authorized a sweeping investigation and study of pension and retirement systems for public employes throughout the state.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that the Administration was trying to restore fairness to the courtroom, which he said had suffered because of "preoccupation with fairness for the accused."

MILAN, Italy, June 9 -- The Polytechnical University here closed its School of Architecture today in an effort to end the occupation of the building by the families of homeless workers, most of whom are migrants from southern Italy.

Rafael Kubelik, the 56-year-old Czechoslovak conductor, has been named music director of the Metropolitan Opera, the first in the history of the company. His three-year contract will begin with the 1973-74 season.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., June 9 -- Craig Jackson, a 22-year-old unemployed Vietnam war veteran, was acquitted today in Atlantic County Criminal Court of the street shotgun slaying of Patrolman John P. Burke in Atlantic City.

Alexander's, Inc., announced yesterday lower earnings for the quarter and 40 weeks ended May 1 despite higher sales during both periods.
A 58-year-old Brooklyn man was seriously injured by a bomb early today when he picked up a shopping bag that he saw while walking on a street in downtown Brooklyn.

Six years ago, Fred Billingsley, a boutique owner, had an idea. Why not collect and then resell second-hand bluejeans? Mr. Billingsley and his four partners pursued the suggestion, and now their endeavor has turned into a $1,000-a-week business.
JERUSALEM -- On my desk before me there are the faces of seven children: serious, smiling, contemplative and one who as yet understands nothing.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 9 -- Vice President Agnew told the 685 cadets graduating from the Air Force Academy today, "Aggression historically has been halted only by the sword, or a convincing willingness to use it."
Voters considering school and library budgets went to the polls yesterday in communities in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties.

Illness caused Maralin Niska to miss her appearance as soloist in the New York Philharmonic's "Promenade Romantique" last Friday, but she recovered in time to sing in the repetition of the program on Tuesday.
BUENOS AIRES, June 9 -- President Alejandro Agustin Lanusse has dismissed his Minister of Public Works and the two men in charge of Argentina's petroleum and electrical energy policies.

The election of Arthur R. Taylor as a director of the International Paper Company was announced yesterday by Paul A. Gorman, chairman and president. Mr. Taylor, who is 35 years old, is an executive vice president and chief financial officer of the company.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Presidential candidacy of Democratic Senator Harold E. Hughes of Iowa, which has been slow to get started, appears to have arrived at a crossroads. At an off-the-record meeting on Monday night, key supporters told the Senator that he must decide soon whether he is willing to mount "a professional effort" to win his party's nomination and that, if not, he must find a graceful way to withdraw from contention.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The White House suggested today that Clark M. Clifford, former Secretary of Defense, and others were raising "false hopes" about American prisoners of war "for domestic political purposes."

Bands of teen-agers roved through a six-block stretch of Havemeyer Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn last night, setting fire to garbage piles in the street, breaking store windows and throwing bottles at policemen.

ALBANY, June 9 -- The Public Service Commission authorized the Consolidated Edison Company today to increase temporarily its electricity rates to bring it $52-million a year in additional revenue.
The stock market meandered through another listless session yesterday and closed lower. A midmorning attempt at a rally fizzled and the market sagged in the afternoon.

After leaving 12 men on base in seven innings without scoring a run, the New York Mets broke through for four runs in the eighth inning at Shea Stadium last night, and wound up with a 4-2 victory over the San Diego Padres.
NEWARK, June 9 -- With the deadline for Edgar H. Smith Jr.'s freedom only an hour away, a Federal appeals court today threw out a Federal Court order that had granted his release in $5,000 bail.

PARIS, June 9 -- The education of Jean-Claude Bouttier, boxer, continued tonight and when the lesson was over, the pupil had become the European middleweight champion. The 26-year-old former butcher, who received much of his previous education in American gymnasiums, admitted he learned a lot tonight from Carlo Duran, an Argentine-born Italian.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J. -- In a tree-shaded suburban garden on a street of expensive homes, the Overprivileged Boys Club held its seventh annual graduation party here last Sunday. Two-Ton Tony Galento was an honored guest, one of a hundred men, women and children on folding wooden chairs in a circle around the 18 graduates, who were in traditional garb -- headguards, mouthpieces and 16-ounce gloves. The ceremonies included nine bouts, two one-minute rounds each.

The Mayors of some of the communities in which branches of the State University of New York are situated agreed at a meeting yesterday to seek legislation making colleges pay for police and fire protection and a variety of other public services.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 9 -- The search for the killer of Edmundo Perez Zukovic, a leader of the Opposition Christian Democratic party, centered today on a young extremist who has reportedly organized criminals for revolutionary violence.

In his thoughtful letter concerning the "extraordinarily vulnerable position" of the draft, Dr. George Margolis raises questions of equity and the unwitting vectoring of forces toward "genasthenia" or "race weakening."

JERUSALEM, June 9 -- Prenier Golda Meir called on the United States today for prompt and far-reaching pledges of new aircraft and advanced armaments for Israel, to balance the military commitments made by the Soviet Union to Egypt last month.

LONDON, June 9 -- The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec Douglas-Home, made a strong appeal today for a political settlement in East Pakistan, terming it an essential condition for any permanent solution to the Pakistani refugee disaster.

When Prof. Robert S. Browne of Fairleigh Dickinson University proposed last week that American blacks seek loans for economic development from Japan, the World Bank, the United Nations and the Soviet Union, 600 black businessmen and economists cheered him enthusiastically.

The Arrow Company, a division of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., has introduced a numerical control principle for manufacturing men's shirts that it says cuts sewing time by 8 per cent and produces garments of continuously consistent quality.
KEY WEST, Fla., June 9 (UPI) -- Four young Cuban fishing captains were found guilty today of violating United States waters. They were sentenced to six months in jail and fined $10,000 each.
Merchants from around the nation were warned here yesterday by a top J. C. Penney Company executive that they have a major credibility problem on service charges for credit sales.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Irked that New York Bar officials have not disbarred William M. Kunstler for his conduct in and out of court, Senator James L. Buckley asked Congress today to authorize the Justice Department to prosecute disbarment charges against lawyers.

Pete Broberg, who turned down $175,000 from the Oakland Athletics in 1968 when he was a senior in high school, was selected No. 1 by the Washington Senators here yesterday in the secondary phase of baseball's summer draft. He is expected to sign a generous contract soon, although he still has a year of eligibility left as a pitcher at Dartmouth College.
Shlomo Katz, editor of Midstream, a monthly Jewish review, charged yesterday that he had been taken off "The David Frost Show" at the last minute because another guest, James Baldwin, objected.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 9 (AP) -- Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the Chief of Naval Operations, today told critics of reforms he has made in the Navy, "It is time for us to withdraw our heads from the sand."

A report from the University of Illinois that corn blight has been identified in 15 Illinois counties, with the prospect that other areas are affected, sent corn futures up yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Deposits at the nation's thrift institutions scored a record net increase of $2.7-billion during May, according to trade reports published yesterday.

PARIS, June 9 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Kiichi Aichi, the Japanese Foreign Minister, announced today final agreement on the terms of a treaty to return Okinawa and other islands of the Ryukyu chain to Japanese Sovereignty.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Two public interest organizations asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to start making corporations disclose what they are doing about pollution control and the hiring and promoting of minority workers.
