Tenant representatives were urged yesterday by Harold Zucker, counsel to the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, to form councils to screen complaints of harassment involving landlords of rent-controlled apartments.
Willie Mfum scored three goals, all by headers, in 11 minutes at Yankee Stadium last night to pace the New York Cosmos to a 4-2 victory over the Rochester Lancers before 2,017 fans.
No classes were held yesterday at Adlai Stevenson High School in the northeastern Bronx because the teachers and students were picketing the Board of Education in Brooklyn.

ALBANY, June 9 -- The Temporary State Commission to Investigate the Governmental Operations of New York City, which was established early this morning by the Legislature, will have some of the broadest powers of any legislative commission in recent history.

A proposed Federal regulation on installment buying should be expanded to cover credit cards, Bess Myerson, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, told a Federal Trade Commission hearing yesterday.

LONDON, June 9 -- The United States Air Force announced today it would conduct a formal investigation into the conduct of Capt. Thomas S. Culver, the legal officer who took part in an antiwar protest in London on May 31.
FORESTBURG, N.Y., -- Dr. James Cinberg caught up with me at the Dated Rock pool on the Neversink River and we confessed to each other that our creels were empty.
The precipitate retreat of striking city employes in the face of the state's refusal to be blackmailed could mark the start of a constructive new phase in civil service labor relations.
A book by Angela Davis, most of which was written in prison, will be published this fall by The Third Press -- Joseph Okpaku Publishing Company.
PPG Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it would raise prices for trichlorethylene, a metal cleaning solvent used widely in industrial processes, by one cent a pound.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 9 -- Ambassador at Large David M. Kennedy said here today that "we have made very great strides toward solving a number of economic issues, including the textile issue."

Water pressure in the city has just about returned to the normal range of 35 to 60 pounds a square inch after dropping Tuesday to a low of 10 pounds in some areas, City Water Resources Department officials reported yesterday.

The Harlem Preparatory School graduated 116 former high school dropouts yesterday, all with scholarships to such institutions as Harvard, Wesleyan, Columbia and the University of the New World in Switzerland.
Will the trust-busters let New Jersey's fourth-largest banking organization swallow the biggest bank in the bedroom community of Englewood?
A bill passed by the Legislature in its closing hours early yesterday was described later by the city's Transportation Administrator, Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, as a "land-grab" measure.

There is nothing new in saying that our Social Security program, which began in 1937, should be brought up to date in keeping with present-day conditions, especially with reference to the reduction of the burdensome welfare program, which has reached the point of no return.

BECKENHAM, England, June 8 (AP) -- Clark Graebner of New York and Stan Smith and Jim McManus of California advanced today to the quarter-finals of the Kent grass tennis tournament today. But Tom Gorman of Seattle was beaten.
Trans World Airlines yesterday became the fourth of the major airlines to decide to tap the equity market to help it reduce outstanding borrowings and to finance additional new facilities.

GENEVA, June 9 -- A special representative of Secretary General Thant of the United Nations today requested the cooperation of the Food and Agriculture Organization and the League of Red Cross Societies in a large-scale food relief program for East Pakistan.
DANBURY, Conn., June 9 (AP) -- The Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, the imprisoned antiwar priest, was taken from the Federal prison here to the Danbury Hospital today, prison officials said.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Deputy Secretary of Defense David Packard gave qualified support today to the Administration's plan to provide financial assistance to the troubled Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

DETROIT, June 9 -- A Federal grand jury believed to be investigating the March 1 bombing of the United States Capitol acted today to insure that an organizer of the Mayday protest in Washington would appear when it convened here next Monday.
TOKYO, June 9 -- The Komeito, Japan's second largest opposition party, has been invited to send a delegation to China, a party spokesman announced here today.

STRATFORD, Ontario, June 9 -- Not for the first time -- and probably not for the last, because institutions breed traditions -- the second night of the Stratford Festival offset the slight disappointment of the first.

No one can argue with the substantial point of Anthony R. Spinelli's attack on our welfare system (Op-Ed May 8): that it is degrading and that it does not solve the problem of poverty. However, he exhibits the usual conservative tendency to heap on the poor the blame for their poverty.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The House Communications Committee was urged today to place spending limits on the new and expensive computerized campaign techniques as well as on radio and television.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- An assistant district attorney for New York County asserted today that the stealing of securities from Wall Street brokerages was rampant.

There is a time for understatement and restraint, and there is a time for beating the big drum. The opening of the Garden State Arts Center's fourth season on Tuesday night in Holmdel, N. J., definitely fell in the latter category.
The current "Biography" series on "NET Playhouse" has come up with several outstanding 90-minute segments in the last couple of months, and it is managing to do so once again with tonight's offering.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 9 -- Tony Jacklin has been in a slump. The 26-year-old Englishman, who defends his United States Open golf title next week, is here to put his game together again. "One piece is here, one is there," he said in attempting to explain his dilemma.

James Michener likes to have his characters perform against the background of -- or in accordance with -- the events of history. The quirks of personality, the oddities of character, the unpredictable Brownian motions of human psychology appear to interest him little. He prefers to represent a history in action.
ANAHEIM, Calif., June 9 -- Billy Cowan and Tony Gonzalez, two left-fielders playing in place of the benched Alex Johnson, beat the Yankees for the California Angels, 4-3, tonight.
By 1976, New York City will be asked to contribute $585,000 a year in additional funds to implement the Metropolitan Museum's master plan, it was revealed yesterday by City Councilman Carter Burden.
Former United States Senator Charles E. Goodell told 746 graduates at Staten Island Community College yesterday that the younger generation could not just "wave a banner and change the world."

The Lindsay administration will press for the enactment of "every dollar" of the revenue package authorized by Albany and still cannot rule out the possibility that some uniformed employes -- policemen, firemen or sanitationmen -- might be laid off, the city's Budget Director said yesterday.
LONDON, June 9 -- Prince Philip celebrates his 50th birthday tomorrow, a royal figure seeking to blend the traditions of the monarchy with the demands of contemporary Britain.

The Lindsay administration will press for the enactment of "every dollar" of the revenue package authorized by Albany and still cannot rule out the possibility that some uniformed employes -- policemen, firemen or sanitationmen -- might be laid off, the city's Budget Director said yesterday.
A realignment of top management will take place at the Continental Can Company, Inc., large packaging manufacturer, effective Aug. 1.
Navy Recruiting will be pulling out of Young Rubicam, Chicago, after a four-year stay and tying up at Grey Advertising. Surely you've heard of Battleship Grey?

Three prominent lawyers urged Attorney General John N. Mitchell yesterday to send Federal registrars and observers into Mississippi to monitor the reregistration of voters and to "adequately protect" black and white voter-registration volunteers.

American Ballet Theater will present one premiere, two new productions, two revivals and a new staging in its summer season at the State Theater from June 29 through Aug. 8. Michael Denard, a principal with the Paris Opera Ballet, will appear with the company during the six-week engagement.

YONKERS, June 9 (AP) -- The New York State Harness Racing Commission today requested Yonkers Raceway to install an addition to the infield tote board, which would indicate the payoff possibilities on daily doubles and exactas.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 9 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird told 720 members of the United States Military Academy graduating class today that they should not be "defensive" about being military men.
Former President Lyndon B. Johnson presented an award here last night to Mrs. Mary Lasker for "dedication to the cause of cancer control."

One of the least frightening items in the United States Army's experimental arsenal is a small red berry the size of a Spanish peanut. Not part of any biological warfare program, the "miracle fruit," as it is referred to by the scientists doing research on it at the Army's labs in Natick, Mass., and elsewhere around the country, is gentle dynamite.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., June 8 -- By some evolution that no one considers it necessary to explain, Foti's Feed and Seed Store has become locally famous over the years for selling not only feed and seed but also Italian spaghetti and the coldest beer in town.

HARTFORD, Thursday, June 10 -- Moments after mandatory adjournment of the Connecticut General Assembly last midnight, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill called for a special legislative session to resolve the state's snarled fiscal affairs.

The House of Representatives has an unusual opportunity today to accomplish three useful goals in one series of votes. It can break out of an outrageous legislative straitjacket fashioned by Agriculture and Rules Committee majorities, expose the corruption written into the Sugar Act, and remove an appearance of hypocrisy in United States policy toward South African racism.
ALBANY, June 9 -- The State Court of Appeals ordered a new trial today in the Breezy Point Park condemnation case and indicated that it considered the $39.7-million award made two years ago too high.
The pitching "firm" of Renko and Stoneman is giving the Montreal Expos added National League prominence.

Among Borough Presidents, the idea of making New York City the 51st state got a very mixed reception yesterday -- from a real cheer in the Bronx to an emphatic "include us out" comment from Staten Island.

The marriage of Miss Mary Lea Guyer, a member of the editorial staff of Time-Life Records, to Richard Blake Gordon, a vice president of the Douglas Elliman Company, Inc., the real estate concern, took place here yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The state of Mississippi asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider its order, announced last Thursday, that Hinds County must be divided into single-member legislative districts.
In San Francisco town, educational television station KQED has a reputation for imaginative fund raising. With the June 12 issue of The New Yorker, that reputation will spread.
Prices and volume on the American Stock Exchange eased yesterday for the third consecutive session.

Just when everybody thought the Somebodies had crept away exhausted from the May social season to rest up in the Hamptons for fall, along came June and the first benefit for the Museum of Modern Art since anyone could remember.

MESCALERO INDIAN RESERVATION, N. M. -- In the shadow of their sacred mountain, which they have developed into a booming ski resort, the Mescalero Apaches are building a sprawling playground for the white man and a fat bank account for their tribe.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- William D. Ruckelshaus, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that his agency had reached water pollution agreements with three cities.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The United States and Canada agreed today on a joint program to eliminate water pollution in the Great Lakes by 1975.
What started out last week as a mild Skirmish involving two airlines and the price of a ticket between New York and Belgium has blossomed into an air-fare free-for-all.

It is not usually considered proper for a foreigner to comment on the political affairs of the United States, but perhaps an exception may properly be claimed for one who has been for twenty years a voteless taxpayer and is deeply disturbed by the deteriorating condition of his adopted home.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Nixon ended a 21-year embargo on trade with Communist China today. He authorized the export of a wide range of nonstrategic items and he lifted all controls on imports from China.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 -- Supporters of Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky, whose chances of running for the Presidency appeared considerably diminished by new electoral legislation last week, now say he will try to run anyway.

LONDON, June 10 -- Buckingham Palace spoke today on the dispute that followed Queen Elizabeth's request for an increase in the royal budget. The palace supported speculation that the Queen's personal fortune was about $4.8-million.
BOSTON -- When the Christian Scientists of this world had their annual meeting here recently, they breezed through the agenda with practiced assurance.
A bank employe who stole more than $25,000 by rigging a computer to deliver stock certificates and dividend checks on fraudulent orders was sentenced to three years yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Senior officials of the Treasury said today that thefts of series E Government bonds had risen alarmingly in recent years. But they said that the pilfering of large - denomination Treasury securities traded in financial markets was declining.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today that it had purchased $273.7-million of mortgages in this week's special "auction" out of $1.1-billion offered.

PARIS -- Soviet diplomacy is thrusting with unmistakable vigor for a European security conference to be convened as soon as possible. The idea is an old favorite of Moscow's but has been given obvious new life. Almost every Russian embassy on this Continent is pushing it and a deputy foreign minister was sent on tour by the Kremlin in Scandinavia and London to press for its attainment.
REDSTONE ARSENAL, Ala., June 10 (AP) -- M. Sgt. William Higdon was convicted today of stealing $7,200 in cigarette promotion funds and taking $723 in kickbacks while running Army clubs in Vietnam.
TEL AVIV, June 10 -- A prominent Israeli political figure acknowledged today that he had a business association with Joseph Stacher, a former American racketeer who is now an Israeli citizen.

SUTTON, Mass., June 10 (UPI) -- Jane Blalock and Kathy Ahern braved stiff breezes and tough pin placements today to shoot three-under-par 70's and share the first-round lead in the $55,000 Ladies' Professional Golfers's Association championship at the Pleasant Valley Country Club course.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Charging the Federal Housing Administration with "abdicating its responsibility," the United States Commission on Civil Rights said today that a new home-ownership program for low-income families had been used to perpetuate segregation.
MOSCOW, June 10 -- The Soviet leadership announced today that it had approved a new master plan aimed at making Moscow a "model Communist city."

JERSEY CITY, June 10 -- A special Hudson County grand jury today indicted all five members of the County Pension Commission and the County Medical Examiner on charges of handing over $392,000 in fraudulent disability pension awards to 100 county employes over a three-year period.
NEWARK, June 10 -- John V. Kenny, the key defendant in the Jersey City-Hudson County conspiracy extortion trial in Federal Court here, was severed from the trial today because of illness.
MIAMI, Fla., June 10 (AP) -- The Cuban Government announced today that it had three private American vessels in custody and would try at least five of their 13 crewmen.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A bill to establish a network of more than 300 drug addiction treatment centers at a cost of $160-million was introduced in the House today by Representative Paul Rogers, Democrat of Florida.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- In his lifelong study of the art of diplomacy, Sir Harold Nicholson reached the conclusion that imprecision of language was one of the greatest barriers to successful negotiation between nations, and this is proving to be true once more in the Paris talks on Vietnam.

MOSCOW, June 10 -- President Nikolai V. Podgorny today praised the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for taking a cautious approach to the Soviet call for negotiations on reducing forces in Central Europe.
Mayor Lindsay moving ahead with discussions on the possibility of statehood for New York City, released a detailed staff memorandum yesterday that hailed the idea.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- Jonathan P. Kniseley, a 12-year-old from Mullica Hill, N. J., won the 44th National Spelling Bee today. "I just made a guess at it," he conceded after winning the championship by correctly spelling the word "shalloon," meaning a kind of fabric.
Leaders of a heavily Puerto Rican section of Brooklyn charged yesterday that garbage in their section had not been picked up for several days.
The Treasury, acting to consolidate a host of Federal credit assistance programs, proposes creation of an umbrella-type agency that would offer its own securities in the market.
Chemical prices rose yesterday on a broad front.
Leading glamour issues showed a mixed pattern yesterday, while the general market gained a little ground.

The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation yesterday became the first of the nation's major steel producers to announce layoffs and facility shutdowns. It said it was laying off 250 employes and banking a blast furnace.

Alberto-Culver announced yesterday how it was going to divide up the $25-million or so in billings that will be exiting from J. Walter Thompson and N. W. Ayer. And they had a surprise to go along with it because, besides the four agencies already announced, they'll be assigning products to Compton -- Alberto-Culver's first agency and one it left in 1965.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine is proposing that he and his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination agree to spend nothing for television advertising until after the party has selected its nominee.

AREA A -- Bluefishing is picking up generally along the New Jersey shore. At Point Pleasant, catches of 5 or 6 pounds are reported and in the Barnegat waters inshore fisherman are pulling in 2-pounders with regularity.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The heads of the Civil Aeronautics Board and the Federal Aviation Administration joined today in saying that it would be unfortunate for the country if the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation went bankrupt.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 -- The Economics Ministry announced today that South Vietnam would open bids this year for oil exploration on its continental shelf in the South China Sea.
Yeshiva University held its 40th commencement exercises yesterday and awarded 925 degrees to graduates of 10 of the university's undergraduate, graduate and professional schools.

Robert Moses, the master planner and builder, divested himself of some typically curmudgeonly Moses musings yesterday when he addressed the 1,300 graduates of Queensborough Community College in Bayside, Queens.

Grain futures prices took off yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as a result of reports that the Southern corn blight is spreading. Sharp increases were recorded not only for corn but wheat and oats futures as well.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday finished mixed as dull trading continued.
SALEM, Ill., June 10 (AP) -- The City of New Orleans passenger train derailed at more than 90 miles per hour in a hail of twisted metal and flame today, killing 10 persons and injuring 94.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I. -- It no longer looks like a butcher shop. But then how many modern kitchens have meat hooks on the wall, chopping blocks on the floor and a sausage maker serving as the kitchen sink?

C. Northcote Parkinson, the British author and humorist, has set out to defy Parkinson's Law -- that corporate growth leads to complexity and complexity leads to decay. So far he seems to be succeeding.

PARIS, June 10 -- The North Vietnamese and the Vietcong said today that if the United States would set a date for its withdrawal from Vietnam, they would discuss a full exchange of prisoners without relation to any other questions.

The New York Stock Exchange won the first round yesterday in its eight-month battle to defend itself against a $3-billion antitrust suit and class action filed here last October by Hans Randolph Reinisch, a 39-year-old New Yorker.
In recent months, the fishing controversy between American lobster fishermen and foreign trawlers off the coast of New England has apparently increased in frequency, intensity and publicity.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 10 -- A California State Senate committee killed last night a bill encompassing Gov. Ronald Reagan's legislative proposals for welfare reforms.

The State Court of Appeals yesterday ordered Thomas A. Ruppert freed from jail and the case against him dismissed, nearly four years to the day after the youth was convicted of setting a fire that killed nine children and three adults in the Yonkers Jewish Community Center in 1965.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Senate began debate today on the McGovern-Hatfield amendment, which would require the withdrawal of all American forces from Vietnam by the end of this year.

Willie Mays has reached the age at which life is supposed to begin. He is 40 years old. If there is an area in which the life-begins-at-40 doctrine has any validity, it's a lead pipe cinch that it is not sports. Most athletes have departed from the scene by their 40th birthday and those who remain are faced by the law of diminishing returns.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 10 -- The Communist and Socialist parties, the mainstays of Chile's coalition Government, charged today that the United States Central Intelligence Agency was involved in the assassination of Eduardo Perez Zukovic, a Christian Democratic party leader.
Gov. Marvin Mendel of Maryland apologized here yesterday for calling Howard J. Samuels a bookie.

Cole Porter, who died in 1964, would have been 80 years old on Wednesday. To commemorate the occasion, Bobby Short, who is a quintessential singer of Porter songs, devoted his entire program that night at the Cafe Carlyle, 76th Street and Madison Avenue, to the songs of Mr. Porter.

Farewell Party of the Rokeby Stable and Bobby Dees Boy, sporting the silks of Martin Wygod, waged a stirring duel in the final phase of the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday, with the former winning by a nose.

GENEVA, June 10 -- Henri Ghent, director of the Brooklyn Museum's Community Gallery, submitted 75 works by "eight Afro-American artists" at a preview here today.

The Orioles unleashed a double-barrelled attack last night against Minnesota -- the pitching of Jim Palmer and the slugging of Frank Robinson -- to coast to their eighth straight victory, a 12-0 rout of the Twins at Baltimore.

Sir Roy Harrod's recommendation of a tripling in the price of gold [letter May 18] is sweet music to the gold miner, who has been a victim for years of worldwide inflation. But how does Sir Roy propose to achieve this objective?

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., obviously still ringing up benefits from the commission surcharge on stock transactions, earned more in the first 18 weeks of 1971 than in all but four full years in its history.

Prof. John Ronayne's letter of May 20 attempts to justify as constitutional the mass arrests in Washington. Although the law apparently was stated correctly, the professor's failure to apply it properly to the facts obviates his conclusion that mass arrests are not per se unconstitutional.

The RCA Corporation yesterday introduced a new video-voice communication system that allows users both in the United States and abroad to exchange pictures, charts and other graphic materials over circuits capable of carrying the voice at the same time as discussions are being held.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday it is holding talks with the Chilean Government, at Chile's request, to explore the possible purchase of I.T.T.'s 70 per cent interest in Compania de Telefonos de Chile, its telephone subsidiary in that country.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Nixon Administration does not foresee an avalanche of trade with China but it hopes that today's relaxation of the two-decade embargo will stimulate the business of diplomacy between Peking and Washington.
Record sales and earnings were announced yesterday by Collins Aikman Corporation for the year's first fiscal quarter which ended May 29.

The New York Shakespeare Festival and La Mama Experimental Theater Club are quite a combination, and last night they got together at the Shakespeare Shrine and Supermarket on Lafayette Street -- it is still implausibly known as the Public Theatre -- and produced one of the happiest entertainments in town.

The current travels of Semyon K. Tsarapkin raise new doubts about the seriousness of Soviet intentions on negotiating mutual force reductions and resolving the Berlin problem. Mr. Tsarapkin is no innocent abroad even though he showed up in Britain without invitation or advance notice. He knows the Atlantic Alliance insists on a Berlin solution as prerequisite for the cherished Soviet project of a general European security conference.

City Councilmen shuffled through piles of form letters protesting a proposed $15-a-year auto-use tax yesterday, then formally received the bills that would enact most of the revenue package authorized by Albany.

ELKHORN, Wis., June 9 -- In these busy weeks, when farmers here in Walworth County need every minute of the long summer day to tend their fields, many are stealing hours to seek out and destroy stands of the Indian hemp plant -- the source of marijuana -- that have grown up unbidden on the waste places of their land.

In his testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, Deputy Defense Secretary David Packard virtually knocked the props from under the Nixon Administration's case for the Government to guarantee up to $250-million in loans to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

During the building of the Cathedral of Chartres, noble men and women joined the general populace in harnessing themselves to wagons to pull the huge stones to the site. At Notre Dame, the lowermost blocks of the foundation were just as carefully dressed as those above ground, because every inch of the building was equally holy.

MONTREAL, June 10 (UPI) -- Al MacNeil resigned today amid a swirl of controversy as coach of the Stanley Cup-winning Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League and immediately was replaced by Scotty Bowman.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- In a reversal of policy that astonished members of a House committee, the Nixon Administration withdrew its support today for any kind of special census in 1975.

The detective squads assigned to the 11 precincts of southern Manhattan will be abolished July 1 and replaced by teams that will specialize in one of four groups of crimes: homicide-assault, robbery, narcotics and burglary-larceny.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Officials of the three major networks agreed today that campaign spending limits for radio and television should be twice as high as those on which Senate Democratic leaders have agreed.

Postal union leaders from New York, Philadelphia, Detroit and Chicago said yesterday that their memberships would strike next month if contract negotiations with the new United States Postal Service did not take a more productive turn.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Pentagon is advertising for bids from small businesses in the Washington area to record verbatim "all newscasts emanating from all metropolitan area radio and TV stations."

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Ten years ago, the Rev. Theodore Martin Hesburgh wrote: "There are the unspoken but very effective conspiracies of builders, real estate brokers and good neighbors who are down-right arrogant in preserving the blessings of democracy for their own white selves alone."

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to suspend trading in two issues and discussed the submission of a proposed new commission-rate schedule to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Nixon Administration and Senate proponents of an independent cancer agency appeared today to have reached almost complete agreement on the strategy for attempting to conquer that large and deadly group of diseases.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Senate passed today 77-to-0 a $5.6-billion aid-to-education money bill that exceeded President Nixon's budget so substantially there were hints he might veto it.

ALBANY, June 10 -- The State Court of Appeals today reversed a lower court's decision that a New York City woman who was receiving welfare aid and whose apartment had been burglarized was en titled to have the stolen and vandalized property replaced by the city's Department of Social Services.

DETROIT, June 10 -- The General Motors Corporation recalled 19,000 trucks and 900 school buses today to correct defects linked to some 50 injuries.

NEW ORLEANS, June 10 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit directed the City of Atlanta today to draw up a new pupil assignment plan complying with the latest United States Supreme Court school desegregation rulings, a decision that could require wide cross-town busing.
Representatives of three Teamster locals on strike since May 20 reached a tentative agreement yesterday with the United Parcel Service.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, who has vowed to defeat the Administration's general revenue-sharing program, unveiled an alternative plan of his own for financial aid to the cities at a secret meeting yesterday with key Democratic office-holders from around the nation.

The Jets lost Verlon Biggs, their 6-foot-4-inch, 270-pound defensive end, to the Washington Redskins yesterday. Biggs who had played out his option with the Jets, signed as a free agent with Washington.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 10 -- A dazzling performance by the great Italian stars, Giorgio Belladonna and Benito Garozzo marked the exhibition match here last night in which a group of experienced Johannesburg experts opposed the Precision international touring team.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Right Rev. John E. Hines, presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church, was named Clergyman of the Year today by Religious Heritage of America, an interfaith, nonprofit organization that seeks to instill Judeo-Christian ideals into all areas of American life.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 10 -- The Pakistani Government appealed today to all refugees from East Pakistan to return home and offered a general amnesty extending to military deserters and politicians.
George Washington High School was forced to close yesterday after three fires in less than 24 hours caused damage estimated at $8,000 inside the building.

An increasing flow of unfavorable views on the Concorde supersonic transport plane have been emanating from some United States airlines that have options to buy the craft.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The House passed today a three-year extension of legislation regulating sugar production after rejecting an effort to restrict imports from South Africa.
OTTAWA, June 10 -- The Canadian Government today introduced a bill to prohibit all advertising and promotion of cigarettes as of next Jan. 1 Passage of the legislation seemed assured.

The police and the office of the Queens District Attorney are investigating vandalism at a new, unoccupied, $50,000-home in the Rosedale section of Queens. Neighbors said it took place because area residents thought a racially mixed couple was about to move in.

Assemblyman Vito Battista yesterday denied Mayor Lindsay's charge that he had made a deal with Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea that killed a compromise bill to relocate homes now occupying a planned school site in Corona, Queens.
GREENWICH, Conn. -- The debate over President Nixon's controversial plan for no-strings Federal revenue sharing with the states promises to burn on throughout this session of the Congress.

RYE, N. Y., June 10 -- Jim Knowles of Greenwich, Conn., won the 67th annual United States Seniors Golf Association championship today, beating Bill Wright of Clementon, N. J., in an 18-hole medal playoff by two strokes.

TUCSON, Ariz., June 9 -- The Federal prosecutor here plans to take before a grand jury this summer the bizarre case of a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who allegedly plotted bombings to foment gang warfare among members of the Mafia.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell withdrew today his objections to the creation of multimember legislative districts in Virginia.

A $1-million reduction in funds has forced the curtailment of hours at the research division of the New York Public Library from 78 hours a week to 40 beginning July 1, Richard W. Couper, president of the library, announced yesterday.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the appointment of Edwin B. Lancaster as senior vice president and chief actuary. Mr. Lancaster, 54, has been a senior vice president of the company since 1969, in charge of personal insurance operations.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy issued a denunciation yesterday of State Supreme Court Justice Arnold G. Fraiman for granting probation to two men convicted of possessing guns and bombs "intended for use against policemen."

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Federal Trade Commission, invoking previously unused authority, announced its intention today to order all major industries to substantiate their advertising claims. Orders to file data in support of claims involving the safety, performance, efficacy, quality and comparative prices of advertised products will be issued, industry by industry, about every three months. The files will be open to the public.

Clete Boyer, who sought and received his unconditional release from the Atlanta Braves in acrimonious circumstances last month, was cleared yesterday to continue seeking baseball employment after being fined $1,000 by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for betting on football games in 1968 and 1969.
Governor Rockefeller, responding with scorn and sarcasm to Mayor Lindsay's criticisms of him and of the recent session of the State Legislature, said yesterday of the Mayor:

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Nixon urged Congress today to approve within the next three weeks a one-year extension of the present economic and military aid program but to provide for their separate administration.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- Black policemen and white officials of police fraternal organizations clashed today at a black policemen's conference over the question of racial polarity in police departments.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A high government official expressed complete confidence today that "economic policies and forces are working toward eventual price stability," though he conceded that the various indicators of inflation had recently been giving off mixed signals.
NANKING, China, June 1 -- Today's visitor to China -- to commune, department store, factory or school -- invariably hears officials describe their achievements by comparing 1971 with 1966.

"The boys deserve it." It was pleasant to read that ecumenical judgment of Stanley Steingut, Democratic leader of the State Assembly, expressing his approval of an increase from $3,000 to $5,000 in expense allowances for members of the Legislature. This proves that when the chips are down, strident voices are lowered, and party differences are forgotten.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Michael McCarthy, the 20-year-old son of former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, was set free today after District of Columbia prosecutors said they were unable to produce evidence to support a charge of disorderly conduct against him.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

More than a dozen Federal, state and local agencies started a central computerized file of complaints by consumers in the metropolitan area yesterday to begin what they called "a large-scale attack on frauds and deceptions against the buying public."

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today its general plans for managing the space shuttle program, considered a key to the nation's major efforts in manned space operations after the Apollo program of landings on the moon.

MIAMI, June 10 -- The natural mother of Baby Lenore will confront at least one of Lenore's would-be adoptive parents in court here tomorrow in an effort to regain from them the child she surrendered for adoption one year and eight days ago.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 -- United States battlefield deaths last week dropped to the lowest point since the start of the big American troop buildup in Vietnam in late 1965.

Twenty-four Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders yesterday issued a statement endorsing the reunification of Jerusalem under Israeli jurisdiction and declaring confidence in Israel's capacity to supervise the holy places in cooperation with Christian and Moslem groups.
A six-day strike that had caused cancellation of several events at Madison Square Garden was settled yesterday when striking employes of the Garden agreed to accept a new two-year contract.
TRENTON, June 10 (AP) -- Edgar H. Smith was returned to the Death House in the State Prison here today after being thwarted in an attempt to secure bail while awaiting a new trial.

MEXICO CITY, June 10 -- At least nine students were killed and more than 130 persons were wounded here tonight in the worst street fighting involving anti-Government students since the protest movement before the Olympic Games in 1968.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Nixon met today in the White House for about an hour and 20 minutes with 11 of the nation's top railroad executives, Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe and Peter Flanagan, an as sistant to the President.

David Hancock, a pianist and recording engineer, was Wednesday night's recitalist at the New York Cultural Center. It is 10 years since he last played in public here, and perhaps he has been too long away from the concert stage.
For the last 11 years, the St. Regis Paper Company has been giving awards to college students for winning package designs.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 10 -- Cpl. Stan Bahnsen, working for the Yankees before going to work for the United States Army Reserves for two weeks, pitched a five-hitter tonight as New York edged the California Angels, 3-2.

HARTFORD, June 10 -- The clock on the State Senate wall struck midnight yesterday, signaling mandatory adjournment, before a vote could be taken on a bill that would have imposed a one-year residency requirement on welfare recipients.

Any institution with the chutzpah to present an art show about women these days is asking for it, as the Brooklyn Museum has just found out. Trying -- I suppose -- to be topical, it has culled its splendid graphics collection for works on the subject of women, and arranged the resulting miscellany (no pun intended) of more than 150 prints and drawings into "Pride and Prejudice: A Woman's Exhibition."

Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said yesterday that he might enter 1972 Democratic Presidential primary elections, particularly the New York primary, to try to win enough delegates to have some influence at the party's national convention.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 10 -- Tom Weiskopf's 66 led the opening round of the $150,000 Kemper open today in the last test for the pro golfers before next week's United States Open.
TOKYO, June 10 -- Government leaders today hailed the agreement, announced yesterday, on returning Okinawa and the other islands of the Ryukyu chain to Japan.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Following is a summary of those United States products placed by President Nixon today on the general license list for the People's Republic of China. No special license is required for the export of these items.

CAIRO, June 10 -- President Anwar el-Sadat declared today that the Arabs faced a battle for generations against Israel, which, he said, would hang like "the sword of Damocles" over the Arabs long after they had recovered the lands lost in the 1967 war.
The Yale Repertory Theater will institute a policy of rotating repertory with its sixth year of professional operation starting Oct. 14.

SEATTLE, June 11 -- The Gold Baton, the highest honor of the American Symphony Orchestra League, was awarded posthumously tonight to Martha Baird Rockefeller of New York City, the widow of John D. Rockefeller.
PARIS, June 11 -- The Nobel Prize-winning novelist Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn defied Soviet censorship with the publication here today of what he called "the most important work of my life."
A Bronx teen-ager who allegedly hurled a rock through a window of a train, causing a Penn Central conductor to lose an eye and another to suffer impaired vision, was arraigned yesterday in the Bronx.

The state and the Westchester County commissioners of social services were directed yesterday to show cause in Federal Court next Tuesday why they should not be held in contempt for refusing to comply with an Oct. 14, 1969, order of the court that enjoined them from applying a one-year residency requirement for welfare assistance.

Price increases were announced yesterday on a variety of chemical products. Dow Chemical U.S.A., a unit of the Dow Chemical Corporation, said it will raise the price of four propylene series dowanol glycol ethers by one-half of a cent a pound, effective June 15 to spot customers and July 1 to contract customers.

With the reference to your editorial suggestion of May 24 that the United States and other members of the World Bank's Aid-to-Pakistan Consortium "stick to their reported demand that the Yahya Government seek a political accommodation with the Bengalis as a condition for the resumption of assistance" for Pakistan, I must point out that the proposal is fraught with what could be grave consequences.
A hijacker surrendered to the police early this morning at Kennedy Airport after boarding the plane in Chicago in a gun battle that left one man dead.

BOSTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it has filed a complaint in Federal court seeking a preliminary injunction against C. H. Wagner Co., Inc., a Boston broker-dealer and its president, Clarence H. Wagner, from further alleged violation of the commission's net capital rule.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 (UPI) -- A Government force of 35 marshals recaptured Alcatraz Island without resistance today, removing 15 Indian holdouts remaining from an occupation that begun 19 months ago.

Naum Gabo, the pioneer constructivist sculptor, has been made an Honorary Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire. The badge and star of the order were presented to Mr. Gabo earlier this week in Washington by Lord Cromer, the British Ambassador, in recognition of "outstanding services to Great Britain and Anglo-American relations."
Strength in American Telephone, which rose 1 1/8 points to 46, helped to steady a stock market that saw prices edge higher for the second session in a row.

HOUSTON, June 11 -- A state grand jury investigating rightwing terrorism in Houston indicted four young men on bombing charges today. Two of those indicted have been publicly identified by a leader of the Ku Klux Klan as being klan members.

BUCHAREST, Rumania -- As much as any theater in Eastern Europe, the Rumanian theater plays a vital part in national life, and if we hear less of it than of the Czechoslovak or Polish theaters it is largely because the Rumanians have no taste for heroics.
Those few readers of this column who are prepared to admit that their bridge game is not always completely accurate can be comforted by the thought that the experts are also human.
The University of Miami announced yesterday that it would begin a program next month to train doctoral scientists to become medical doctors after two years of additional education.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- W. Averell Harriman, former United States representative at the Vietnam peace talks in Paris, said today that the Administration was unwilling to discuss a date for the withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam because "it is quite clear" that the President "wants to see the present Government in Saigon maintained."
The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday it had submitted a proposal to the Japanese Government to acquire a 34.2 per cent interest in Isuzu Motors, Ltd., a motor vehicle producer.

The dying of Congressional Medal of Honor winner Dwight Johnson on the floor of a grocery store has the impact of a modern tragedy. Jon Nordheimer's perceptive report of May 26 portrays Sergeant Johnson's feelings of apathy and estrangement, demoralization by unemployment, a sense of being exploited by the Army even while hospitalized.

Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts said in court yesterday that evidence connecting two suspects in a social club holdup to last month's shooting of two patrolmen on Riverside Drive was in possession of the police and the New York County District Attorney's office.

New Jersey's Department of Environmental Protection announced yesterday that the beaches at Sandy Hook and in the Monmouth County and Raritan Bay areas had not affected by the raw sewage discharge that resulted from the recent New York City strike of municipal workers and would therefore be open to bathers this weekend.

Eight years ago Sara Shelburne left her native Richmond, Va., to study law abroad. Today, she's happy as a lark, living in Paris in an apartment in Montmartre with a huge terrace and loads of flowers.

MOSCOW, June 11 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, called on the United States today to accept military parity with the Soviet Union and join in efforts to insure "equal security" for both sides.
TOKYO, June 11 (Reuters) -- The Finance Ministry announced today that Japanese individuals would be allowed to buy and sell foreign securities starting July 1.

GAINESVILLE, Fla. -- Final examinations were held this week at the University of Florida but nobody has yet found an answer to the painful question that disrupted this 22,000 student campus all spring:

WASHINGTON -- Five-year-old Theressa Holloway, the youngest of eight children, is completing her second year in a local Montessori school, and if her mother has any complaint, it's that her daughter now "sure talks a lot."

A steady barrage of insults and profanity, interrupted by an outbreak of fist fights, greeted the directors of the city hospital system yesterday at the first public meeting they have held since they took over last July 1.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, June 12 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu, moving to strengthen his Government's position before the legislative and presidential elections here later this year, today made the first important changes in his Cabinet since its formation in September, 1969.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Nixon Administration has decided that Americans will no longer be permitted to enter southern Laos as leaders of teams keeping watch on enemy movements along the Ho Chi Minh Trail network.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- Amtrak, the recently formed National Railroad Passenger Corporation has named four new vice presidents and a controller.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed yesterday for the second consecutive session in continued light trading.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Harry and James Huisman of New York will receive a patent June 22 for the methods they use in cutting 144 facets on their diamonds -- a far greater number of reflecting surfaces, they say, than other diamond cutters supply.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- President Nixon pledged today to enforce existing prohibitions against racial discrimination in housing, but said he would not use Federal leverage to force local communities to accept low- and moderate-income housing against their wishes.

PETROS, Tenn., June 11 -- James Earl Ray is out of solitary confinement and has regained some of his prison privileges after his attempt to escape a month ago, warden Robert H. Moore of Brushy Mountain State Prison said today.

It is one of the ironies of modern museological practice that so-called "permanent" collections are so little available to the public so much of the time. Museums are constantly acquiring new additions to their permanent collections, but these collections are more often in storage than on public exhibition.

The Supreme Court's ruling in Baker vs. Cart in 1962 against the unfair, undemocratic apportionment of legislative districts was a historic accomplishment. That decision and those which derive from it broke the rural grip which had been strangling many state legislatures, did away with the startling disparities in population between comparable legislative and Congressional districts, and rescued Negroes from various kinds of racially inspired gerrymandering.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 11 -- Bob Lunn, who found a formula to reduce his weight, indicated he had another for reducing his golf score today. With a six-under-par 66 in the second round of the $150,000 Kemper open, the 26-year-old Californian led by one stroke with a 36-hole aggregate of 135.

The New York Philharmonic's June Promenade concerts being given this weekend are offering the first New York performances of some very pretty music by Reinhold Gliere, the Russian composer. The work is a Concerto for Coloratura and Orchestra, and it was composed during the grim days of World War II.
PARIS, June 11 -- French officials are dropping hints that the Government is becoming more favorable to exchange-rate flexibility.
LONDON, June 10 -- If you think of London as a grand, gray-skied city of pomp, circumstance and Portland stone, think again. And put on your sunglasses.
Kuru, one of the strangest and most insidious diseases known, is fading away in its New Guinea habitat, apparently because of a ban on ritualistic cannibalism.
MEXICO CITY, June 11 -- The Mexican Government said today that it was not involved in any way in last night's armed attack on an anti-Government student demonstration.

WARSAW, June 11 -- A car carrying the Chinese Ambassador to Poland backed into a driveway of the United States Embassy here today, starting a rumor that diplomatic talks were under way between Washington and Peking.

ADDIS ARABA, Ethiopia, June 11 (UPI) -- President Idi Amin's Uganda delegation won a no-contest victory for seats at a ministerial session of the Organization of African Unity today." But the delegation said it would boycott next week's ministerial meeting and a later summit session.

Small jazz groups have a tendency to mark off a small musical area for themselves and to concentrate on this territory to such an extent that their performances soon fall into predictable patterns. But the Joe Newman Quintet, which played yesterday afternoon at the Jazz Center 57 West 57th Street, showed how wide a scope such a group can have with the application of a little imagination.
ROME, June 11 -- The Vatican announced today new legal procedures to expedite the handling of petitions for annulment of Roman Catholic marriages.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Mayor Lindsay and a group of his fellow big-city Mayors appealed to the House Ways and Means Committee today to enact some form of revenue-sharing program. They received in turn, strong hints from some committee members that fiscal help for the cities may be on the way.

LONDON, June 11 -- All over England this week children are coming home from school asking their parents for a few pence to give for relief of the East Pakistan refugees. In the newspapers the refugee tragedy has been the dominant story for many days; the largest-circulation tabloid has spread a relief appeal over page one.
BECKENHAM, England, June 11 (AP) -- Top-seeded Clark Graebner of New York and Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., advanced today to the men's semifinals in the Kent lawn tennis championships.

Community development corporations that promote economic development in poor communities around the country were praised during a United States Senate subcommittee hearing in Brooklyn yesterday as a "new hope for the inner city." to the nation." More than 30 witnesses -- community leaders, politicians, businessmen, residents, officials of development corporations from other cities and economists -- testified that while the corporations "had not solved the problems" of poverty they had "brought hope" to many people.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A Federal court of appeals here nullified today a 17-month-old Federal Communications Commission policy not to consider license challenges against radio and television stations that have "substantially" met the programing needs of their communities.

GENEVA, June 11 -- The outside walls and doors of the Rath Museum, where an exhibition of works by eight black American artists will open tomorrow, were smeared last night with black paint and with the slogans, in English, "black power" and "Kill the pigs."

DUARTE, Calif., June 11 (UPI) -- The flight recorder recovered from the wreckage of an Air West DC-9 showed today that the plane was airborne for only eight minutes before it collided with a military jet, killing 50 persons.
BONN, June 11 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government announced today plans for a major tax reform program aimed at easing the burden on low-income groups and increasing taxes on the rich.
ZURICH, Switzerland, June 11 -- The glut of dollars is buying troubles for Special Drawing Rights, the world's newest reserve asset.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- An Army general censured for allegedly failing to meet the required standards of performance in investigating the Mylai massacre will retire June 30.
After a weak opening, wheat futures prices rose sharply yesterday but later profit taking halved the gain.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The first president of the National Academy of Sciences' new Institute of Medicine said today that his organization intended to be vigorous and aggressive in confronting health issues important to the nation.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declined today to delay the take-over of Channel 3 in Jackson, Miss., by a nonprofit organization.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Democratic National Convention of 1972 will ban all floor demonstrations and lengthy speeches, shake up the traditional alphabetical roll-call and make the nomination of favorite-son candidates all but impossible.
LE MANS, France, June 11 -- The race is not always to the swiftest and the way the swiftest are talking, the 39th edition of the 24 Hours of Le Mans might not be a race at all.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Edward C. Jaegerman, former managing partner of Charles Plohn Co., had been permanently barred from association or employment with any member organization of the exchange.

WICHITA, Kan., June 11 -- Randy Matson and Jacques Accambray shattered meet records with their 16-pound implements today at the United States Track and Field Federation's ninth outdoor championships at Wichita State University.
MOSCOW, June 11 -- The Soviet Union plans to build up an existing mill into the nation's largest iron and steel plant in the heart of European Russia, near the principal metal markets.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, said today that much more information is needed about how banks operate if citizens are to be able to evaluate their performance.
LAKENHEATH, England, June 11 -- The United States Air Force today opened an official public investigation of Capt. Thomas S. Culver, a legal officer involved in antiwar activities.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 11 -- The Frigidaire division of the General Motors Corporation has announced it will lay off 1,152 more hourly employes on June 18, raising the total employe cutback since last November's labor contract negotiations to 3,222.

The Coastal States Gas Producing Company announced yesterday the appointment of Harry G. Fair as president, succeeding Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., who continues as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Fair was previously an executive vice president of Pullman, Inc.

A Federal judge agreed yesterday to consider whether the Port of New York Authority's "covenant" with its bondholders did in fact amend the interstate compact by which the authority was set up and therefore should have been approved, like the compact, by Congress.

Schuyler G. Chapin has been named assistant manager of the Metropolitan Opera, beginning with the 1972-73 season. Goeran Gentele, who becomes the company's general manager that season, has announced the appointment. No details about Mr. Chapin's responsibilities were disclosed.
Auction records were broken for the second time in a month last Tuesday when an 18th-century American desk was sold for $104,000 at the Samuel T. Freeman Galleries in Philadelphia.

TOKYO, June 11 (AP) -- The Japanese Government granted approval today for the Chrysler Corporation to acquire a minority interest in the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation. The link-up with the American automobile maker was the culmination of an effort begun by the two companies in 1968.

TEL AVIV, June 11 -- Bomb attacks today killed two Arab workers in the Gaza Strip who had been waiting for buses to take them to their jobs in Israel, according to an official announcement here. Eighty-one Arabs in the area, which is occupied by Israel, were reported injured.

Elton John appeared Thursday and again last night before an impassioned audience at Carnegie Hall, in what must be the best-produced rock concert there in a great long while.

YONKERS, June 11 -- At the finish of the $35,000 mile-and-a-quarter Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight, George Sholty, driving Laverne Hanover, wasn't sure he had won and Jack Kopas, handling Super Wave, wasn't sure he had lost.

WASHINGTON, June 11, (UPI) -- The Pentagon accused Senator William Proxmire today of seeking publicity in charging that the Pentagon plans to expand "snooping activities" by recording and transcribing Washington area news broadcasts.

New Model Cities elections will be held June 18 in eight of 21 slum districts because of "irregularities" during the balloting three weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- The Nixon Administration sent Congress today proposed legislation to provide a $50,000 payment to the survivors of any state or local policeman killed in the line of duty.

PALERMO, Sicily, June 11 -- The screech of brakes. Revolver shots. The tinkle of broken glass. The wail of a car horn held down by the weight of a dying man. Day after day the sounds of violence echo through Palermo's littered streets, followed by the scream of sirens.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 11 -- Chile's governing Marxist coalition suffered a significant defeat today when a key legal adviser to President Salvador Allende Gossens lost in an attempt to be elected rector of the University of Chile.

FREEVILLE, N. Y., June 14 -- The sign on the big barn right off Highway 13 reads "Love Inn," and it's well-known in the area as a crash pad. The long-haired youths who congregate there are clearly middle-class drop-outs.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has announced a new policy of setting fixed terms of six years for pastors of local parishes and restricting pastors to two consecutive terms in the saint parish.

Nestle, a big name in chocolate, has just introduced a new chocolate drink in New York.

Alitalia, the Italian airline, introduced a $199 youth fare between New York and Rome last night despite a ruling by the United States Civil Aeronautics Board prohibiting it.

Tony Oliva, who has the highest career batting average of any active player in the American League (.311 going into the season), appears headed for his third batting championship. This time his winning percentage could be his best ever.

KANSAS CITY, June 14 -- Lee MacPhail, the Yankees' general manager, arrived in Kansas City a few hours before tonight's game with the Royals and talked about the dwindling chances of making a trade before the deadline at midnight tomorrow.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 14 -- Earl Hines yesterday received the third annual James P. Johnson Award from the Rutgers Institute of Jazz Studies. The award, presented in recognition of his contributions to American music, was made during the fourth annual conference on discographical research, held at Hickman Hall on the campus of Douglass College.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 14 -- A group of 15 blacks and Puerto Ricans today filed a suit in Federal Court in Bridgeport against this affluent suburban community, charging it with racial and economic discrimination.

NEW HAVEN, June 14 -Father James Groppi and 10 other demonstrators were arrested today as they sought unsuccessfully to disrupt the Yale University commencement exercises. Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany was honored at the commencement.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission has begun to study campus radio stations with an eye to regulation over those that expand their audience coverage beyond the campus.
HONOLULU, June 14 (UPI) -- Debris was sighted today in the South Pacific, where an Air Force C-135 transport vanished with 24 persons aboard, apparently while monitoring French nuclear tests.

LONDON, June 14 -- With Wimbledon a week away and the players short of match play on grass, pelting rain forced the abandonment of the World Championship Tennis tournament at the semifinal stage in Bristol, postponed the South of England event at Eastbourne and dripped dismally through the glass roof on the courts as the London grass championships moved indoors today at the Queen's Club.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 14 -- National Guard units patrolled the streets of this city tonight to curb marauding bands of hippies, Negroes and Mexican-Americans who had created serious disorders through the day.

The Rent Guidelines Board announced yesterday new maximum rent increases, ranging from 8 per cent to 13 per cent, for 350,000 rent-stabilized city apartments from July through June 30, 1972. Rent-controlled apartments are not affected.

This reflects in part profits from ocean-shipping activities conducted by the 46 per cent owned Marcona Group and higher income from the company's interests in mining of coking and steam coal, Australian and United States iron ore.

Some sentimentalists might be tempted to withhold official status front the United States Open golf championship that began yesterday at classic Merion just outside of Philadelphia. The reason? Samuel Jackson Snead is missing and the millionaire hillbilly has been causing folks to hold their breaths during Opens ever since his first one in 1937.
Madison Avenue has had its last Tuesday evening Magic Promenade of the summer.

SEATTLE, June 17 (UPI) -Leslie Bacon, tired and nervous, said today that she would be in New York City by June 30 to face a Federal charge linking her to an unsuccessful plot to bomb a Manhattan bank.

VIENNA, June 17 -- The Interternational Air Transport Association has urgently appealed to the governments of the world to limit the mushrooming activities of charter or nonscheduled, airline service. If this is not done, the association said, the present scheduled airline network on which the world relies for most of its commerce "may be destroyed by the frustrated operators themselves or because of the pressures."

The international oil industry, still recovering from the buffeting it took from the producing countries in the negotiations in Teheran and Tripoli earlier this year, is in the midst of another crisis.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 18 -- About 3,000 textile industry leaders and workers staged a rally here today, opposing any restrictions on South Korean exports of manmade and wool textile goods to the United States. American and Korean officials continued negotiations on the issue.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (Reuters) -- The United States is studying a Soviet proposal for a five-nation nuclear disarmament conference, the state department said today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18 (AP) -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology said today it had heard from Daniel Ellsberg, the former Government adviser who is alleged to have given classified documents on Vietnam to The New York Times.

LONDON, June 15 -- Like most of the 1,000 hotels, guesthouses and hostels in London, the King George VI Memorial Hostel was unusually busy this morning.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- In a new decision in the Texas Gulf Sulphur case, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has upheld the bulk of the district court's decision imposing penalties on officers and employes on the basis of inside information.

Persistently high unemployment and the cries of anguish from the nation's financially-squeezed mayors have apparently persuaded the Administration to re-examine its opposition to the public service jobs bill. President Nixon last year vetoed a Democratic-sponsored manpower bill which included Federal subsidies for jobs on city and state payrolls. Another veto had been predicted for the public service employment bill now in a House-Senate conference.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Within hours after The New York Times published secret Pentagon documents Sunday, Attorney General John N. Mitchell and Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird began discussing possible attempts to stop the articles.

In the 1620's a newspaper publisher in England was sent to jail for printing without a license. In the 1640's another publisher was jailed for "interpreting" a speech made in Parliament.

Condemned to death by the living, the abandoned building on East 4th Street burns madly. A couple of Molotov cocktails carefully ignited and carelessly thrown light up the block as hundreds of local residents mill about, singing and dancing, having a good time.

English, the Democratic National Committeeman from New York, who is in over-all charge, will be a group of about six key operatives.

ALBANY, June 18 -- Changes in the state election law requiring generally a doubling of the number of petition signatures to put a candidate on the ballot have been signed into law by Governor Rockefeller.

TOKYO, June 18 (Reuters) -- The Japanese Cabinet's council of economic ministers decided today to step up the implementation of the eight-point program adopted June 4 to avert growing pressure for an upward revaluation of the yen, Cabinet spokesmen said today.

LONDON, June 18 -- Hugh Leonard's "The Patrick Pearse Motel" at the Queen's Theater picks up the threads from "John Bull's Other Island" by showing Ireland exploiting its national relics to bolster the tourist trade: the difference being that where Shaw prophesied an invasion of British developers, Mr. Leonard portrays the Irish as fully capable of Americanizing their country without any help from outside.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 18 -- Eduardo Frei Montalva, the Christian Democratic leader and former President, said today that the disbanding of all armed groups by the Chilean Government was necessary to achieve political stability here.

ROME, June 17 -- The Precision international team ended its world tour here Wednesday night. In a series of 12 matches that began in Taipei, Taiwan, a month ago and stretched through much of Asia and part of Africa, the touring group of Benito Garozzo, Giorgio Belladonna, both of Rome, and Katherine Wei, Dorothy Hayden and this writer, all of New York, was defeated only once, by a young Tel Aviv team.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., June 18 -- Dr. George M. Stroll, Shelter Island's only physician, is 71 years old. Every morning for the last 10 years he has climbed into his car to make the rounds of the sick and infirm he cares for all alone on this island of 1,500 year-round residents and 5,500 summer visitors.

PAWLING, N. Y., June 18 (AP) -- The remains of former New York Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and his wife, Frances, were permanently interred last Wednesday in the Pawling Cemetery. The bodies had reposed in a vault at the cemetery pending completion of a mausoleum.

NEWARK, June 18 -- Frank G. Manning, the former Hudson County engineer who is the Government's principal witness in the Jersey City-Hudson County corruption trial in Federal Court here, resisted defense efforts today to reduce his credulity and to reduce doubts about his insistence that he was a reluctant and unhappy "bag man" for John V. Kenny.

WASHINGTON -- The nation-state is obsolete. Because of radical changes in the world environment, the basic political unit around which international society has been organized for almost 400 years is no longer capable of meeting desperate human needs. The crisis is particularly acute for the large nations which are increasingly unable to use their unparalleled accumulations of power to decrease the sum of human misery.

The 22-year-old Murphy putted his way to a 7-and-6 victory over Gilison in the final that lasted 30 of a scheduled 36 holes.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 20 -- Time was when foreign oil men here looked forward each year to June 24 and July 5, Venezuela's big patriotic holidays. It meant two more days at the beach or golf course.

Soaring losses on bad loans were a principal factor that caused the First National City Bank to fall short of its targeted increase in earnings last year, according to a confidential analysis by Walter B. Wriston, chairman of the $26billion institution.

JERUSALEM, June 20 -- Five ministers reported separately to the Cabinet today on efforts -- successful for the moment -to suppress a wave of strikes and labor agitation in Israeli hospitals, electricity plants and other vital public services.

A Brooklyn peace organization held a rally in Prospect Park yesterday afternoon to protest the war in Vietnam and to show other Americans that in the pursuit of peace there could be no generation gap.

NEW DELHI, June 20 (AP) -Meghalaya state imposed a month-long evening curfew on its 300-mile heavily forested border with East Pakistan today in what was termed a move to protect life, property and communications and to guard against infiltration of Pakistani spies.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 20 -- French Bird, one of the smallest eligible yachts entered in the Storm Trysail Club's Block Island Race Week, won the American Yacht Club's feeder race today from 48 other boats, the largest of six feeder races to this small island in Long Island Sound.
JONES BEACH, L.I., June 20 -- Helicopters, motor launches and uniformed policemen filled in here today for lifeguards who have not shown up for work since the beach season opened.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 20 -- About 4,200 pentecostal Roman Catholics conferred and worshiped at the University of Notre Dame this weekend in the first international and the fifth national conference on the charismatic renewal in the Catholic Church, also known as the pentecostal movement.
KENVIL, N. J., June 20 -An unknown quantity of a high explosive that ignites spontaneously unless kept wet may have been stolen from a railroad car here, the police warned tonight.

ORFORD, England, June 20 -- In "Akenfield," his classic study of an English village, Ronald Blythe wrote that to those coming from the outside world Akenfield seems "a holy place . . . a little arable kingdom where flints are the jewels. . . . Its very sounds are formal, hieratic: larks, clocks, bees, tractor hummings."

The people of the Baltic states -- Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia -- have been recalling a sad anniversary. PITTSBURGH, June 20 -- Steel mills were trimming their 1971 estimates last week.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 20 -- "Laver to win Wimbledon," says the seedings, the record, the betting and common sense. But a niggling doubt assails the mind. The greatest player of his generation is top-seeded, an even favorite against the field and is gunning for his fifth title here over the decade during which he has reigned supreme as amateur and pro.

ST. PAUL, June 20 -- The National Wanderer Forum, an annual gathering of conservative Roman Catholics, ended its 1971 session today by "vigorously opposing" Government involvement in population control.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 20 (AP) -- The West All-Stars, led by Cazzie Russell, Earl Monroe, Jimmy Jones and Willie Wise, posted a 111-100 victory over the East today in the first Martin Luther King Jr. benefit basketball game involving players from the National and American Basketball Associations.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 20 -- William Ofori-Atta, Foreign Minister of Ghana, peered over his spectacles at his audience of fellow African diplomats and said: "We know we are not serious. South Africa knows we are not serious, too."

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Council on Environmental Quality took steps today to minimize environmental damage to an area of Florida disrupted by the Cross-Florida Barge Canal, now suspended.

If he two-putted, he would enter an 18-hole playoff tomorrow with Lee Trevino, who was sitting on a white wooden bench in the Merion Golf Club locker room, sipping a beer and ignoring a nearby TV set.

ARDMORE, Pa., June 20 -- Lee Trevino spurted on the last nine holes today and ended in a tie for first with Jack Nicklaus at par 280 in the United States Open golf championship today. The 1968 Open champion shot a 69, although a bogey 5 at Merion's 18th hole allowed the title to slip from Trevino's grasp.

TEHERAN -- The main subject of conversation in Iran is the forthcoming International Cultural Festival at Persepolis. "We have been at it for the past 13 years," an aide to the Minister of Court told a visitor.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The meticulous report of the Citizens Research Foundation on political spending in 1968 has disclosed, above all, a staggering increase from 1964. Total costs were up 50 per cent, from $200 to $300 million; the cost of electing a President and Vice President rose 67 per cent from $60 to $100 million. By comparison, the nation emerged with Dwight Eisenhower twenty years ago for the bargain price of $11.6million.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 22 -- An explosive device was found this morning at the base of the stone wall near the entrance to the Soviet Union's estate here. It was disarmed by the Nassau County police before it could do any damage.
LONDON, June 22 -- The British Government has ordered out of the country two Soviet diplomats "detected in intelligence operations against the United Kingdom," the Foreign Office announced today.

MOSCOW, June 22 -- The Soviet Union and Cuba today made public a communique that was intended to show improved relations between the two countries but that was deliberately vague on Latin American policy.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- The Chicago Sun-Times said today that it had obtained top-secret State Department documents showing that high-ranking Kennedy Administration officials had advance knowledge of the coup d'etat that toppled President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam in 1963.

NEWARK, June 22 -- The Evening News of Newark and the striking North Jersey Newspaper Guild agreed today to a Federal mediator's call for a negotiating session on Friday at 11 A.M. at the office here of the mediator, Joseph DeLorenzo.
ALBANY, June 22 -- Governor Rockefeller today signed three bills creating a New York City Housing Development Corporation.

Robert J. Kleberg Jr., owner of the famed King Ranch, who came to New York to inspect Canonero II for a possible acquisition, saw one of his $100,000 purchases make a winning debut at sunny Belmont Park yesterday.

ZIZIA, Jordan, June 22 -- Palestine refugees gave King Hussein of Jordan a tumultuous welcome today as he visited one of their camps for the first time since the civil war last September between his army and Palestinian commando forces.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 22 (AP) -- Gov. Reubin Askew signed into law today a bill giving Florida a Presidential preference primary next March 14, the earliest in the nation.

Bishop Industries, Inc., producer of toiletries and beauty aids, announced yesterday the end of its proceedings under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
