WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Commissioned Corps of the Public Health Service, the elite cadre of Federal doctors for almost a century, would be abolished if the Nixon Administration took the advice of an advisory committee report that was made public today.

GENEVA, June 24 -- Robert L. Vesco, president of the International Controls Corporation, and Richard E. Clay, a member of the company's board, have become board members of Global Natural Resources Properties, Ltd., an offshoot of Investors Overseas Services.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 24 -- The American Medical Association's annual convention ended in confusion today after a rift opened among the new president, the president-elect, the board of trustees and the policy-making House of Delegates.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 25 -- Fresh South Vietnamese troops were flown in American helicopters to the bomb-shattered Firebase Fuller and retook the mountaintop position early this morning, just a day after it had fallen to North Vietnamese troops.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had filed a complaint in Federal District Court in New York seeking an injunction against alleged violations by the Memorex Corporation and two individuals of the anti-fraud and periodic-reporting provisions of the securities laws.
A tentative agreement on terms of a new three-year Broadway production contract was reached early yesterday morning by Actors Equity Association and the League of New York Theaters.

A short time ago women who are accustomed to paying up to $2,500 for an evening gown were happily being fitted for summer and fall designs at Mainbocher's salon. This week, the last of those outfits were delivered to their owners, and yesterday a chapter of the old order passed on with a brief burst of noise -- and just a few sighs.

An offensive tackle is a disciplined introvert, the strong silent type, while a defensive tackle is the opposite -- extroverted, individualistic, hell bent. Similarly a wide receiver is a body cultist and a showoff while a defensive back demonstrates arrogance and aggression. Quarterbacks? They may show a variety of traits, but the good ones always demonstrate confidence.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mixed yesterday in the lightest trading in more than five months.

When a singer has as many interesting qualities as Marian Taylor does, it is disconcerting find that her songs frequently do not come out the way she apparently expects them to or as the listener might reasonably expect them to.

The H. J. Heinz Company realized a 15.6 per cent increase in earnings for the fiscal year ended April 28, setting a record for the eighth consecutive year, the food processing company reported yesterday from its Pittsburgh headquarters.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate passed today the bill continuing the military draft for two more years.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 -- The trial of a chemical company charged with polluting the Monongahela River was suddenly adjourned today while the judge and the defense attorney heatedly discussed the law on which the trial is based.
The Archbishop of Newport, Wales, said yesterday that he had recently considered making a national television comeback, but that not enough stations in the United States were interested.
As David E. Guerrant, chief executive of Libby, McNeil Libby, explained it yesterday, the last two years saw the giant food processor move from a productionoriented to a marketing-oriented company.
How do you view Applied Health Services, Inc.? Well, there are at least two schools of thought. It may be a hot stock. So far the market seems to think so.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- The Pennsylvania Supreme Court, in a 5-to-2 decision, declared the state's first personal income tax unconstitutional today.

J. Lee Rankin, the city's Corporation Counsel, was directed by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to review procedures of all city agencies with rulemaking functions to insure that their meetings are open to the public.

WASHINGTON -- There is not the slightest doubt in my mind that The New York Times will receive many journalistic awards for its publication of the Pentagon Papers on Indochina. After all, a scoop that runs a million and a half words is not exactly to be sneezed at in journalistic circles.
Even the dogs were curious yesterday morning when five VISTA workers draped their paneled truck in boldly patterned patchwork before taking to the streets of New York in search of store buyers.

Arthur Miller, the American playwright, and Augusto Boal, a leading stage director in Brazil, met the other day to talk about "newspaper theater," a form of revolutionary satire gaining wide popularity in Latin America as a means of outwitting Government censorship.
YUMA, Ariz., June 24 (AP) -- A two-seat Cessna 150 crashed near here today after it circled the city for almost three hours without a pilot.
The Maritime Administration has been enjoined from paying an unspecified portion of $36.8-million in operating subsidies due eight major steamship lines.
The city's job freeze has reduced the force of Consumer Affairs Department inspectors from 200 to 80 during the last two years, the agency's Commissioner, Bess Myerson, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, refused again today to show Congress either the raw materials or the editing procedures that Produced the television documentary "Selling of the Pentagon" last winter.

VERNON, Ind., June 24 -President Nixon paid a nostalgic visit today to his mother's birthplace in rural Indiana and used the occasion to exhort several thousand well-wishers to cling to the values that she Knew as a Quaker girl around the turn of the century.
BAY SHORE, L. I., June 24 (UPI) -- A teen-ager drowned early this afternoon in the Atlantic Ocean off Robert Moses State Park on Fire Island.

Airlift International, Inc., one of the hot stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange prior to the market slide that began late in 1968, will be delisted as a result of a vote yesterday by the Amex board of governors.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The New York Times asked the Supreme Court today to permit it to resume publication of material from the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.

American Airlines, Inc., raised $89.92-million yesterday with the sale of 3.3 million new common shares, a move putting it among several others in the industry that have tapped the equity markets recently.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 24 -- The money is pouring in to Box 1972, Montgomery, addressed to "The Wallace Campaign."

AMP, Inc., has elected Joseph D. Brenner as president. Mr. Brenner, formerly vice president of operations, succeeds S. S. Auchincloss who was elected vice chairman and continues as chief executive officer. C. J. Frederickson, formerly vice president and chief financial officer was elected chairman of the finance committee, a new post.
OTTAWA, June 24 -- The New Democratic party won a sweeping victory over the incumbent Liberals in elections in the prairie province of Saskatchewan yesterday.
PORTSMOUTH, N. H., June 24 -- The magnetic attraction of New Hampshire's Presidential primary reached futher into the Democratic party today, drawing Representative William R. Anderson.
Looking Glass, a rock group from Glen Gardner, N. J., gave a free concert Wednesday afternoon at Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center.

A long fight for control of the $1-billion Security National Bank, Huntington, L. I., appeared to have come to an end yesterday. The Abacus Fund, Inc., the bank's largest stockholder, announced that it had agreed to sell its 766,710 shares of Security -- roughly 25 per cent of the total outstanding -- for $43 a share, or almost $33-million.

PARIS -- Who is doing what to whom and why in Madagascar is a question deeply disturbing to several capitals and especially to Washington which has been accused of fomenting a conspiracy against President Philibert Tsiranana. One consequence of this murky tale of plot end counterplot is that U.S. Ambassador Anthony Marshall is being quietly withdrawn.
In any situation as complicated as the Middle East, it is not difficult to find accords that have been violated by one side or the other.

The members of the N.Y.U. Dance Ensemble obviously know, respect and admire one anothers' skills, and Wednesday evening they prepared a program of dances featuring themselves and invited the public to the School of Arts Theater. The tonality was warm and humorous and the performers, Nora Guthrie, Rachel Lampert, Andrea Stark, Ted Rotante and Byron Wheeler, were lithe, coy and generally engaging.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa resigned today from all remaining positions of leadership in the teamsters' union, including the presidency of Detroit Local 299, which he used as a springboard to the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Five liberal Senators -- four Democrats and one Republican -- called on the United States today to change its longstanding policy and press for the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

Dear Bob Dylan: You remember me. I'm the fellow at the bar at Gerde's Folk City back in 1961 who patted you on the back and said how enjoyed your singing. You said, "Thank you," if memory serves. That was not long after Robert Shelton had written about you in The Times and said a lot of glowing things about your talent.

The New York County Democratic executive committee endorsed Supreme Court Justice Frederick Backer for Manhattan surrogate yesterday, but he faces a fight for the party nomination in the Sept. 14 primary.

Mrs. Nellie R. Duncan has resigned as superintendent of Community School District 23 in Brooklyn after a three-month controversy in which she was charged by the district board with misusing $18,000 in Federal education funds.

PARIS, June 24 -- Le Duc Tho, a high-ranking member of the North Vietnamese hierarchy, returned to the peace talks here today after more than a year's absence and said he was ready to stay "as long as my presence is needed."
A 23-year-old airline hostess was found murdered in her Yorkville apartment last night. The police said she had been raped and then strangled by stockings that were wrapped around her neck.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, demanded yesterday an immediate investigation of allegedly "racist" activities by Andrew G. Donaldson, the superintendent of Community School District 9 in the Bronx.

Pausing at the curb, flashing a glance to her right, Barbara Lynn cut across Madison Avenue in a slow, ladylike gait in midblock yesterday morning. Then she saw the taxi headed toward her.

After opening lower, silver futures prices closed near the of 200 to 210 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) in expanded trading.

IMPERIAL, Calif., June 24 (UPI) -- Poisonous gas from a fire-engulfed pesticide storage area forced evacuation of nearly 1,000 persons from their homes today in this Southern California community.

The opening on Wednesday night of the 54th season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts played by the Goldman Band was enriched and enlivened by the presence of the All-City High School Chorus, which sang four selections with the band in the middle of the program.

BRUSSELS, June 24 -- The European Common Market Commission has put forward plans for discouraging the flow of hot money into community countries, and for limiting the harm these flows do to anti-inflationary policies pursued by governments of the six-nation unit.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -The House of Representatives rejected today an amendment to an appropriations bill that would have authorized the United States payment of dues owed to the International Labor Organization.
ERIE, Pa., June 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Joanne Carner and Donna Caponi posted two-under-par 70's at the Kahkwa Club golf course today to share the first-round lead in the United States Women's Open.

An alliance between two brothers in public service -one the Bronx District Attorney, the other an official of the city's Department of Correction -resulted yesterday in the arrest of a prison guard accused of trafficking in narcotics.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 24 (UPI) -- The United States command reported today that 25 Americans died in combat in Indochina last week. This was the same number as the previous week and well under the average of 46 a week so far this year.

LOS ANGELES, June 24 -- A powerful explosion early this morning trapped 18 workmen behind a wall of fire and dense smoke in a tunnel under construction in suburban Sylmar. Six bodies have been recovered and littel hope was held out for 11 other workman.

ST. PAUL, June 24 -- Minnesota's Twin Cities are doing very well by opera. The Center Opera of Minneapolis has made some highly provocative experiments with the form, and this summer is touring two of its productions on the East Coast, "Faust Counter Faust" by John Gessner and H. Wesley Balk and "The Mother of Us All," the old but still avant-garde work of Virgil Thomson and Gertrude Stein.

LOS ANGELES, June 24 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Times reported in today's issue that the National Security Council rejected a recommendation by a State Department expert in 1963 that the United States should pull out of Vietnam because it could not win the war against the Communists.
CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP) -- Dan Sikes shot a 64 today and took a two-stroke lead in the first round of the $150,000 Cleveland open golf tournament.

DUCDUC, South Vietnam, June 18 -- The villagers here, a district seat of huts and muddy paths, do not look ahead. Their war is only a short distance away and memories of the attack last March by North Vietnamese troops are very fresh.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered a 10-day suspension of over-the-counter trading in securities of the Medical Investment Corporation, Minneapolis, for failure to supply audited financial statements required by the regulatory agency.

NEWARK, June 24 -- While many major railroads are complaining that business is softer than they had anticipated, the head of the Union Pacific Railroad said here today that his system's business right now "is dandy."
Details of the city's new withholding tax rates were made public yesterday, along with the impact of the new cigarette tax and the possibility of an expansion of the new plastic-container tax.

GENEVA, June 24 -- A member of President Nixon's Commission on International Trade and Investment Policy urged today the launching at the "highest political level" of a major international economic negotiation.

Plans for a national news service that would report exclusively news of black and other minority groups, particularly in deprived communities, were announced yesterday at the Interchurch Center on Riverside Drive.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Justice Department failed today to win a new hearing in the Court of Appeals on its effort to stop The Washington Post from resuming publication of information contained in the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.

Reports of imminent rapprochement between the Soviet Union and Israel may be premature, but hints that both nations are open to some kind of accommodation deserve all possible encouragement. The Nixon Administration is helping a Senate committee draft a new bill that would expand the proposal for rescuing the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation by making it possible to salvage other companies that get into similar financial trouble.
BONN, June 24 -- The Defense Committee of the West German Bundestag or parliament, approved today the purchase of $1.1-billion worth of Phantom F-4-E reconnaissanc aircraft from the United States.
The money supply spurted upward during the week ended June 16, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

PEKING, June 19 -- The doctrines of the Cultural Revolution have been translated into new Communist dogma. Under Mao Tse-tung that dogma has propelled China into a continuing revolution that is producing a new society and a new "Maoist man."

BERLIN, June 24 -- Walter Ulbricht lost his next-to-last important post, that of chairman of East Germany's National Defense Council, today. The Volkskammer, the country's Parliament, unanimously appointed Erich Honecker, the new First Secretary of the party, to the position.

The air-pollution code that is expected to be passed next month by the City Council would crack down on city facilities, which a Councilman described yesterday as probably the city's "worst violator, including Con Edison."

LONDON, June 24 -- Jean Giraudoux, last seen in London in Harold Clurman's short-lived production of "Judith" 10 years ago, is as ripe for revival as any mid-century French dramatist, but the National Theater is not helping his cause with Laurence Olivier's production (at the New Theater) of "Amphitryon 38," the work that embalms him in postwar memory as a lightweight fantasist.
SYRACUSE, June 24 (AP) -- Three members of Cornell's National Collegiate champion crew qualified today for Saturday's finals in the United States rowing trials for the Pan-American Games.
WARSAW, June 24 -- Poland unveiled a new five-year economic plan today that shifts priorities from investment in heavy industries to the needs of the nation's hard-pressed consumers.

One of Ralph Nader's associates, Bradford C. Snell, charges that the big three auto producers are using the practice of annual model change to transform the industry into a "collective monopoly" (letter June 12).

The Boston Stock Exchange annouced yesterday that its board of govemons had voted to let a representative of listed companies join the board. Exchange governors normally are representatives of member investment firms.

The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement to sell all its oil and gas interests to Ashland Oil, Inc., for about $90-million in cash and possible future contingency payments.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Air transport security officials came to Washington today to inform a Senate subcommittee that mail thefts at Kennedy International Airport in New York had shrunk to nearly zero.
The Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was ordered yesterday to refund $113,202.83 that it charged 64,338 customers for "sundries" between December, 1969, and May, 1970.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 24 -- The Brazilian Federal Court of Appeals today cleared the way for prosecution of policemen who have executed petty criminals in the name of anonymous vigilante groups called "death squads."

NEWPORT, R. I., June 24 -- Winners in four of the five classes in the Annapolis-toNewport yacht race were determined this afternoon, but most of the fleet was still struggling through fog five days after the start.

Granite Management Services, Inc., disclosed at yesterday's annual meeting in Los Angeles that Arthur G. Sherman, president, and Herbert I. Cooper, executive vice president, are giving up their posts but will continue as directors. They had been elected to their executive posts only last month.

Dr. Joseph T. English, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, said yesterday that he was "totally dissatisfied" with the corporation's practices on the hiring of members of minority groups. He said he would take immediate steps to bring blacks and Puerto Ricans into top-level policy-making jobs.
Talks in the trade of an imminent rise in the processor price for frozen orange juice sent futures of that commodity higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Trading was slow and price changes narrow on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
Sixty-five members of Actors Equity Association's council, the union's governing board, unanimously ratified yesterday the terms of a new three-year Broadway production contract.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The board of directors of the National Association of Broadcasters went on record today in support of Dr. Frank Stanton of the Columbia Broadcasting System and of newspapers that have printed excerpts from a secret Pentagon study of United States involvement in Vietnam.

ST. LOUIS, June 25 (AP) -The St. Louis Post-Dispatch said today that former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara labeled the pacification program in South Vietnam "a bad disappointment" in 1966 and told President Johnson he saw "no reasonable way to bring the war to an end soon."

Mayor Lindsay warned yesterday that city subway and bus riders were in "imminent danger of a sizable fare increase," and he asked the three city-appointed members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to develop a plan to save the 30-cent fare

Mayor Lindsay yesterday blamed cutbacks in Parks Department personnel and litter left by tourists for what a member of the House of Representatives from Missouri called "the valley of a garbage dump" in Battery Park.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 25 -- After six years of litigation in Federal and state courts, the City of Montgomery called for trial today the cases of 160 persons arrested on minor charges during the Selma-toMontgomery march in the spring of 1965.

DETROIT, June 25 (AP) -Automobile production in the United States dropped this week as the annual vacation and model-change-over period got under way.
A little awkwardly, but with obvious pride, 10 men and one girl strode up to the dais in the Mount Morris Park Amphitheater in Harlem yesterday to receive their high school equivalency diplomas.

Blue and white historical Staffordshire, the English pottery with printed decoration of scenes recording American events or views of significant landmarks, is coming into its own again after years of neglect.

GARY, Ind., June 25 (AP) -A former employe of The Gary Post-Tribune was critically wounded last night in a gun battle with agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who arrested him on charges of attempting to extort $30,000 from Walter T. Ridder, publisher of the paper.

UNITED NATIONS, New York, June 25 -- Soviet officials said here today that it was unthinkable that the Soviet Union would consider resuming diplomatic relations with Israel as long as the Israeli Government had not withdrawn all its soldiers from occupied Arab territories.

CLEVELAND, June 25 (UPI) -- Bobby Mitchell, who never has won a Professional Golfers Association tour event, gained the lead after 36 holes today in the $150,000 Cleveland open golf tournament with a sevenunder-par 64. His total of 130 gave him a stroke edge over Dan Sikes.
TRENTON, June 25 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of the state's busing program for parochial- and private -school children, reversing a lower-court decision.
The Inland Steel Company, the nation's seventh largest steel producer, announced yesterday in Chicago that it would guarantee not to raise prices on steel sheets before next Nov. 28.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- After four years of ideological and financial conflict with Gov. Ronald Reagan, California's much praised college and university system is torn by internal dissension over where it is going and how much it should spend to get there.
LONDON, June 25 (UPI) -The British Overseas Airways Corporation, citing a glum longrange outlook, disclosed today it has canceled orders for four Boeing 747 jumbo jets scheduled for delivery in 1973.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 25 -- The Block Island Race Week IV jinx of fog, calm, fog, foul current and more fog showed a new face today -- sunshine and flat water. Nevertheless, the hurried Storm Trysail Club committee persisted and finally got off to a shortened race.

Part of the total reason for the strange collapse of the Cincinnati Reds, last year's National League Champions, has been the ineffective pitching of Jim Merritt, the lefthander who won 20 games in 1970.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 26 -- The Justice Department announced this morning that a Federal magistrate in Los Angeles had issued a warrant for the arrest of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg on charges that he had "unauthorized possession of top-secret documents and failed to return them."

Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, yesterday published an account of the American involvement in the Vietnam war that it said was based on galley proofs of Lyndon B. Johnson's forthcoming Presidential memoirs.
A 15-year-old boy drowned at Jones Beach yesterday, the second drowning in two days at state parks being struck in a pay dispute by 350 lifeguards.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- The National Association of Securities Dealers, which regulates over-the-counter trading, has taken disciplinary action against seven firms and 11 individuals for violations of its rules of fair practice.
BUENOS AIRES, June 25 -The Argentine peso was cut in value to 4.40 to a dollar today, the fourth minor devaluation in less than three months.

The beginning chapters of Herbert Lieberman's "Crawlspace" sound like the opening chords of any traditional spook sonata: ominous, threatening, menacing. In those pages, the everyday is combined with a touch of the irrational in the best of haunted-house formulas. But a third of the way through, "Crawlspace" modulates into something bigger, darker and even more menacing.

SPOLETO, Italy, June 25 -The freshness of youthful musicianship from the United States and some practical scholarship combined to produce enthusiasm for Spoleto's resurrection of the real "Boris Godunov" at last night's Festival of Two Worlds opening.
MOSCOW, June 25 -- The dismissal of a public-health inspector who refused to yield to political pressure has erupted into something of a scandal here.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 25 (UPI) -- Gov. Ronald Reagan's antipoverty director has been accused by a Federal auditor of having improperly spent almost $100,000, including $2,101 on political telegrams. The telegrams allegedly were sent in behalf of George Murphy, who was then the Republican Senator.

WASHINGTON June 25 -Lawyers for the California Rural Legal Assistance Project filed suit in Federal Court today to force the Office of Economic Opportunity to release immediately a study of the antipoverty project.

BONN, June 25 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt signaled today to East Germany's new leader, Erich Honecker, that he think it is time to resume discussions on establishing formal relations between the two German states.

Congressional efforts to speed the end of American military involvement in the Indochina conflict have become focused appropriately this year on Selective Service legislation now moving toward final action.

Skouras Jr., who was elected chief executive officer of the corporation. The other members of the new committee are Spyros P. Skouras Sr., who also continues as chairman, James J. Connolly, who continues as executive vice president of the corporation, and A. T. DeSmedt who has been elected president.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -The major contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination will hold another "unity" meeting next month in search of agreement on ways to hold down the cost of campaigning against one another.

ATLANTA, June 25 -- A conference of Jewish community relations leaders affirmed today its continued opposition to any Government funding of sectariansponsored education. Representatives of Orthodox Judaism dissented.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -Gov. Milton J. Shapp announced today that he would ask the Legislature for new tax, following a 5-to-2 ruling yesterday by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court that the state's first personal income tax was unconstitutional.

TURIN, Italy, June 25 (UPI) -- The police said today they had recovered stolen art works worth $3.2-million and detained two persons, including a grandson of Benito Mussolini's Popular Culture Minister.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -Representatives of the nation's news media accused the Government today of attempted censorship in blocking publication of the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.
BERLIN June 25 -- A Soviet marshal today publicly praised Walter Ulbricht, the veteran Communist who recently lost key positions in the East German leadership.

The American Cyanamid Company said yesterday that it planned to increase prices by about 7 per cent on its line of Cymel melamine molding compounds used primarily in plastic dinnerware and in the manufacture of buttons.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Thieves of Wall Street securities are sophisticated enough to learn the art of computerized crime even if actual stocks and bonds are replaced by an electronic bookkeeping system, an insurance executive told Senators today.

The 71st Regiment Armory, the red-brick fortress overlooking Park Avenue at 34th Street, will close today after 79 years of service as a military installation, sports arena and a convention and exhibition hall.
ALBANY, June 25 -- The State Board of Regents today granted approval for students at the City University of New York to earn a Bachelor of Arts degree through a personally selected curriculum.
PARIS, June 25 -- "It's a great lesson for us," said a young French journalist.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -An invention patented this week makes welding by ultrasonics, or silent sound, even more silent. In such welding, materials are joined through heat created by waves that are beyond human hearing.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A military race relations institute, planned by the Defense Department since March, will open in October at Patrick Air Force Base in Florida, just south of Cape Kennedy.
The new-issue market scored a strong advance this week with much of the interest centered on Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the world's largest investment house, which went public.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 -- Thomas Warner Gorman is in privileged company tonight following a 6-3, 8-6, 6-4 victory over Ross Case of Australia that enabled him to gain the quarterfinals of the all-England Lawn Tennis championships with top-seeded Rod Laver and John Newcombe, the defending champion.

The getaway day card at Belmont Park today will be headed by the Saranac, an allowance test for 3-year-olds at a mile. A field of eight may compete in the 64th running of the event and if all go, the gross value will be $57,100, the winner earning $34,260.

PEKING, June 20 -- In China today one sees everywhere evidence of what people power -- enormous numbers of men and women equipped with only primitive tools but all thinking alike and acting in concert -- can accomplish.

NEWARK, June 25 -- Walter Wolfe, the Hudson County Democratic chairman who, with seven political associates, is on trial here in Federal Court on charges of conspiracy and extortion, leaped from his chair three times during sessions of the trial today to disrupt the courtroom.

EUGENE, Ore., June 25 -"From a practical point of view, I shouldn't be here," Dr. Delano Meriwether said today after his spectacular victory in the l00yard dash at the national Amateur Athletic Union outdoor, track and field championships.

In a recent column, "The New China Hands," James Reston states accurately that "if Peking and Washington do finally agree to re-establish diplomatic relations, the U.S. Government will be ready with a new generation of China specialists." He then supplies a dramatis personae which excludes the new generation.
Total newsprint consumption in the United States in May was 838,763 tons, a 2.5 per cent decline from May, 1970, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.

Directors of Lines Brothers, Ltd., a British toy manufacturer, announced yesterday that they had accepted the offer of Gallaher, Ltd., the British tobacco subsidiary of American Brands, Inc., to acquire 55 per cent of Lines by late 1976.

A 67-year-old man sitting at an open fourth-floor window in his West Side apartment early yesterday morning was shot through the head and killed by a random bullet fired from a car on the street below.

Canonero II, the "horse that nobody wanted," has been sold for a sum "in excess of a million dollars." W. J. (Buddy) Hirsch announced yesterday that Robert J. Kleberg Jr., the master of the King Ranch in Texas, had purchased the Kentucky-bred colt from his owner, Pedro Baptista, of Caracas, Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -Stephen Hess, whom President Nixon is considering for the chairmanship of the National Endowment for the Humanities, said today that he was saddened by reports of opposition to his nomination by many American scholars.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A program of self-regulation drafted by advertisers and the Council of Better Business Bureaus drew unexpected criticism today from a Presidential aide.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The wife of Robert G. (Bobby) Baker, former aide to the Senate Democratic majority, testified today that thousands of dollars worth of stolen silverware, china and art objects were stored in her home in Washington in the fall of 1969.
Four United States Senators watched a 16-year-old boy buy five glassine bags of heroin for $10 from a pusher at 137th Street and Lenox Avenue in Harlem yesterday.

LENOX, Mass. -- Long before the Attorney General turned on The Times to try to suppress publication of classified documents, historians had suffered from the Government's denial of access to confidential records without which they could not write serious history.
FORT McPHERSON, Ga., June 25 -- Capt. Ernest L. Medina was ordered today to stand trial for murders at Mylai but the possibility that he could get the death penalty was eliminated.

The English tradition in the art of landscape, at once so romantic and so softspoken, is appealing on several counts. It celebrates all that is most lyrical, humble and affecting in the observable world of nature.

Dr. Hollis S. Ingraham, the State Health Commissioner, said yesterday that state supervision of the New York City Health Department "is not going to mean any immediate or profound change in our relationship."

KONSTANZ, West Germany, June 25 -- American monetary authorities would have faced a swing in short - term interest rates above 17 per cent in the first quarter this year had they tried to hold the money supply to a 6 per cent annual growth rate, Federal Reserve Board officials disclosed today.

PHOENIX, Arizona, June 25 -- Vice President Agnew, in a spirited defense of the Nixon Administration's record in attempting to end the Vietnam war, called the newspaper publication of top-secret Pentagon papers a "common, cheap, fencing operation."
We know that in May more mutual fund shares were cashed in than sold -- the first time this has happened since the Investment Company Institute started keeping tabs in 1954.

The State Commissioner of Human Rights, Jack M. Sable, promised to investigate complaints of discrimination he received yesterday in a two-hour meeting with 20 representatives of Italian-American civic, labor, political and church groups.

It was at the foot of the street corner ladder of the late Harlem orator, Carlos Cooks, that Ronnie Brathwaite and his brother, Cecil Elombe Brath, learned as kids about nationalism. They never declaimed from the top of it, but today, some 20 years later, they stand out prominently among the growing number of young African Nationalists in Harlem.

Just in the last few minutes, almost as an epilogue to Hiroshi Inagaki's "Machibuse," which opened yesterday at the Bijou, eight furtive, heavily cloaked men appear in the mist-shrouded middle distance of a snowy landscape.

CLEVELAND, June 25, (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit cleared the way today for extradition to Pennsylvania of two more persons charged in the killing of Joseph A. Yablonski, United Mine Workers official, and his wife and daughter.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- Mortgage money continues to be available in sizable amounts through federally insured savings and loan associations, Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today.
OCEAN BEACH, Fire Island, L. I., June 25 -- The Security National Bank, which has $1-billion in assets scattered through its 67 branches on Long Island, launched its 68th branch this week.

With Ron Swoboda playing left field and a rookie, Ron Blomberg, in right field, the Yankees treated themselves to a "new look" last night, and it included a 13-hit outburst that routed the Washington Senators, 12-2.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- The Government announced today its first moves to control inflation of prices and whitecollar compensation in the construction industry. The announcement came nearly three months after the Nixon Administration began clamping down on wage increases for construction workers.

The Quebec provincial Government's rejection of a new draft Canadian Constitution is good news only for Quebec separatists. It was a decision taken by a Liberal Government committed to seeking Quebec's goals inside the Canadian federation; but the real victor was the opposition Parti Quebecois, which aims at outright separation from Canada.

Scores of merchants in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn have told the Kings County Board of Trade that they will close their stores Monday -Italian-American United Day -only because they are afraid of boycotts or broken windows if they stay open.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today heard three prominent specialists -- a historian, a scientist and a China scholar -- urge the United States to establish diplomatic relations with Peking
COPENHAGEN, June 21 -They met in the central railroad station. "Say, you know where the information center is?" asked t Carlyn Hove, a 19-year-old Seattle coed, who was carrying a knapsack.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (Reuters) -- Senator Warren Magnuson, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, pledged his support tonight to establishment of a Government financing agency to help the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and other ailing companies.

PARIS, June 25 -- The proCommunist Pathet Lao has renewed a proposal to the Vientiane government for a ceasefire in Laos followed by talks to bring about "peace and national agreement" The proposal was announced by the North Vietnamese delegation to the peace talks here and confirmed by reports from both Vientiane and Hanoi.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- President Nixon called today for a national effort to upgrade nursing homes for the elderly, which he said were too often "warehouses for the unwanted -- dumping grounds for the dying."

The Neptune Raincoat Company, a subsidiary of Beck Industries, Inc., yesterday filed a petition in the United States District Court for a reorganization under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Liabilities and assets were each listed at $1,733,230, as of April 28.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 25 (AP) -- Abuse of the right of habeas corpus by convicted criminals has clogged the Federal courts and is stripping jury decisions of any finality, Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today.
The city's Board of Ethics has cleared Councilman Robert I. Postel of a conflict-of-interest charge in the first reversal of a major opinion in its 12year history.
In South Vietnam, the U. S. had stumbled into a bog. It would be mired down there a long time. -- Nikita Khrushchev to Ambassador Thompson, July 1962.

A confidential police report says that Chief Assistant District Attorney Frederich M. Ludwig of Queens decided not to prosecute a narcotics detective on a perjury charge despite Mr. Ludwig's stated belief that there was "sufficient evidence" for conviction.
A team of 25 detectives combed the Yorkville section of Manhattan yesterday in a door-to-door search for leads in the murder of a young airline stewardess.
The liquidity position of the nation's manufacturers improved again in the first quarter of 1971, reflecting a reduced demand on them by customers for extended payment terms.

Ben Kahn and Leo Ritter brought the curtain down this week on a month's round of fur showings. And just in time, too. The temperature outside during Mr. Ritter's display was a steaming 88 degrees, and even Russian crown sable seemed too far in the cold future to be tempting.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Defense Department said today that it was asking Selective Service officials to draft 16,000 men for July and August. The draft call, to be divided about equally between the two months, is the lowest since last December, when approximately 7,000 men were drafted.
A city correction officer who was involved in an altercation with an inmate in the Kings County Hospital prison ward has been suspended without pay pending an investigation of the incident.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 25 -- A hunt was reported under way near the demilitarized zone today for the scores of enemy mortar and rocket emplacements that contributed to the Government's loss of Fire Base Fuler yesterday.
HARTFORD, June 25 -- The Republican Governor and the Democrats who control the Connecticut General Assembly moved tonight toward agreement on a state fiscal program for the coming year.

WINDHOEK, South-West Africa, June 17 -- This staid little capital of a remote territory that does not know whether it is a country, a colony or just another province of the South African Republic has, as of this week, what the Continental Hotel proclaims as "a new form of entertainment" -- go-go girls.

The news that Mack Trucks, Inc., has signed a preliminary agreement with the Soviet Government to help design and equip the world's largest truck factory suggests that history is about to repeat itself.
ROSWELL, N.M. -- One by one, the young men of Roswell who fought the war in Vietnam are coming home to reclaim their place in the burning desert sun.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 25 -- A 32-year-old urban economist who calls himself "probably the youngest and the poorest black Republican appointee in the Nixon Administration" criticized the Administration sharply tonight, saying it had not made a "moral commitment to social justice, to stemming poverty, to tap the spirit of the young."

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- The Chicago Sun-Times said today that Government documents revealed that the Central Intelligence Agency had advised President Richard M. Nixon in 1969 that if the United States withdrew from Vietnam "all of Southeast Asia would remain as it is for another generation."
CANTHO, South Vietnam, June 25 (AP) -- The most sweeping crackdown so far against illegal drug use by American servicemen in South Vietnam is under way in the Mekong Delta.

As a former commuter no longer employed in New York City, I have become annoyed at attempts to charge commuters more money for the extravagances of Mayor Lindsay, and particularly for remarks in this connection such as one found in one of your recent editorials: "Commuters derive their livelihoods from work in this city; they use its services; they ought to shoulder a larger share of its costs."

The Nixon Administration has responded to the demand for reordering domestic priorities by applying a mission -oriented model to the country's social needs. This model may be appropriate for technological challenges, but not for social problems.

WASHINGTON -- The Pentagon study disclosures engender mixed emotions, although the elements in the mix are not of equal weight. Not even a determined opponent of a damnable war can, I think, greet the episode with undiluted joy, for it adds new ingredients of unmeasurable consequence to what has become a Greek tragedy without a last act.
It is fatally easy for a player with a wealth of high cards to overestimate his defensive potential.

The 39-year-old chief rabbi of Milan, Italy, started on a five-hour walk from Kennedy International Airport to the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn early this morning because a delay had forced his airplane to land after sundown, the beginning of the Jewish sabbath.
The St. Louis Post-Dispatch yesterday published 38 columns of articles drawn from the Pentagon papers on United States involvement in Vietnam.

MONTREAL, June 25 -- The New York Mets swept a double header from the Montreal Expos tonight in Jarry Park, but only picked up half a game on the division-leading Pittsburgh Pirates. The scores were 4-1, 4-2.

The International Josquin Festival pursued its pleasant and instructive course on Thursday night with another large audience of professional and amateur musicologists in attendance. The third of four public concerts brought the Schola Cantorum Stuttgart to Alice Tully Hall in a cappella program of works by the Renaissance master Josquin des Prez, conducted by Clytus Gottwald.
CHICAGO, June 25 -- Judge Joseph A. Power refused today to open sealed indictments against law enforcement officials who were involved in a raid in which two Black Panthers were killed by the police.

I wish to dissent from the "Policy Statement by U. S. China Scholars" which appeared as an advertisement in your June 14 issue. In this many of my colleagues advocate "that the People's Republic of China be granted its legitimate seat in all United Nations bodies as the sole Government of China."

A marathon meeting of taxi owners, union leaders and city and state officials failed yesterday to resolve an industry controversy over an unratified wage agreement and the mounting number of gypsy cabs cruising for passengers on the streets of New York.
The Holy Modal Rounders, in their latest configuration, are playing a program of their usual fractured country music through tomorrow at Folk City, 130 West Third Street.

ERIE, Pa., June 25 (AP) -Joanne Gunderson Carner fired an erratic one-over-par 73 in the second round of the 19th United States Women's open today, then watched it stand up for a two-stroke lead as Donna Caponi, the defending champion, slid to a 75.
LOS ANGELES -- One came from the Social Register, another from the field of advertising, a third from the fringes of show business.
Ron Swoboda, the rebel of the Mets returned to New York last night in the uniform of the Yankees.

DACCA, June 25 -- People talk with foreigners in a whisper and keep looking behind them to see if anyone is listening. Soldiers and special police -- brought from West Pakistan, more than 1,000 miles away -stop and search cars and buses and people carrying bundles.

A Congressional subcommittee heard testimony yesterday that the city's antipoverty agencies had become mechanisms to foment ethnic conflict between blacks and Puerto Ricans and between blacks and Jews.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 25 -- The Rev. Dr. David G. Colwell of Seattle was elected today moderator, or spiritual leader, of the two-million member United Church of Christ. His election opened the fiveday biennial general synod of the denomination in the Grand Rapids Municipal Auditorium.
A group of Brooklyn business men has received a $437,000 Federal grant to start a program of rehabilitation for former convicts.
LONDON, June 25 -- British businessmen are generally giving a warm reception to the terms obtained for British entry into the European Economic Community.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 25 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells won the 68th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament today, defeating the defending champion, Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Baltusrol, on the 37th green. Mrs. Hart had a 2-up lead after 34 holes.

LONDON, June 25 -- It is not only in myth that kingdoms are lost for want of a nail. In the real world, what seem little matters of timing and procedures may affect great political events. So history may see the decision of the British Labor party's executive, just taken, to hold a special party conference next month on whether this country should join the European Common Market.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had ordered administrative proceedings against Charles W. Steadman of Washington and a group of investment-advisory and other corporations related to mutual funds that he controls.
Stock prices continued to ease yesterday as trading activity remained near the lowest level of the year.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -The Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments tomorrow on the Government's effort to enjoin The New York Times and The Washington Post from publishing material from the Pentagon papers on Vietnam.

Saul Landau's "Fidel," which opened yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, is the 96-minute version of the one-hour documentary that was originally presented here on Channel 13 in June, 1969. Having missed the television presentation, I can only report that the theatrical 'Fidel" is all of that -- theatrical -- as well as funny and moving and very persuasive.

HOUSTON, June 25 (AP) -Soviet and American space experts completed five days of discussion on development of a compatible docking system here today and announced that a study was under way on plans for the linkup in space of American and Soviet spacecraft.

The National Association of Laymen, a group devoted to reform of the Roman Catholic Church, opened a three-day annual meeting here yesterday amid its members growing conviction that the church-renewal movement was sorely in need of new directions.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that 1971 would be a year of "gradual improvement" in the economy, with the gross national product estimated at $1.05billion, well under the Government's forecast.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Secretary of Commerce, Maurice H. Stans, declared unequivocally today that the United States "has been losing, and is continuing to lose, its competitiveness in world markets."

The sixth year of the Schaefer Music Festival at the Wollman Rink in Central Park opened big on Thursday evening -- a big crowd, two capacity audiences of 5,000 each at the evening's two concerts, and two big bands, Duke Ellington's Orchestra and the Thad Jones-Mel Lewis Orchestra.

EUGENE, Ore., June 25 -- Dr. Delano Meriwether achieved his impossible dream, Rod Milburn broke the oldest world record in track and field, and Steve Prefontaine shattered 13 minutes in the three-mile.

LONDON, June 25 -- Lord Boyd Orr, the first director of the Food and Agricultural Organization and a winner of the 1949 Nobel Peace Prize, died today at his home near Brechin, Angus, Scotland. He was 90 years old.

RHINEBECK, N. Y., June 26 -- To cap a day of perfect weather, Mrs. Henry Sutliff Jr.'s consistent, all-white coarse-coated Sealyham terrier, Ch. Jenmist Dougal, was named best in show today at the 29th annual Mid-Hudson Kennel Club's all-breed event.

GORONTALO, June 18 -- The airstrip is grass and it takes the air force pilots an hour of circling to find it. The road to town is rutted and bumpy. Girls peer from windows of thatched houses, their face caked with a green beauty mixture made from mango skins and rice paste.
DETROIT, June 26 (AP) -Joe Coleman hurled a five-hitter and the Detroit Tigers scored on a wild throw by Cleveland's shortstop, Eddie Leon, to beat the Indians, 1-0, tonight.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., June 26 -- The first known North American birth of wild monk parakeets, a spectacular, nonmigratory native of the South American subtropics that may be establishing residence in the metropolitan area, has been reported here.

PENSACOLA, Fla., June 24 -A former New York City social worker is fighting to keep her teaching position at a small state university in Pensacola where she and three other liberal professors have been dismissed in the last year.

HONG KONG, June 26 -- The introduction of workers, peasants and soldiers into China's schools and the lowering of academic qualifications for enrollment at universities have created problems that have been discussed in the press and provincial broadcasts monitored here.
CAIRO, June 26 -- President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and King Faisal of Saudi Arabia ended today a week of strategy talks that appear to be a prelude to a new Arab effort for unity against Israel.
PEKING, June 21 -- While touring the Peking Experimental Chemical Works, this reporter selected a worker to interview.

JERUSALEM, June 26 -- Israel and Jewish communities overseas entered upon a new working relationship this week, giving foreign Jewish leaders and fund-raisers a closer operational role -- in theory at least - in internal Israeli affairs.

WITH the summer vacation period underway, I'd like to pass along a warning to fellow-travelers: Don't try to bring drugs across borders. My own recent amusing (in retrospect) experience will suggest a few good reasons why.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A national survey on the hopes and fears of the American people shows a "new and urgent concern over national unity, political stability and law and order."
SAIGON, June 26 (AP) -- Field informants reported today that three teams on intelligence missions led by Americans had been wiped out behind enemy lines in South Vietnam and Laos.

The Pan Africa-United States international track meet, scheduled for July 16 and 17, at Duke University, Durham, N. C., is being billed on the African Continent as a significant preliminary to the 1972 Olympic Games at Munich.

ERIE, Pa., June 26 (UPI) -- Mrs. Joanne Gunderson Carner, struggling with an erratic driver, scored birdies on the first two holes, then scrambled the rest of the way for a par 72 and a five-stroke lead after the third round of the $33,000 United States women's open golf championship today.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 26 -Eight members of the Spring Offensive Committee, a coalition of soldiers and former G.I's., filed suit in Federal court this week for $50,000 in damages and an injunction against alleged police harassment growing out of picketing by the group of Tyrrell's Jewelers, Inc., a national chain operating in military towns.
THURMONT, Md., June 26 (AP) -- President Nixon gathered some of his top economic and domestic officials today at Camp David, his mountaintop retreat, for a two-day review of budget problems.

ATLANTA, June 26 -- Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights, today characterized as "the most self-serving argument possible" the contention of the military that surveillance of civilians does not violate constitutional rights.

HONG KONG -- The Chinese Communist guards at the bridge leading from this British Crown Colony to mainland China are pretty nonchalant these days about the passage of Americans into the once forbidden country. Nine young American graduate students and four of their wives trooped across the narrow railway bridge last week, and in Peking Premier Chou En-lai said such visits would become reciprocal in due time.
EUGENE, Ore., June 26 -- John Smith woke up this morning and told Wayne Collett, his roommate, college teammate and track rival, that it was time for a world record in the 440-yard dash.

In April, Random House published an extraordinary novel with a mysterious history. "Ali and Nino" was originally published in Vienna in 1937 under the pseudonym Kurban Said. PHOENIX, Ariz., June 26 -The nation's Young Republicans ended a six-day convention today firmly committed to President Nixon and to conservative Republican politics.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird clearly indicated today that he would be happy to take another Cabinet post if President Nixon was re-elected next year, although he said he intended to leave his Pentagon job at the end of Mr. Nixon's first term.
BERKELEY, Calif., June 26 (AP) -The United States-Soviet Union track meet, upstaged in 1971 by table tennis as a diplomatic sports event, will be held for the 10th time this week.

I was surprised to learn in the article on backpacking (Travel section, May 9) of the backpacker's scorn for the hiker and camper. It is astonishing that the backpacker, worried about runs in his waterproof nylon, bodycontoured, aluminum - framed pack, holes in his polyethylene ground cloth, and shortages in his freeze-dried food supply, would have the simple time for condescension toward those so naive as to bring civilization to the wilderness.

So far, Antietam has managed to retain its natural, rural setting, being virtually exactly as it was on that fateful Sept. 17, 1862.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 26 -- One year after the departure of the last American ground forces from Cambodia, the Vietnamese Communists are still in control of three-quarters of the sparsely populated countryside, but most Cambodians and foreign diplomats here still believe that the enemy has his eye one South Vietnam, not on Pnompenh.

With a fanfare of "East Side, West Side," the Music Grove of Forest Park, in Glendale, Queens, last Sunday began its 16th consecutive summer of living up to its name. The fanfare inaugurated a series of programs by the Seuffert Band that will be held every Sunday afternoon at 3 P.M. through the Labor Day weekend.

Italy's largest automobile manufacturer is represented in New York by an expert in international trade. His chief duties, however, are not directly related to the sale of cars, but rather to the task of expediting an exchange of goods and commodities.

PITTSBURGH, June 26 -- A series of unusual incidents highlighted the fourth annual Triad River renaissance weekend regatta on the Allegheny River today. The rowing program was run off between helicopter pickups by the United States Coast Guard and water ski jumps plus a flying parachute water skier.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -Thursday marks the end of 196 years of postal business as usual -which the American public has come to believe is usually bad. The Post Office Department will officially become the United States Postal Service, an independent Government agency with a businesslike structure.

PORT ARTHUR, Tex., June 26 -- Oil wells are pumping away in the eastern half of the Sabine River here, pouring royalty money into the Louisiana state treasury, while the state of Texas broods, unable to get clear title to the western half of the river that it claims.

Successes for the "New Careers" program -- developing job advancement systems for poor people -- were reported yesterday at a Congressional hearing here, but with calls for further efforts at improvement.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 26 -- James B. Moore's Lure continued Resolute Class domination today but most of the fleet of 96 boats in the Cow Bay area, Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound competition struggled to beat the time limit.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, charged today that the Pentagon had paid the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation $46.8-million in disputed and possibly unjustified claims on its shipbuilding contracts.

DETROIT, June 26 (UPI) -- Newspapers that have published portions of a secret Pentagon study on the origins of the Vietnam war have been used by the peace movement for a propaganda point, The Detroit News said in a front-page editorial in its Sunday editions.

PERHAPS the most important attribute exhibited by Bobby Fischer in his recent 6-0 match victory over Soviet grandmaster Mark Taimanov is his incredible will to win, a quality in which he is doubtless unequalled by any player alive. Twice in the match -- in the second and fourth games -- he played out, and won, end-games that virtually everybody else had abandoned as drawn.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 26 -- The fog relented, the sun shone brilliantly and the wind blew gloriously today as the Block Island Race Week IV came to a close with a round-the-island yacht race that was the first one to finish since 1969.

DETROIT, June 26 -- "We lost our way some time in the 19th century," said Archibald Rogers, trying to explain how he and his fellow architects had designed the cities that are now called unlivable.

PRETORIA, South Africa -- Namibia is not exactly a global household word, and the world did not miss a heartbeat last Monday when the International Court of Justice in The Hague delivered an opinion on that curious noncountry, otherwise known as South-West Africa.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- Favorites finished third in both divisions of the Whitemarsh Handicap for fillies and mares today at Liberty Bell race track where 11.520 patrons wagered $1,153,053.

About 40 members of the Italia-American Civil Rights League and six black supporters disrupted traffic for more than half an hour last night in front of the Daily News Building in noisy protest over an article that they charged "was trying to start a race war."

MARINA DEL REY, Calif., June 29 -- In many ways, Marina del Rey symbolizes Southern California. For the essence of the Southland, as it is called here, is neither Hollywood nor religious fanatics nor any of the other exotic stereotypes.
MOSCOW, June 29 -- Pyotr Y. Shelest, a Soviet Politburo member, has called for a public campaign to rid the Soviet Union of what he regards as the latest Western scourge -- hippies.
Seven Shop-Rite supermarkets here have been fined for selling corned beef that was excessively corny, the Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

PARIS -- The contretemps developing between NATO and the island republic of Malta could, unless settled by friendly agreement, prove immensely embarrassing for the defense of Western Europe. For Malta is the plug of the Mediterranean; it is in a position to block either east-west or north-south movement across those waters.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Donald T. Regan, chairman of the board of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., said today that brokerage firms should be required, by law and necessary regulations, to do more than they are doing now to prevent thefts of securities.

TOKYO, June 29 -- The Bank of Japan decided today, as a way to slow Japan's rising exports, tp raise all interest rates on export preferential financing loans by one-fourth percentage point to a uniform 5 1/2 per cent a year. The new rate will go into effect Aug. 10.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 29 -- An effort to free the kidnapped British Ambassador to Uruguay, Geoffrey Jackson, through the good offices of Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, the Socialist President of Chile, has failed.
The stock market put together a surprisingly strong rally yesterday as volume showed a brisk rebound from Monday's sleepwalking session.
ALBANY, June 29 -- Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill that reappropriates $51.1-million in state aid for local narcotic addiction programs.
BONN, June 29 -- The third round of negotiations between the United States and West Germany on offsetting the dollar drain caused by maintenance of American troops here ended tonight without success.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Senate Labor Subcommittee said today that it would turn over to the Justice Department for possible criminal prosecution its investigative records on the United Mine Workers of America election in 1969.

An air conditioning system that at night stores "coolness" for use the next day, thus reducing power demands during hot spells, is being developed at the newly formed National Center for Energy Management and Power.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- A Federal judge ordered the International Brotherhood of Teamsters today to give its two million members a wider voice in running union affairs.

Thirty-six newspaper deliverers employed at the Brooklyn plant of The Daily News and 50 newsstand vendors have been indicted by a Brooklyn grand jury on charges involving newspaperstealing, The News said today.

The merger if it had come to fruition would have been the largest merger in the history of the oil industry, with combined assets of the companies totaling $5-billion.
