MOSCOW, July 5 (UPI) -- A Soviet eye surgeon restored the sight of a man whose eyes had been burned by chemicals by fabricating part of a new right eye for him from the rear half of his left eye, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today.
The television camera pointed straight at the business executive while the interviewer threw one tough question after another at him.

OTTAWA, July 5 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's foreign exchange reserves totaled $4.85-billion at the end of June, down $26.8-million from the record $4.88-billion at the beginning of the month, the Finance Department reported today.
STOCKHOLM, July 5 (Reuters) -- A young Russian asked for political asylum here today after narrowly escaping an apparent kidnapping attempt by Soviet Embassy officials, police sources said tonight.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 28 -- Martial law has made the traffic run on time in Istanbul and Ankara, Turkey's two biggest and formerly most chaotic cities. The military-backed Government, which invoked emergency powers in 11 of the 67 provinces two months ago, is finding, however, that it is easier to discipline drivers and vehicles than to institute the more basic reforms that are the Government's reason for being.

Brooklyn detectives investigating the murder of a man whose body was found Sunday in the trunk of his car in the Bath Beach district were checking yesterday on whether the slaying had any connection with a suspicious race that touched off a riot at Yonkers Raceway on June 7.

At 4:35 P.M. on Monday, June 7, a car driven by Leslie Kempler, a 21-year-old white man, struck the rear of a bus at a busy intersection in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn and then careened into another automobile.

BONN, July 5 -- President Pompidou of France and Chancellor Willy Brandt opened a new round of regular consultations today with almost six hours of talks and sightseeing aboard an excursion boat cruising down the Rhine from Mainz to Koblenz.

Tenants in the luxury apartment building at 239 Central Park West, who had withheld about $40,000 in rent in a battle with the management over maintenance, turned the money over to the management last week.

PARIS -- Had an old widow in Brooklyn suddenly inherited the fortune of J. P. Morgan, the event would not have been more startling than the fate, which, on Feb. 5, 1966, befell the obscure, seldom-visited Parisian institution on the edge of the Bois de Boulogne: the Musee Marmottan.
The Major League Baseball Players Association has filed an unfair labor practice charge against the 24 major league clubs, citing their refusal to divulge terms of a new television contract.

ATLANTA, July 5 (AP) -- Capt. Ernest L. Medina, facing trial on charges of murder and assault in the 1968 raid on Mylai, has left for Vietnam with an Army prosecutor and his military defense attorney.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that the Westinghouse International Company had been integrated into the corporate structure of Westinghouse and that four regional vice presidents had been named to serve as corporate representatives in areas outside the United States.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 5 -- A pipeline carrying anhydrous ammonia ruptured after dark on June 5 near the remote community of Floral in northeast Arkansas, sending about 80 tons of gas billowing over the countryside.

Anyone for "Swan Lake"? When the American Ballet Theater first mounted the David Blair productions of "Swan Lake" and, later, "Giselle," they both were brilliant in concept but there were moments of awkwardness about the way the company had taken to them.

WASHINGTON, July ,5 -- Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco may visit Israel later this month in an effort to narrow the gap between Israeli and Egyptian positions on the terms of an agreement to reopen the Suez Canal.
TORONTO, July 5 -- The Canadian Government has initiated its first broad-gauge action to curb take-overs of Canadian businesses by Americans.
MISSOULA, Mont. (AP) -- Women have invaded another traditionally all-male stronghold -- the domain of the professional forest-fire fighter.

BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, July 5 (AP) -- Julian Beck, the theatrical director, and his wife, Judith Malina, have been detained by the Brazilian political police "until further notice," police sources reported today.

PARIS, July 5 -- Communications Minister Robert Galley charged today that the United States had vetoed a new trans-Atlantic telephone cable against the advice of its own experts in order "to favor excessively a system it dominates" -Intelsat.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- "It is not enough to say that Mr. Johnson in 1964 was behaving in more or less the customary way. The question that matters is why men who lead democracies -- even, and indeed especially, men who count themselves as standing on the left of center -- behave like this. . . . The problem which has burst out of its cage is the relationship between democracy and war."

An agreement was reached in London last week under which Ogilvy Mather International would acquire all of the advertising activities of S. H. Benson (Holdings) Ltd., with billings of $68-million, and extend its sphere of influence from 17 to 24 countries.

Chief Justice Warren E. Burger says that the Supreme Court "was actually unanimous" in principle in its 6-to-3 decision last Wednesday against the Justice Department's effort to bar publication of material from the top-secret Pentagon papers in The New York Times and The Washington Post.

For their annual dinner in Chicago recently, the pro football players had Bill Cosby, who used to run track, as their speaker. Cosby told them: "My best time for the 440 was 63 seconds. You see, I went to an all-white high school." Everybody broke up. Cosby set the tone for a warm, friendly evening.

PEKING, July 5 -- Representatives of Australia's opposition Labor party emerged from trade talks yesterday with China's assurance that it will give equal consideration to Australia and Canada as potential suppliers of wheat once Canberra establishes diplomatic relations with Peking.

Unless Dr. Henry Kissinger can bring back from Saigon better news about Vietnamization than the published reports suggest, the latest Vietcong proposals appear to have put President Nixon in an excruciating dilemma.
PARIS, July 5 -- American pressure on Europe and Japan to accept voluntary restraints on exports to the United States or face stiff restrictive measures is being viewed in Europe with mounting alarm.
Two executives of Parents' Magazine Enterprises have written a book on the selling of magazine advertising, which they and others in the field believe is a first.

YONKERS, N. Y., July 5 -- If Women's Lib becomes aware of the conditions written by Ed Parker for the Ed Sullivan Pacing Series, which got under way tonight at Yonkers Raceway with Gamely ($19.20), El Patron ($22.60) and Flying Bret ($21.80) winning one-mile divisions, the racing secretary may find himself in hot water.
An off-duty policeman shot and seriously wounded a man who allegedly slashed him With a knife while attempting to rob him in the East Village last night.
A magazine that may soon become a collectors' item has been circulated in recent days in the city's police stations and among friends of policemen.

SAIGON, South Vietnam July 5 -- Gen. Duong Van Minh, a potential challenger for South Vietnam's presidency this fall, has charged in an interview that President Nguyen Van Thieu is using intimidation and pressure to insure his re-election and has urged that the United States apply all its influence for a fair and honest contest.

As one of the original legislative sponsors of the no-fault auto insurance bill in Massachusetts, I have read with considerable dismay advertisements placed in The Times by groups of persons opposed to the adoption of a no-fault system in New York and certain letters to you in opposition to the plan.
ATHENS, July 6 -- Greek efforts to speed a compromise solution of the long-smoldering Cyprus problem have drawn a near blank, diplomatic sources here and in Ankara, Turkey, fear.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A Federal district court has ruled that a desegregating school system cannot impose test-score requirements on its teachers that reduce markedly the ratio of Negroes on its faculty.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The United States is giving such serious study to the Vietcong peace plan submitted in Paris last Thursday that a formal response is likely to be delayed, senior Administration officials said today.
Joseph A. Colombo Sr. was operated on for two hours at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday to ease a blockage of fluid that had built up in his skull. The hospital called the operation "routine."
THE HAGUE, July 6 (Reuters) -- A new five-party Cabinet, headed by Premier Barend W. Biesheuvel, was sworn in today by Queen Juliana at her Huis Ten Bosch Palace.

Thomas J. Whelan, the two-term mayor of Jersey City, and Thomas M. Flaherty, the City Council President, forfeited their offices on their conviction Monday of extortion conspiracy, a New Jersey state official said yesterday.

Bon Vivant the Newark soup maker, doesn't advertise much, but when it does it's usually in an upscale medium. Yesterday its ad agency, the Lee Mandell Company, was in the process of killing an ad scheduled for the September Town Country.

PARIS, July 6 -- Following are excerpts from the transscript of an interview today with Le Duc Tho, a member of the Politburo of the ruling Communist party of North Vietnam, conducted by Anthony Lewis of The New York Times. Mr. Tho spoke in Vietnamese, which was translated into English by an aide, Phuong Nguyen Dinh. Two other aides, Tran Thien Can and Nguyen Thanh Le, were with him.
Bache Co., Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, has elected Elliot J. Smith as senior vice president. Mr. Smith is national sales manager and heads the firm's marketing and sales division.

The bond markets, hit with a prime rate increase they had been expecting and waiting for New York City's record-smashing $357.5-million financing today, decided that the best thing to do yesterday was to hold their ground and let trading activity dry up.

It may be trite to say that dynamite comes in small packages, but the saying fits Davey Vasquez perfectly. Vasquez, at 5 feet 1 inch, is the smallest professional boxer in New York, but he is one of the best.

Louis Armstrong was more than a great jazz virtuoso. He was the root source that moved jazz onto the path along which it has developed for more than 45 years. Through the sheer power of his musical imagination and personality, he reshaped the relatively limited urban folk music in which he grew up, opening up the possibilities that have made it part of a global culture.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 6 -- A major change in the format of the Korean armistice commission meetings at Panmunjom, where American and North Korean generals have engaged in sterile argumentation for 18 years, is in prospect if a recent suggestion of the senior United States negotiator is heeded.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that he had information that cost overruns on the Navy's F-14 jet fighter plane could approach $4-billion.

City Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin charged yesterday that two men had pocketed a $300,000 windfall from an inflated mortgage from the city's Municipal Loan Program and suspended further payments for slum rehabilitation to the pair.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Twenty-one House Democrats charged today that the Commerce Committee's attempt to cite the Columbia Broadcasting System and its president, Frank Stanton, for contempt of Congress was a threat to the First Amendment.
NEW HAVEN -- The class of 1951 has just held its twentieth reunion at Yale but Jack Downey wasn't there. Jack and an assistant, Richard Fecteau, have been in prison in China since Nov. 29, 1952.

Will the windup of the Vietnam war mean a continuing unemployment problem for the United States? Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. has already asserted that much of the nation's present unemployment is a result of winding down the Vietnam war.
PARIS, July 6 (UPI) -- Mrs. Binh indicated today that the latest Vietcong peace proposals were not an inflexible take-it-or-leave-it package.
SOUTHPORT, England, July 6 -- To hear them talking this is not the golf course it's cracked up to be.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- The head of the Subversive Activities Control Board conceded today that there was not enough work to keep the board and its staff busy.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 6 -- The urban guerrillas of Uruguay have apparently decided to avoid upsetting the nationwide elections scheduled for November.

STOCKHOLM, July 6 (UPI) -- Kipchoge Keino of Kenya won a mile race tonight in 3 minutes 54.4 seconds, the fastest time in the world this year. The American world record-holder, Jim Ryun, finished a distant last in the field of 10 runners.
The National Railroad Passenger Corporation, known as Amtrak, released new nationwide schedules of intercity passenger trains yesterday including improved long-haul service.
Both your June 2 editorial "One Down and . . ." and the recent billboard-removal legislation may in fact miss the point.

LONDON, July 6 -- The opening production of "The Devil's Disciple" at London's new Shaw Theater is a rather melancholy event for the British youth theater movement. It marks the end of a dream for Michael Croft, the founder of the National Youth Theater, who seven years ago almost succeeded in establishing a drama center where work by professionals and youths could have flourished under the same roof.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 6 (UPI) -- Songcan, owned by the Donhy Stable of Forest Hills, Queens, and Saucy Wave, owned by Bert V. James of Pittsburgh, won the Grand Circuit Stakes features today at Historic Track.
BERLIN, July 6 -- Moviemakers from Italy won the lion's share of prizes at Berlin's 21st nternational film festival, which ended tonight, free of political turmoil, after 12 days.

ATHENS, July 6 -- The Greek authorities have declared that no formal charges have been lodged against Christos Sartzetakis, the former investigating magistrate whose activities were depicted in the film "Z".

DETROIT, July 6 -- Stan Bahnsen, the pride of the Yankees' pitching staff for more than five weeks, failed to last two innings tonight as the New York club was beaten by the Tigers in a 2-hour-58-minute marathon, 12-7.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The policy-making body of the National Science Foundation has told the White House that the United States needs a comprehensive national research program to help man understand and cope with his increasing effects on world environment.

An East Harlem planning group modeled after the local community planning board concept was instituted yesterday by Representative Herman Badillo, Democrat of New York, to co-ordinate neighborhood needs with Federal programs.

Two vice presidents of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation took early retirement yesterday. They are Frank L. Frain, 58, who had been senior vice president-finance and a director, and Rodgers Donaldson, 62, who had been vice president and general counsel.
Evidence continued to mount yesterday that markets for steel were much weaker than the industry anticipated only a few months ago.

Whitney North Seymour Sr., a former president of the American Bar Association and of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, was awarded the A.B.A. medal, the association's highest award, last night.

The State Harness Racing Commission yesterday suspended the part-ownership in five horses held by Mrs. John A. Lombardo of Brooklyn, whose husband was found shot to death Sunday in the Bath Beach district.
WARSAW, July 6 -- Polish authorities sought today to discourage would-be defectors by publicizing an unsuccessful attempt by 15 Polish vacationers to escape to the West from Yugoslavia.

By unanimous voice vote of its 297-member policy-making unit, the American Bar Association adopted yesterday a set of courtroom guidelines that urged judges to set the tone for orderly proceedings by behaving well themselves.
Dock Ellis of the Pirates, whose real name is Dock Ellis Jr., owes it all to chewing gum.
Most players, even the greatest, double the opponents into game now and then. Those who never do so are overcautious, and frequently allow their opponents to go down two or more tricks undoubled.

Supergraphics are now available in kits that enable amateurs to install them quickly and easily as wall decorations. The patterns offered by Dimensionals include a giant blue hand, a purple orange and gold arrow, a motif of four circles and a large rectangular bar with a sphere.

William K. Stevens' excellent news article (June 1) documents the outstanding job Samuel Kostman has done in a few short months as principal of George Washington High School. In a subsequent editorial (June 4), The Times praised the "new esprit de corps" in the school which it attributed to Mr. Kostman's "combination of firmness, personal involvement and flexibility" and his "imaginative leadership."

AUSTIN, Tex., July 6 (AP) -- Walt W. Rostow, former aide to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, has accused The New York Times of misleading the public with its account of the Pentagon papers, The Daily Texan said today.

ALBANY, July 6 -- Basing its work on earlier research that confirmed the presence of a blood antigen in patients with cancer of the digestive tract, a research team in the State Health Department reported today finding a similar antigen in patients suffering from cancer of the breast, lungs, bladder, prostate, kidneys and nervous system.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 6 -- A leading Negro economist predicted here today that it would be "quite some time" before there would be any improvement in the employment situation for black Americans.
NEW ORLEANS, July 6-- District Attorney Jim Garrison filed seven criminal charges today against two Federal officials who were involved in the bringing of bribery charges against him last Wednesday.

Minsky, full brother of the outstanding European campaigner, Nijinsky, made an unsuccessful American debut at Aqueduct yesterday when he finished fourth in a field of six in the $20,000 Sea O Erin purse, a 1 1-16-mile race on turf for 3-year-olds.

Thousands of New Jersey commuters homebound from the financial district of Manhattan confronted new turnstiles built for exact change as PATH's handsome, marble faced rail terminal under the World Trade Center opened yesterday.

Slowly, reluctantly and fearfully, the United States is moving toward a nuclear-powered future. It is not that people have learned to love the atom; it is because few can think of any other acceptable answer to the nation's energy crisis.

PARIS, July 6 -- Jean - Marcel Jeanneney, economic adviser to the late Charles de Gaulle, urged today that France accept a German proposal for a generalized Common Market currency float against the dollar.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Democrats proposed today a seven-point program they said would get the economy moving again and combat inflation.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Is there room in the 1972 Democratic Presidential ring for one more halt? Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma seems to think so.
Winners of the fourth annual Shubert Foundation Playwriting Contest were announced yesterday by Lawrence Shubert Lawrence, chairman of the board of directors of the Sam S. Shubert Foundation.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 (Reuters) -- Typhoon rans and wind struck Indochina today, cutting back American air strikes. Military spokesmen reported a comparative lull in ground fighting.

If Congress does what is clearly expected of it, the Gateway National Recreation Area will soon become a reality. With Administration backing, enthusiastic support in the Congressional delegations of both New York and New Jersey and the approval of all who want to bring parks to the people, the likelihood is that a Gateway law will be passed in this session of Congress.

VIENNA, July 6 -- A caucus of Chancellor Bruno Kreisky's Social Democrats decided tonight to call for the dissolution of Parliament tomorrow and new elections "to break the present equilibrium," which Dr. Kreisky says, is "paralyzing political activity."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 6 -- Syria announced today that the Western-owned Iraq Petroleum Company had agreed to increase by more than 50 per cent its payments for the right to pipe oil across Syrian soil to the Mediterranean Sea.

Laboratory tests have revealed botulin, the toxin that causes botulism, in four additional cans of Bon Vivant brand vichyssoise from the same batch as the can that has been linked to the death of a Westchester banker last Wednesday and the partial paralyzing of his wife.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, a Congressional leader known for his interest in the dollars and cents of Government, spoke to the American Bar Association last night about crime -- in terms of dollars and cents.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- The Government announced today that it would begin selling crime insurance Aug. 1 in 11 states and the District of Columbia where private insurance is not available at reasonable rates.

A little old man poked his baldish head, covered with a black yarmulke, into Room 402 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Far Rockaway, Queens, and said, "Please, is Mr. Holzman here? I would like to get some autographs for my grandchildren. They are Knick fans."

The Independence Day weekend was the busiest of the season, with championship races being run on Saturday, Sunday and Monday. For Mark Donohue personally, it was one of his most successful ever -- two consecutive victories, the first in the Schaefer 500 at the Pocono International Raceway in Pennsylvania, and the second in the 210-mile GBX Trans-Am at the Donnybrooke track in Minnesota.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it had reduced prices on most of its Mylar polyester film by as much as 10 per cent to 20 per cent.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 61 -- President Nixon said today the United States would face severe economic competition from the Soviet Union, China, Western Europe and Japan in the next few years and needed to institute internal reforms to meet the challenge.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted in early April to seek a "temporary" and "minor" tightening of money-market conditions with the aim of slowing the growth of the money supply and other monetary aggregates, it was disclosed today.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday the first step to acquire approximately 9,000 acres of land for part of a fourth jetport for the metropolitan area at Stewart Airport.
A policeman commandeered a l0-speed racing bicycle last night to capture a sneak thief in Central Park. He got his man after an eight-block chase.

If, as many believe, American jazz -- that indefinable offspring of the historical and cultural and racial vortex of New Orleans -- is this country's singular contribution to the art of the world, it was surely Louis Armstrong more than any other who made it so. No one else played so creative or enduring a role in the evolution and development of jazz or in insuring its survival.

Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday a series of refunding operations under which it will have a call on an additional $50-million in bank credit, with an interest rate one-half of one percentage point above the prime rate.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers announced a reorganization of the State Department's structure and practices today that he said would provide for better management, a more reliable periodic review of policy objectives and a fairer personnel policy.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Senator George McGovern of South Dakota today accused Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic national treasurer, of violating neutrality while demonstrating support for the unannounced Presidential campaign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.
Louis Armstrong, the celebrated jazz trumpeter and singer, died in his sleep yesterday morning at his home in the Corona section of Queens. He had observed his 71st birthday Sunday.

Many of the folks in Detroit's marketing-advertising-media community didn't discover until yesterday that Ford announced late Friday it was moving three car lines out of J. Walter Thompson, the agency for the entire Ford Division for over 20 years.

A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that, in effect, millions of residential tenants in New York State were entitled to interest on security deposits they entrusted to landlords before last Sept. 1.

KUWAIT, July 6 -- Vice President Agnew brought his touring caravan to the Middle East today with a warning that there was not yet cause for "undue optimism" for peace in the Middle East despite renewed United States efforts to achieve a settlement.

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday the adding of $15-million to the 1970-71 capital budget for new mass transit projects to qualify the Transit Authority for $24-million in surplus Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority funds.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 6 -- Anthony Serigano, director of sanitation for the Town of Babylon, was found guilty today of third-degree grand larceny in conjunction with the theft of funds from the town's Republican Club treasury in 1968.
OTTAWA, July 6 -- Canada's Trade Minister, Jean-Luc Pepin, returned from China today filled with enthusiasm over the prospects for trade now that the two countries have opened diplomatic relations.
A rough, pounding surf and the death of a 22-year-old man by drowning caused the Long Island State Park Commission yesterday to close Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Park to swimmers.

Interesting dance beginnings did not often develop to interesting conclusions at the Cubiculo Monday evening. Carolyn Bilderback, Shawn Avrea and Charlotte Honda presented a program of choreographic ideas and images that for the most part went subtly and sometimes blatantly awry.
Prices of metals futures continued to rise yesterday as a result of the copper strike.

YONKERS, July 6 -- When the subject of septuagenarian trainer-drivers in harness racing bobs up, the names of Earle Avery, 77 years old; Sanders Russell, 71, and Sacher Werner, 72, dominate the conversation.

The Harris Trust Savings Bank, a principal Chicago institution, reported yesterday a 25.1 per cent decline in second-quarter earnings reflecting a substantial decrease in loans and sharply lower rates.

Four different ensembles were presented by the Society of Black Composers in a concert at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on Monday night, but the program turned out to be surprisingly homogeneous.
The nation's major banks -- many of them carefully playing the role of reluctant dragon -- began yesterday to raise their prime lending rates to 6 per cent from 5 1/2 per cent.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 6 (UPI) -- A Federal judge dismissed indictments today against two Ohio banks charged with making illegal loans to political candidates during the state's 1970 primary election campaign.

With the recent attack by the Palestinians on a tanker in the Red Sea bound for Elath, Israel, the foolishness of our Government's support of Israel regardless of the consequences to our own best interests or the Israelis' has entered a new phase.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 6 -- Three former Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association women's champions led after three races today in the Syce Cup sailing championships on the Sound.

DENVER, July 6 -- Bobby Fischer, moving forward in his quest for the World's Chess Championship, defeated Bent Larsen of Denmark in 41 moves in the first game of their match tonight in Temple Buell College here.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Women faculty members at major colleges and universities throughout the nation are bringing charges of sex discrimination.
Now that Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., has gone public, you can march right out to your friendly neighborhood stockbroker and buy a piece of the world's biggest brokerage house.

SOWETO, South Africa, July 2 -- Every weekend an average of 15 people meet violent death in this "Bantu urban area," South Africa's largest ghetto and one of the biggest all-black settlements in Africa.
Aggressive price promotions and consistent, seasonal weather favored retail business in New York last month, yielding a moderate increase in sales over June, 1970.

KEY WEST, Fla., July 7 (UPI) -- The Coast Guard released four Cuban fishing boat captains and their vessels to Cuban authorities in international waters last night as part of an exchange being negotiated for four Americans held in Cuba.
A Federal grant of $1,084,782 has been awarded to the Mayor's Criminal Justice Coordinating Council to establish night and weekend courts in the Bronx and Queens.

Brooks Robinson, the third baseman for the world champion Baltimore Orioles, was the top vote-getter for the American League All-Star team, according to the figures issued yesterday by the baseball commissioner's office.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 6 (AP) -- The Apollo 15 astronauts were limited to contact with 102 persons today as they began a three-week preflight medical isolation. The isolation is intended to limit exposure to disease or illness that could delay their launching to the moon July 26.

FORT MEADE, Md., July 6 (AP) -- A military judge refused today to dismiss one of four charges against Col. Oran K. Henderson of the Army arising out of the alleged covering up of the killing of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai in 1968.

ALBANY, July 6 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today the signing of a bill authorizing New York City to buy and modernize Yankee Stadium as a means of keeping the New York Yankees and the Football Giants in the city.

Ominous signs, including two power failures and the disabling of Jerry Koosman, descended upon Shea Stadium like a rainstorm last night as the Mets completed the first half of their season by losing to the Montreal Expos, 5-1.
MOSCOW -- Leonid Gaidai, the master of Soviet comedy films, is at it again, poking fun at file foibles of the system.

A ground swell of financial support for the Newport Jazz Festival began to develop yesterday following the cancellation of the festival on Saturday. Damage caused when hundreds of young people broke into Festival Field during the Saturday night concert was estimated by George Wein, producer of the festival, from $20,000 to $30,000.
The stock market scored a slight advance yesterday, despite the growing number of banks that raised their prime rate to 6 per cent from the former 5 1/2 per cent level.

BUFFALO, July 6 -- For the first time in the history of the Buffalo Police Department, a group of policemen stood in a line-up tonight at headquarters in a case of alleged police brutality, but the complainants were unable to single out anyone.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., July 6 (UPI) -- Nimble, a 42-foot sloop from Portland, Ore., was the first casualty of the 1971 trans-Pacific yacht race today when she reported a crushed mast. The report was made in the daily roll call of the 69 sailing craft embarked on the 2,225-mile race from here to Honolulu.

Now that the President has apparently dropped the phrase "forced integration of the suburbs" from his lexicon, it is dismaying to see this same distortion of a complex issue reflected in The Times editorial [June 15] on his recent housing message.
Roadway Express, Inc., reported yesterday substantially larger revenues and earnings in the 12 and 24 weeks ended June 19.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Outstanding consumer installment credit rose significantly in May, although by less than April's record increase, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Environmentalist objections to energy development were held to have become excessive yesterday by an Assistant Secretary of The Interior and spokesmen for the coal and oil industries during the American Bar Association meeting here.

DUBLIN, July 6 (Reuters) -- Fred Stolle lost the first set, but the Australian recovered to beat the Wimbledon junior champion, Bob Kreiss of Bel Air, Calif., 4-6, 6-2, 6-3, and reached the quarter finals of the Irish open tennis tournament today.
The vanguard of state auditors who will make he first comprehensive outside investigation of New York City's government arrived yesterday at the Municipal Building.
STONY BROOK, L. I., July 6 -- The first Montessori method school in the United States to include students at the high-school level opened its doors yesterday on a 14 1/2-acre farm here.

Its discreet legend, lettered in gold, reads "To help maintain the standards and support the educational activities of the Frick Collection, contributions in any amount are welcome."

William McChesney Martin, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is still a few weeks away from completing his eagerly awaited study of the New York Stock Exchange, but he has already made it clear that he hopes to create a broad national securities market with a reorganized New York exchange as its center.
Two women charged with prostitution were held without bail yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court by an irate judge who complained that "the midtown area is inundated with prostitution."

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 6 -- Attorneys for a 20-year-old American sailor who arrived in Charleston as a stowaway after escaping from the Spanish authorities are battling what they say are Navy plans to return him to Spain without benefit of extradition.
TRENTON, July 6 -- A New Jersey Appeals Court ruled today that a nun did not have the same right as a priest to withhold information concerning crimes.

CAIRO, July 6 -- Two United States diplomats met today with the acting Foreign Minister of Egypt, Hafez Ismail, starting a new round of talks aimed at breaking a deadlock on terms for a reopening of the Suez Canal.

HAVERHILL, Mass., July 6 -- "Next thing she'll be doing deodorant commercials," they shouted at her sarcastically.
A 20-year-old youth was identified by six women last night as the person who had robbed and, in some cases, raped them in the last three months.

Coal-fired power plants, "because of radioactive material contained in most coal," give off gases with low levels of radioactivity and "often emit more radioactive material than nuclear plants," Charles F. Luce, chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company, said yesterday.
Health Services Administrator Gordon Chase reported yesterday that rats were eradicated in 500 of the city's most infested blocks during the first six months of this year.

Soviet authorities have still not made public the conclusions of the special commission which investigated last week's tragic death of the Soyuz 11 cosmonauts. But they have already announced that they regard the experiment in which the deceased cosmonauts participated as having been a major success, and that they intend to move rapidly toward establishing a permanent manned orbiting space station.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Senator Mike Gravel defended to the Senate today his public reading of parts of the Pentagon papers on the United States involvement in Vietnam.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 (AP) -- Gen. Duong Van Minh, leader of the group that overthrew President Ngo Dinh Diem in 1963, was quoted today as denying that the United States had supported and encouraged the coup.

SAN DIEGO, July 6 -- Eight young sailors and marines who became heroin addicts in Vietnam will arrive here tomorrow to begin three months of intensive treatment at the Navy's new West Coast drug rehabilitation center.
In relatively light trading, stock prices on the American Stock Exchange rose slightly yesterday.

BONN, July 6 -- France and West Germany ended two days of summit talks here today without reaching an agreement on monetary problems resulting from Bonn's decision last May to float the Deutsche mark.

Higher education's financial crisis, most often associated with the private institutions, is having an increasingly profound effect on publicly supported colleges and universities, according to a survey released yesterday by the National Association of State Universities and Land-Grant Colleges.

MIAMI BEACH, July 6 -- Teamsters' convention delegates, who have heard few kind words from top Administration officials in the last decade, were praised today by President Nixon and Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Appealing to patriotism and enlightened self-interest, President Nixon admonished leaders of the steel union and the steel industry today to reach a "constructive'' contract settlement.

Kaufman Broad, Inc., engaged in on-site housing, and the Sun Life Insurance Company of America have reached an agreement in principle to merge. The proposed transaction, announced yesterday by the Los Angeles-based realty-development company, is valued at about $67.6-million.
A patrolman who infiltrated the Jewish Defense League is to testify for the Government at the conspiracy trial of Rabbi Meir Kahane and about a dozen J.D.L. members.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Commerce Department published today, after lengthy study, a new set of measures of the United States balance of international payments. The new measures are designed to be more meaningful than the old, which had become increasingly difficult to interpret.
ROME, July 6 -- Italy's Ministry of Foreign Trade declared today that, contrary to local reports, Italy has not decided to limit the exporting of textiles to the United States but only footwear.
The National Broadcasting Company over the weekend dropped television commercials by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey promoting its oil drilling operations in Alaska.

PARIS, July 6 -- A high-ranking North Vietnamese leader said today that the new Communist offer to return war prisoners if American forces are withdrawn by the end of 1971 was not dependent on a political settlement in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON -- More than a century ago Alexis de Tocqueville told us: "Scarcely any political question arises in the United States that is not resolved, sooner or later, into a judicial question."
DETROIT, July 6 -- Nothing in the dealer's showroom, from Detroit or Europe, appears able to slow the assault of the Japanese automobiles on the American market.
The Board of Education has set a new limit on the maximum number of instructional periods that may be offered by city high schools starting in the fall.
In what is believed to be a New York first for a very high frequency television station, WOR-TV will present, beginning July 19, a daily dramatic series in Spanish.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that tile city would soon open two "nonsecure" residential facilities in neighborhood settings for youngsters charged with minor crimes or who are in need of supervision.

Telford Taylor, former United States prosecutor at the Nuremberg trials, called on President Nixon and Congress yesterday to appoint a national commission to investigate the origins and conduct of the war in Vietnam.

Indian security police helped Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, dodge anti-American demonstrators yesterday at New Delhi airport. Mr. Kissinger arrived for a two-day visit that is expected to include talks with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 -- The First Surety Corporation, a Burbank, Calif., savings and loan holding company, has petitioned the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to force divestiture by a bank of a controlling interest in the holding company.

CAIRO, July 7 -- President Sadat warned in a speech today that 1971 would be decisive in the Arab conflict with Israel, as two United States diplomats pursued a secrecy-shrouded mission here to seek a formula for reopening the Suez Canal.

An article in The New York Times on Tuesday dealing with the demise of the Police Department's house organ, Spring 3100, erroneously listed the telephone number of Police Headquarters as Spring 7-3100.

Delegates to the American Bar Association closed their three-day convention here yesterday by voting not to urge the Government to withdraw from Vietnam "as soon as physically and logistically possible."

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced tile arrests yesterday of two New Jersey men charged with robbing Sophia Loren of jewelry at gunpoint, in the actress's suite in the Hampshire House on Central Park South last October.
A jazz program dedicated to the memory of Louis Armstrong, who died on Tuesday, will open a series of six "connoisseur jazz concerts" to be held at Town Hall starting Saturday evening.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 7 (AP) -- The Newport City Council tonight canceled the license for a folk music festival scheduled for July 16-18. The vote was 5-2.

Walsh.

Kaufman Broad, Inc., reported yesterday sharply higher earnings for the fiscal half year ended May 31 with sales up 50 per cent. In addition directors voted yesterday to split the stock on a two-for-one basis and declared a regular quarterly cash dividend.

CAIRO, Friday, July 9 -- Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, the Cairo editor and adviser to President Anwar el-Sadat, said today that the time had come for the Arabs to draft a new strategy against Israel combining warfare against the Israelis and political and economic pressure against the United States.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 8 -- An unexpected increase of 50 per cent in the Aid to Families With Dependent Children welfare case load in Suffolk County for the last year has caused an $18.9-million deficit in the county's welfare budget.

Miss Georgeanne Madouros, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Panagiotis D. Madouros of Forest Hills, Queens, was married in Athens yesterday to Theodoros Christos Contoyannapoulos, son of Mrs. Christos T. Contoyannopoulos of Athens and the late Mr. Contoyannopoulos. The ceremony was performed in the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of Athens.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to rise yesterday in slackened trading.
A 51-year-old customer who walked into a holdup in an automobile renting office at First Avenue and 38th Street was shot dead yesterday by one of two gunmen.

" Emilio Pucci is my master," admitted Yannis Tseklenis, a personable 33-yearold Greek fashion designer who visited New York last week. Like the Italian who convinced women to wear printed dresses the year round, Tseklenis aspires to a niche in the wardrobes of women who are international about fashion.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A private dossier on alleged Communists and subversives -- kept for 23 years by a retired Army colonel and his wife -- has been turned over to Senator James O. Eastland by the Pentagon.

LONDON, July 8 -- On the afternoon of May 31, Capt. Thomas S. Culver stood on the fringe of a crowd of 300 other American servicemen at Hyde Park Speaker's Corner. "I feel I've got to speak out against the war," said Captain Culver, a member of the Staff Judge Advocate's Office at Lakenheath Air Force Base, 82 miles from London.
The Civil Aeronautics Board, retaliating against Australian rebuffs to United States airlines, voted yesterday to bar Australia from starting jumbo-jet service to this country in September.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Defense Department acknowledged today that its plans to build the B-1 long-range bomber as a successor to the B-52 had been criticized by the General Accounting Office, but it defended the Air Force program.
DETROIT, July 8 -- Bill Gilbreth, a 23-year-old Texan from Abilene, faced the New York Yankees for the first time tonight and the southpaw had little difficulty.
DENVER, July 8 -- Bobby Fischer took a commanding lead today when he defeated Bent Larsen for the second straight time in their 10-game match in Temple Buell College here.
DUBLIN, July 8 (UPI) -- Evonne Goolagong and Mrs. Margaret Court set up a repeat of their Wimbledon final by advancing today to the final of the Carrols Irish open tennis championships.
Forty-nine policemen received medals yesterday from Mayor Lindsay for bravery in the line of duty.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 8 (UPI) -- Angela Davis embraced George Jackson, one of the three so-called Soledad Brothers, as she met him here today.

LAKENHEATH, England, July 8 -- The United States Air Force opened court-martial proceedings today against Capt. Thomas S. Culver, the first American officer charged with taking part in an antiwar protest in Britain.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 8 -- Mrs. Betty Foulk of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Old Greenwich, Conn., nailed the lid on the Syce Cup, emblematic of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association women's sailing championship, today.

NEW ORLEANS, July 8 -- An integrated team of lawyers with deep roots in the civil rights movement will open a new law firm here next Thursday that will try to show young black lawyers how to represent the poor and the blacks and still make a living.
Assemblyman Anthony Olivieri of Manhattan announced yesterday the formation of a committee to prepare a new standard lease for city apartment dwellers to replace the one now in effect.
The New York Telephone Company raised its rates at 12:01 A.M. today to reflect a $190-million temporary increase approved July 1 by the State Public Service Commission.

But today, a truly qualified clubhouse lawyer would undoubtedly be named the most valuable player in his vicinity. Neither the average athlete nor the average fan is equipped to cut his way through the legal thickets that have sprung up on all sides.

NAIROBI, Kenya, July 8 -- President Idi Amin of Uganda threatened today to shoot down any aircraft that crossed Uganda's border with neighboring Tanzania and to attack any Tanzanian ships approaching Uganda's shores on Lake Victoria.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Central Intelligence Agency has told President Nixon that the new Vietcong peace proposal is aimed at embarrassing the United States "both at home and overseas" and encouraging the opponents of President Nguyen Van Thieu in South Vietnam.
BRUSSELS, July 8 -- The European Common Market and Japan today ended a three-day round of trade talks without any progress toward agreement.

TRENTON, July 8 -- A Federal District Court judge today dismissed a suit brought by the National Welfare Rights organzation against New Jersey's new welfare regulations.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) -- John Kenneth Galbraith, Harvard economist, said today that legislation to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy would serve no purpose except to increase the political stock of Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) -- Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, charged today that toothpastes containing stannous fluoride, a decay-retarding additive, really stained teeth. He asked the Government to require warning labels on the toothpaste tubes.
Elimore C. Patterson will become chairman of the board and chief executive officer of J. P. Morgan Co. and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York on Aug. 1, the company announced yesterday.

A flourishing American institution, the far-flung business convention, is being carried to new heights this weekend as 5,300 lawyers and their families -- a total of 12,000 people -- depart for a round of educational, convivial and tax-deductible events in Europe.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The House of Representatives voted today to expand export credit financing by the Export-Import Bank but blocked a move designed to liberalize East-West trade.

LAKE CHARLES, La., July 8 (AP) -- A burning fuel barge exploded in the Intracoastal Waterway today after colliding with another barge about 40 miles southeast of Lake Charles. There were no reports of injuries.
A "hot line" between Brooklyn and Washington sizzled yesterday with messages and instructions in an international search for cans of food that might contain the lethal botulism toxin.

NEW ORLEANS, July 8 (AP) -- Judge Herbert W. Christenberry barred District Attorney Jim Garrison in United States District Court today from arresting two Government officials who brought Federal charges against him.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A new environmental group filed suit against the Atomic Energy Commission in United States District Court here today seeking to halt the underground nuclear test planned this fall on Amchitka Island in the Aleutians.

What an ethical drug ad agency, a consumer-goods agency, a rent-a-car company and a book publisher might well have in common is Francis Joseph Scully. He has tried them all, and at 46 years of age he appears to have taken a rewarding route.

BUTTE, Mont., July 8 (AP) -- Federal Judge W. D. Murray declared a mistrial today in the conspiracy trial of Edward G. Partin, a Louisiana teamster offical, after the jury failed to reach a verdict.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Paul W. McCracken, chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, told Congress today that the Federal budget for the new fiscal year just begun was already $7-billion more stimulative for the economy, in more spending and less revenues, than was planned in January.

Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, Democrat of Manhattan, proposed yesterday that more inspectors be hired by the city's Health Department and the State Agriculture Department to insure adequate supervision of wholesale meat distributing and packing facilities.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 8 -- A man was fatally wounded in a Roman Catholic district of Londonderry today, the second shot and killed there by British soldiers in clashes with rioters since last night.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 8 -- Frank E. Fitzsimmons was unanimously elected today to a five-year term as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Spring arrived late this year in New England but it was accompanied by a whole series of thaws on the international front. GENEVA, July 8 -- More than 1,400 compounds have been tested by the World Health Organization since 1956 as potential insect-killers. But only five, the organization said today, have successfully passed the severe tests in the laboratory and in the field to qualify for operational use.

Seven persons were arrested and seven policemen were reported injured in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn last night when Molotov cocktails, bottles and stones were thrown by a member of a crowd of about 200 people protesting the killing of a young Puerto Rican by a policeman on Wednesday.

AREA A -- Fishing along Barnegat Light is poor, and one local operator complained, "I ask the fish why, but they don't tell me anything." If anglers are lucky in the area, they might catch some flounder. Around Brielle, excellent bluefishing is reported in the Mud Hole and the Klondike.

BUENOS AIRES, July 8 -Gen. Alejandro A. Lanusse, Argentina's military president, has set forth a moderately nationalist economic program as the framework for a political effort to restore an elected government here.

DETROIT, July 8 -- The Ford Motor Company confirmed today that it is considering importing small Japanese-made trucks for sale in the United States and also announced a dividend increase. If Ford does import the trucks, it would mean that the company would cancel plans to build a similar small truck in this country, and would be another example of Detroit's manufacturers deciding that they aren't able to compete with the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The sudden Presidential bid of Senator Fred R. Harris is moving into high gear. The Oklahoma Democrat is expected to announce within a few days that he will not seek re-election to the Senate next year, in order to concentrate on national office.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 8 -- Amateur golf was on the upswing today as a record 142 teams in the John G. Anderson memorial tournament completed the first half of a 36-hole qualifying test. Both the East and West courses of the Winged Foot Golf Club were in use.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 9 -- United States helicopters airlifted 1,500 South Vietnamese troops into the Parrot's Beak section of eastern Cambodia yesterday for the start of a pincer movement against enemy troop concentrations and supply lines.

New York's pro football teams were involved yesterday in separate conferences without commitments -- the Giants on a proposed contract for a New Jersey stadium, the Jets on Jim Hudson's uncertain future as a difensive back.

The nation's major banks have increased their prime lending rate from 51/2 per cent to 6 per cent.
