Rabbi Meir Kahane, the head of the militant Jewish Defense League, said yesterday, at a news conference that he and his followers would not be deterred from using explosives or other forms of violence against Soviet installations in this country if they considered it necessary.

Twenty-three years ago, just after World War II, a fashion magazine used a Capezio ballet slipper to accessorize one of the full-skirted shirtwaist dresses of the period. "Since we were one of the first retail accounts Capezio had," recalls Murray Gerstein, "we got the editorial credit.
Bond prices moved upward yesterday as investment bankers prepared to bid today for the $150-million of New York Telephone Company bonds scheduled for sale today.

Two young black women whose backgrounds differ but who share the belief that black experiences overlap have combined their talents and experiences in their first Off Broadway production, "Black Girl."

A partner in a Manhattan restaurant was held in $50,000 bail in Federal District Court yesterday on an indictment charging him with plotting to smuggle cocaine into this country concealed in hollow wooden table tops.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation had record sales and earnings in the quarter and half ended June 30, with profit up about 13 per cent and sales up 4 per cent in both periods, it was reported yesterday.

OTTAWA, July 12 -- The unprecedented commitment of four American natural gas distributors to advance $75-million for exploration in the Canadian Arctic is an example in miniature of a mammoth transborder energy partnership that could unfold during the next decade.

When Gabriela Mistral, the Nobel Prize-winning Chilean poet, died in 1957 at the home of her friend Doris Dana, in Roslyn Harbor, L. I., she left behind hundreds of pages of unpublished manuscripts and thousands of pages that were never translated into English.
Police narcotics raids in the city and around the country are growing larger and more frequent. Less certain, however, is what effect the raids are really having on America's drug problem.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 9 -- "The blacks are getting cheeky," a farmer from the northern Transvaal complained during a visit to South Africa's administrative capital the other day. He is a local leader of the Reconstituted National party, an ultraconservative splinter group that accuses Prime Minister John Vorster of being soft on blacks.
RABAT, Morocco, July 12 -- With King Hassan II in attendance, the Moroccan Army today buried 20 of its men who were killed on Saturday during the thwarting of an attempt to overthrow the monarchy.
A violinist has lost a court battle to keep a Stradivarius violin that he received from a friend who later encountered tax trouble.

William Henry Moore, the 56-year-old chairman of the Bankers Trust Company, is a banker on the spot. This Thursday, he is scheduled to try to convince the House Banking and Currency Committee that the Government should guarantee $250-million in additional loans to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to allow it to build its L-1011 Tristar airbus. Bankers Trust is a principal creditor of the company.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Federal Trade Commission accused Grolier, Inc., today of a wide range of deceptive practices in the sale of encyclopedias and other publications.

The state and New York City expect to receive $200-million and to create more than 15,000 new jobs for the unemployed over the next two years under the Emergency Employment Act signed yesterday by President Nixon.
The Warner-Lambert Company announced yesterday the filing of a suit in the Federal District Court in Washington, D. C., against the Federal Trade Commission and its members.

The Metropole, the long, narrow, mirror-lined room on Seventh Avenue just north of Times Square that housed a wide variety of jazz from Dixieland to big bands before it installed the topless Go-Go girls who now perform on the platform behind its bar, is getting back into the jazz field.

Don't expect an Ophelia-like demise of New York State Regents exams. A few years ago I entered the lists against them in an article in the Columbia Teachers College Record. Rebuttal from a state testmaker consisted of a series of vitriolic condemnations of anyone questioning examination-based education. His entire argument gyrated around the italicized statement:

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Women's National Political Caucus, a new organization dedicated to increasing the political power of women, announced today the guidelines it will use in deciding what candidates it will support for public office.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A Greek exile appealed to the United States today to stop military assistance to Greece because the military junta, he said, had reduced the Greek Army to a police force hardly capable of carrying out its commitments under the Atlantic alliance.

One thing that strikes a visitor to the home of Frank Perdue in Salisbury, Md., is that almost everything that can be made in the form of a chicken -- is. There are chicken ashtrays, chicken pitchers and chicken lamps.

Our democracy does not work well in secret. The Pentagon Papers illuminate the arrogance of those in high places and the serious erosion, if not breakdown, of our constitutional system of checks and balances.
The municipal hospital system was urged yesterday to open its traditionally closed-door directors' meetings to the news media.

Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia set yesterday a hearing for July 22 on a plan by the trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company for handling claims of Canadian creditors.
There were no arrests for prostitution in Manhattan on Sunday and no arraignments of prostitutes in Criminal Court yesterday -- the first time in 15 years that there have been no such hearings.
PARIS, July 12 -- The French franc continued in demand today, with the Bank of France again compelled to purchase dollars to keep the franc rate from going through its upper limit.
Dr. Antero Lacot, the controversial administrator of Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, has been appointed to the second highest position in the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

The Eastman Kodak Company introduced yesterday two new low-cost security cameras and special films aimed specifically at the market for small businesses that cannot afford the elaborate equipment used by banks and department stores.

Another one of those memorable performances with which Erik Bruhn is generously endowing American Ballet Theater's season at the State Theater took place Sunday night when he made his first appearance with Natalia Makarova in his own staging of Bournonville's "La Sylphide."
DETROIT, July 12 (UPI) -- Earl Weaver, manager of the American League team for tomorrow night's All-Star Game, proposed today that players once again join in the selection of team members.

MOSCOW, July 12 (AP) -- A group of 29 Jews from Soviet Georgia began a hunger strike today in Moscow's central telegraph office to protest lack of action on their requests to emigrate to Israel, Jewish sources reported.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 12 -- Those versatile Bostwick brothers -- Pete and Jim -- added the 19th annual Ike Golf tournament team title to their many sports achievements today as each shot a par 72 over the Wheatley Hills Golf Club course.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- No President since Franklin D. Roosevelt has been a conservationist in his private beliefs and instinctive personal reactions. Roosevelt, an Easterner who loved the West, would not meet the rigorous standards of the new environmental movement.

BREVARD, N. C. -- Winfred Lee Jones, 90 years old, stood on the porch of his unpainted house, which was the color of aging tortoise shell, and looked through the shade trees in the yard down into the narrow valley, across the neat rows of cabbages in the reddish brown fields to the creek that has always tied his valley to the next and the next.

" The Betsy," a novel by Harold Robbins about the four-year planning, development and manufacture of a new model of an automobile, which is slated for publication by Simon Schuster in the fall will be filmed by Warner Bros. and Cinema Video Communications next year.
SEOUL, South Korea, July 12 -- The United States and South Korea joined today in an expression "of continued determination" to maintain strong forces here "capable of deterring aggression."

When Isamu Noguchi was told two years ago that an 18th-century samurai's house was about to be destroyed to make way for a road, the lean, intense sculptor who calls New York City his home but also spends part of each year in Japan and Italy, said he wasn't interested in saving it.

The growing number of would-be Democratic Presidential candidates is a testament to the party's confidence that it can defeat President Nixon for re-election. The unusual variety of these candidates in experience, style and convictions is a testament to the party's traditional diversity.

Although I have neither researched nor been researched in reference to the issue of drug abuse, I have questions for those who will be studying drug addiction as part of our nation's mounting interest in the problem.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 12 -- Mrs. Marion Hazard McVitty, a well-known personality here as an official observer for the World Federalists, died yesterday of cancer at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 60 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Speaker of the House Carl Albert joined George Meany and other labor leaders today in a wholesale denunciation of the Nixon Administration's economic policies.
TRENTON, July 12 (AP) -- The state's second-highest court ruled today that the State Police did not have the right to stop and search a car simply because its driver and occupants had long hair.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A special World Bank mission has concluded that East Pakistan has been so ravaged by the West Pakistani military crackdown that new international development efforts "will have to remain in a state of suspension for at least the next year or so."

WANTAGH, L. I., July 12--Assemblyman Joseph F. Lisa, Democrat of Queens, charged today that misuse of funds by the Long Island State Park Commission could mean that all Long Island state beaches would have to be closed by August.
LONDON, July 12 -- Prime Minister Heath said today that he was completely confident of winning Parliament's approval for British entry into the European Common Market.

Lieut. Gen. Stanley R. Larsen, the Sixth Army commander who order the court-martial of the Presidio 27 on mutiny charges, has been given a new assignment -- deputy commander in chief of U. S. Army Pacific.

DETROIT, July 12 (UPI) -- Jerome Lee, serving time on an arson conviction, was mistakenly released from jail up completion of a 30-day contempt of court sentence stemming from his refusal to testify at the murder trial of 12 fellow Black Panthers, officials disclosed today.

Mayor Lindsay looked over the Consolidated Edison Company's Big Allis generator yesterday. The giant machine, shut down from last Wednesday to Saturday with bearing trouble, was merrily roaring away producing 900,000 kilowatts to meet the city's electric demands.

The First National City Corporation, parent of New York's largest bank, reported yesterday a 19.4 per cent profit increase for the second quarter. This was in sharp contrast to the year-to-year declines at its competitors that have reported so far.

The Supreme Court has made it clear that the protection of the First Amendment extends not only to newspapers and magazines but also to radio, television and movies. It has also ruled that persons holding public office or who are in the public eye are legitimate topics of press coverage and comment.

Steel production dropped last week to the lowest level of 1971, partly because of the July 5 observance of Independence Day and partly because of generally weak market demand. Major mills are not normally closed for one-day holidays, but many smaller operations can be halted or run at a slow pace.
The "inch-ahead" stock market, fighting the summer doldrums and some disappointing profits for individual companies, continued yesterday to creep toward higher ground.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Two well-established operating rules of legislative life are at work against C.B.S. News in its struggle against chairman Harley Staggers and the House Commerce Committee:
Buying plans of the American consumer, after improving steadily in the first four months of 1971, have dropped significantly in the last two months, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it would increase prices of plastic film and sheeting used in a wide range of commercial, agricultural and household items by 4 per cent to 6 per cent, effective Aug. 1.

CAIRO, July 12 -- The press and radio revolutionary Libya were reported today to be continuing expressions of support for army units that attempted to overthrow King Hassan II of Morocco last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The New York Stock Exchange launched today its appeal for higher sales commissions for its members with the argument that brokers needed larger profits if they were to attract the additional investment capital they would need for stable future operation.

A Presidential poll involving President Nixon, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama had Mr. Nixon winning with 44 per cent of the vote, Louis Harris, the poll-taker, reported yesterday, according to the Associated Press.

Members of the Committee on the Atlantic Salmon Emergency (CASE) are bitterly disappointed that a meeting of the 15-nation International Commission for Northwest Atlantic Fisheries (I.C.N.A.F.) held last month in Halifax, Nova Scotia, brought no agreement to end the high seas fishery for Atlantic salmon in the Davis Strait off West Greenland.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Mayor Lindsay asked Congress today for $2.6-million to reimburse New York City for police protection during the 25th anniversary celebration at the United Nations last fall, but the State Department advocated a smaller payment -- $1.3-million.

HOUSTON, July 12 (UPI) -- A sparring partner knocked Muhammad Ali, former heavyweight champion, flat on his back today with a short right to the chin during a workout for Ali's fight with Jimmy Ellis on July 26
Prize Silver outgamed Peace Corps in the stretch drive to win the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The event, a seven-furlong dash for older horses, was witnessed by a crowd of 30,792.
HAVANA, June 12 (Reuters) -- A passenger was killed yesterday when a grenade exploded during an attempt to hijack a Cuban airliner, the Cuban radio reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Dissident coal miners accused the Labor Department today of dragging its feet and refusing to overturn a key United Mine Workers union election they say was stolen from them.

Frank W. Green, who became president and chief operating officer of Fieldcrest Mills, Inc., on May 26, has resigned this post, effective immediately, for "personal reasons." G. William Moore, chairman and chief executive of the company, which manufactures home furnishings textile products, will also take over the presidency, a post he previously held.
Nervously and perhaps a bit tensely, Wall Street is awaiting the Investment Company Institute's monthly report on mutual-fund sales and redemptions.

Jerry Tabb of Tulsa University, the most valuable player in this year's College World Series, had two singles and a home run yesterday as the United States Pan-American team posted a 4-2 victory over the Atlantic Collegiate Baseball League All-Stars at Shea Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- United States officials declared today they were satisfied that the military balance in the Middle East remained unchanged despite evidence that Soviet arms deliveries to Egypt and Syria had increased during the last three months.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Ernest Gruening, the former Democratic Senator from Alaska, said tonight that President Nixon "hasn't any intention of ending" the war in Vietnam "and never has had."

SANTIAGO, July 12 -- President Salvador Allende Gossens signed today the constitutional reform passed by Congress yesterday nationalizing large copper mines in which United States companies have about $700-million invested.

Georges Simenon is one of the few mystery writers to show a proper respect for the act of murder. In so many novels of this genre, killing is simply a condiment to spice the plot. The murder market has been seized by inflation. A half dozen or even a dozen people are sometimes dispatched just to keep the reader awake and the pot boiling.

Betty Furness, whom Governor Rockefeller appointed as the state's first consumer affairs adviser during his re-election campaign a year ago, resigned yesterday, charging that the State Legislature was more interested in protecting industry than the consumer.

The City Art Commission gave preliminary approval yesterday to three more elements of the Metropolitan Museum's controversial master plan: the Rockefeller wing for primitive art; the Western European arts wing; and a glass-enclosed sculpture court.

The Democrats who defeated and dismantled the once fabled Tammany Hall political machine under the banners of "reform" a decade ago are now marked for "reform" themselves in a series of bitter West Side primary contests.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 12 -- Workmen installed 3,000 feet of flexible oil containment booms and wire nets across the mouths of half a dozen St. Petersburg bayous and inlets yesterday and today to keep thousands of dead fish killed by a red tide in Tampa Bay from getting into the waterways.
The average reader of The New York Times, equipped with hindsight, is smarter than any President.
In record trading, copper futures dropped yesterday on the Commodity Exchange after rising steadily since the start of the copper strike July 1.
PARIS, July 12 -- Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser, spent a day in Paris conferring with the American delegation to the Vietnam peace talks.

The Long Island Railroad train that crashed into the rear of another train loaded with commuters at Pennsylvania Station last Friday afternoon had "passed a restrictive signal," the Federal Railroad Administration reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Following are excerpts from a report by a mission of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development that visited East Pakistan last month and from a report on a survey of the western area of the province by Hendrik van der Heijden, an economist and member of the mission.

BRUSSELS, July 12 -- Britain and the European Economic Community agreed today on plans for phasing out Britain's exchange controls on the movement of capital to other Community countries in five years after Britain joins.

A young woman who was a girlfriend of Jerome A. Johnson last May, a month before he allegedly shot Joseph A. Colombo Sr., has said that Johnson had acquired plane tickets to the island of Jamaica with a departure date at the end of June.
PARIS, Ky., July 12 (AP) -- Bold Ruler, one of the greatest sires in the history of thoroughbred racing, was destroyed today after a recurrence of cancer in the horse's digestive tract.
JACKSON LAKE, Wyo., July 12 -- Tom McCall was scarcely off the plane here last night when he was saying critical things about a fellow Governor, Ronald Reagan of California.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The District of Columbia has asked the Justice Department's Law Enforcement Assistance Administration for a $14,900 grant to help develop a contingency plan for the "humane" confinement of persons arrested in mass protests.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12 -- The commanding general of the United States Army's 23d Division, the Americal, is being replaced, the American military headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Lieut. Gen. Robert C. Taber, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for manpower, says that the Pentagon's new drug-testing program in Vietnam is prompting more servicemen to participate in a drug users' amnesty program.

One-third of the members of a Tenant Advisory Council formed by City Rent Commissioner Benjamin Altman have threatened to resign in protest against what they call the uselessness of the organization, it was learned yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 (AP) -- Bill Sharman was named coach of the Los Angeles Lakers of the National Basketball Association today. He received a five-year contract, the terms of which were not announced. It was estimated he would get $70,000 a year.

Net income of a representative group of 76 large member firms of the New York Stock Exchange dropped to $33.3-million in May, less than half the $71.3-million earned by the same firms in April, the exchange disclosed yesterday.

President Nixon's recent address at the annual convention of the American Medical Association laid emphasis upon the huge cost to the nation of the Health Security Bill (S.3) introduced by Senator Edward Kennedy with the support of labor and many members of the Congress.

Following an adjustment late Sunday in the final team standing in the National Amateur Athletic Union women's track and field meet at Bakersfield, Calif., the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn moved into a first-place tie with the Mayor Daley Youth Foundation of Chicago.
The question of state aid to non-public schools, which perennially occupies legislators, has come to a head in the proposal for a voucher system of aid to parents of children attending such schools.
The Times' June 28 editorial "Welfare Employability" refers to the regressive welfare reforms recently enacted by the State Legislature.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The merger discussions between Trans World Airlines and Pan American World Airways, which surfaced publicly today, were brought to the attention of Attorney General John N. Mitchell three months ago in a memorandum from his predecessor of the Eisenhower years, Herbert Brownell.

Trustees of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and the Gray Line Corporation announced yesterday an agreement in principle for settling claims between the two companies and eliminating ownership of each other's stock.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A House and Senate conference committee that has been trying to reconcile differences in draft-extension bills recessed for a week today, still deadlocked over a Senate amendment calling for total troop withdrawals from Vietnam.
Davey Vasquez avenged the only loss on his professional record in successfully defending his North American bantamweight title last night in Madison Square Garden.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12 (UPI) -- American military strength in South Vietnam dropped 3,100 men last week to a five-year low of 236,300 The withdrawal pace was nearly 50 per cent ahead of schedule, according to United States command figures disclosed today.
Serious flaws in the auditing of brokerage houses by independent accounting firms have been disclosed by a six-month survey conducted under State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., July 13 -- After a year and a half of planning and preparation, the Army has begun destroying the nation's stockpile of germ and toxin warfare agents, along with the munitions that would have been used to carry them to an enemy.

DENVER, July 13 -- A group of nine Russian scientists this week will be the first from the Soviet Union to visit the Atomic Energy Commission's Nevada test site where the United States conducts its underground tests of atomic weapons.

Funds have been allocated for construction of a "floating island" that could serve as a prototype for midocean weather stations, bases for sea-floor mining operations or platforms to carry nuclear power plants.
A program to provide taxi or livery service at reduced rates for the elderly who are not receiving health care because they cannot use public transportation was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

For a world that takes stability for granted and Government reshuffles at The Hague in stride, the Cabinet sworn in by Queen Juliana last week had a striking aspect -- and it was not the debut of Barend Biesheuvel as Premier. It was the absence from the list for the first time in nineteen years of Joseph Marie Antoine Hubert Luns, the world's senior foreign minister.
Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed Mafia leader who was shot in the head June 28, is being treated with antibiotics to ward off systemic infection, a Roosevelt Hospital spokesman reported yesterday.

BOSTON, July 13 -- A Federal grand jury here has been presented information gathered by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who have attempted to learn how secret Pentagon papers were made available to the press.
DENVER, July 13 -- Bobby Fischer defeated Bent Larsen of Denmark in 33 moves in the fourth game of their chess match today. Fischer leads, 4-0.

This is the time of year when travelers from outer space visit the New York area, and the leading hot shoes will provide a lively weekend as they show what they do to win well over $100,000 a year. That dazzling spectacle of noise, fantasy and blinding speed, a big-league championship drag meet, plays for three days at Englishtown, N.J., 15 miles south of New Brunswick.

The J. C. Penney Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had called for redemption all of its $125-million issue of 4 1/4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures. The effect of the call will be to force holders of the debentures to convert them into Penney common stock since any holder who does not convert his bonds stands to suffer a stiff loss.
The mercury was touching 93 degrees on 34th Street when Amtrak's Merchants Limited, once the pride of the old New Haven Railroad, pulled out of Pennsylvania Station for Boston the other evening.
A Massapequa, L. I., couple who are fighting a court order to return the 3-year-old Chinese-American girl they hoped to adopt have disappeared from their home, taking the child with them.

Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, the political scientist who made the Pentagon papers available to the press, said during a long television interview last night that Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser, had been consulted about the Pentagon study before the project began.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the world's biggest brokerage house, reported yesterday that earnings for the first half of the year advanced by 160 per cent to $40,243,000 from $15,470,000 a year earlier.
YONKERS, July 13 -- In the opinion of the linemaker, $5 should get you $1, if you believe, as many do, that Albatross will win the Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway Friday night.

DETROIT, July 13 -- No dramatic developments emerged today from the meeting of the player representatives of the 24 major league teams with Marvin Miller, director of the Players Association, and Dick Moss, the Association's counsel. But some of the matters discussed may get to be well-publicized issues eventually.
Howard M. Stein is not upset by all the chatter about net redemptions in the mutual-fund industry. His viewpoint is worth examining.

Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., announced yesterday several organizational changes, including the election of Heath B. McLendon, 38 years old, as executive vice president and a member of the executive committee.

The City Council unanimously approved yesterday a stringent air-pollution control code that reduces the allowable sulphur content in fuels burned here and limits the amount of particle emissions from ventilators and fuel-burning equipment.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13--Arab commando spokesmen said here today that Jordanian tanks and infantry had begun an all-out offensive against guerrilla positions in Jordan.

CASPER, Wyo., July 13 -- Van Irvine, a rancher facing 29 charges following the thallium sulphate poison deaths of 22 eagles, pleaded no defense today and paid minimum fines totaling $675 plus $4 costs.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma proposed today that Democratic Presidential candidates agree to curtail spending and to debate regularly in the 1972 primary contests.

A suit in Federal Court here is seeking $30-million in damages for shareholders in the Real Estate Fund of America, Ltd., a foreign-based mutual fund that sold shares overseas to persons making real estate investments in the United States.

The International Business Machines Corporation posted record after-tax profits in the quarter and half year ended June 30, but the gains over the previous year continue to narrow, according to results issued yesterday from its Armonk, N. Y., headquarters.

SAIGON South Vietnam July, 13 -- President Nixon's special advisor on drug abuse finished today a three-day tour of United States military drug-detection and treatment center in South Vietnam, but declined to specify what he had found.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)--The four top-seeded players advanced with victories today in the first round of the $50,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -David Packard, Deputy Secretary of Defense, argued before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today that the United States must proceed with deployment of offensive and defensive missiles as "bargaining chips" in the strategic-arms talks with the Soviet Union.
Quick now: if one brand of tissues costs 29 cents for a box of 125, and a second brand costs 39 cents for two boxes of 200 each, which brand is cheaper?
The Goldfield Corporation filed suit here yesterday in State Supreme Court seeking an accounting by former officers and directors, including Richard C. Pistell, who had been chairman and president.

Harmon H. Goldstone, chairman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, said yesterday that the commission would recommend to Mayor Lindsay approval of architects' plans for the restoration of nine old houses on the site of the Washington Street Urban Renewal Area.

The report of a World Bank mission to East Pakistan last month is a devastating indictment of the West Pakistani military crackdown in Bengal. It strongly challenges the Administration's policy of continuing both military and economic support for the Yahya Khan regime in Islamabad.
The New York Cosmos and Apollon of Greece battled to a 1-1 tie at Yankee Stadium last night before 4,763 fans, the largest home crowd ever to watch the Cosmos.

DETROIT, July 13 -- Frank Robinson was named the All-Star Game's most valuable play tonight, but he and the rest of the American Leaguers preferred to talk about Reggie Jackson's mammoth homer that started them on the way to their first victory since 1962.

Stuart N. Scott has a fortunate -- and for a New York lawyer, unusual -- qualification for the new job he is in line to take on as head of the state committee that will investigate New York City's governance.
HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 13 -- The Suffolk County Legislature today authorized the acquisition of the 231-acre Gardiner Manor estate in West Islip for $2-million.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Miss Muriel E. Forsland, a Chicago high school teacher who left $2-million to the University of Chicago for medical research, amassed her fortune by almost daily trading in common stocks, using as beginning capital only her $9,000-a-year teaching salary.

Four of the 15 directors of the city's public hospital system, dissatisfied with the direction of the system and the speed with which it is moving, called yesterday for a special board meeting to discuss a wholesale reorganization.

HOUSTON, July 13 -- The Stuffer Chemical Company in a statement today denied that its sulphuric acid plant was the source of the chemical smog that has made groups of people ill four times since April 22.
NAIROBI, Kenya, July 13 -- Vice President Agnew met informally here today with Kenya's President, Jomo Kenyatta.

LAKENHEATH, England, July 13 -- A United States Air Force court-martial found Capt. Thomas S. Culver guilty today of having taken part in an antiwar demonstration in London on May 31 in violation of military regulations.

Both The Times and the President of the United States are concerned about the safety and well-being of the American people, but while your. editor is responsible only to your American readers, the President is responsible not only to Americans but also to foreign governments.

LONDON, July 13 -- An official report charged today that Robert Maxwell, former chairman of Pergamon Press, Ltd., a major publisher of scientific books, could not be "relied on to exercise proper stewardship of a publicly quoted company."

Weakness in two cornerstone issues -- International Business Machines and American Telephone -- caused shakiness yesterday in the general stock market. More than 1,000 issues showed declines on the New York Stock Exchange.

Arthur G. McKee Co., specializing in the engineering, design and construction of metal refining, coal preparation pits and food precessing plants, announced yesterday that it is planning to make a provision of $3-million in its financial results for the first six months ended June 30, 1971, to cover "probable losses on certain large lump-sum contracts."

BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 13 -- A huge crop of 38 Giant rookies and free agents broke into specialized groups today as training camp opened on a brilliant, comfortable afternoon more suited to baseball than football.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 13 -- Gene Francis shot steady golf in a strong wind on his home course at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today to win the 19th annual Ike Tournament with a 54-hole total of 218 -- two over par.

Three performers in a live sex show were sentenced to jail terms yesterday by a Manhattan Criminal Court judge--the first time this has happened in an obscenity case in the memory of court officials and members of the District Attorney's staff.

If Carl David Askling's July 3 Op-Ed article "Who Needs the National Anthem?" was meant to be humorous, the printing of it was a waste of Valuable newspaper space. If it was meant to be serious, Mr. Askling has missed the whole purpose of the public rendition of our national anthem.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 13 (AP) -- United States and Soviet negotiators began what conference sources called "serious consideration" today of their goal to reach accord on the limitation of defensive antiballistic missiles and offensive strategic weapons.

Monroe Kaufman is a successful insurance manager from New Rochelle, N. Y., who enjoys sports in all seasons. He owns season tickets for home games of the New York Giants, treks off to ski in Vermont and drives in from Westchester County with his family on foggy winter nights to watch the New York Knicks battle Lew Alcindor.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 13 -- James French Baldwin's big sloop Sorcery was first to finish in the 360-mile race from Marblehead, Mass., to this port, and late tonight she was assured of winning Class A honors.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The House voted today to recommit to the Commerce Committee -and in effect to kill -proposed citation for contempt of Congress against the Columbia Broadcasting System and its president, Dr. Frank Stanton.
Voters in five communities in Suffolk County and one in Nassau County voted on school budgets, members of the school boards and a number of propositions yesterday.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 13 -- It's become feast or famine so far as wind is concerned for the 73d Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week over the first four days.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Nixon Administration plans to replace David K. E. Bruce as chief United States delegate at the Vietnam peace talks in Paris on or about Aug. 15, senior officials said today.
In moderate trading, prices yesterday suffered their worst loss in three weeks on the American Stock exchange.
The City National Bank of Columbus, Ohio, announced yesterday two banking innovations designed to speed Credit-card payments to merchants and to provide aroundthe-clock banking services to consumers.

Three Board of Education bills totaling more than $9,000 -- including one for an "executive development program weekend seminar" at a resort in the Catskills -- have been challenged by Controller Abraham D. Beame.
Frank Serpico, the detective whose information led to criminal and department charges being brought against 20 policemen, has been assigned a police bodyguard.

The suonds of the p'i p'a, cheng, ch'in and erh hu were heard at the meeting of the International Bach Society in the Lincoln Center Library auditorium on Monday night. One might have expected to hear Bach transcriptions being played on these Chinese instruments, since the composer's music has been adapted to just about everything that can be played, from balalaikas to steel drums.
The city broke ground yesterday for a two-and-a-halfacre neighborhood park in Woodside, Queens, that was authorized in 1936 by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia.

PARIS -- Communist strategy in this final phase of the Indochina war seems postulated on proving Abraham Lincoln was wrong and that it is indeed possible to fool all the American people all the time. Hanoi has reason to believe it may well demonstrate this cynical theorem's accuracy.

A state report said yesterday that Consolidated Edison had lost all four of its 168,000-kilowatt gas-turbine emergency electric generators, mounted on barges in Gowanus Creek, on the same day its million-kilowatt Big Allis unit broke down last week.

By signing the $5.5-billion school-aid bill that exceeds his own request, President Nixon has put an end to a three-year feud with Congress. Aside from erasing the unfavorable image of an education-minded Congress battling an anti-education Administration, the truce offers Mr. Nixon an opportunity to do some economic pump-priming for a socially vital purpose.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, July 14 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird ended two days of consultations here yesterday with the issuance of a joint statement that apparently fell far short of the specific assurances and commitments his South Korean hosts had sought.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)--A Senate panel was told today that the Nixon Administration had rejected a recommendation of Government health specialists for a national push this year against childhood lead poisoning.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy made public today a survey on East Pakistan prepared by two American officials and declared that it showed that millions would starve unless emergency measures were taken before Aug. 1.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Labor leaders said today that industry's growing use of cheap labor abroad threatened a return to sweatshops and collapse of the economy.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 13 -- A total of 965 sanitary and housing violations, including widespread rat infestation, were discovered in migrant labor camps in Suffolk County investigated by the County Health Department last year, according to a report presented to the County Legislature today.
Q. Do you regret the publication of this report?

HEMPSTEAD, L. I. July 13 -- Perhaps the most significant project in the early days of the New York Jets' training camp will be the inspection of Roger Finnie, whom his teammates call "Superman," at both defensive end and defensive tackle.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Secor D. Browne, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, today labeled legislation aimed at quieting the roar of jet aircraft too expensive, technologically impossible and diplomatically risky.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A powerful civil rights coalition severely criticized today the Nixon Administration's policies and practices in providing housing for minorities and the poor.

DETROIT, July 13 -- Vida Blue gave up two home runs in three innings tonight, but his American League teammates recovered from that shock to defeat the National League, 6-4, and break an eight-game losing streak in baseball's 42d All-Star Game.

Financial disagreements, which have been major between owners and players in recent years, continue to harass pro football. Greg Landry, the Detroit Lions' regular quarterback, considers the only salary offer his club has made to be "ludicrous."

When the Shell Oil Company moved its corporate headquarters to Houston, Ogilvy Mather wasn't far behind. It probably isn't wise to let too much space come between a client and an agency when there is about $25-million in billings involved.
PARIS, July 13 -- French Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing reasserted today for the second time in two weeks that France would not upvalue the franc.

EAST LANSING, Mich., July 13 -- A 22-year-old college dropout who goes about barefoot and wearing overalls is in the City Council race in usually tranquil East Lansing, a city of 47,500 with winding streets and splendid homes.
LONDON, July 13 -- Britain turned in a strong foreign-trade performance in June, earning a merchandise surplus of 39-million ($93.6-million), the Department of Trade and Industry announced today.

When President Nixon submitted his fiscal 1972 budget last January, it showed an $11.6-billion deficit. Expenditures were budgeted at $229.2-billion, but revenues were estimated at only $217.6-billion because the economy would still be recovering from the 1969-70 slump.

Mattel, the toy manufacturer that recently joined with Robert B. Radnitz, the movie producer, to form Radnitz/Mattel Productions, will make eight feature films over the next three years. Two will be directed by Martin Ritt, who was responsible for "Hud" and "The Spy Who Came In From the Cold,"

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Defense Department explained today what had happened to $1.7-billion in United States support for the Government of South Vietnam that an audit by the General Accounting Office had not been able to trace.
ALBANY, July 13 -- Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea said today that his fellow Asseblymen believed that Governor Rockeller vetoed more bills than he should have following the 1971 session.

Three members of the company performing the rock musical "Stomp," whose theater in Atlanta was burned down on Saturday, arrived here yesterday by bus to raise money to resume their theater activities.

Some of the Miss Universe contestants met some of New York's most eligible bachelors Monday night. After several hours of mutual inspection, desultory conversation, dining and dancing, it was a toss-up as to which group was more unimpressed.

TRENTON, July 13 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a hospital may give a blood transfusion to save the life of an adult patient even if it violates the patient's religious beliefs.
ELK, Wyo., July 13 (UPI) -- The deaths of three persons, including one run down by a buffalo in a meadow, were reported today in two Wyoming national parks.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Administration's effort to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy passed its first legislative test today.
Five months ago Jay Feigus won the master pair title in a New York sectional tournament at the age of 78, and became the oldest man ever to win a major New York title.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 13 -- President Nixon announced today that he would nominate David Luke Norman to be Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Civil Rights Division.

The Corporation for Public Broadcasting announced yesterday reception of a $1,120,000 grant from the Mobil Oil Corporation renewing its funding of "Masterpiece Theater" for two years. The series, which last season presented "The First Churchills," "The Spoils of Poynton," "The Possessed" and "Pere Goriot," is televised Sundays at 9 P.M. on more than 200 noncommercial stations belonging to the Public Broadcasting Service network.
ATHENS, July 13 -- Greece's exiled King, Constantine, and the United States Ambassador to Greece, Henry J. Tasca, have met at Porto Ercole, a fashionable Italian resort.
A three-judge Federal District Court hearing on a constitutional challenge to New York State's one-year welfare residency requirement was scheduled yesterday for Aug. 9 in Buffalo.

An independent evaluation of the city's Community Education Centers has recommended that local residents be given greater operational control over the programs, which cost $14.6-million in the last school year.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -Total business inventories rose $630-million in May, about the same as in April and indicating a slightly faster inventory growth in the second quarter than in the first, the Commerce Department reported today.
The city's Offtrack Betting Corporation announced yesterday that starting tomorrow it would start taking daily-double, exacta and across-the-board wagering on races at Aqueduct.
They dress expensively, drive luxurious cars, and are seen most frequently between the hours of 11 o'clock at night and six in the morning around Times Square.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 14 (AP) -The South Vietnamese Supreme Court yesterday upheld the constitutionality of a newly enacted and controversial election law that restricts the number of presidential candidates.

RABAT, Morocco, July 13 -Ten high-ranking officers of the Moroccan Army died before firing squads this morning, with cries of "Long live Hassan II" on their lips. On command, units of the army, navy and air force spat on the bodies.
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 13 (AP) -- American-backed Meo tribesmen were reported today to have extended Laotian Government control over the entire Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos.

Johnny Sample, who played professional football for 11 years and capped his career by helping the New York Jets win the 1968 Super Bowl, was arrested in Philadelphia yesterday on charges of having cashed 15 forged United States Treasury checks that were stolen from the mails.

The state's Urban Development Corporation and a group in Harlem agreed yesterday to form a subsidiary to help community organizations build and operate housing, cultural, civic and commercial facilities in the area.

Ralph Nader, Representative Reuss of Wisconsin, John W. Gardner's public-interest lobby Common Cause and a number of other plaintiffs have brought suit against the United States Treasury to force it to withdraw its new Asset Depreciation Range (A.D.R.) system, which would reduce business taxes by an average of $3.9 billion a year over the next decade.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -Joseph A. Beirne, president of the Communications Workers of America, announced this afternoon that his 500,000-worker union would strike the nation's telephone system at 6 A.M. tomorrow.

HOUSTON, July 13 -- A case of Venezuelan equine encephalomyelitis in a human has been confirmed in a Mexican town near the Texas border, and a number of residents of Brownsville, a small Texas border town, apparently have the illness, a United States Public Health Service official said today.

If you set out to make a movie about wasted lives, you will, such are the paradoxes of the art, most likely be undone by problems in form and dramatic structure -- though it might have seemed that the real challenge was only to discover a decent bond of sympathy with the quality of human suffering that is your subject.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -The Federal Reserve Board is concerned that Congress may be on the verge of passing legislation that could result in a large and rapid outflow of dollars in the form of bank loans to foreigners.

WASHINGTON -- As we approach another Olympic year we have already heard the rumblings of the problem that has plagued the Olympic movement for years. Avery Brundage, speaking for the International Olympic Committee (I.O.C.), has warned that several European skiers may be barred from the 1972 winter Olympics on the grounds that their amateur status has been tainted by "commercialism."

DETROIT, July 13 -- Sparky Anderson, the first National League manager to be on the losing side of an All-Star Game in nine years, had one big regret tonight: He didn't get Manny Sanguillen, the Pittsburgh catcher, into the game.
ST. LOUIS, July 13 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals acquired a wide receiver, Homer Jones, from the Cleveland Browns today for a high future draft choice.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 13 -- President Emilio G. Medici has ordered the formation of three new Indian reservations.

Soybean futures prices continued the rise started the day before during the opening moments of yesterday's session on the Chicago Board of Trade. But, after several seesaw moves, prices dropped sharply as a result of profit taking just before the close.

The New York Telephone Company auctioned $150-million of bonds yesterday. They were designed to yield investors 7.90 per cent, but the response was only fair and the advance in the corporate bond market came to a halt.

Senator George McGovern announced yesterday that he was seeking legislation to facilitate registration and voting by the 18-to-21-year-olds granted the vote under the recently approved 26th Amendment to the United States Constitution.

America's textile industry differs from any other industry in that it must be considered from a historical standpoint. The Japanese textile industry was wiped out during the war and in order to permit the sale of raw cotton and of textile machinery to Japan after the war, the industry worked out a quota system to provide for a very generous amount of importation of finished goods.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 (UPI) -- The Screen Actors Guild announced today it had tentatively approved a new three-year contract with film producers. The Guild had set deadline of 12.01 A.M. tomorrow for a strike against major studios, independent companies and the three major television networks.

" A man may stand there and put all America behind him," Thoreau wrote more than a century ago after ending a visit to Provincetown on Cape Cod. And he had the canny foresight to add, "The time must come when this coast will be a place of resort for those New Englanders who really wish to visit the seaside."

LOS ANGELES, July 13 (AP) -- The actor Robert Stack filed a $25-million damage suit against the Columbia Broadcasting System today, charging that its controversial "Selling of the Pentagon" misrepresented his position on the Vietnam war.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 13 (UPI) -- President Nixon and his top diplomatic advisers talked today about the National Women's Political Caucus -- and not very kindly.
RIFLE, Colo., July 10 -- Big-time art is coming to this small mining and cow town in western Colorado -- really big art, all the way from New York City in the form of an incredible orange curtain.

NEWARK, July 13 -- Hope for a settlement of the American Newspaper Guild strike against The Evening News of Newark dimmed today following the rejection by the newspaper's management of a nonstriking crafts union's suggestion that the management return to a pre-strike offer of settlement it had made to the Guild.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Federal Trade Commission ordered seven automobile manufacturers today to document 60 advertising claims such as "over 700 per cent quieter" and "109 advantages to keep it from getting old before its time."

Three years ago, with much fanfare and covert crossing of fingers, Angel Records signed the Chicago Symphony to what was proclaimed as a trend-defying contract. The European company hoped show, officials said, that a great symphony orchestra could still be recorded at a profit in this country in spite of steeply rising costs and falling classical sales.

To the Editor: Dean Acheson's conclusion that we need a "self-governing body for the press... to stimulate... self-restraint in publishing material ethically undesirable ("The Purloined Papers" Op-Ed July 7) is a frightening, though perhaps unconscious, attack on constitutional liberties.
Sharply reduced earnings for two top paper producers -- the International Paper Company and the St. Regis Paper Company -- were reported yesterday for the second quarter and the half.

A prominent Lebanese diplomat recently told me there is an intense rivalry between Red China and the Soviet Union for influence in the Arab Middle East. In Lebanon, the commandos get arms from both rivals, and most of those in Lebanon and Jordan were trained in Red China.
The Center for Policy Research has received a grant of $124,300 to study the use of cable television for communication and decision-making on the community level.

State Supreme Court Justice James J. Leff has accused two 27-year-old New York City policemen of trying to "perpetrate an audacious swindle" with a $100,000 personal injury suit against a taxicab company and one of its drivers.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -Staff members of the Securities and Exchange Commission questioned today just how small investors who get turned away by brokers finding their business unprofitable are going to be put in touch with a broker who will serve them, as the New York Stock Exchange has promised.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- A Federal judge denied today a request by the Warner-Lambert Company to keep the Federal Trade Commission from issuing a complaint charging it with antitrust violations in the acquisition of Parke, Davis Co.

Two of the most highly developed techniques in the jazz world were on display Monday night at the Wollman Rink in Central Park -the piano technique of Oscar Peterson and the vocal technique of Ella Fitzgerald.

ROME, July 13 (AP) -- A parliamentary commission, after a seven-year investigation, named 13 Mafia leaders today, describing them as "bloody criminals, killers, drug dealers, persons capable of any atrocity." Publication of the report marked the first time a parliamentary investigation had identified leading Mafiosi.
Governor Rockefeller will appoint Stuart N. Scott, outgoing president of the New York State Bar Association, to head the state investigation of New York City operations.

When the collections of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pearlman, Mrs. Alex Hillman and Mr. and Mrs. Philip Levin moved into the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday, the Summer Loan Exhibition 1971 was finally complete.

MOSCOW, July 13 -- At the far end of Moscow's busy Central Telegraph Office, 33 Jews from Soviet Georgia sat on stools or sprawled on the floor tonight as the second day ended in their self-announced hunger strike to obtain permission to emigrate to Israel.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator Robert P. Griffin charged the Labor Department today with failure to enforce the Landrum-Griffin Act -- the law he helped write 12 years ago as a "bill of rights" for organized labor.

Never take a designer's word about his collection. "The daytime things are just good clothes to wear," Norman Norell said before his showing yesterday. "The evening things are very fantastic, very showy."
The Monsanto Company, a major producer of man-made fibers, announced yesterday price increases for much of its nylon product line in the apparel area.

Copper futures prices, which had dropped the last two sessions, despite the continuing strike in the industry, rose yesterday on the Commodity Exchange (Comex) here. Trading was moderate.

Scholarly confusion surrounding the art of the 18thcentury printmaker Giovanni Battista Piranesi is formidable. One need only consider, say, the baffling chronologies of prints pulled during his lifetime and compound that with perplexing dates of prints pulled after his death.

Voters in seven communities in Suffolk County voted yesterday on school budgets and fiscal proposals as well as school board candidates. In two districts, budget items submitted for the second time were rejected again.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 14 (AP) -- John Rotz brought Cautious Bidder back from a poor start to an impressive victory today in the $103,575 Hollywood Lassie Stakes at Hollywood Park.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -Ralph Nader advanced today a plan to revise the nation's private pension programs and increase the individual worker's control over his share of the money.

To mobilize a considerable part of the nation's medical resources for attacks on diseases of the heart, blood vessels and lungs, $16.4-million in Federal funds has been granted for the establishment of 29 specialized centers of research. Two of the largest will be in this city.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Senator James L. Buckley said today that the nation had been on "an antimilitary binge" forcing sharp cutbacks in large areas of defense spending essential to its security.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Australian Embassy told the State Department today that China had expressed interest in participating in a new Geneva conference on Indochina.

The city administration is to get majority control of the board of directors of the non-profit corporation that for the last five years has been working to develop the old Brooklyn Navy Yard as an industrial park.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate upheld today President Nixon's veto of a $5.6-billion bill embracing an emergency job program for the unemployed. The vote was 57 to 36, five short of the two-thirds needed to override a Presidential veto.
A late rally led by the glamour issues -- and coming as a surprise to some observers -trimmed losses in the stock market yesterday. The DowJones industrial average dipped 1.17 points to 891.21.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 14 -- After two apparently frenetic and formless days of training camp, patterns began to emerge today in drills among the Giant rookies and free agents at C. W. Post College.

LONDON, July 14 -- What is a national theater? Britain's National Theater seems to take a deliberately controversial view of the question. The danger, I suppose, of any national theater is that it becomes too conventional, too hidebound.
