For two years George Meany has been warning the Nixon Administration that pleas for voluntary restraint are never going to check the wage-price spiral. Last weekend, in his strongest statement yet, the crusty A.F.L.-C.I.O. chief set forth his conviction that mandatory controls on an across-the-board basis represent the only way to halt inflation.
The United States Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that 1,200 cans of a batch of Bon Vivant vichyssoise that was found to contain botulinus toxin were still unaccounted for.
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, parent company of New York's second largest bank, reported yesterday a sharp deterioration in its profitability during the month of June.

On Tuesday evening, the Police Department scheduled a news conference for 10 A.M. yesterday on the near-fatal shooting of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed Mafia leader. Then, at the last minute yesterday, the conference was called off. "I had a sore throat," Chief of Detectives Albert A.

WASHINGTON -- Publication of the Pentagon Papers has increased a widespread feeling that the public has not been adequately informed of United States intentions in Vietnam. The credibility of the Government was already at low point. To restore confidence it is essential that the Administration now clarify its aims in Vietnam.

Word from Helsinki indicates that the latest round of strategic arms limitation talks has got off to a good start, at least in the sense that serious discussions aimed at constructive results have taken place. The improved atmosphere was forecast last week by Pravda's commentary on SALT resumption, which read like an effort to begin preparing Soviet public opinion for an agreement.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14 -- The Western White House sought today to discourage speculation that President Nixon was preparing a "package response" to the Vietnamese Communists' sevenpoint peace proposal of July 1.
Muddy Waters brought his blues band to the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art Tuesday night for the second evening in the museum's current series of folk concerts.

Dean Acheson (Op-Ed July 7) says that the "purloined papers" should have been returned to their owners, "the Government," Like the Chief Justice, he views the papers as physical possessions, in the category of lost shirt-studs or stolen five-dollar bills. Even so, it seems odd to return the evidence of deceit and betrayal of public trust to the authors of the deceit.

The lawyer of a police lieutenant accused of conspiring with the men of his command over the division of bribes said yesterday that the prosecution's key witness had told "two completely different stories while under oath."

An opposition group attempting to wrest control of Investors Overseas Services -- the giant mutual fund group -- from Robert L. Vesco, its board chairman, reported from St. John, New Brunswick, yesterday that it had obtained a preliminary injunction against Mr. Vesco.
Three premieres and a revival will be presented by the City Center Joffrey Ballet in its six-week fall season from Oct. 6 through Nov. 14 at the City Center.
Minor inconvenience rather than major disruption was the rule yesterday on the first day of the nationwide telephone strike.

The Suburban Action Institute said yesterday that it had asked the Federal Government, in effect, to block the General Electric Company's plan to move its corporate headquarters from Manhattan to Fairfield, Conn.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today charging the Reynolds Metals Company, the nation's second largest domestic producer of aluminum, with illegal reciprocity.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Two Democratic Presidential candidates, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and Senator Edmund S. Muskie, joined today in a proposal that the United States and Soviet Union freeze the deployment of nuclear weapons while they seek an agreement to control strategic arms.

PASADENA, Calif., July 14 -- The stands of the Rose Bowl were empty Sunday. The only action on the football field came from automatic sprinklers scattering arcs of water to protect the grass from the sun, already scorching at 9 A.M. But outside, 20,000 persons formed long lines at the ticket booths and paid 50 cents for admission to the plaza that circles the stadium.
An American Telephone and Telegraph Company supervisor hovered over her pupil, who sat grinning at a bank of switchboard lights and wires.

A judge in Small Claims Court reserved decision early this morning in a case involving a taxi driver who contends that owners have been illegally deducting money from their drivers' paychecks since March 2, when the cab fares were raised.

TUNIS, July 13 -- King Hassan II of Morocco, who staved off an attempt at a military coup last Saturday, has been assured of the support of his North African neighbors, Tunisia and Algeria, at least on the surface.
Criminal Court Judge Alfred H. Kleiman announced yesterday his withdrawal as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for surrogate.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Industrial production rose in June for the fourth consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it had expanded the data storage capacity of its System/7 and provided a new custom-designed console. The System/7, introduced last fall, is I.B.M.'s lowest-cost computer, renting for as little as $352 a month.

International Business Machines absorbed a 13-point thrashing Tuesday in heavy trading and then skidded 2 more points yesterday as Wall Street emerged from its shock over the huge computer company's cheerless second-quarter financial report.

LONDON, July 14 -- Prime Minister Heath, faced with hardening opposition from the trade unions and the Labor party, sought to marshal the full support of his own party today for his Government's decision to join the Common Market.

TRENTON, July 14 -- William A. Sternkopf who was convicted in Federal Court in Newark with seven others last week of charges of corruption in Hudson County resigned today as New Jersey commissioner on the Port of New York Authority.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Public support for wage and price controls is at the highest level since the Korean war, according to a Gallup poll released today.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 14 -- Paul Simpson, a 20-year-old college golfer, followed last year's pattern when an amateur won, by leading the New Jersey open with a 69 today.
NORTH BERGEN, N. J., July 14 -- Visit New York City from New Jersey. That's the latest.
With trading slackening off from the day before, prices on the American Stock Exchange declined slightly yesterday.

A chess tournament for computers will be held in Chicago over the first weekend in August. It is reassuring to know that some of our best technical minds are at work in this area, and we may someday have a machine that can hold its own with Bobby Fischer.

Profits of three major paper companies -- the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, the KimberlyClark Corporation and the Scott Paper Company -- continued to be depressed in the second quarter and first half, according to their mid-year reports yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -Two antiwar groups and 18 individuals sued the Federal Bureau of Investigation today, asking the Federal District Court here to enjoin as unconstitutional "continuous and malicious harassment" by agents since the theft of F.B.I. files at nearby Media in March.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz suggested strongly here yesterday that his office was compiling evidence that might lead to legal action against several New York brokerage firms on charges of irregularities in the reporting of their financial condition.
An official of the teamster union's pension fund was indicted yesterday on charges of obtaining a $55,000 kickback to approve a pension-fund loan to a financially troubled textile company.

The Mississippi Corporation announced yesterday the election of Downing B. Jenks as president and chief executive and Robert H. Craft as chairman. They succeed the late William G. Marbury who held both posts. Mr. Jenks is president of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, a subsidiary, and Mr. Craft is chairman of Mississippi River's finance committee.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 14 -- Contact lenses were ordered today for Rich Caster, the New York Jets' wide receiver with an opportunity to be a starter following George Sauer's retirement.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 14 -- The astronauts and machines of Apollo 15 completed their final practice countdown tests today and appeared to be ready to embark July 26 on the nation's fourth moon-landing mission.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A proposal to ban arms aid to Greece was narrowly defeated today in the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
More than $200-million in city construction for such things as schools, libraries and firehouses has been halted to bring pressure on building trade unions to admit more blacks and Puerto Ricans.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 14 -- The appointment of Donald Forst as managing editor for news coverage of Newsday was announced today by David Laventhol, editor of the Long Island newspaper.
Availing himself of the splendid interference that his father set up for him, Bobby Woodhouse rode the Birchfield Farm's Brenda Beauty to victory in the $33,800 Astoria Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

DETROIT, July 14 -- New-car sales sagged sharply in early July with 159,776 United States models reported sold, down 12 per cent from 181,491 deliveries a year before and the lowest selling rate for July 1-10 in a decade.

A nuclear detective team, assigned to monitor any radioactive build-up around atomic power plants, described yesterday how scientists used the same method to find a missile nose cone lost in Mexico that contained a low-energy radioisotope.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 14 (UPI) -- Alf M. Landon, the Republicans' 1936 candidate for president, said today that modern Presidents had no right to wage war and mislead Congress and the public in the style of "the old discredited divine right of monarchs."

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -The State of New Jersey asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit today to deny a new trial for Edgar H. Smith Jr., who has spent 14 years on Death Row -more than any other condemned man in the country.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 14 -Six cases of Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a dangerous viral disease transmitted by tick bites, were reported in Suffolk County last month, according to Dr. George E. Leone, the county's Health Commissioner.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 13 -- The growing economy is undergoing strains that are hurting nonwhites now but may help erode apartheid in the long run.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 14 -Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky accused President Nguyen Van Thieu today of using "dictatorial practices" to silence the opposition, muzzle the press and insure his re-election.

Weakening prices for beverage cans and disruptions related to the first-quarter strike sharply reduced profits of the American Can Company in the three and six months ended June 30, according to yesterday's semiannual report.

If Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy decides to crack down on the men who patronize the city's prostitutes -- a move he is "considering," he said yesterday -- he will be taking on a job that many law officials say is even more difficult than the job of cracking down on the prostitutes.
BOSTON, July 14 (AP) -Carl Yastrzemski and Billy Conigliaro of the Boston Red Sox made their peace today and Tony Conigliaro reported he batted all last season with his left eye almost closed.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 14 -- Wellington Mara, president of the New York Giants, denied today a report that the club had reached agreement with the New Jersey Sports Authority to move to the new sports complex planned for the Hackensack Meadowlands.
DETROIT, July 14 -- Last night's All-Star Game started as the Vida Blue story and wound up as the saga of the Reggie Jackson-Frank Robinson mutual admiration society.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans described as totally unfounded today charges that seals on the Pribilof Islands off Alaska were being inhumanely and indiscriminately slaughtered.
The president of American Airlines, George A. Spater, has notified the system's 35,000 employes that another workforce reduction "has begun."

WASHINGTON, July 14 -Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, pressing Israel's repeated requests for more American Phantom fighter-bombers, today accused Secretary of State William P. Rogers of helping "to make the Soviet Union a major Middle Eastern power."

WASHINGTON, July 14 -On July 14, 1789, the day of French independence, the streets of Paris rang with the sound of gunshot. Today French embassies around the world observed Bastille Day, but the only sounds were of corks popping from thousands of champagne bottles.

On the chance that a new open-door policy may have been initiated by a United States table-tennis team, an intrepid impresario is making an effort to get into mainland China with one of his six ice shows.

In South Africa whites either accept the immorality of the racist system whilst enjoying the world's highest standard of living, or oppose the system and suffer harassment and police surveillance. There is no neutral position.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that "substantial progress" had been made in ridding the midtown area of street solicitation by prostitutes since a police crackdown began last week.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The new welfare reform bill, if passed, will provide the munificent total of $2,400 a year for a family of four, providing the family meets the work rules and survives the other red tape in which the program will be wrapped.

Hell hath no fury like a women's liberationist scorned, and yesterday two of them were furious over reports that President Nixon, Secretary of state William P. Rogers and Henry A. Kissinger, the Presidential adviser, had made jokes about the recently formed National Women's Political Caucus.

NEW HAVEN -- For the first time in its long male history, Yale College last month graduated women -- 182 in a class of 1,132. Called superwomen when first admitted two years ago as transfer students, they have frequently scored higher academically than their male classmates.

Contrary to popular opinion, a literary reputation is one of the hardest things in the world to lose. Once among the elect, a novelist is as difficult to impeach as a President. There are some who receive large advances on the strength a string of failures because somewhere, early in their careers, they had a single success.
We read with great interest the July 8 news article by Richard Phalon on efforts under way to rid the harbor of debris.
" Show a little tenderness!" Irving Clayton pleaded yesterday as he waved a jar marked "Phoenix House" near the face of an oblivious passer-by on Fifth Avenue near 53d Street.

TAMTHONG, South Vietnam, July 8 -- One year after the allied attack on Cambodia swept them into the Indochina war, the Vietnamese settlers in Cambodia who fled the fighting there have put down new roots in South Vietnam and, despite the hardships, say they want to stay.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 14 -The Chinese Nationalist Government here appears almost resigned to losing its seat in the United Nations. It plans to fight to the end but is already contemplating the aftermath of defeat.
Consumers are not ready to accept the almost checkless society that bankers and some businesses would like.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -When leaders of the Communications Workers of America asked members sanction the strike that began today against the Bell System, the request was made over a network of 65 television stations.
The doubling of classroom space at Queens College is proposed in the master plan for the Flushing institution, which was released yesterday. The cost was put at $140-million.
The Federal Trade Commission's constantly widening area of interest now actively includes that ever-popular form of advertising: the product endorsement.
LAKENHEATH, England, July 14 -- Capt. Thomas S. Culver was reprimanded today and fined $1,000 for taking part in an antiwar demonstration.
DENVER, July 14 -- Bent Larsen of Denmark obtained a postponement today of his chess match tomorrow with Bobby Fischer of the United States because of illness.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Telephone service remained virtually unimpaired today as about 400,000 members of the Communications Workers of America began a nationwide strike against the Bell System.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- It could almost have been predicted that the delegates to the National Women's Political Caucus in Washington last weekend would boo and heckle Dr. Benjamin Spock as a "sexist."

During the Spingold Knockout Team Championship in Chicago next week, many of the top-ranked experts will be considering their chances of representing the United States in the World Team Olympiad in Miami next year.

LONDON, July 14 -- With some of its members wearing top hats and cutaway coats, the American Bar Association began its London meeting with unaccustomed pageantry today in ancient Westminster Hall, the birthplace of England's earliest courts.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 14 -- Ken Legler of the host Larchmont Yacht Club and Ned Nunes of Belle Haven Club at Greenwich, Conn., won the Lightning Class races, which, because of too much wind, were the only ones the juniors could sail on Long Island Sound today.
Forty-two students who "walked out" of the public school system graduated yesterday from the New York Urban League Street Academy Program and are bound for colleges across the country.

When Mrs. C. Westcott Gallop Jr. of Wayne, Ill., showed a dog in competition for the first time, she was not yet old enough to qualify for junior showmanship. She was 9 and the rules say a child must be at least 10 to enter either the novice or junior classes.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy accused President Nixon and the American Medical Association today of forming "a marriage of convenience" opposed to meaningful reform of the nation's health care system.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 (AP) -- United States and South Vietnamese troops with bulldozers and tanks began clearing a large wooded and scrub-brush area north of here today to permit farmers to return to land that had long served as a Vietcong stronghold.
A collection of stolen rare books was recovered last night by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation at a Queens motel near Kennedy International Airport, the F.B.I. reported.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 14 -- The question of Australian relations with Communist China is shaping up as the major issue on which the next national elections will be fought.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 14 -Jordan announced today that her troops had been battling Palestinian commandos in the northern hills since yesterday in an attempt to push them away from inhabited areas.
The bond market meandered through a session that was extremely quiet for a Wednesday yesterday and wound up just about where it started. Interest rates thus showed no significant change.

CAIRO, July 14 -- Relations between Egypt and Jordan, alternately warm and frigid over the last 15 years, were cooling fast today as a result of Egyptian anger over the new drive by the Jordanian Army against Palestinian guerrilla encampments.

HONOLULU, July 14 (AP) -- Pushed by a 20-knot northeast wind, the 73-foot ketch, Windward Passage, sailed past Diamond Head to become the first yacht to finish the trans-Pacific yacht race, finishing at 8:09 P.M. yesterday, Hawaii time.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -House subcommittee investigators charged today that an official of the United States Postal Service had committed himself to awarding a$3.4-million job evaluation contract to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation before sending out requests for competitive bids.

Elected officials, civic leaders and residents of eastern Queens argued yesterday before the City Planning Commission against construction of three 32-story apartment buildings on a small part of the Glen Oaks golf course.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- David Mieher, news director for television station WLBT, Jackson, Miss., testified at a Federal Communications Commission hearing today that his station had followed standard news-service guidelines in identifying persons in its news broadcasts.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- Cliff Richey, Arthur Ashe and Clark Graebner, three of the top-ranking American players, were knocked out of the $50,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament in the second round today.
HALIFAX, N.S., July 14 -- Ted Hood's Robin became the official winner of the 14th biennial Marblehead-to-Halifax yacht race today when time ran out on all the other prospective challengers.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -Members of Young Americans for Freedom, a conservative student organization, demonstrated today across the street from the White House against the admission of the Communist China to the United Nations.

BOSTON, July 14 -- The Justice Department was reported today to be planning to ask a Federal grand jury here to hand down a criminal indictment against Neil Sheehan, a reporter for The New York Times, in connection with the revelation of the Pentagon papers.

I compliment The Times and John Noble Wilford for the recent series, "Nation's Energy Crisis." In a debate normally dominated by extremists on one side or the other, all loudly shouting their projections of doomsday unless this or that policy is immediately adopted, it is comforting to find some calmer heads who can sort out the problems and arguments clearly and dispassionately.
PARIS, July 14 -- The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development forecast today continued slack in the United States economy over the next year and a deteriorating trade balance.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -Representative Wright Patman called on the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation today to furnish "hard evidence" that it had exhausted all other avenues for loans before his committee voted on the Administration bill to provide Government loan guarantees.

Into the brave new world of environmental litigation enters a book intended to give lawyers and laymen a knowledge of the legal weapons with which to combat the various forms of pollution that are, in Ralph Nader's introduction, "more than something smelly and ugly," but rather "a silent, lethal long-range form of violence."

JACKSON LAKE, Wyo., July 14 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan indicated today that he would probably support President Nixon's plan to convert the aid to dependent children welfare program into a program for guaranteed annual income for poor families.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -Hubert Humphrey, a former Chief of Protocol in sneakers and about 2,000 others ate catfish hushpuppies and watermelon at a gasoline station parking lot three blocks from the Capitol last night.

DETROIT, July 14 -- The 1971 All-Star Game turned out to be a good show, with the American League finally winning one, 6-4. It also demonstrated, indirectly and by contrast, a deep baseball problem that had been getting quiet but persistent attention among officials from Commissioner Bowie Kuhn down.

BIG SUR, Calif. -- A girl hitchhiked through here the other day, carrying a pack with the words "Boy Scouts of America" stamped on it. But the "Boy Scouts" had been crossed out and the word "Freaks" written in.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -Senator Harold E. Hughes of Iowa is expected to announce at a Capital Hill news conference tomorrow that he will not be a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

MOSCOW, July 14 -- Soviet readers, still curious about how it was possible for several American newspapers to publish secret Pentagon papers on Vietnam without the Government's approval, were today given a conspiratorial explanation that reflects some current Soviet thinking about America.
A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the city must give up its traditional examinations for selecting school principals because the tests discriminated against blacks and Puerto Ricans.
PARIS, July 14 -- The West German central bank is determined not to show a monthly increase in its dollar holdings during the period of the floating mark.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Navy and the Marine Corps announced today an amnesty program for drug abusers who volunteer for rehabilitation, but they said two-time violators could face disciplinary action.
Observations with California radio telescopes have, for the first time, detected a chemical molecule beyond the Milky Way Galaxy, or star system, of which the sun, earth and other planets are a part.
The two largest-selling mini-buses in the United States are "grossly inadequate" when it comes to safety, the magazine Consumer Reports charged yesterday.

The General Host Corporation announced yesterday it has received valid tenders for more than 80 per cent of the outstanding voting securities of the Cudahy Company, based on preliminary calculations received from the tender agent.
TRENTON, July 14 (AP) -- A state appeals court overturned today a ruling by the State Banking Commissioner granting the Union County Trust Company the right to open a branch office in Eatontown.

Radio station WLIB-AM, which caters mainly to New York's black community, has been sold for $1.9-million to a group headed by Percy E. Sutton, Manhattan Borough President, and Clarence B. Jones, editor and publisher of The Amsterdam News.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14 -- The White House said today that President Nixon was prepared to override a recommendation by the House Armed Services Committee against his proposed transfer of more than 4,000 acres of Camp Pendleton to the State of California for recreational use.
RABAT, Morocco, July 14 -King Hassan II received a special Egyptian envoy tonight after having kept him waiting for two days.

" I couldn't understand how I could breathe. It wasn't fresh air but at least re was air. I lost all track of time. I felt the sweat running down my face and it was tickling me. I had a strong desire to scratch my nose, but I couldn't move my hand. I cried again, wondering at the same time why I didn't feel hungry.

An Administration official said yesterday that Japan was moving "at long last" toward a significant reduction of her import barriers, but asserted that her restrictions on foreign investment were still far from liberal.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -The Nixon Administration proposed yesterday that any limit on campaign spending cover expenditures for direct mail as well as radio, television and newspaper advertising.

Displaying that curious mixture of anger and resignation that characterizes the horseplayer, New Yorkers got their first chance yesterday to make a full range of wagering on the "flats" at nine of the city's 13 offtrack betting offices.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, July 16 -- The Nationalist Chinese Government today lodged a strong protest with the United States against President Nixon's plan to visit Communist China.
Although volume was higher, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed unchanged yesterday.
Higher costs and lower prices reduced profits of the Aluminum Company of America by 23.9 per cent in the second quarter and 33.2 per cent in the half.

The Joint Federal Strike Force Against Organized Crime is investigating a report that a Yonkers Raceway executive and a state-appointed track official won more than $6,000 on a suspicious race that touched off a riot at the Yonkers harness track on June 7.

Our Mayor John Lindsay now proposes a massive program to diminish noise in dear old Fun City. This comes as a disappointment when we recall how Mr. Lindsay at the start of his term as Mayor jettisoned a New York City Code -- initiated during Mayor Wagner's incumbency -- to prohibit blowing of automobile horns.

ROME -- When President Nixon gloomily reflected last week on whether the United States was destined to emulate ancient Rome and fade away in a welter of decadence, the people of this city were given particular food for thought. For, since the days of its Republican and Caesarian grandeur, Rome has declined with a kind of baroque solemnity and even today is entering on new and perplexing troubles.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 15 -- The Garden City Hotel, which for almost a century was the center for such diverse activities as quiet weddings, gala balls and raucous political conventions, is closing its doors.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Selective Service System is planning to go ahead with the 1972 draft lottery early next month regardless of whether Congress acts by then to extend the draft law, officials said today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- Ken Rosewall, playing brilliantly at the age of 36, defeated Rod Laver, 5-7, 6-3 6-1, today to advance to the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Washington Star tennis tournament.
Lou Piniella got even with the Cleveland Indians last night.

Three people have drowned at Jones and Robert Moses Beaches as the Long Island State Park Commission continues to spend over $160,000 per week in police personnel and equipment, rather than rehire all the qualified lifeguards.
" I remember when you'd bust a gut to have Kate Smith introduce one of your songs on her show. Now it's a record or nothing."

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 15 -- President Nixon said tonight that he would visit China before next May at the invitation of Premier Chou En-lai to "seek the normalization of relations between the two countries and also to exchange views on questions of concern to the two sides."

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, disclosed today that the form of revenue sharing that he is thinking of supporting would involve financial aid only to those cities and counties that could prove their need for it.

Writing as a pro-Arab organization's executive member, James Jones (letter, July 7) boasts of an attack last month against a tanker bound for Israel, predicting a Red Sea "closed to non-Arab shipping . . . a closed sea (mare clausum)." All this would stem, he claims, from "the foolishness of our Government's support of Israel. . . . "

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -Bruce Crampton of Australia fashioned a five-under-par 66 today to take the first-round lead in the $150,000 Western open golf tournament but Lee Trevino warned, "I'm not out of it yet."
AUSTIN, Tex., July 15 -Texas oil production will decline a bit further in August. Today's proration hearing noted lessened demand in evidence submitted by the purchasing companies.

Protasis was the star of the show in the Queens County Chamber of Commerce purse at Aqueduct yesterday. Under the guidance of Chuck Baltazar, the Cragwood Stable filly took the six-furlong test for 3-year-olds by half a length over Sigmund Sommer's Sky Play.
NEWARK, July 15 -- The week-old office of the Newark chapter of the Italian-American Civil Rights League was destroyed by fire early today.
More than a million copies of the paperback edition of "The Pentagon Papers" are in print, according to Bantam Books, the publisher.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 15 -- In his gray sweat suit, Matt Snell watched as the New York Jets ran through their offensive plays.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 15 -- David M. Kennedy, President Nixon's roving ambassador, returned today from an extended trip to the Far East. He will report to the President tomorrow on his efforts to obtain voluntary restraints from South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong on textile exports to the United States.

PARIS, July 15 -- David K. E. Bruce, the United States representative at the Vietnam peace talks, told the Communists today that their latest proposal for a settlement left their objectives unchanged and set "far-reaching" and "harsh" conditions.
The Monsanto Company reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter rose 10 per cent while sales grew 3 per cent.

TORONTO, July 15 (Canadian Press) -- The Ontario Securities Commission today extended a 15-day trading ban on shares of I.O.S., Ltd., to July 27, when it will hold another hearing to determine whether trading should be resumed.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- The Treasury Department said today the West Coast Commodity Exchange's plan for trading in gold futures is illegal and will not be permitted to operate.
Croswell Bowen, for many years a staff writer for The New Yorker and an author of books on crime, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack at his home, 6 East 76th Street. He was 66 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A group of officials of some of the nation's largest corporations expressed opposition today to proposed increases in the sales commissions charged by member brokers of the New York Stock Exchange.
Local, interstate and overseas telephone service functioned here normally yesterday despite a nationwide strike against the Bell System by 400,000 members of the Communications Workers of America.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 -David Callahan, president of the West Coast Commodity Exchange said today that the exchange would proceed with its plans to trade in gold futures despite a statement by the United States Treasury that it would be illegal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 15 -- Eighteen of Peking's supporters called today for the General Assembly to recognize Communist China, this fall as one of the Big Five powers in the Security Council and to expel Nationalist China from all United Nations bodies.

PARIS, July 15 -- The Benelux countries -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- have signed a trade treaty with the Soviet Union that could help break down barriers between the Soviet Union and the Common Market.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Previously classified information read into the record of a House Government Operations subcommittee today disclosed that 26,843 nonmilitary Vietcong insurgents and sympathizers were "neutralized" in 14 months through Operation Phoenix, a counterinsurgency program in South Vietnam financed by the United States.
In the menus below dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

Jimmy Helms flew in from the fourth "Olympiad of opening Monday night of his four-week engagement at Shepheard's in the Drake Hotel, 56th Street and Park Avenue, bringing with him a medallion for "best singer" at the festival, where he competed with entrants from 41 countries.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -Representative Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, said today he would vote for the Administration's bill to guarantee loans to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation if the committee decided action was vital before Aug. 6 to save the company from bankruptcy.
Mayor Lindsay visited three public housing projects under construction in two boroughs yesterday, and praised the City Housing Authority for achieving a "record number of housing starts during June."

AMMAN, Jordan, July 15 -As Jordanian troops battled Arab commandos today for the third day, a Government spokesman announced that the army had dislodged the guerrillas from a dozen sites in the Ajlun-Jarash area of northern Jordan.
MOSCOW, July 15 (AP) -- The police early today arrested 45 Jews who had been holding a hunger strike in Moscow's central telegraph office, Jewish sources reported.
Lindsey Hill Spight, a founder of the broadcast representation firm of Greig, Blair Spight, predecessor of John Blair Co., died Monday in Orinda, Calif. His age was 68.

A Queens savings and loan association, with the support of a group representing 174 savings and loan associations in the state, yesterday challenged the constitutionality of a 1953 statute requiring savings and loan associations to pay franchise taxes to both the state and the city at a higher rate than those levied against commercial banks.
When Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith's initial public offering was devoured by hungry investors last month, everyone assumed the floodgates were open for a spate of other brokerage-house issues.
OTTAWA -- Canadian art has struck a nationalist note here with an exhibition in the National Gallery of Canada called "True Patriot Love."

WASHINGTON, July 15 -Three young former drug users testified today that amphetamines were easy to obtain illicitly and that their overuse was often a first step toward incarceration in a mental hospital.

When they begin practicing tomorrow at Trenton Speedway for Sunday's Northern 300, drivers and mechanics of the country's best stock-car teams will be searching for some esoteric little secret to give them some advantage. Often it is something trivial, but many of these Southern crews treat it seriously until it is tried and dropped. This secret in stock-car racing is called "the tip."
When a South Vietnamese lawyer who heads a small antiwar movement scheduled a reception in Saigon recently, the police kept all but one of the guests from entering.
For any little boy just old enough to venture out by himself, any sortie into the streets of Manhattan can be a disaster.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Henry A. Kissinger's secret visit to Peking last week, announced tonight by President Nixon, capped two years of overtures by the United States to China, based on the Presidents conviction that Peking must become a full-fledged member of the international community.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (Reuters) -- The State Department expressed regret today over yesterday's announcement by the new left-wing Icelandic Government that it planned to close down the American-manned Atlantic-alliance base at Keflavik.
The City Health Department, reversing a long-standing policy, has decided to make public the names of restaurants that do not promptly correct violations of the Health Code.
A brisk market rally in leading issues ran out of fuel yesterday. The Dow-Jones industrial average, ahead by 4 1/2 points at 11 A.M., finished at 888.87 with a loss of 2.34 points.

Dan Wagoner's sense of fun ripples happily from the Dada calculated lunacy of "Brambles" to the friendly movement humor of "July 13," his newest group work. The piece was given its premiere funnily enough on July 14 at the New York University School of Education and is a warm sportive dance for himself, Mirjam Berns, Cathy Boyd, Emmy Devine, Sally Hess and Judith Moss.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 15 -- The senior sailors, returning to Larchmont Yacht Club's 73d Race Week after three days devoted to the juniors, finally got some favorable weather on Long Island Sound today.
The publisher of Time-Life Books has become the first woman vice president in the 48 years of Time Inc. She is Miss Joan Manley, 39 years old, who last year became the corporation's first publisher.

YONKERS, July 15 -- Albatross, a 3-year-old pacer Stanley Dancer believes "may turn out to be the best ever," will seek his ninth straight victory and 10th in 11 starts this season in the 17th annual Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.

John Mack Carter, president of Downe Publishing, confirmed yesterday that he had devised a special circulation plan for American Home magazine, which is designed to build up urban readership while cutting down on the rural.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Federal Power Commission established today substantially higher rates for natural gas produced in the Rocky Mountain region in a decision that may presage higher gas prices for consumers throughout the country.
Newswire accounts of a United States proposal for a Vietnam ceasefire lifted some bond prices early yesterday but most later settled back to levels reflecting little or no gain.

Msgr. John M. Oesterreicher objects (letter July 6) that I failed to offer a single argument regarding his May 26 Op-Ed item on Jerusalem. My response of June 25 was indeed a broad indictment of manifold violations against the Geneva Conventions.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 15 -Syria began efforts today to end the fighting between the Jordanian Army and the fedayeen.

Walter B. Degnan, president of the council that represents most of the city's 4,000 school administrators, urged yesterday that licensing tests for school supervisors here be revamped to satisfy a Federal judge who banned hundreds of such tests on Wednesday because he said they discriminated against blacks and Puerto Ricans.

HOUSTON, July 15 -- Overcoming a discouraging start, which found them four runs behind in the first two innings the New York Mets struck back and ended their six-game losing streak tonight by beating the Houston Astros, 9-4.

The nation's money supply spurted during the week ended July 7, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday. The increase of $3.2-billion to a daily average of $228.4-billion came despite the efforts of the central bank to tighten the money market so as to slow the rate of monetary expansion.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 15 Bob Benning, often a spotter for the American Broadcasting Company when pro tour events are televised, took the lead in the New Jersey open golf championship today. A. second round of 69, one under par for the 6,502-yard Montclair Golf Club course, gave the Plainfield Country Club professional a three-stroke margin with a 36hole aggregate of 139.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 15 -- The Chilean Central Bank announced today that two large foreign banks -- the Bank of America and the Bank of London and South America -- had agreed to sell their operations here to the nationalized banking system.

The Bowery Savings Bank announced yesterday the election of Miss Dolores J. Morrissey as vice president in charge of the bank's bond portfolio and money position. She will be the bank's first woman vice president.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -For the eighth straight year, the Republican Elephants tonight trounced the Democratic Donkeys in the annual Congressional baseball game, held at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -The Securities and Exchange Commission today endorsed legislation that would exempt certain variable annuities from a requirement that they refund to purchasers, at any time within 45 days of their purchase, the full value of their investment plus any sales charges.
Trafalgar House Investments, Ltd., announced yesterday in London that its bid terms for acquisition of the Cunard Steam-Ship Company, Ltd., were equal to 200 pence, or about $4.80 a share.

Area A -- Anglers are doing extremely well with bluefish along Barnegat Ridge, about 22 miles south of Manasquan Inlet. The choppers, averaging 8 to 10 pounds, are responding to chumming. School tuna also are being encountered in the same region.

After a few faltering starts Biedermeier may indeed gain a foothold this year in the collecting enthusiams of New Yorkers. Or so Macy's hopes in what is thestore's third attempt in a decade to revive the early 19th-century neoclassic style with a large group of German and Austrian examples of the mode.

The city's Human Rights Commission yesterday criticized all parties concerned in the removal of Dr. Arnold H. Einhorn as chief of pediatrics at Lincoln Hospital, last November, but concluded that his removal had not been made because of ethnic discrimination.
Thick, sticky oil was washed up on the Coney Island beach last night from Bayonne, N. J., and on other city beaches where nearly 40,000 gallons of oil spilled from a Navy ship on Wednesday.
At 10:35 A.M. yesterday, to the imperative sound of alarm bells and klaxons, 2,500 occupants of the 38story Seagram Building began filing out of their offices.

NEWARK, July 15 -- The bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey and all the unions that represent its employes agreed today "to scrap the old bible of work rules" in an effort to save the ailing carrier, which has lost $100-million in the last 12 years.

The Police Department's Internal Affairs Division is investigating allegations by a former policeman dismissed for accepting a $100 bribe that it is a common practice for Harlem policemen to accept illegal payoffs from heroin dealers.

Some very good ballets danced less well than usual and a minor work that gained enormously from its excellent performance, made up American Ballet Theater's newest mixed bill of the season Wednesday night at the State Theater.
A 32-year-old woman was found slain in her Greenwich Village apartment last night while her husband was performing in a play in Central Park.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 (AP) -- The allied commands today issued casualty summaries for last week listing 29 Americans, 238 South Vietnamese and 1,105 North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops as killed in action.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Enthusiasts from all parts of North America are converging on this city to compete in what promises to be the biggest bridge tournament ever held anywhere. It is the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships, which begin here tomorrow and continue for 10 days.

AMHERST, Mass., July 15 (AP) -- Jim Plunkett, the Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback from Stanford who was the National Football League's top draft choice this year, signed a multiyear contract with the New England Patriots tonight.
Dr. Theodore Powell was dismissed last night as president of the City University's Kingsborough Community College, effective immediately.
James W. Brady, publisher of Women's Wear Daily, resigned yesterday to become a vice president of the Hearst Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -Senate and House versions of a major financial program to help train doctors and other health professionals will go to a conference committee, perhaps next week, following passage of two Senate bills yesterday.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 15 -- Gov. George C. Wallace's political problems at home were intensified this week by a break between the Governor and his Lieutenant Governor, Jere Beasley.
WASHINGTON, Friday July 16 -- The Government sought to head off a railroad strike scheduled to begin at 6 o'clock this morning.
The New York Stock Exchange announced major revisions last night in the rules governing the financial structure of its member firms.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Six years and six months after it filed suit, the Government brought the United Mine Workers union to trial today for alleged violations of a Federal law that is supposed to guarantee democratic procedures in organized labor.
The Police Department said yesterday that it would continue to raid sex shows in the Times Square and Greenwich Village areas as part of its crackdown on prostitution and pornography.

Three policemen denied yesterday that they attended a meeting in June, 1967, during which another policeman allegedly told them that only those who picked up graft from gamblers would share in the graft.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Federal Reserve Board approved today an increase in the discount rate to 5 per cent from 4 3/4 per cent.

MILWAUKEE, July 15 -- Moderates in the 2.8-million-member Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod scored victories on two crucial issues today at a convention that has pitted them against their president, the Rev. Dr. Jacob A. O. Preus, and his conservative supporters.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, on the verge of bankruptcy as a result of huge cost overruns on military programs and delays in building its L-1011 Tristar airbus for commercial airlines, says that nothing can save it but a Government loan guarantee of $250 million. Powerful pressures are being brought to bear on Congress to grant this loan guarantee.
The manufacturers of plastic products and their trade association sued in State Supreme Court yesterday to bar New York City from levying a special 2-cent tax on most plastic containers sold here.

I applaud your June 28 editorial "The Paper Jungle." Your criticism of the back office paper mess in Wall Street, "the unreliability of the accounts of many brokerage firms" and of their auditors is entirely warranted. Certainly, drastic and immediate changes are essential if we are to have any possibility of avoiding a recurrence of the 1970 crisis -- probably with even greater intensity and devastation.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- The Nixon Administration has moved to strengthen the Subversive Activities Control Board, which has been under fire for lack of work, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- In a move described as a first priority in the development of an all-volunteer force, the Army Chief of Staff, Gen. William C. Westmoreland, announced today a decentralization of management and control of training in the field.

Despite great advances in medical science, heart attacks, strokes and cancer continue to exact a heavy toll among Americans. Details on these and other major killers and cripplers were listed yesterday in a study released by the National Health Education Committee.
Underlying the current drive against obscenity here, with its mid-Manhattan raids, is a tinge of irony.
Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle, who has headed the Archdiocese of Washington since 1948, has submitted his resignation to Pope Paul VI, but apparently does not really want to retire.

NEW DELHI, July 15 (AP) -Foreign Trade Minister I. N. Mishra complained in Parliament yesterday that the Motion Pictures Export Association of America had not kept the terms of its contract to popularize Indian films in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The biggest percentage of its population on welfare and the rate of increase in the District of Columbia is running nearly 60 per cent above last year, a Department of Health, Education and Welfare survey shows.

Dave May -- not to be confused with Carlos, Lee, Jerry or Rudy May -- has hit three ninth-inning home runs in Milwaukee's five games at Yankee Stadium this season. The first two spoiled shutouts for Steve Kline and Mel Stottlemyre.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -Senator Robert Dole, the Republcan National Chairman, said today that any decision to prosecute criminally the distributor of the Pentagon papers or the newspapers that printed them could be politically harmful to the Republican party.

The South Street Seaport Museum put on public display yesterday 14 tons of gear -- including a windlass, a capstan and davits -- that will be used in the restoration of the steel-hulled square-rigger Wavertree.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans urged today that programs to halt pollution be weighed carefully -- and slowly -- to determine if they will be too costly or ineffective.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted today in favor of proposals to withhold military and economic assistance from Pakistan and Greece.
After rising the day before, copper futures prices dropped yesterday in commodity trading despite the fact that the copper strike has not ended.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans urged today that programs to halt pollution be weighed carefully -- and slowly -- to determine if they will be too costly or ineffective.

President Nixon's announcement last night that Henry Kissinger had visited Peking would have been sensation enough, but the President's revelation that he himself has been invited to Peking by Premier Chou En-lai and that he has accepted that invitation is simply astounding. A few months ago, it was considered remarkable that the Chinese invited an American Ping-Pong team to their country with American reporters accompanying it.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -Senator Harold E. Hughes of Iowa withdrew from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination today after having implied to his staff that he would not be displeased if they went to work for Senator George McGovern of South Dakota.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -Department of Labor statistics released today show that unemployment among Vietnam veterans aged 20 to 29 increased substantially in the second quarter of 1971 over the same period last year.

WASHINGTON -- In December, 1970, several dozen victims of the fullest automated war of our time were asked to record their memories in drawings. They were Laotian refugees from the devastated Plaine des Jarres in northeastern Laos who were at that time residing in camps around Vientiane.

UNITED NATIONS, New York, July 15 -- Secretary General Thant welcomed President Nixon's announcement tonight that he would visit China as opening "a new chapter in the history of international relations."

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Following is a chart comparing peace proposals by President Nixon in June, 1969, and October, 1970, with Vietcong positions in 1969 and July, 1971. Mr. Nixon has not yet replied to the latest Vietcong proposal.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 16 (AP) -- Two thirds of a 1,500-man South Vietnamese task force pulled back to South Vietnam yesterday from a fruitless, one-week drive into eastern Cambodia.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -The Senate, acceding to Administration wishes, refused today to accept a House-approved limitation of $20,000 on subsidy payments to individual farmers.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- Blacks were catching up with whites in some economic and social areas in the United States between 1960 and 1968, but fell further behind in several key measurements of income and family life, a Government-financed study showed today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted major increases today over President Nixon's budget recommendations for urban housing and veterans' medical care.

President Nixon, in his "journey for peace" to Peking, will seek to break down a great wall of hostility that has separated the United States from Communist China for 21 years. His task will not be an easy one.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 (AP) -- Gen. Duong Van Minh, a possible contender for the Presidency of South Vietnam, charged today that American support of President Nguyen Van Thieu could prevent a fair and honest election on Oct. 3.

Penny Payne's earliest memories are of watching her mother, Mrs. Frank J. Payne, at work as a dress designer and trying to imitate her.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Apparently oblivious to a wave of ridicule that arose over a similar effort about a year ago, a Federal interagency committee is considering eliminating the word "poverty" from official reports.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 15 -- Influenced by Jerry Shay's slow recovery from a severely broken right leg last season, the Giants acquired an experienced defensive tackle, Roland Lakes, from the San Francisco 49ers today in exchange for their No. 2 choice in the 1973 college draft.
Following is the transcript of a statement yesterday by President Nixon on United States-China relations as recorded by The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, July 15 -The Senate, acceding to Administration wishes, refused today to accept a House-approved limitation of $20,000 on subsidy payments to individual farmers.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- Blacks were catching up with whites in some economic and social areas in the United States between 1960 and 1968, but fell further behind in several key measurements of income and family life, a Government-financed study showed today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted major increases today over President Nixon's budget recommendations for urban housing and veterans' medical care.

President Nixon, in his "journey for peace" to Peking, will seek to break down a great wall of hostility that has separated the United States from Communist China for 21 years. His task will not be an easy one.
