A smoky subway fire forced 900 rush-hour riders to flee on ladders and catwalks yesterday morning in the Lexington Avenue tunnel south of 14th Street. Eleven passengers received hospital attention, and one of them was admitted for observation after a sweltering trek to daylight.

Behind locked doors on the fourth floor of Brooklyn State Hospital a voluntary design program has just been completed that has proven therapeutic for the patients and the "single most important project so far" for the Parsons School of Design students involved.

The Yankees made impressive progress on two reclamation projects last night. They began reasserting their territorial rights to the right-field seats, and Lindy McDaniel showed another sign that he might yet reassert his position as a highly reliable relief pitcher.
Nine companies offered their shares publicly for the first time this week, but investors were reluctant to buy them.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Who but Henry A. Kissinger could have slipped into mainland China, arranged a chat for President Nixon with Premier Chou En-lai and Chairman Mao Tse-tung, and kept it all a secret?

LANSING, Mich., July 16 -- Gov. William G. Milliken will order a program to improve the lives of Michigan's 16,854 Indians on Tuesday when he resolves a fishing rights dispute among three tribes and groups of angry sportsmen.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York warned yesterday that a "significantly increasing" number of counterfeit $10 and $20 Federal Reserve notes had been circulated in the last two weeks in the Second Federal Reserve District, which includes New York State, northern New Jersey and Fairfield County in Connecticut.

A new record system called stereoquadraphonic that permits four channels of sound to be reproduced from a two-track source has been developed by Columbia Broadcasting System Laboratories under commission from Columbia Records.

Although weary city workers cleared Coney Island of an oil spillage yesterday morning, incoming tides and unfavorable winds dumped so much more oil on the beach later in the day that it will probably be closed to swimmers again today.

JACKSON, Miss., July 16 -- Mississippi has closed two major lakes to commercial fishing following a report from the Food and Drug Administration office in Atlanta that fish from the lakes contained pesticides as much as three times above the danger limit.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 16 -- Chinese in influential Government and business circles here at first reacted with disbelief to President Nixon's announcement that he would visit Communist China and then with dismay.

PARIS, July 16 -- France is determined to show that a speculative influx of capital can be fought with an arsenal of exchange controls and remains absolutely committed to maintaining the franc's present fixed relationship with the dollar, Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing said today.

WASHINGTON, July 16--President Nixon appeared today to have significantly defused criticism of the Indochina war and outflanked his potential Presidential challengers with his announcement that he would visit China.
LONDON, July 16 -- Western European Governments today welcomed President Nixon's decision to visit China and said they hoped it would contribute toward world peace and stability.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Nixon's success in arranging a trip to China evoked the widespread judgment here today that American policy, in Mao Tse-tung's phrase, was taking a great leap forward.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- Lee Trevino fell out of contention and Bobby Nichols and Dick Lotz moved into a tie for the second-round lead at 138 today in the $150,000 Western open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Food and Drug Administration and a panel of the National Academy of Sciences have recommended tighter controls over two stimulant drugs, one of which has been widely used to treat children.

PEKING, July 16 -- Chinese officials expressed pleasure today over the planned visit of President Nixon, but offered no information about the talks between Henry A. Kissinger and Premier Chou En-lai that arranged it.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- John Newcombe of Australia downed Andrew Gimeno of Spain today and moved into the semifinal round of the $50,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament.
" I don't mind doing a little light porter work," said Eugene Hudson yesterday as he waited in line at a Brooklyn state employment office for his $68.35 welfare check.

HOUSTON, July 16 -- The sort of versatile futility that made the New York Mets famous long before they acquired the normal cares of struggling pennant contenders reappeared in full glory tonight in a 9-4 loss to the Houston Astros.

DURHAM, N. C., July 16 -- One of the more bizarre moments in international track and field -- in which a runner misjudged the finish line by a full lap in the 5,000-meter run -- marred another impressive victory by Steve Prefontaine during the Pan-Africa-United States dual meet today.
Joe Namath arrived in New York yesterday and promised to report to the Jets' training camp tomorrow along with 26 other experienced players.
The House Banking Committee voted yesterday in Washington to slice four days of hearings on legislation in an effort to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy.

DENVER, July 16 (UPI) -- The Internal Revenue Service has filed tax liens totaling more than $8-million against the King Resources Company and its subsidiaries. The liens were filed earlier in the week but did not come to light until today.

What is there to say about the American Ballet Theater's "Mendelssohn Symphony," Dennis Nahat's ballet, which had its premiere Thursday night at the State Theater? That Mr. Nahat, a 24-year-old soloist with the company who has previously choreographed three other ballets, has done it again?
MIAMI, July 16 (UPI) -- Knight Newspapers, Inc., announced today record earnings for the second quarter and the first six months of this year.

LONDON, July 16 (UPI) -- Ford of Britain had just lost the biggest production contract in British automotive history. The company spokesman turned up his hands and said, "That's history now. We've got to move on to other things."

The Discount Corporation of New York, the big Government bond dealer that until recently was notably shy about disclosing its quarterly profits, reported yesterday that its earnings declined to $294,473, or 59 cents a share in the second quarter, down 23 per cent from the $382,475, or 77 cents a share it earned in the second quarter of 1970.
AMHERST, Mass., July 16 (AP) -- Joe Kapp, quarterback for the New England Patriots, packed his bags and quit the team today, refusing to sign a National Football League standard players' contract.

BERLIN, July 16 (AP) -- East Germany has freed six Americans who had been in its jails from six to 22 months on various charges, among them assaulting border guards, hostile provocations and trying to help Germans escape.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the first major company in the industry to issue midyear results, had its best profit performance in the second quarter and first half in five years, according to yesterday's report.

With Federal Reserve Board approval, seven Federal Reserve Banks this week have raised from 4 3/4 per cent to 5 per cent the discount rate they charge member banks in their districts. The probability is that the other five regional Federal Reserve Banks will follow suit next week.
This is relative to two statements made in a recent news story from Athens, "Greek-Albanian Links Resume After 31 Years."

A Federal indictment charged here yesterday that eight men, including a reputed member of organized crime, conducted a conspiracy to distribute millions of shares of worthless stock throughout the country.
Federal agents have been secretly recording conversations in the dining room at Yonkers Raceway for well over a month.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 16 -- Officials at the Western White House said today that President Nixon's trip to China could be made late this year at the earliest and that he would confer with Mao Tse-tung as well as Premier Chou En-lai.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The House sent to the Senate yesterday a $2.32-billion, one-year program authorization for the Atomic Energy Commission. It did so after refusing to halt an underground test explosion in Alaska.
The South Carolina Electric and Gas Company reported yesterday a slight decline in first-half net income despite higher operating revenues.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 16 -- When there's wind, there's a sailboat race, as there was today for only the second time for the senior division of Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week, including a race for cruising yachts.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 16 (UPI) -- The Newport festivals were given a lift Wednesday when the City Council approved a resolution authorizing the Mayor to appoint committee to study the future of music festivals in the city.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 16 -- The Garden City Hotel, whose closing was announced yesterday, is not for sale, its owner said today.
WARSAW, July 16 -- President Nixon's announcement of his planned trip to China appeared to create confusion among officials in Eastern Europe and delight among ordinary citizens.
BIARRITZ, France, July 16 (UPI) -- Peter Thomson of Australia shot a three-under-par 66 today to take the second-round lead in the French international open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -- The Food and Drug Administration disclosed yesterday that 204,000 candy bars and 7,100 boxes of candy, most of which have already been sold and presumably eaten, were contaminated with rodents and insects.

MARLBOROUGH, Conn., July 16 -- In the early evening the rattling drums and the shrill fifes had been distinct and moving. But now there were perhaps 100 drummers hammering away and a score or so fifers blowing their hardest, and the sound was deafening -- an artillery barrage with crickets.

The State Commissioner of Human Rights yesterday ordered the Bay Shore, L. I., Fire Department to accept the membership application of a black policeman who has been trying to join the volunteer group for five years.

DETROIT -- Both the collapse of the Chicago Plan for Equal Opportunity and the Department of Labor's announced intention to impose an arrangement in its place are bound to make the debate about "hometown plans" -- of which Chicago is the most prominent example -- grow louder.

HOYLAKE, England, July 16 (UPI) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., upset Mrs. Margaret Court, 6-2, 7-5, today and moved into the final round of the Rothman's North of England tennis tournament.

Mortimer L. Janis, who had been an assistant fur buyer at the Franklin Simon chain of ready-to-wear apparel stores in the nineteen-forties, is returning Aug. 15 as president of the New York-based company. Mr. Janis succeeds Edwin G. Roberts, who will become president of the Dayton Hudson jewelry store chain.
FRANKFURT, West Germany July 16 (UPI) -- A shaky United States dollar slipped to a new low today in heavy trading on the Frankfurt foreign exchange market.

State Housing Commissioner Charles J. Urstadt yesterday criticized the City Housing and Development Administrator, Albert A. Walsh for having promulgated a new rent regulation, and ordered him to rescind it.
WASHINGTON, July 16--The Federal Power Commission approved today sharply higher rates for natural gas produced in the southern Louisiana area, the nation's biggest source of supply.

ALBANY, July 16 -- The state's Environmental Conservation Department today ordered Zoar Valley, a 3,500-acre state park near Buffalo, closed to overnight camping and motorcycling to prevent "irreversible damage" to the park's ecology.

In 1960, following the earthquake which destroyed many Chilean cities, Dr. C. G. Jung wrote: "Even though today's scientists may reject the idea, the earth seems to be in tune with the destructive fury of mankind." Jung was establishing a close relationship between the spirit of mankind and the spirit of the earth, suggesting that the earth has a soul of its own.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the nation's leading manufacturer of earth-moving machinery and a major producer of diesel engines and electric-generator sets, had an increase of nine per cent in profit for the second quarter and 7.52 per cent for the first half, it was reported yesterday from Peoria, Ill., headquarters. Sales for these periods set records.

Say this for "The Brazen Women of Balzac," yesterday's new sex-teaser at the New Embassy Theater: With its color photography, lovely rustic settings and tasteful manor interiors, it's certainly beautiful to look at. Ditto the girls, a hot-eyed covey of belles who swarm around the premises and a group of willing gents.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, proposed tax reductions today for businesses and for low-income individuals but said he would make the cuts absolutely conditional on two other changes in national economic policy.
The Securities and Exchange Commission will now require certification of financial statements filed by banks, the agency announced yesterday in Washington.
As if making up for his lackluster performance in the All-Star game, Oakland's Vida Blue returned to competition in the American League's regular schedule with a fury last night.
A New York City police lieutenant denied yesterday that he ever offered to let a policeman in his command use his attic as a hiding place for graft.
MOSCOW, July 16 -- Western diplomats expressed the view today that the news of President Nixon's plan to visit China had come as a stunning surprise to Soviet leaders.

From its inception, America has been well served by a two-party political system. It has been saved from the turmoil of some multiparty situations such as are now occurring in Italy. The endless wheeling and dealing between a myriad of splinter parties creates an unstable atmosphere.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)--The Senate confirmed today the following nominations by President Nixon:...
The stock market responded early yesterday with a flurry of buying to President Nixon's surprise announcement that he will visit China before next May.
The immediate effect of the strike that began yesterday on the Union Pacific Railroad and the Southern Railway was on rolling freight.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Scientists on the staff of the Offshore/Sea Development Corporation, New York, have succeeded in feeding oysters with mammalian blood.

The growth in deposits at the nation's mutual savings banks set a record last month, but the rate of gain was lower than earlier in the year, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks said yesterday.

Do things go better with Coke? Clothes, for instance? The Coca-Cola Company, which over the years has stamped its name on glasses, trays and lampshades, has figured out a new way to plaster it across the country. This time, the customer is the billboard. Cotton beach pants with the red Coke label and the slogan, "It's the real thing," are the company's newest premium idea.

American apparel manufacturers will ultimately be unable to win the battle against Japanese imports and would be better advised to begin setting up Japanese licensing agreements and joint ventures to cash in on a big potential in Japan, according to an industrial engineer who has spent much time in the Orient.

Douglas M. Johnson, who had been financial vice president of the United Nuclear Corporation, was elected the company's president yesterday by the board of directors following the annual meeting, which was held at the New York Hilton Hotel.

TOKYO, July 16 -- The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest manufacturing concern with annual sales of more than $24-billion, today signed an agreement with ailing Isuzu Motors, Ltd., of Japan to acquire a 34.2 per cent interest in Isuzu.

We regard the news media's handling of the Pentagon papers as weak, inconclusive and confusing to the public. Granted, the media have shown courage and solidarity in defending the freedom of the press in America. However, apart from the admirable efforts of The Times, they have displayed, on the whole, little initiative or incisiveness in clarifying for the public the significance of the information contained in the report.

In sharp contrast to most major banking organizations, the BankAmerica Corporation, parent company of the nation's largest bank, reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter rose 7.4 per cent from last year.
CHATTANOOGA, July 16 (UPI) -- Civil antitrust suits filed by Chattanooga's two daily newspapers against each other were settled today out of court.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 -- Dr. William D. McElroy was named chancellor of the University of California campus at San Diego today and will leave the directorship of the National Science Foundation about the end of this year to take the job.

The Hartford Fire Insurance Company has named William M. Griffin president of Hartford Securities Company, Inc., a new broker-dealer subsidiary. Mr. Griffin is a senior vice president of finance of Hartford Fire.

NORMAN, Okla., July 16 -- Senator Fred R. Harris, the son of an Oklahoma sharecropper, announced today that he was giving up his Senate seat to organize a campaign for the Democratic nomination for President.

HARTFORD, July 16 -- A Federal District Court judge today temporarily restrained Connecticut from enforcing its new one-year residency requirement against applicants for local welfare until a three-judge Federal Court could rule on the law's constitutionality.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange opened higher but closed slightly lower yesterday in slackened trading.

It is important that the misleading letter by J. Sinclair, president of the Fraser Island Defence Organisation, Queensland, Australia, in The Times of July 8, be answered forthwith so that the situation relating to Fraser Island may be placed in its proper perspective.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Democratic party's Commission on Delegate Selection and Party Reform armed itself today for the continuing struggle to bring state parties into compliance with its guidelines before the 1972 National Convention.

The nationwide strike against the Bell System by 400,000 members of the Communications Workers of America and by other unions entered its third day yesterday, with little progress toward settlement but no signs of a deterioration in telephone service.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 16 -- Coleman Zeno was a little nervous about reporting to the New York Giants' training camp but when he discovered it wasn't as arduous as the Grambling College camp, he settled down.

Some people in Wall Street are confident the new package of brokerage commissions now being discussed at hearings in Washington will garner approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission with only minor changes.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- House leaders have set a target date of mid-October for final adjournment of this session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Train crews struck the Union Pacific Railroad and the Southern Railway early today, effectively bringing traffic to a halt on the two lines by the day's end.

CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., July 16 (AP) -- Bobby Unser recorded the fastest official lap in the history of Indianapolis-type car racing today -- 193.444 miles an hour -- to win the pole position for Sunday's $75,000 Michigan 200-mile race.
PARIS, July 16 -- In "The Making of The President 1968" Theodore White records a comment by Richard Nixon on the function of the American Presidency.

OTTAWA, July 16 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's record export performance continued through June, reaching $1.64-billion and bringing the half-year total to more than $8.73-billion, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16 (AP) -- While a series of small skirmishes dominated the ground war today, United States B-52 bombers flew four more raids along South Vietnam's northern frontier in a continuing effort to block an enemy build-up.

As dusk fell over Manhattan on a recent cloudless summer evening, blues singer Dan Smith blew a few warmup notes on his harmonica into a microphone set up in front of a small portable stage on a pier at the end of Fulton Street. This was a signal that another of the regular Tuesday and Thursday evening folk concerts of the South Street Seaport Museum was about to begin.

MILWAUKEE, July 16 -- Divided delegates of the 2.8-million-member Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod ended a stormy eight-day convention here today with expressions of reconciliation, a sentiment that had been little more than the gathering's motto all week.
NEWARK, July 16 -- Dr. Aaron H. Haskin, Newark's Health Officer and the second-ranking official in its public-health establishment, has been suspended and accused of neglect of duty.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Government auditors said today that the Department of Labor had added millions of dollars to the cost of Federal construction projects over the last decade by setting wage rates too high.

ATHENS, July 16 -- Premier George Papadopoulos reacted critically today to a vote by the United States House Foreign Affairs Committee in favor of proposals to withhold military and economic assistance from Greece and Pakistan.

A belief by speculators that the announcement of President Nixon's proposed visit to Communist China could result in increased trading in farm products sent grain and soybean prices higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Carl Taylor, a Kansas City outfielder, stormed off the field one night in May, burned some of his equipment and fled to Florida. Curt Flood ran away to Europe and Clete Boyer took off at Paul Richards and didn't land until he reached Hawaii.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has suspended for 30 days two patrolmen convicted in a department trial of giving false testimony in court.

FARIDPUR, Pakistan, June 29 -- Maj. Nazir Baig, the martial-law commander in the Faridfur District just west of Dacca, is a chunkily built Baluchi tribesman from West Pakistan who has spent nearly six of his 20 years of military service in East Pakistan.

Russell V. Stephenson yesterday submitted his resignation as president and chief executive officer of Mohawk Airlines, which has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to approve its acquisition by Allegheny Airlines.

The second president of the State University of New York, College at Old Westbury, L. I., recently described his experience with the original staff and students: "They sometimes speak as if they'd just come from a war."
Jeanne M. Holm, a 50-year-old former silversmith, has become the first woman in the Air Force to earn the rank of general.
Analysis of tremors from 30 underground nuclear explosions has shown that two of them released more than 10 times as much pent-up energy as was generated by the blasts themselves.
The whopping price of $415,800 that a fine 18th-cenury Parisian writing table brought at auction a few weeks ago proves once more that it pays to concentrate on the best in collecting antiques.
Possibly the most important U.S. influence on the South Vietnamese elections will derive from the rate of pull-out.
BEAVER FALLS, N. Y., July 16 -- Miss Elizabeth Leigh Frigerio and Lawrence Ellis Lewis were married here this afternoon.

BEAVERKILL, N. Y. -- Two of the country's leading conservation organizations -- the Sierra Club and Friends of the Earth -- have brought suit against a housing development here that may have a far-reaching effect on the use a property owner may make of land that lies adjacent to legally protected wilderness areas.

LAKENHEATH, England, July 16 -- On the sprawling United States Air Force Base here, the trial of Capt. Thomas S. Culver was barely overshadowed this week by a widely anticipated and eagerly discussed event: the opening of the new swimming pool.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- The Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began here today with nearly all the country's top-ranked players embarked on 10 days of fiercely competitive play.

The governments of most of Communist China's neighbors appeared yesterday to welcome the news of President Nixon's forthcoming trip to Peking, but on Taiwan, the Chinese Nationalists reacted initially with disbelief, then with dismay.

GENEVA, July 16 -- The International Telecommunication Union has expanded its regulatory role into new fields of space communications by making provisions for the use of satellites for broadcasting television programs and for keeping watch on the earth's natural resources.

LONDON, July 16 -- American and British speakers at the American Bar Association convention criticized today some of the key safeguards for criminal suspects established during the nineteen-sixties by the Warren Court.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Justice Department rejected today a plan for redistricting Hinds County, Miss., for upcoming county elections, finding that black voting strength might be diluted by the changes.

BELLPORT, L.I., July 16 -- A two-acre lot near this South Shore village that is in daily use for storage and movement of heavy construction equipment is also being used to store a trailer-truck load of nuclear waste, its shielding deteriorating and emitting measurable quantities of radiation.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 16 -- Eleven years ago Milton (Babe) Lichardus finished in a tie for the New Jersey open golf championship. This afternoon the 42-year-old professional from the Shackamaxon Country Club in Scotch Plains, N.J., again tied for the crown after equaling Bob Benning's 72-hole aggregate of 289.

CHICHESTER, England, July 16 -- Critics notch their declining years not with birthdays but with festivals. The Chichester Festival, set in the luxurious greenness of Sussex, has now reached its 10th season, and I remember the first as if it were the day before yesterday.
MOSCOW, July 16 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin told four Americans today that it was crucial for the Soviet Union and the United States to cooperate in a major fight against environmental pollution.
ROME -- In the Eternal City, the best way to man's soul may be through his stomach.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Some diplomats here and in the United Nations predicted today that Peking would obtain admission to the United Nations this fall, replacing the Chinese Nationalists.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A steady, but not rapid, recovery of the economy from the 1970 recession was confirmed today by the Government's most comprehensive measure -- the Gross National Product.

" Well, there are a million stories in the naked city and you've probably heard all of them. So if I tell you I'm going to call a book 'Thank You for the Giant Sea Tortoise,' you'll just have to be a good sport about it," Mary Ann Madden crisply notifies us. Here are three slim new books that have to do, in one way or another, with life in Manhattan.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 16 -- Former Gov. William Wallace Barron, 59 years old, was sentenced to 12 years' imprisonment today and fined $50,000 for bribing a Federal jury foreman in 1968.

Gleaming heads the list for today's running of the Lexington Handicap at Aqueduct. Rigged at top weight of 126 pounds, the Calumet Farm's 3-year-old star is the strong favorite to take the 1 3-16 mile turf race against 10 rivals.
ALBANY, July 16 (AP) -- The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation today was granted a $32.2-million temporary increase in its electric rates in upstate New York.

HOUSTON, July 16 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin said late today that an outbreak of Venezuelan equine encephalomyelitis in Texas was an agriculture emergency. He promised massive Federal aid to try to halt the disease, which is rapidly spreading through Texas toward other states.

KINSHASA, the Congo, July 16 -- Vice President Agnew, ending the African phase of his world tour, conferred privately for 90 minutes today with President Joseph D. Mobutu of the Congo and then continued the talk at a luncheon in a thatched-roof hut with a sweeping view of the Congo River.
FORT ORD, Calif., July 16 (UPI) -- An Army private has been charged with the murder of two lieutenants and the attempted murder of three other officers in Vietnam.

Tom Wicker's almost savage reply to Dean Acheson's remarks on The Times' publication of the Pentagon papers suggests that Mr. Acheson has struck a nerve when he wonders why the papers weren't returned to their owner as stolen goods.

The Federal Communications Commission has traditionally taken a narrow view of its own "fairness doctrine." Except in overtly partisan political matters, it rarely polices the television networks and stations vigorously to make sure that they present contrasting viewpoints on major issues.

YONKERS, July 16 -- Albatross paced his slowest mile tonight since he won in 2:00 2/5 at Roosevelt Raceway last May 22. But the 2-minute performance turned in by the colt was good enough for a 1 1/2-length victory over H. T. Luca in the $106,795 Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

BELFAST, July 16 -- The principal opposition group in the Northern Ireland Parliament, the Social Democratic and Labor party, announced today that it would boycott the legislature and form an alternative assembly.
A City Buildings Department inspector pleaded guilty yesterday to receiving a bribe from a Bronx building contractor.

The New York Stock Exchange alleged yesterday that several employes of the First Devonshire Corporation, a former member firm now in liquidation, had been accepting payments from customers and registered representatives for "favored treatment" of their accounts.
Hedge and Donna Capers, a folk-singing couple from Los Angeles, are playing through Monday at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.
AJLUN, Jordan, July 16 -- Jordanian Army guns shelled the hilly country west of Ajlun today after Palestinian commandos had fled there from the shell-pocked Ajlun woods.
The Federal Power Commission's approval of higher prices for natural gas producers in the Southern Louisiana gas fields yesterday will mean higher gas bills for New Yorkers.

The Kenton Corporation announced yesterday plans for its acquisition of Arlan's Department Stores, Inc., subject to approval of stockholders of both companies. Directors of the two have already approved the transaction.

Residents of the Glen Oaks section of Queens fighting the proposed construction of three 32-story luxury apartment buildings in their community may find that the developer will erect a fourth building if his application for special permits is denied by the City Planning Commission.

CAIRO, July 17 -- Ending a three-day meeting to discuss new rifts in Arab ranks, President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, President Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya and delegations from Syria and the Sudan tonight condemned what they termed repressions in Morocco since the uprising there a week ago.

MOSCOW, July 17 (AP) -- Thirty-five Jews who were arrested while conducting a hunger strike in Moscow's central telegraph office have been sent back to the Soviet Republic of Georgia to serve jail terms, Jewish sources reported today.

New Yorkers strolling along almost any midtown street in these 90-degree July days will often be greeted by a "snowfall:" white flakes glinting in the sun. tumbling out of the sky. If you scoop up some of the "snowflakes," and happen to have an electron microscope handy to examine them, you will find the white fluffs to be composed of millions of fibers of asbestos.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 17 -- A boat that can't seem to lose and a husband-and-wife team that hasn't lost its class title in three years were the dominant prize-winners today as Larchmont Yacht Club's curtailed 73d Race Week came to a close.

ZERQA, Jordan, July 17 -- King Hussein promised today to support Arab commando activities against Israel, but he denounced the guerrilla leaders and said the Jordanian Army crackdown on commandos in northern Jordan this week had been necessary and successful.
HARTFORD, July 17 -- A movement to reconvene the Connecticut General Assembly to repeal or modify the recently enacted state income tax appears to be gaining momentum.

July 17 -- When the Thad Jones-Mel Lewis Jazz Band performs tomorrow afternoon at 5 on the lawn of the Longwood High School, it will be a tribute to the faith and persistence of Ann Sneed, program director of the International Art of Jazz, an organization that has presented free neighborhood jazz concerts in Suffolk County every summer since 1968.

Mr. Pepper assumes direction of Scott's corporate planning function, law, finance, commercial development, environmental activities, the fibre division and timberlands. The company selected Paul C. Baldwin, vice chairman, to replace Mr. Pepper as head of international operations. Mr. Baldwin was previously chief staff officer. J. Lawrence Shane was named vice president of finance.

MILWAUKEE, July 19 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago said tonight that he would nominate the Mayor of Milwaukee, Henry W. Maier, for Vice President at the 1972 Democratic convention "if he wants it."

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Two New Jersey men, a judge and a lawyer, will be nominated by President Nixon to fill vacancies on the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia, the White House announced today.
LOS ANGELES, July 19 -- A standard police technique for eliciting information from reticent persons under interrogation is known as the "Mutt and Jeff" tactic.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Mayor Lindsay told a House subcommittee today that the proposed Gateway National Recreation Area at the entrance of New York Harbor could not succeed unless the Federal Government paid for transportation facilities to let the public get to the area at reasonable cost.

MADRID, July 19 -- Vice President Agnew concluded his three-day official visit to Spain today with unexpectedly long courtesy calls on Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon, the designated successor to Generalissimo Francisco, and on Vice President Luis Carrero Blanco.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Housing starts rose again in June to a level just under the Government's target figure of 2 million units a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Prices of copper futures dropped yesterday, with heavy sales, following the first settlement in the national copper strike that began nearly three weeks ago.

U.S. Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc., announced yesterday second-quarter and first-half gains in sales and earnings. The company is the first major forest-products concern to show higher earnings for the second quarter and first half ended June 30.

The National Broadcasting Company has shaken up its local news division, appointing Bernard Shusman director of Channel 4 News. He replaces Richard Graf, who becomes director of N.B.C. news program services, a news and feature syndication operation for some 120 stations.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Communications Workers of America and the Bell System agreed today on a new contract. Telephone workers were ordered to return to work at midnight tomorrow, ending a week-long strike.
AMSTERDAM, July 19 -- The more the Netherlands Dance Theater changes, the more it remains the same. The company opened its summer season at the State Theater here in Amsterdam tonight.

In what appeared to be a belated reaction to the Federal Reserve's discount rate increase last Thursday, bond prices declined moderately yesterday in light trading activity.

DENVER, July 20 -- Bobby Fischer defeated Bent Larsen in 40 moves in the sixth game of their chess match in Temple Buell College here today. The final score was 6-0.

National Review, the conservative weekly magazine, published yesterday a selection of what it described as "highly classified documents" dealing with United States involvement in Vietnam, which it said had been leaked to the magazine.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 20 -- Relying on a new and untested environmental quality amendment to the State Constitution, Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania personally obtained a temporary court order here today against the construction of a $1-million commercial observation tower at the Gettysburg National Military Park.

The common-law wife of a former Black Panther leader held in a Bronx holdup was held in $100,000 bail and questioned yesterday as a material witness in the machine gun shooting May 19 of two policemen who were guarding the home of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

The Bon Vivant soup plant in Newark had not been inspected by the Food and Drug Administration for more than four years nor by the New Jersey Health Department for nearly five years before botulism was traced to a can of its vichyssoise, state and Federal officials acknowledged yesterday.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation yesterday joined the ranks of other companies that have recently announced price increases on certain aluminum products. The company said its increases would average about 6 per cent, effective Sept. 1. Revere Copper Brass, Inc., made a similar announcement on Monday.
MOREHEAD, Ky., July 20 (UPI) -- Army engineers said tonight that danger of a spillover at a temporary coffer dam was "imminent."

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- William D. Ruckelshous administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that, so far as he could determine, his relations with President Nixon "remain very good."

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A Nixon Administration official said today that 64 Southern and border state school districts had been told that their desegregation plans must be altered to comply with standards set by the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- After nearly 24 straight hours of negotiation, contract talks between the United States Postal Service and seven postal unions seemed to be going nowhere early yesterday morning.
LONDON, July 20 -- Harold Wilson, in an agitated speech, tonight denounced his fellow Labor party members who support British entry into the European Common Market.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The Friends of the F.B.I -- an organization formed to combat criticism of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and J. Edgar Hoover -- reports an "excellent response" to the several hundred thousand requests it has sent out for tax-deductible contributions.

A 1969 Supreme Court ruling that military jurisdiction was illegal in the trial of non-service-connected crimes was applied retroactively yesterday to a 1944 case by a Federal District Court judge here.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- The president of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio told a Senate panel today that oil companies, including his own, sometimes supply each other with gasoline when the need arises.
Taki is a Manhattan teenager who writes his name and his street number everywhere he goes. He says it is something he just has to do.

SOUTH SIOUX CITY, Neb., July 20 -- The Governors of 13 Middle Western states agreed today that they each needed more money badly. But they were widely split over whether it would be better to get these funds through the revenue-sharing plans of President Nixon or Representative Wilbur D. Mills or through some form of Federal tax credit that would allow them to increase state taxes.

State Attorney General Louis Lefkowitz disclosed yesterday what he described as "a fraudulently coordinated manipulation" of the price of an over-the-counter security by known "underworld figures" that had cost the public and members of the New York Stock Exchange more than $100,000.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Selective Service System announced today that the next draft lottery would be held Aug. 5.
LONDON, July 20 -- The United States and Britain agreed today to a regular exchange of information in the field of planning and community development.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to cut off sugar imports from any nation engaging in uncompensated expropriation of American property in the future.

MOSCOW, July 20 -- The head of the Moscow Film Festival told Soviet readers today that movie festivals should be regarded as "serious ideological confrontations" between bourgeois and Communist views of art and not as places for movie stars to attract publicity.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., July 20 -- Kendrick R. Wilson's Troon, a Whitby-45 sloop that won the 81-mile distance race from Rye to Fishers Island to open the American Yacht Club's 40th annual cruise, triumphed in Division I today in the first of the races for series trophies.

For the last three years Gilbert Advertising has been doing advertising for Club Mediterranee, which now offers group fun for vacationers in five different sun spots. That advertising was instrumental in bringing it another client in the same general area.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- A foreign aid authorization of $3.44-billion for the current fiscal year was approved today by the House Foreign Affairs Committee. The amount comprised $1.43-billion for economic development loans and grants and $2.01-billion for military aid grants and sales on credit.

TOKYO, July 20 -- Amid growing political repercussions here over President Nixon's forth-coming visit to China, Premier Eisaku Sato has reaffirmed his Government's basic position that it wants to improve relations with Peking but not at the cost of giving up its ties with Taiwan.
Tevye, the perennially optimistic Ukrainian Jewish dairyman with five unmarried daughters and a nagging wife, pushes past Dolly Gallagher Levi, the bumptious Yonkers matchmaker, tonight.

Your recent series of articles about the nation's energy crisis was impressive, written by John Noble Wilford, but I cannot agree with the final article's serious questioning of continued economic growth in order to solve the energy crisis by reducing the use of electricity.

PATERSON, N.J. -- Close up, it could be Santo Domingo or Santurce or Cali on a hot summer night. The streets are steamy and crowded, spicy tropical smells waft from the kitchens, and the bars and street comers are amurmur with Spanish jokes and flirtations.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- The Senate refused today to delay an underground nuclear explosion this fall in the Aleutian Islands, which the Defense Department said was intended to test a key element in the Safeguard antiballistic-missile system.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- The clock continued to run backwards for the New York Mets today as they lost to the Cubs, 4-2, before a capacity crowd of 37,270 at Wrigley Field.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., July 20 (UPI) -- Two widows and three young sons of one of the women were found shot to death in their homes less than a block apart. The police said the 19-year-old son of the second woman was being held as a "material witness in protective custody."

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 20 -- President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan was reported today to have received a letter from Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, expressing regret over the unauthorized publication in the American press of a World Bank report on the situation in East Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Government has dismissed a Federal grand jury in Boston looking into the Pentagon papers case and replaced it with another grand jury. Government sources said the action was taken because of a leak to the press.
ROME, July 20 -- The message on the runways, as the Italian high-fashion showings chug along, is that real clothes are back. But the men's undershirt is the most popular style among the spectators.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday that it was able to restore service before noon to most of the telephones in the Wall Street area that had been knocked out of service by a fire late Monday afternoon.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 20 -- The old and the new Giants, 71 strong, bumped heads, arms and elbows for the first time today at their sprawling training grounds at C. W. Post College.
The state's Department of Correctional Services has issued new guidelines that liberalize access by newsmen to prisons and prisoners.

Cheerful young children ate cheese sandwiches and bananas, scrawled bright crayon pictures on manila paper and frisked and tumbled in the aisle of the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall yesterday.
WAPAKONETA, Ohio, July 20 -- It was almost an ordinary summer's day in this quiet, unassuming town, whose most famous son, Neil A. Armstrong, took man's first steps on the moon two years ago today.
A Bureau of Labor Statistics survey published yesterday indicated that there were far more people out of work in four poverty areas of New York City than customary unemployment figures showed.
LONDON, July 20 -- Lieut. Col. Babakr al-Nur Osman, the newly named leader of the Sudan, said here today that plans for yesterday's coup d'etat had been under discussion since February.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, called today for permanent Government controls on the prices of the nation's 2,000 largest corporations and on the wage demands of the biggest labor unions.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Two Representatives who recently visited Vietnam and reported that heroin users made up 10 to 15 per cent of all American servicemen there accused the Nixon Administration today of "trying to sweep the problem under the rug."
There are 45,016 baseball seats in Washington's Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium. Last night 3,887 of the seats were in use, including three by the nation's first family.

CAIRO, July 20 -- The new military Government in the Sudan moved today to lift restrictions on the country's Communist movement and abolished Egyptian-style political formations recently organized by the deposed leader, Maj. Gen. Gaafar al-Nimeiry.

The joint effort of New York State, New Jersey and the Federal Government [July 7 editorial "A Park for the People] unfortunately misses one essential ingredient. In providing parks and beaches for people in this urban area, the densely populated cities of Newark and Jersey City and the Hudson peninsula have been ignored.

The Times commented editorially on July 3 on Israel's plan to compensate Arab residents of East Jerusalem for property they held within the pre-1967 borders of Israel, stating that "it was a positive gesture that unfortunately is likely to have negative results in terms of over-all Israeli-Arab relations."

Now that New York City is to have one of the most stringent air pollution codes in the country, a serious effort must be made to provide equally stringent enforcement. Up to now it cannot be said that even inadequate laws have been adequately executed.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 20 -- William (Buddy)Gilmour, Carmine Abbatiello, Ben Webster and four other trainer-drivers have been told by Roosevelt Raceway to "go elsewhere" when the track opens its summer meeting Friday night.

BETHESDA, Md., July 20 -- Mrs. Sallie Lucile Lewis MacCracken, widow of William Patterson MacCracken, the first Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics, was married here this afternoon to Vice Adm. Vincent Raphael Murphy, U.S.N., retired, a widower.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A partner in a small securities firm that handles small transactions for less than the fixed price prescribed by the New York Stock Exchange said today that he thought he could still make money even if the exchange's price, which he has to undercut, were lowered.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Senate Democratic leadership caught the Republican opposition by surprise today by calling up for Senate consideration the election reform bill designed to limit campaign spending.
The 17-year-old girl sat dejectedly in a Brooklyn office of the State Employment Service yesterday, her patience running out.
A portion of the Coney Island beach was still closed to swimmers yesterday because of traces of the oil that fouled the beach late last week and forced its closing Friday.

MEDFORD, Mass. -- In its Pentagon disclosures the press has fallen into the same trap as those who over-classified the study in the first place. Because of its secrecy, the press has treated the study as if it contained astounding revelations, and has conveyed that view to the public.

Revenues and earnings of the Xerox Corporation in the quarter and six months ended June 30 were the highest of any quarter or half-year in its history, the midyear report from the company's Stamford, Conn., headquarters disclosed yesterday.

The chairman of the Mayor's special panel studying the tunnel fire in the IRT subway last Friday said yesterday that current emergency procedures were subject to "misinterpretations which could lead to conflicts."

The Mobil Oil Corporation, the first major petroleum company to issue midyear results, reported yesterday that it had record earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30 with increases exceeding 13 per cent.

An Army Corps of Engineers official said yesterday that the agency had asked the three United States Attorneys whose jurisdictions cover New York harbor to look into the possibility of taking action against the owners of 97 deteriorating piers here.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 20 -- Attorneys for Angela Davis argued today that the indictment against her for murder, kidnapping and criminal conspiracy should be dismissed.
MOSCOW, July 20 -- The Soviet Government today affirmed support for Communist China's admission to the United Nations and opposition to an international conference on Indochina.
The Penn Central was ordered yesterday to install stand-pipes for fire protection in its four East River tunnels, which are used principally by the Long Island Railroad.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., a member of the New York Stock Exchange for decades, will have its own shares listed on the Big Board next Tuesday and will begin trading under the ticker symbol MER.
Three claimants are seeking possession of a painting by El Greco stolen from a mansion in Madrid during the Spanish Civil War and recovered here by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last month.

ROME -- The United States has decided as a matter of policy that its interests will best be served in Italy by revivification of a unified Christian Democratic party. Therefore it is determined to help press for that party's reorganization prior to the 1973 parliamentary elections.

Tom Wicker, in his July 11 column, asked a rhetorical question: "Why should the United States make more loan funds available to impoverished nations when not enough loan funds are available to impoverished areas of this country?"

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Nixon sent his Ambassador at Large for trade matters, David M. Kennedy, to the Far East today for new discussions on possible voluntary limits on exports of textiles to the United States.

The Stuttgart Ballet has returned to town -- it is now at the end of its American tour and alive and well, for a bare two weeks, at the Metropolitan Opera House. During these two weeks it is offering its standard repertory and one novelty.

The United Brands Company announced yesterday that John M. Fox has resigned as president of the Boston based food company. Mr. Fox will assume a high level executive position with another company to be announced in the near future. He will continue as a director and a consultant of the company.
The Health Department would be given the power to register abortion clinics and to shut them down if they failed to meet standards, under regulations published yesterday in the City Record.

The Elcor Chemical Corporation of Midland, Tex., which has suffered severe losses in the last year because of depressed sulphur prices, announced yesterday that it had filed under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act for an arrangement with its creditors.

DENVER, July 20 -- The Army completed today the last of its tests on equipment to be used in disposing of 3,071 tons of mustard gas stored since World War II in steel cylinders at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal
The New York Knicks announced yesterday that Red Holzman would continue as coach and general manager of the team through the 1971-72 National Basketball Association season.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 20 -- President Salvador Allende Gossens and his left-wing supporters said today that the Government's defeat Sunday in a congressional by-election would not alter his basic policy of making Chile a socialist country.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The United States Postal Service and seven postal unions signed today a contract covering more than 650,000 workers -- the first collective bargaining agreement in the history of the post office.
Under heavy selling pressure, soybean prices dropped as much as 7 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, July 20 -- Harry Bridges, president of the striking International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, told delegates to the International Longshoremen's Association convention here today that he expected his union's 21-day-old tie-up of West Coast ports to go on "for two or three more months."

That irony is reflected with special force in yesterday's developments in the week-long national telephone strike.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 -- The two-story, tile-roof house at 8814 Vista Del Mar here seems to have everything: four bedrooms, three baths a huge swimming pool and a spectacular view of the Pacific Ocean.
LOS ANGELES, July 20 (AP) -- Democrats tightened their control of the California Legislature tonight when a Democrat opposed to Gov. Ronald Reagan's programs won a special State Senate election here.
An Evanston Ill., woman who owns Florida orange groves has filed a complaint against Walston Co., the brokerage house, charging sex discrimination.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 20 -- Endurance, a 43-foot Menominee, Mich., sloop, was named the top performer today as the winner of Division I in the 64th annual Chicago-Mackinac race, which ended yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 21 -- South Vietnam today reportedly launched its largest operation in six months in eastern Cambodia with the announced aim of providing security for the forthcoming South Vietnamese elections.

TRENTON, July 20 -- James C. Kellogg 3d, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, paid an unscheduled visit to Gov. William T. Cahill today to discuss the Governor's veto of an 800-room hotel at the World Trade Center.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Foreign diplomats engaged in consultations with the Nixon Administration said today that the United States hope of keeping Nationalist China in the United Nations might collapse if Taiwan failed to indicate soon how it would react to the anticipated admission of Peking this fall.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A 29-year-old convict told a Senate investigating committee today that he was, as another convict had testified last month, one of the two men responsible for a $21.5-million mail theft at Kennedy International Airport in 1968.
A favorable flow of earnings reports provided the fuel yesterday for higher stock prices. The Dow-Jones industrial average, running ahead throughout the session, rose 5.91 points to finish at 892.30.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- After an hour of sparsely attended debate, the Senate passed unanimously today an $18.7-billion appropriation bill to finance housing, veterans and space programs. The vote was 87 to 0.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- At just about half past 1971, The Tormentor Who Never Rests sat at his fiery desk in his nethermost den and wrote in his diary.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- One of the world's strongest mixed partnerships led the field of 84 pairs into the final session of the life master pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here tonight.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 20 (AP) -- John Rauch resigned unexpectedly today as head coach of the Buffalo Bills of the National Football League.

The credit markets moved on several major fronts yesterday to fine tune interest rates as a heavy volume of financing was offered to investors.
WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., July 20 (AP) -- Tom Gorman of Seattle and Ray Moore of South Africa became the first seeded players eliminated in the Tangle-wood international tennis tournament today.

LONDON, July 20 -- As Britain tries to move out of the stop-go economic bind that has restrained her economic growth since World War II, there may be some lessons to be learned by the United States.

MILWAUKEE, July 20 -- The mayors of the nation's largest cities and representatives of the nation's counties agreed today that despite differences on some major questions, they had to cooperate to win major legislative victories in Washington.

PARRIS ISLAND, S. C., July 20 (UPI) -- A Marine drill instructor has been fined $100 and relieved of all recruit training duties as a result of an investigation into alleged exercise periods that hospitalized 39 recruits with a kidney ailment.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP) -- Four young men plan to enter a high-pressure chamber at the University of Pennsylvania Medical Center next week for studies that may Indicate the depths to which man may some day dive into the sea.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 20 -- Al Woodall took the snap from center, cocked and fired the football. Zap, it hit Vernon Studdard, a rookie receiver who wasn't looking, high on the shoulder pad and bounced off his white helmet. This was at the Jets' practice here today.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 20 -- Five men, including the reputed head of the Joseph Bonnano Mafia family, have been indicted on loan-sharking charges.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- A young Negro member of the Nixon Administration criticized Vice President Agnew today for his remarks on black leadership and said he was aware that his words could cost him his $21,000-ayear job.

RAMTHA, Jordan, July 20 - Syria and Jordan reported today exchanges of artillery fire at the border here as Arab wrath mounted in the wake of Jordan's offensive against the Arab commandos.
The New York Yankees, who have been on the receiviing end of some five-run innings lately, staged one of their own last night and their timing was impeccable.

The Board of Education is planning to make its own study of the extent of drug abuse among pupils here as part of a planned stepped-up attack on the problem, Isaiah E. Robinson, the board's president, said yesterday.

Five subsidiaries of Cowles Communications, Inc., that sell magazines on an installment basis have begun a program designed to phase out their operations. The companies are Home Reader Service, Educational Book Club, Civic Reading Club, Home Reference Library and Mutual Readers League.
The accounting profession announced here yesterday a proposed tightening of the disclosure requirements of brokerage houses in reporting their financial condition.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it has completed its offering of $1,375,000,000 of convertible preferred stock.

WARSAW, July 20 -- Last December, when Poland's Baltic ports were exploding in revolt, a Warsaw worker paused over lunch one day to list his complaints, and presumably those of the workers then sealed off on the coast.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 20 (UPI) -- Two years after man first landed on the moon, the countdown started today for next Monday's launching of Apollo 15, the most ambitious lunar voyage yet.
BERNARDS TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 20 (AP) -- An elementary school music teacher changed sex from male to female during the last school year and is having her contract reviewed by the local school board.

The International Flight Service of the Federal Aviation Administration announced yesterday slight changes in the frequencies that provide up-to-date weather information at major airports. While primarily intended for trans-Atlantic pilots, the service is useful for domestic travelers during periods of hurricanes or winter storms.
Many major borrowers -- from the Federal Treasury to the Ford Motor Company to Maryland and Ohio -- moved into the credit markets yesterday to seek large amounts of money.

The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that New York City, rather than the state, should be the beneficiary of the fines levied against the United Federation of Teachers and its president, Albert Shanker, as a result of the 1967 teachers' strike here.

MOSCOW, July 21 -- A leading Soviet newspaper published an assertion today that President Nixon's planned visit to Peking was the result of anti-Soviet maneuvering by both the United States and Communist China.

WARSAW, July 21 -- Edward Gierek, the Communist party leader, told the nation's restive youth today that problems at home should be weighed against the "serious economic, moral and social shortcomings of capitalist society."

DENVER, July 21 -- Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, with only one more hurdle between him and a match challenging the world chess champion, racked up his second straight shutout of a grandmaster last night after his opponent turned down a sure draw.
Net income of American Brands, Inc., advanced 16 per cent in the second quarter and 22 per cent in the first half, the company announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Congress has reintroduced the Appalachian regional development bill. The new bill no longer includes a section creating jobs.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Government offered today its first long-term bond issue in six years, bearing 7 per cent interest, and opened the offer to subscriptions by individual investors of up to $10,000.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday reversed an early upward drift and closed lower. At the close of trading the index was off 0.04 at 25.53.

LONDON, July 21 -- There were signs of further monetary unease today as the dollar weakened against the German mark and the French franc, and the price of gold leaped to its highest price in many months.

Last night, after "Fiddler on the Roof" had given its 2,845th performance, making it the longest-running musical ever on Broadway, Mayor Lindsay walked on the stage and said that two years from now, he's going to play the leading role in the show.

The Eastman Kodak Company achieved record sales and earnings in the second quarter with 9 per cent increases, but half-year earnings declined despite peak sales for the period, the mid-year report from Rochester headquarters disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- The life master championship ended here late last night in a victory for Alvin Roth of New York and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N. J. This was Roth's second victory in the event, and Mrs. Rappaport added her name to the short list of distinguished women players who have won this famous title.

The General Electric Company said yesterday that its aircraft engine group expects to lay off more than 7,000 employes this year. It blamed the combination of "a decline in the growth rate of air travel together with the cancellation of the United States supersonic transport program."

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Congressional investigators heard testimony today that United States officials in Saigon were seeking to influence next October's national election in favor of President Nguyen Van Thieu and that the balloting would be a "mockery" of the democratic process.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21 -- Maj. Gen. Ngo Dzu, who was accused by a Connecticut Congressman of being "one of the chief traffickers" in narcotics in Southeast Asia, sent the Congressman a letter today requesting that he make his evidence for the charges public.
Corn futures prices for the more distant contracts continued downward on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after the July delivery dropped to almost 8 cents a bushel.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 22 -- The last American combat battalion was withdrawn from the area just below the demilitarized zone as Communist shellings of the bases now manned by South Vietnamese continued today, military sources said.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida and other Florida officials related today a long story of mismanagement, improper use and waste of funds granted to their state by the Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Administration.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 21 (AP) -- Henry Forrest, who trained the 1966 Kentucky Derby winner, Kawaiking, concluded his first venture in buying last night by running his total to $690,000 for six yearlings at Keeneland's summer sale. His top bid was $200,000 for a daughter of Herbager being sold by Mrs. George G. Proskauer of Akron, Ohio.

The most discussed new portable appliance introduced at the National Housewares Show held recently in Chicago was the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's electric can opener called the "Sesame." It removes the lid with its rim so that it can be replaced snugly on ean that are able to be stored after only part of their contents have been used.

The short interest in issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange -- a widely followed indicator of the market's technical condition -- fell by 1.08 million shares, or 5.9 per cent, in the month ended July 15, the Big Board disclosed yesterday.

Thomas D. O'Malley, Insurance Commissioner of Florida, has filed a $5-million damage suit against the brokerage concern of H. Hentz Co., Inc., it was disclosed yesterday. The suit, which also names 17 other defendants, charges them with scheming to convert the assets of an insurance company and with concealing the insurer's insolvent condition.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 21 (AP) -- Angela Davis made her own plea in court today to be allowed to act as her own attorney or co-counsel.

MONTAUK, L. I., July 21 -- Kendrick R. Wilson Jr.'s Whitby-45 sloop, Troon, and G. R. Corwin Jr.'s Alala, an Apache-37 raced by Mrs. Corwin, triumphed on the 40th annual American Yacht Club cruise again today. Both are out of the host American Y.C. at Rye, N. Y.

The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stockholdings by major stockowners, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange yesterday said it had no list available this week.

Despite Mayor Lindsay's statement yesterday that considerable progress had been made in reducing welfare cases in hotels, a veritable dumping ground for welfare families has developed in at least seven hotels in a small sector of the attractive Brooklyn Heights neighborhood.
An automobile suddenly dropped from sight on Riverside Drive at 97th Street about 5 P.M. yesterday when a 20-by-30-foot section of the pavement opened up beneath it.

The semifinal elimination match between Tigran Petrosian, a former world champion, and Grandmaster Viktor Korchnoi, both of the Soviet Union, began inauspiciously, not, perhaps, for the players themselves, but for the chess world in general.

A profit squeeze reduced slightly the net earnings in the trust departments of 10 major New York City banks last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The net trust earnings of the 10 banks -- First National City, Chase Manhattan, Manufacturers Hanover, Morgan Guaranty, Chemical, Bankers, Irving, Marine Midland, Bank of New York and United States Trust -- came to $123.7-million in 1970, down from $123.9-million the year earlier.

Although Odetta began her Tuesday evening concert at the Metropolitan Museum with a contemporary romance by Buffy Sainte-Marie, and dotted the rest of the program with new compositions of her own, she basically remained true to the folk traditions that sparked her career some 15 years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The biggest question mark in the Democratic party today is Edward M. Kennedy. Is he going to be a candidate, or is he not? And if he is, is he the strongest opponent for Mr. Nixon that the Democrats could put up?

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The new National Women's Political Caucus has had so many inquiries from men asking how they could help achieve its aims that the organization is considering forming a Friends of the Caucus, Representative Bella S. Abzug said today.

NEW HAVEN, July 21 (UPI) -- A United States District Court judge has dismissed a $500,000 damage suit against the Government by a Danbury couple who contend their son's death in Vietnam's "illegal war" violated his constitutional rights.

In our most meaningful writers from Emerson to Norman Mailer, says Theodore Gross, idealism warred against authority. There was a moral imperative in these men that ran counter to the accepted values of their society. He goes even further. What was best in their works derived from the tension set up between their impulse and the force from the outside.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 21 -- Pakistan has acknowledged a message of regret sent by Robert S. MacNamara, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, regarding the unauthorized disclosure of a bank report highly critical of the Pakistani Government.
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., named Edward F. Ryan a senior vice president and chief financial officer, effective at year end.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 21 -- There he was, Roger Finnie, the burly 250-pound lineman waiting for the start of the daily morning workout of the Jets when he was approached by Buddy Ryan, the defensive line coach.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Administration has worked out a new formula that would go far toward meeting the demands of big-city Democrats that financial needs of local governments be taken into account in distributing general revenue-sharing funds.

" I've been called a thief and a crook and those things are never pleasant, but my first duty is to the law and to my conscience," State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer told an interviewer in 1959.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 21 -- George S. (Sandy) Dillon Jr. of Sleepy Hollow, the 1968 champion and a co-leader in Monday's qualifying round, and Dr. Jerry Sacks of Briar Hall, who got into match play only after winning a five-way playoff for the final berth, won the semifinals of the 52d amateur championship of the Westchester County Golf Association today.
Fun City, an illusion for some New Yorkers, turned into reality yesterday -- right on Mayor Lindsay's doorstep at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Government will pay the Ford Motor Company a token one dollar to build an experimental safety vehicle, under terms of a contract signed today by Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe and Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the board of the Ford company.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 21 -- Some 3,000 lawyers and judges from 114 countries met today under the auspices of the World Peace Through Law Center, in what was said to be the largest international conference of the legal profession ever held.

NEWCOMB, N.Y., July 21 -- More than 400 people, ranging from expert woodsmen to long-haired students, tramped methodically through the Adirondack Mountain forests today in search of 8-year-old Douglass Legg, who went for a walk near here 12 days ago and has not been heard from since.

While flamboyant, fun-loving Willie Mays was enjoying the idolatry of the New York press in his Polo Grounds days, quiet, conservative Henry Aaron was almost buried in the anonymity of the Midwestern city noted principally for its beer.
