The good barge Hughes 136 rocked and rolled at its dockside moorings, the band struck up a water-logged version of "Down by the Riverside," and the American Waterways Wind Orchestra launched its annual series of concerts in the New York area with a concert at East River Park.

DUBAI, July 1 -- The timbers of the great dhows creak loudly in this humid, low-lying Persian Gulf port. They creak with the wind, they creak with the tide and they creak with the weight of smugglers' gold.

The Police Department announced yesterday that a 29-year-old father of four had been cleared of suspicion of committing "dozens" of rapes in fashionable apartment houses in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau County and possibly other counties in the metropolitan area.

ROME, July 21 -- The nineteen-forties look has receded for a spell, giving the press and buyers attending the couture shows here a chance to worry about something other than their lost youth. Both Heinz Riva and Mila Schon returned to couture elegance with a vengeance. The question is, are we ready for it?

FORT DIX, N. J., July 21 -- Army officials say that an increasing number of recruits from Northeastern cities are bringing their civilian-acquired heroin addiction with them to this sprawling training center.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The House Banking Committee narrowly approved today an emergency loan-guarantee program designed to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy.
The Board of Education last night eliminated reduced-fare transportation for 50,000 high school students who live less than a mile and a half from school.

Amid recurring reports that he is about to change parties as a prelude to a Presidential candidacy, Mayor Lindsay discussed his political future with a leading fund-raiser at a Gracie Mansion meeting within the last week.

William F. Buckley Jr., the publisher of National Review, acknowledged yesterday that the magazine's published collection of "highly classified documents" was a hoax. It had fooled a large segment of the American news media.

TEL AVIV, July 21 -- The Israeli authorities have evacuated an undisclosed number of Palestinian refugees from the densely populated Jabaliya camp and have resettled them elsewhere in the occupied Gaza Strip, it was disclosed here today.

CAIRO, July 21 -- An Egyptian fact-finding mission was reported today to be conducting urgent inquiries in Khartoum, the capital of the Sudan, into the seizure of power Monday by a group of left-wing officers. The new rulers appear to oppose plans to link the Sudan ultimately with Egypt, Libya and Syria in a federation.

HARRISON, N. Y., July 21 -- Lee Trevino said today that he would save his best golf shots and his better jokes for tomorrow. The United States, Canadian and British Open champion is among 150 who will start in the $250,000 Westchester Classic, richest tourney on the pro circuit.
As a college student who resides at school, I read with interest the July 12 news article entitled "College Town Puzzle: 18-Year-Old Vote."

Nico Lugo Jr., a 28-year-old former businessman here and a graduate of the Inter-American University in Puerto Rico, was named yesterday to head the migration division of the Puerto Rican Department of Labor.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Army announced today the dismissal of charges against Col. Joseph R. Franklin, who had been accused by another officer of covering up atrocities in Vietnam.
BOSTON, July 21 -- The Massachusetts Attorney General ruled today that voters under 21 years of age have a right to choose their own place of residence for purposes of voting.

In a deal with an unprecedented safety clause, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Oslo Museum of Applied Art have entered into an agreement by which the two parts of a major work of art, formerly divided between the two institutions, will be reunited as the property of the Metropolitan.

The current campaign spending practices, including skyrocketing costs for TV, mean that no one can afford to run for political office unless he is extremely wealthy or is willing to accept very large contributions from other sources, which generally have the strings of special interest attached.

KARLSRUHE, West Germany, July 21 (AP) -- The eight-car Switzerland Express, with 300 to 400 passengers aboard, jumped the tracks on a curve south of Rheinweiler, south of here today, gilling at least 25 persons and injuring about 100, the police said.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A new assessment of the internal security of South Vietnam by the United States Embassy in Saigon shows that the enemy is gaining strength in up-country areas evacuated by American forces as well as in parts of the densely populated Mekong River Delta.
American Airlines and Trans-World Airlines issued their June and first-half income accounts yesterday. Both showed profits for the month but large losses for the six-month period.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously today for a proposal to repeal a 1955 Congressional resolution giving the President author ity to employ United States forces to defend Taiwan and smaller islands off Mainland China held by the Chinese Nationalists.

Robert F. Lawson, the general manager of the Penn Central, said yesterday that the railroad "would be derelict in our responsibilities if we were to accede to the orders of the Fire Department" requiring the installation of a standpipe system in four East River Tunnels.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Senator George McGovern of South Dakota apologized to the Democratic National Chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, today for charging that Robert Strauss, the party treasurer, had violated neutrality in the campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 21 -- The Apollo 15 astronauts passed their preflight medical examinations "with flying colors" today and continued preparations for the launching of their moon-landing mission at 9:34 A.M. Eastern daylight time next Monday.

Fires reportedly set by vandals in six cars of a Penn Central train of 79 refrigerator cars stored in a tunnel under Riverside Park sent dense smoke rushing up through gratings late yesterday and indirectly caused a massive rush-hour traffic tie-up.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia issued a procedural rebuke today to one of this city's most prestigious law firms, Williams, Connolly and Califano.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- There is a striking difference between the reactions in this country and in China to President Nixon's announcement of his forthcoming visit to Peking. Here there are banner headlines, an outburst of optimism about the future and warm congratulations for the President.

The New York State Banking Board, acting on the recommendation of William T. Dentzer Jr., the State Superintendent of Banks, approved yesterday the expansion of the First National City Corporation into Suffolk County and the formation of a new bank holding company by the State Bank of Albany and the Liberty National Bank and Trust Company of Buffalo.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Not even their highest hit total of the year could save the New York Metz today as their pitchers gave up runs faster than the batters could make them, the result being an 11-7 loss to the Chicago Cubs.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Four industrial aid-giving nations have made voluntary contributions totaling $110-million to the World Bank to help sustain an important lending operation pending action by Congress.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said yesterday that it had initiated discussions with the Midwest Oil Corporation for the purpose of merging Midwest with Standard's wholly owned domestic exploration and production subsidiary, Amoco Production.

Hundreds of black children and their parents showed up yesterday for free medical examinations at "miniclinics" set up in Central Harlem as part of a super block party organized by Dr. Benjamin Watkins, honorary mayor of Harlem.

MOREHEAD, Ky., July 21, (UPI) -- Workers piled sandbags on top of a temporary earthen coffer dam today to keep the rain-swollen Licking River from spilling over the top and pouring tons of water over thousands of acres of tobacco farmland.
LONDON, July 21 -- Prime Minister Heath today hailed the "rapid movement" toward detente in the world and said that Britain could best play her part as a member of the Common Market.

A $42.6-million development in East Harlem to provide housing for low- and moderate-income families as well as a variety of community services has received tentative approval from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.

President Nixon is wise to discourage speculation about the effect of his new China policy on Vietnam. Euphoric hopes in the country, stirred in part by earlier White House comments, could boomerang badly if the war is not ended. But equally dangerous is the effect Mr. Nixon's own hopes for Chinese aid may have on his strategy for peace in Southeast Asia.

Howard University and Atlanta University, two of the country's major predominantly black universities, were each the recipients yesterday of $1.75-million grants from the Ford Foundation to help finance graduate social science programs.

A Westchester County grand jury is about to hear the case of the killing of a Stamford woman who was found so close to the Connecticut border that surveyors were called in to determine which state had jurisdiction.

The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company said yesterday that the bankrupt carrier should be able to operate throughout the rest of this year if there is no steel strike or widespread railroad shutdown.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A bill to permit wider buses to operate on the nation's interstate highways was approved today by the House.
A man shot fatally on a Brooklyn street on Tuesday was identified by the police yesterday as a "buddy" of a former member of the Joseph Profaci Mafia family in Brooklyn.

Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, with his usual dramatic flair, brought Government officials from the United States and the Soviet Union to an old Harlem warehouse yesterday to brief members of his organization who leave today on a trip to Russia.

Few kennels have had the impact on a breed that Watteau has had on the smooth fox terrier. Watteau representatives not only have been big winners in their native England, but also have played leading roles on the Continent, in the United States, South Africa, South America and Australia.

CRUGERS, N. Y., July 21 -- Environmentalists challenged today the adequacy of the state's emergency plans in case of a nuclear accident as they attempted to set a precedent here and deny Consolidated Edison the use of its new atomic power plant.

His sonorous voice in fine form, Laurence Olivier made his maiden speech before Britain's House of Lords, and he gave it some neo-shakespearean cadences. "I fear your lordships may find grim cause to reflect upon the prescient genius of the introducer of this tenderest of courtesies," he said.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21 (Reuters) -- The South Vietnamese command said today that it planned to issue a set of ground rules for the press that "will very much restrict reporting on military operations.''
About 90,000 striking Bell System telephone workers yesterday defied back-to-work orders by their national union leaders.
WINROCK FARM, Ark., July 19 -- The United States wastes its former Governors, according to Winthrop Rockefeller, the Republican former Governor of Arkansas.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's ninth largest steel producer, announced today that it would begin shutting down its plants in anticipation of a strike on Aug. 1.

LONDON -- One of the Englishman's prized privileges is that of keeping his freedom although accused of crime. To be kept in custody pending trial is both to hamper the preparation of an accused person's defense as well as to prejudge the outcome, at least marginally.
ALBANY, July 21 -- The state's Organized Crime Task Force entered today the investigation of alleged race rigging at Yonkers Raceway.

MILWAUKEE, July 21 -- Two of the leading Democratic Presidential aspirants told county leaders today what the local officials wanted to hear about revenue sharing: that the nation needs a comprehensive plan that provides relief for the counties as well as the cities and states.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today defeated a Nixon Administration plan to finance and operate Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty under a tax-exempt corporation chartered by Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Food and Drug Administration is organizing a major study of over-the-counter mood drugs to see if they really are effective as sedatives, sleep aids or stimulants, as their advertisements contend.

Chevron Flight showed commendable closing ability to take the $35,000 Great American at Aqueduct yesterday.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 21 -- A Jordanian Government spokesman announced tonight that the Government had freed 2,000 Arab commandos who had been seized during the recent fighting in northern Jordan.

BUENOS AIRES, July 21 -- A new "terrorist" organization has taken to the streets here recently. Although they are not rightist or leftist bomb throwers and work only during business hours, their impact is far more profound than that of the anti-Government guerrillas.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Nixon accepted today the resignation of Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, the Nobel chemist who has been chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission for a decade.
The New York Yankees, who won a game in the ninth inning the night before, lost one in the ninth yesterday when the Minnesota Twins punched over a run for a 2-1 victory at Yankee Stadium.
The deficit in the United States international balance of payments soared to a record in the second quarter, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company estimated yesterday.

Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr., the du Pont heir who last October filed under the Federal Bankruptcy Act with $62.8-million in personal liabilities and $25.9-million in assets, charges that his signature was forged on a document used to borrow $100,000 from a bank in Ohio.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 21 -- Gov. J. J. Exon of Nebraska called on his colleagues and several hundred diners today to "give a warm Siouxland welcome to the Hon. Birch Bayh," and a spotlight picked up a man standing midway down the darkened auditorium. He was applauded warmly.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Kaye Beard along with two Curtis Cup players advanced to the quarterfinals of the 71st women's western amateur golf tournament today.

The city's Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday that a study of 10 leading brands of pork and beans showed that the pork content ranged from 7 per cent down to zero.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- James R. Schlesinger seldom leaves home without consulting a road map. Even if he and his wife are just going to a dinner party a few miles away, he finds the spot on the map and works out the best route to get there.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The nation's manufacturers operated on average at 73.2 per cent of capacity in the second quarter, little changed from the low level of the first quarter, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Net income of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) rose sharply in the second quarter and first six months of 1971, the petroleum giant reported yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, July 21 -- Beneath the speeches and other routine business of the 42d convention of the International Longshoremen's Association lie a host of problems that face not only the union, but also -- and especially -- its president.

JERSEY CITY, July 21 -- City Clerk Thomas F. X. Smith looked at the 35,000 new nominating petitions that had just arrived from the printers today and said, "We may need two voting machines if this election comes off."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21 -- South Vietnamese troops in eastern Cambodia were reported today to be reoccupying part of a Communist infiltration corridor that they had left open after a retreat early in June.

A list of the 10 original shareholders in the Dreyfus Corporation who have agreed to return part of the money they received from the sale of their stock in 1965 was obtained yesterday by The New York Times.

Counsel for Patricia Green, who is being held as a material witness in the machine-gun shooting May 19 of two policemen guarding the home of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, will move today before Supreme Court Justice Xavier C. Riccobono for her release from detention in Civil Jail.

A proposal for a new town with homes for 60,000 people and office and industrial space for 35,000 employes, to be built over the Sunnyside railroad yards in Long Island City, Queens, was presented yesterday by the Urban Development Corporation.

Neither George Hamilton's portrayal nor his personal production of "Evel Knievel," the daredevil stunt rider, hits the mark. Seven years ago, young Hamilton fared infinitely better as another folk hero, Hank Williams, the country singer, in "Your Cheatin' Heart."

After a show of strength at the opening of trading yesterday, prices of stocks on the American Stock Exchange declined and closed lower. The index ended at 25.47, down 0.06 yesterday.

The San Francisco Giants show no signs of cracking in their bid to finish first in the National League's Western Division. Yesterday Ken Henderson and Jimmy Rosario combined to lead them to an 8-7 victory over Pittsburgh's Eastern Division leaders in 10 innings.

Your perceptive editorial on July 3, "Avoiding Another Money Crisis," urges improvement in the flexibility and stability of the world monetary system. This is a critical need not only to avoid monetary crises but also to allow the U.S. and other countries independence in the management of their domestic economies.
Pan American World Airways reported yesterday a $2,387,000 net loss for June and a deficit of $15,589,000 for the second quarter. For the six months ended June 30, the deficit reached $39,465,000.
LONDON, July 22 -- A Dutch chemical company recalled one of its tankers to Rotterdam tonight after protests by six Governments over plans to dump 600 tons of chemical wastes in the North Atlantic.
Insurance against losses in the stock market would be very nice indeed, so the announcement by National Securities and Research that it would offer such protection attracted considerate attention.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A week has passed since President Nixon scheduled his journey to Peking and shook up the world of diplomacy.
The arrest of three men here on charges of possessing stolen securities valued at over $100,000 was disclosed yesterday by Federal agents here.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Congressional Black Caucus asked President Nixon today to send Federal examiners into Mississippi to check on the recent reregistration of voters in 26 counties.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 22 -- The Giants lost their fine defensive end prospect, Wes Grant, today following an argument, but tonight gained Ron Johnson, the club's first 1,000-yard runner, who reported to camp following a three-day holdout.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 22 -Chileans are eating increasing amounts of Danish pork French poultry and Argentine beef imported to offset local shortages.
A 17-year-old honor student who was erroneously identified as an assailant in a mugging in the Bronx was exonerated yesterday after the police arrested a look-alike suspect.

The House Banking Committee has approved a bill that would authorize $2 billion in Government loan guarantees for companies in trouble, especially for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, which says it must have $250 million immediately to save it from bankruptcy.

A privately researched report on the Kent State University shootings, which is being widely circulated by a church group, contends that a small group of Ohio National Guardsmen had agreed among themselves to "punish" students and opened fire on a signal.

ROME -- Italy's political enfant terrible, Giorgio Almirante, is an avowed ex-Fascist whose adversaries call him neo-Fascist and who is certainly at least quasi-Fascist. Mild mannered, quiet, he prefers to think of himself as a "qualitative democrat" who favors liberty for everybody except the Communists, whom he would outlaw.
Offtrack horseplayers had to do their wagering by the manual system yesterday after the Offtrack Betting Corporation's computers broke down for the second day in a row.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The newspapers and news agencies that accepted as genuine the "top-secret" papers on Vietnam published by National Review this week were not the only ones embarrassed when William F. Buckley Jr., the conservative magazine's publisher, admitted yesterday that he had perpetrated a hoax. They had high official company.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22 -- American battle deaths last week were the lowest in nearly six years, the United States command announced today. It said the total reflected the continuing withdrawal of American troops and the low level of combat.

It has a 400-mile Red Sea coastline and is bordered also by Egypt, Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda, the Congo, Chad, Libya and the Central African Republic.

Stock prices retreated yesterday under the pressure of mildly negative news on the economic front. It was a sleepy, rather dispirited pullback with some poorer earnings reports causing pronounced declines in individual issues.

Conjecture in New York financial circles late yesterday indicated that John Y. Brown Jr., chairman of the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation, is expected to resign that post shortly and become a top executive and principal of Lum's, Inc.
Plans for a redesigned 540-foot high New York Telephone Company equipment center, which would dominate an area just north of the Brooklyn Bridge, were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

Five-year-old Monty Gibbs, wearing a junior-sized Yankee uniform, stood in the middle of the New York clubhouse after yesterday's game and evoked boisterous laughs from the bigger boys in regularsized Yankee uniforms by imitating Horace Clarke at bat.

The Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's second largest chemical company, following the industry leader E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., had lower profits in the quarter and six months that ended June 30, despite slightly higher sales, it was reported yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 22 -- The World Conference on Peace Through Law gave tentative approval today to a proposed treaty to control cloud seeding and other forms of weather modification, although an official of the World Meteorological Organization said that weather-changing efforts usually do not work.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 22 -- Any thought that "Catch-22" might be a victim of overexposure is dispelled by the stage version that Joseph Heller has adapted from his novel. The play is having its premiere engagement at the John Drew Theater under the direction of Larry Arrick.
CAIRO, July 22 -- The Sudanese leader who was deposed in a coup d'etat Monday reclaimed power today after neighboring Libya ordered a plane carrying two of his rivals down and took them into custody.
HARRISON, N. Y., July 22 -- Arnold Palmer, who has been resting from tournament golf, put together a 64 today, his low round of the year, to lead the $250,000 Westchester Classic by a stroke.

In a radio interview here recently, Walt W. Rostow complained bitterly against publication of the Pentagon papers by The Times on the ground that they represented a distortion, being incomplete, and accompanied by commentary which he viewed as misinterpretation.

H. Hentz Co., Inc., responding to a $5-million lawsuit filed against it by the Insurance Commissioner of Florida, said yesterday that it had complied with all legal requirements and New York Stock Exchange rules in handling sales for an insurance company.

Lester Markel believes that an independent, well-funded, innovative public TV, once it is weaned from "Capitol Hill and Corporation Heights," could make average citizens more knowledgeable. [Op-Ed July 8.]
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Genoa Salami, an Armour Company product, is being recalled from stores because nine persons became ill from eating it, the Agriculture Department said today.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- That much neglected combination, good pitching and good hitting in the same game, was rediscovered by the New York Mets today. Tom Seaver pitched a six-hitter, Tommie Agee hit two home runs and Ken Boswell one, and the Mets ended a harrowing trip with a 5-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

"Omo Africa" is a small, eager company of a dozen dancers and musicians who have interested themselves in the use and development of ethnic dance materials. While their enthusiasm is commendable, their expertise trails behind at some considerable distance.

The Treasury Department announced in Washington yesterday that it has banned all speculative trading in gold coins, effective immediately. AREA ABluefish, from 5 to 12 pounds, are being found in quantity on Barnegt Ridge by boats chumming with ground mossbunkers. Anglers are using butterfish, smelt and bunkerbacks. School tuna, 12 to 25 pounds, are being captured in smaller amounts in the same area.

Thousands of patrons -- mostly youths in informal attire -- waited overnight Wednesday at Madison Square Garden and at more than 100 Ticketron outlets for tickets to two benefit shows featuring two of the four Beatles, George Harrison and Ringo Starr, and the Indian sitar player Ravi Shankar.

TRENTON, July 22 (UPI) -- Gov. William T. Cahill has asked for a full financial disclosure on the proposed College Football Hall of Fame to be built on property belonging to Rutgers, the state university.

MOSCOW, July 22 -- Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, who is now only one step from challenging the Soviet grandmaster Boris Spassky for the world chess title, has suddenly become a celebrity in the chess-crazy Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Arms Control and Disarmament Agency maintained today that despite recent progress in seismic detection, the United States must still insist upon some on-site inspections to monitor a ban on underground nuclear tests.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, July 22 (UPI) -- The Armco Steel Corporation reported today it would lay off 250 regular employes next week at its Ashland, Ky., works because of declining demand for flat rolled products.

"I have never heard such language in the House," said Representative Gerald R. Ford, the House Republican leader, as he demanded that Representative William Clay, a Missouri Democrat, apologize for remarks about Vice President Agnew.
Ruth Lopez, small and blond, was beside herself with joy. She danced elfishly about the classroom, hardly noticing her companions busily playing with sand and printing block letters on posters.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy, in an experiment to see whether tighter supervision will mean better police service and less corruption, yesterday ordered a vast increase in the number of sergeants assigned to four widely scattered precincts.

It is difficult to know when and how the Scarpetta v. De Martino case and the fate of "Baby Lenore" will ultimately be settled, but as a board member of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, I can no longer refrain from making a strong protest of the treatment accorded the agency by the press.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 22 (UPI) -- Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., making effective use of drop shots, toppled fifth-seeded Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., 6-4, 6-3, today to continue the wave of upsets in the $50,000 First National tennis tournament.

Number 10's helmet looks too big. It dwarfs his narrow shoulders and on the football field, wearing gray shorts, he appears to be a high school sprinter who is having a fling with the New York Giants at their training camp.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 22 -- Disagreement over how to cool Yugoslavia's inflated economy is blocking formation of the new Government that is due to be sworn in here within a week, Borba, the semi-official Communist party newspaper, reported today.

A 22-week-old fetus with Rh disease and anemia was partially delivered by Caesarean section Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center, given a complete blood transfusion through the neck artery and returned to the womb to continue gestation.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- American negotiators have proposed to the Soviet Union an arms control agreement that would halt construction of both land-based missiles and missile submarines.

RAMTHA, Jordan, July 22 -- Syrian-based Arab commandos stepped up their attacks on northern Jordanian border areas last night and today, despite a statement by King Hussein that life had returned to normal in Jordan.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Senate agreed today to vote Monday on a move to limit debate on legislation designed to aid the financially pressed Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 22 -- A three-judge Federal court warned the Alabama Legislature today to be prepared to hold special midterm elections next year to meet the constitutional demands of legislative apportionment.
The Federal Reserve System's restrictive stance in the money market was clearly evident this week, banking figures published yesterday showed.
The Marine Midland Bank yesterday announced the election of Ulric St. Clair Haynes Jr. as a director. Mr. Haynes is senior vice president of Spencer Stuart Associaees, management consultants.

William Rivera, 12 years old, stood guard over the family belongings in the lobby of the Concourse-Plaza Hotel in the Bronx. The Rivera possessions were packed in suitcases, in cartons, in plastic garbage bags. Some were piled in food carts.

TOKYO, July 22 -- From conservatives to radicals, a consensus seems to be shaping up that, as a result of President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Peking, Japan confronts a major change in her China policy, and perhaps in her policy toward the United States as well.

"I want you to know, this is the first time I've strung beads since I got out of kindergarten," said the stockbroker, as he leaned forward to pick up another tiny bead and slide it over a long needle and down a white thread.

At a time when some other companies have been leaving New York City for the suburbs, a manufacturer of office furniture has moved from Valley Stream, L.I., to the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. A previous owner moved the plant from the city in 1964.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., July 22 -- A Burlington County jury here late today found a Hudson County police captain and two Northern New Jersey gambling figures guilty of conspiracy and bribery in the protection of gambling rackets

Representatives of the Long Island State Park Commission and union lifeguards, who have refused to work at Long Island's state beaches since the season began six weeks ago, will meet today for the first time since June 30 to discuss their contract dispute.
About 80,000 dissident telephone workers in the country remained away from their jobs yesterday, continuing their defiance of national leaders of the Communications Workers of America.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Three recent large-scale studies in the United States and Canada indicate that illicit drug use is far higher than average among teen-agers whose parents use tranquilizers or stimulant medications regularly, a leader in one of the studies said today.
MADRID, July 22 (UPI) -- The Government confirmed tonight that there was an outbreak of cholera in northeastern Spain, but said that the situation was under control.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 22 -- The director of Creedmoor State Hospital testified today that he had supplemented his $37,500 annual state salary with $28,200 in outside fees.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A number of wives of American prisoners of war lashed out today at John F. Kerry, the peace-group leader, accusing him of using the prisoner issue as a springboard to political office.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Nixon Administration backed down today on a controversial proposal that would have cut an estimated 275,000 welfare recipients from the Federal food stamp program.

AMHERST, Mass., July 22 -- Such are the uncertainties of pro football that Mike Taliaferro, forgotten, alienated and asking to be traded a few days ago, is suddenly the No. 1 quarterback of the New England Patriots, a team with a future and 46,000 season tickets sold for its new stadium.

The two sons of the late Samuel Bronfman, founder and president of Distillers-Sea-grams, Ltd. -- Edgar M. Bronfman and Charles R. Bronfman -- were elected at a directors' meeting yesterday to the top executive posts of the Montreal-based liquor concern.

AUGUSTA, Me., July 22 -- The Maine Environmental Improvement Commission yesterday denied the application of Maine Clean Fuels, Inc., to construct a $150-million oil refinery on tiny, uninhabited Sears Island, in Penobscot Bay.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., July 22 (AP) -- Five charges of first-degree murder were filed against a Sheboygan youth today, alleging that he shot and killed his widowed mother and the mother and three brothers of a former girl friend.

A Yonkers Raceway director who chatted in the track's dining room with Nicholas (Cockeye Nick) Rattenni shortly before a suspicious exacta race on June 7 denied under oath yesterday that he had any "improper association" with the reputed Westchester County underworld boss.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 22 -- The Westchester County beach at Glen Island was closed today after the New Rochelle Health Department found what it called an unsafe bacterial count.

BERLIN, July 22 -- The Ambassadors of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union held a thorny and relatively brief session today in their protracted effort to resolve some of their differences over Berlin.
LONDON, July 22 -- Britain demanded today that Libya apologize for causing a British Overseas Airways Corporation VC-10 airliner to land at Benghazi.
NEWARK, July 22 -- Fourteen persons were injured today, five of them seriously, in an explosion in a resin-fabricating building of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company plant here.

PARIS, July 22 -- North Vietnam's chief delegate, Xuan Thuy, apparently alluding to President Nixon's plans to visit Peking, accused the United States today of seeking to divide the Communist world by "perfidious maneuvers" in a "false offensive" for peace in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, reaffirmed today his opposition to letting the states participate in the benefits of revenue sharing, or whatever new form of direct financial aid to local governments ultimately emerges from his committee.
LEICESTER, England, July 22 (UPI) -- Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., defeated a limping Mrs. Judy Dalton of Australia, 3-6, 8-6, 6-4, today to gain the final in the Midland tennis tournament.

LEWISBURG, Pa., July 22 (AP) -- Martin Sweig, who was chief administrative aide to former House Speaker John W. McCormack, entered the Federal penitentiary here today to begin a 30-month sentence for lying to a Federal grand jury that was investigating influence peddling and for misuse of the Speaker's office.

NEWARK, July 22 -- Acting on information supplied by Salvatore Provenzano, president of the New Jersey Joint Teamsters Council, a Federal grand jury has deleted his name from a counterfeiting indictment and substituted that of his local's business agent.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 22 -- Roosevelt Raceway opens a 72-program harness-racing meeting tomorrow night with its innovative triple again added to the customary win, place, show, daily double and exacta wagering.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The top-ranked teams went into action in the Spingold knockout team championship this afternoon after enjoying a bye-round yesterday in the feature of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

Gib McCabe, a Newsweek man for 29 years, once its publisher and now its vice chairman, will be getting the Henry Johnson Fisher Award. It's the biggest thing in the magazine industry, the Publisher of the Year.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy and a group of veterans from his 1968 campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination met in New York's St. Regis Hotel yesterday and for six hours discussed what he should do in 1972.
NEW ORLEANS, July 22 (AP) -- Delegates to the Elks' national convention rejected today a resolution to remove the word "white" from the organization's membership requirements.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The general manager of the American Public Gas Association charged before a Congressional committee today that the Federal Power Commission had failed to protect consumer interests when it approved a $4-billion increase in gas rates. It acted, he said, on the basis of questionable evidence.

Members of humane organizations here have formed a coalition to effect a "thorough reformation of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals," which they contend is itself cruel to animals.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A House vote on President Nixon's bill to give Federal money to school districts that are desegregating appeared today to have been delayed at least until the beginning of school in September.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A senior official of a Congressional watchdog agency delivered an indictment today of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, a major Federal project to help states to combat crime.

A series of lectures by various communication leaders on 'Freedom of Expression -- Foundation of American Liberties" will be sponsored by the Edward L. Bernays Foundation of Cambridge, Mass., it was announced yesterday by Mr. Bernays.

HARRISON, N. Y., July 22 -- "Arnie's Army" was prepared for a good showing from its man and so were "Lee's Fleas," but nobody was quite prepared for the seven-under-par 65 that Larry Wood shot in the opening round of the Westchester Classic yesterday.
The American Electric Power Company reported yesterday records in net income and per-share earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30 and for the month of June.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Nixon and Secretary of State William P. Rogers conferred at the White House today in an attempt to define United States policy on the thorny problem of Chinese representation at the United Nations.

DENVER, July 22 -- Republican leaders prepared today for a radical increase in the number of women delegates at their national convention next year and a modest rise in representation for black and young people.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- Representative Robert H. Steele said today that the South Vietnamese general he accused of being a heroin trafficker was also being investigated in connection with the looting of two abandoned United States military bases.
HEBRON, Israeli-Occupied Jordan, July 21 -- A new attempt to assert an independent Palestinian role for the moderate west-bank leaders is taking shape here this week.

A new ambulatory detoxification program, featuring treatment with methadone for seven-day periods and aimed at reaching 36,000 of the city's estimated total of 150,000 heroin addicts, was announced by Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

Jazz, traditionally a nocturnal art, is turning up more and more as a daytime divertisement. This is not precisely a new turn of events. Six years ago businessmen began blowing off their jazz steam at weekly jam sessions called "Jazz at Noon" at Chuck's Composite, a restaurant on East 53d Street.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 22 -- Winston Hill, the Jets' 278-pound all-pro tackle, may be the best customer for the scale in the Hofstra field-house. He checks his weight four times daily.
Texaco, Inc., and the Getty Oil Company yesterday announced earnings gains for the quarter and first six months of 1971.

Despite the oft-proved capabilities of the Soviet intelligence services, the Kremlin evidently was as surprised as everybody else when the Nixon trip to China was announced. That there was no Moscow "line" on the subject became clear earlier in the week when sharply different reactions appeared in Warsaw and Sofia.
American Ballet Theater's production of Fokine's "Petrushka" is a beautiful and tactful realization of a modern classic.

Wustenchef, the Augustin Stables' German-bred campaigner, won the $22,450 Meadowbrook Hurdles at Aqueduct yesterday for his third stakes triumph in a row. The achievement emphasized Wustenchef's versatility, for in his last outing he won the Sussex Handicap on the turf.
The Court on the Judiciary will attempt to question a witness who told a Senate subcommittee of two occasions that he had bribed State Suppreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer.

General Nimeiry's reported return to power only three days after he was ousted by a junta of left-leaning officers underscores the continuing instability of the Sudan -- indeed, of the whole Arab world.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, chairman of the judiciary subcommittee on refugees, publicly implied today that the United States was planning to send police teams to East Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Under pressure from welfare rights activists, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare disclosed for public comment today a controversial proposal by Gov. Ronald Reagan of California for special exemption from some Federal Medicaid regulations for his state.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- House and Senate conferees agreed today to open the way for a further expansion of trade with Communist countries, including China, by authorizing the Export-Import Bank to supply export credits for shipments to those countries.
R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., the giant tobacco, shipping and foods concern, reported yesterday a 30.1 per cent leap in its second-quarter profit. Both earnings and sales reached record levels.

PARIS, July 22 -- The Dassault Company and the Breguet Company, two large builders of airplanes in France, announced today they would merge into a new $300-million - a - year enterprise to be called the Marcel Dassault-Breguet Aviation Company.
LONDON, July 22 -- The House of Commons debate on British entry into the Common Market brought an unusual apology today from Harold Wilson, leader of the Labor party Opposition.
SAIGON, July 22 (AP) -- South Vietnamese troops sweeping through eastern Cambodia in a new drive clashed for the first time today with North Vietnamese forces.

GENEVA, July 22 -- Robert E. Slater, president of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., has rejected the claim that this embattled financial group is in default on a $5-million loan from a subsidiary of the International Controls Corporation of Plainfield, N. J., it was learned today.
The New York City Transit Authority has begun using urinalysis to determine whether job applicants are drug users, and is rejecting those whose test results are positive.
Anthony Augello, a reputed Mafia figure, was arrested last night after the police allegedly found two loaded .38-caliber pistols in the car he was driving in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- New orders for durable goods, an important "leading indicator" of the economy, declined in June after increasing in May, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A witness who said he spent 20 years on the shady side of the securities field and businesses related to it told a Senate subcommittee today of a second instance in which he allegedly bribed Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer of the New York Supreme Court.

The odds against scoring a hit with a new stage production either on or off Broadway are estimated to be about 10 to 1. The chances of succeeding with a revival, according to Theodore Mann, founder-producer-director of the Circle in the Square, are "in 1,000."
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The House by voice vote today increased by $50,000 a year the clerical allowance for the office of Speaker Carl Albert, Democrat of Oklahoma.

The Jersey Central Power and Light Company sued the General Electric Company yesterday for $62.8-million in damages allegedly suffered from the delayed completion of the Oyster Creek, N.J., nuclear generating station.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Public Health Service estimates that one out of every 10 microwave ovens in home use in the United States last year probably leaked radiation in excess of the industry's own voluntary limits.

ROME, July 22 -- It's not easy being king of anything, as many monarchs have observed, but Valentino manages. He never falls on his face. With a fall collection that is pure, classic and tailored, he secures his crown for another year.

CAIRO, July 22 -- The leaders of a challenge to the authority of President Anwar el-Sadat last May will be tried on charges of high treason, the prosecutor of Egypt, Dr. Mustafa Abu Zeid Fahmy, said during a television broadcast tonight.

HOUSTON, July 22 -- A virus that has killed more than 1,000 horses in Texas may have established a foothold in three other states -- Oklahoma, Louisiana and Arkansas -- the United States Department of Agriculture said today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Commercial banks have set up an investment company called Minibanc with projected assets of $3-million to $10-million to lend capital to minority-owned banks, the American Bankers Association announced yesterday.
Brewer Shipley, a folk-singing duo who live on a farm outside Kansas City, are playing through Monday at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.
MANILA, July 22 -- Anti-Communist crusaders from 45 nations began their annual convention here today determined to carry on despite the thaw in relations between the United States and China.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 22 -- Despite thundershowers and the threat of lightning strikes, launching pad technicians continued preparations tonight for Apollo 15, the moon-landing mission set for liftoff next Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Chicago North Western Railway and the United Transportation Union reached agreement today on a new contract. It was the first major breakthrough in the long dispute between the union and the nation's railroads.

There was a 7.5 per cent increase in the number of murders, rapes robberies and assaults -crimes against the person -reported to the Police Department last month, Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday.

The results of an investigation into alleged wrongdoing by State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer will be reported to the Court on the Judiciary by the end of September, the counsel for the court said yesterday.
HEBRON, Israeli-Occupied Jordan, July 21 -- On a rocky hillside at the edge of this ancient city of the Patriarchs an extraordinary apartment house is nearing completion.

New York's banned harness-racing stars are being given the cold shoulder by other tracks, a phone check disclosed yesterday.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 23 (AP) -- The House of Deputies voted today to impeach President Jorge Pacheco Areco but the move failed to obtain the two-thirds majority needed to immediately oust him.

A 25-year-old clerk employed by the Bankers Trust Company was seized yesterday on a busy street in the financial district as he sought to sell $1.2-million in negotiable securities for $40,000, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.
Rabbi Meir Kahane received a five-year suspended sentence, was fined $5,000 and was placed on probation for five years here yesterday for plotting to make a bomb.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A strike appeared probable tonight against two more major railroads tomorrow morning, as negotiators for the rail carriers and the United Transportation Union failed to break a deadlock at the bargaining table today.

BOSTON, July 23 (UPI) -- Lawyers for Daniel Ellsberg filed a nine-page brief with a Federal magistrate today, detailing their contention that because of illegally obtained wiretap evidence Dr. Ellsberg should not stand trial for leaking the Pentagon papers.

NEWTOWN, Conn. -- America's latest weekend sport is "tag" sales, also known as garage sales since that is where they are most frequently held. In the East, tag sales abound throughout spring, summer and fall in suburban areas of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut. They are going concerns in California, and elsewhere in the country they are growing rapidly.

The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday at San Francisco that it would most likely have to raise about $500-million of new capital next year to finance its construction program. This would be in addition to the $300-million it exppects to raise from an offering of common shares in September.
HATTIESBURG, Miss., July 23 (AP) -- The New Orleans Saints of the National Football League signed Archie Manning, their No. 1 draft choice, to a multiyear contract today.

Tubman's long tenure as the autocratic but sometimes benevolent President of Liberia, now ended at 75, must be judged against the unique and checkered history of the African republic founded by freed American slaves. The city's comprehensive air-pollution-control code, which was passed by the City Council on July 13, will not be signed into law until Aug. 21, in order to give the Environmental Protection Administration time to set up machinery to enforce it, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

Walter E. Auch says some misunderstandings exist about insurance against losses in mutual funds. He should know. He is president of Nations Securites and Research, which offers such protection to buyers of its Fairfield Fund.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 23 -- A squadron of 130 craft will launch the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise tomorrow morning with a traditional sail from Newport, R. I., to Padanaram Mass.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 23 -The prosecution prepared to rest its case today against Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader who is being tried a second time for the fatal shooting of an Oakland policeman.

Poor relief, the authors suggest, is not systematic charity but systemic sanitation, clearing up the noisome statistical debris of recurring economic crises.

A hijacker with a gun at the back of a terrified stewardess was shot and killed on a Kennedy Airport runway yesterday as he moved toward a Trans World Airlines jet he had ordered for a flight to Milan, Italy, his second air piracy of the day.

There are so-called "money" players in every sport, and the Philadelphia Phillies not only have one, he even bears the name. Last night in Veterans Stadium, Don Money hit his sixth homer of the season to provide the decisive run in the Phillies' 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
Perhaps I missed the point, but your Amtrak editorial (July 14) left me with a nagging thought. Is there some truth to charges that the press waits for the news to happen to it?

NEW ORLEANS July 23 (AP) -- Fire raced through the 12th floor of the downtown Howard Johnson Motor Lodge today, killing six persons and forcing some guests to escape by swinging down four stories from balcony to balcony.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A substantial minority of the shareholders of the Fidelity Trend Fund voted today to require this mutual fund to make public a detailed justification of the annual fee it pays to its managers.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- Arthur Penn, the American film director, today received praise from Pravda, the Communist party paper, for his "Little Big Man," which the paper described as having exposed "the enormous crimes against mankind that have marked the path of capitalism from the beginning to our days."

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson announced today that the Nixon Administration was ready to begin disbursing emergency job funds to 700 state and local governments as soon as Congress provided the money.
HOUSTON, July 23 -- In the heat of the Astrohall, Muhammad Ali flopped back on a rubbing table today after his workout.

CAIRO, July 23 -- President Anwar el-Sadat declared tonight that he would not allow 1971 to lapse without a decision for war against Israel unless agreement was achieved for a withdrawal by Israeli troops from all Arab territories occupied in 1967.

CAIRO, July 23 -- Four of the leftist officers in the Sudan who ousted Premier Gaafar al-Nimeiry Monday and in turn were overthrown yesterday were executed by a firing squad in Khartoum today, the official Sudanese radio reported.

The Air Force has awarded the Hughes Aircraft Company a $69.9-million contract to build a new television-guided missile to be fired by fighter planes against tanks, artillery and other ground targets.

PARIS, July 23 -- Two Sudanese diplomats proclaiming loyalty to Premier Nimeiry said today that the Communists had tried to depose him because time was running out against them, and predicted that the counterstroke would be "fierce."

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Three top-ranked teams headed by New York experts faced tough matches in the third round of the Spingold knockout team play at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here this afternoon.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 23 -President Salvador Allende Gossens, leader of Chile's left-wing Government, and General Alejandro Agustin Lanusse, Argentina's military President, began a two-day meeting today on a wide range of common problems.

Yet another collection of color-splashed, boldly patterned patchwork skirts has arrived in town from yet another Appalachian cottage industries program. Not the least of the virtues of the 50 one-of-a-kind fashions from the Patch Blossom Exclusive collection that are at Altman's are the moderate prices for the eye-catching designs. On view in the third-floor Studio III shop are minis, $50; midis, $60, and maxis, $70.

" I've had to do things to this country that no one ever should have to do," President Jorge Pacheco Areco told a visitor to Uruguay last year. He meant that he had felt compelled to impose drastic measures utterly foreign to South America's most durable democracy in an effort to recharge an economy plagued by inflation, inefficiency and strikes, and to maintain public order against the urban terrorism of the Tupamaro revolutionaries.

The Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct today will have a gross value of $117,100 if all 14 overnight entrants "go." The winner of the 1 1/4-mile test will earn $70,260. Listed for its 83d running, the Brooklyn is the third part of the New York Racing Association's handicap triple crown, which has been won only three times.

SOTOGRANDE, Spain, July 23 -- "We have quite a lot of counts here," Mrs. Ann Clay, the English public-relations woman for Sotogrande, said as she turned down the offer of an orange slice for her second glass of Sangria.
GREEN BAY, Wis., July 23 (AP) -- Surgeons will replace part of a tendon in Bart Starr's aching throwing arm, the Green Bay Packers announced today.
BONN, July 23 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt indicated today that he expected a four-power settlement of the Berlin problem during the autumn.

HAUPPAGE, L. I., July 23 -- The former director of a state mental hospital that had a staff but no facilities testified today that at least three such hospitals and five state schools exist throughout the state.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Senator Stuart Symington disclosed today that the Administration still intended to permit approximately $15-million in arms to be shipped to Pakistan despite repeated official statements implying that a total embargo had been imposed on arms since civil war broke out in East Pakistan March 25.

DALLAS, July 23 (AP) -- Bob Hayes, Dallas Cowboys wide receiver, says he paid $200 to keep an extortionist from kidnaping his daughter and bombing the homes of Coach Tom Landry and the club president, Tex Schramm.

HARRISON, N. Y., July 23 -- Lee Trevino, the Texan whose spectacular golf swept the United States, Canadian and British Open championships during the last month, failed by one stroke today to qualify for the last 36 holes of the $250,000 Westchester Classic as Arnold Palmer continued to set the pace.
Prices, drifted lower again on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, with the index closing at 25.44, down 0.03. A week ago the index stood at 25.61.

MEXICO CITY, July 23 -- Attorney General Julio Sanchez Vargas announced last night that an official investigation had failed to identify the rightwing extremists who fired upon leftist student demonstrators on June 10, killing 13.

A four-man delegation of American church and synagogue leaders, just returned from a week-long trip to the Soviet Union, reported yesterday that they "look to the future of religion in the Soviet Union with cautious optimism."

SAN DIEGO, July 23 -- The Republican party's decision to hold its 1972 convention in San Diego was greeted tonight with scattered cheers and considerable misgivings among this city's 700,000 citizens despite their predominantly Republican loyalties.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (AP) -- A band of 15 enemy demolition men staged an attack early today on the headquarters in South Vietnam for the recently begun South Vietnamese sweep in eastern Cambodia.

The Chemical Bank announced yesterday the appointment of six vice presidents. All had been assistant vice presidents, and all, except one, are with the bank's national division. The exception is Robert A. McBride of the metropolitan division. The other vice presidents are John A. Farnsworth, William C. Pierce, Robert L. Thornton 3d, Warren T. Upson and Royall Victor 3d.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 23 (UPI) -- Fans created a disturbance at Monmouth Park today when the third race exacta payoff was $63.40 after the winning horse paid $34.60 straight.

SALISBURY, Conn. -- Among the staggering problems that face the President on the day he takes office, the appointment of ambassadors might be considered among the less urgent. Embassies can run for some time on their own momentum, but eventually the President will have to sit down with his Secretary of State and divide up the embassies between career officers and political friends.

In a market dominated by earnings reports and earnings prospects, stock prices edged lower yesterday. On Wall Street, some analysts described the market as "currently indecisive.''

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 23 -- The Atomic Energy Commission has signed four new contracts to provide $323,886,496 in uranium enrichment services to the nuclear power industry. These bring the total of all contracts to approximately $4-billion.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Consumer prices rose strongly in June for the second consecutive month, following four months of slackened inflation, the Labor Department reported today.

A group of high-ranking State Department officials and members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee walked around one of the seamiest blocks in Harlem yesterday as part of a tour "to see what the end of the heroin pipeline looks like, to meet with addicts and to see them."

Prices on new stock issues retreated across a broad front this week in quiet trading activity.
The Lykes-Youngstown Corporation reported yesterday second-quarter earnings of $10.3-million, up 152 per cent from the year-earlier period.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board confessed to Congress today that there had been "very little progress" in checking inflation and said this lack of progress constituted "a grave obstacle" to a rapid recovery in production and employment.

State Senator Seymour R. Thaler's letter of June 25 defends his actions in helping to kill the bills before the State Legislature to toll the East River bridges. That letter demands a response, because it is factually incorrect and because it implies that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (M.T.A.) misled him.
John Y. Brown Jr., denied yesterday reports that he planned to resign as chairman of the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation, the nation's largest commercial food-service company.
President Tito of Yugoslavia will visit the United States in October, to return the visit President Nixon made to Yugoslavia last year.
A leading authority on accounting called on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to play a more "militant" role in promoting good corporate reporting practices.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The head of a leading environmental organization has urged President Nixon to support William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, in his struggle against Administration officials who want to relax enforcement of the 1970 Clean Air Act.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Food and Drug Administration moved today to accelerate the collection of Bon Vivant soups and other food products after finding evidence of under-processing in the company's black bean soup and in more of its vichyssoise.

PASSAIC, N. J., July 23 -Leo Berna, a 67-year-old Passaic resident and former restaurant owner who retired last year, now holds a winning $50,000 New Jersey lottery ticket on the drawing held yesterday after having won another $50,000 last Jan. 28.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I. July 23 -- Kendrick R. Wilson Jr.'s Troon, a Whitby-45 of the host club fleet, won her third daily squadron run on the 40th annual American Yacht Club cruise today. But the boat she beat by more than 5 1/2 minutes of corrected time in the final race of the six-day voyage wound up as the series champion in the International Offshore Rule Division.
MADRID, July 23 -- Spain has asked the United States for 10 million doses of anticholera vaccine, according to informed sources here.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. -Despite a windstorm, soft economic conditions and bathless bathhouses, this old resort is turning a sunnily optimistic face toward "the season."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 23 -- The United Transportation Union, which represents 1,600 Long Island Railroad trainmen, announced today that it would strike the railroad at 5 P.M. on Monday unless Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the line enters contract negotiations.
Wheat and corn were lower, oats fractionally lower and soybeans substantially lower at the close today on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Detectives arrested 12 persons early yesterday morning in a luxurious East Side penthouse that allegedly was the center of a $100-a-night call-girl operation.
MOSCOW, July 23 -- The Soviet Union reported today that its industry continued to perform at a higher rate than planned for the first six months of the year.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- Gennadi I. Voronov, a member of the ruling Communist party Politburo, today lost his post as head of the Russian Republic's government and was transferred to a less important ministerial assignment.

The National Broadcasting Company has petitioned the Federal Communications Commission for a rehearing on the agency's ruling that Esso ads carried on the network promoted one side of a controversial issue.

DENVER, July 23 -- The Republican party decided tonight to hold its 1972 Presidential convention in San Diego, deep in politically conservative Southern California and conveniently near the summer White House in San Clemente.
Anthony Augello, who the police say is an associate of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., way held in $100,000 bail in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday, charged with illegally possessing weapons.

LONDON, July 23 -- The question dominating political talk in Britain is whether Harold Wilson, after all his years of careful balancing, is headed now for a great fall. His performance in the last week has begun to raise doubts about whether he can keep a grip on himself and on the leadership of the Labor party.
The telephone strike became concentrated in New York State yesterday as large blocs of workers in New Jersey and Connecticut settled with their companies and went back on the job.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 23 -- After a five-day lull, Tampa Bay's so-called red tide, a neurotoxin that discolors sea water and in heavy concentrations kills fish, returned in force today.

About 10 per cent of the paint offered for sale in New York City for interior use contains more lead than is allowed by law, according to a high city official who warned that the paint could cause lead poisoning of children.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- An instant transaction system is designed to transfer money from one bank account to another by telephone. A depositor will be able to select a purchase in a shop have his bank credit the necessary funds to the store and walk away with his parcel and a printed sales receipt.

SAIGON, July 23 -- Contenders for South Vietnam's presidency are filling the air these days with charges and countercharges, some aimed at the United States, some at each other. A few are even intended to influence the voters.

MILWAUKEE, July 23 -- While Bo Diddley, Chuck Berry and Little Richard rocked and rolled at Milwaukee's Summerfest on the shores of Lake Michigan tonight, the Yankees beat out a rhythm of two-run singles and defeated the Brewers, 6-2.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 23 -- As Roosevelt Raceway reopened its doors tonight for the start of a 72-card summer meeting, George Morton Levy, the president, foresaw drops of 5 per cent each in both attendance and wagering during the stand, which will last through Oct. 14. Offtrack betting, Levy said, would be the cause of the slumps.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Defense Department today argued publicly, as it has been contending privately, that nuclear testing must be continued to assure the reliability of the United States' atomic arsenal.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Government might be forced to start conscripting men previously deferred from the draft unless Congress passed a draft extension bill by September.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today a search in 12 states for broiler chickens and chicken feed that may be contaminated by an industrial chemical.

WASHINGTON July 23 -- Since 1961, a total of 150 persons have been accused of 115 hijackings of United States aircraft, and one of foreign registry, engaged in air commerce in this country, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

DETROIT, July 23 -- The automobile makers today reported their dealers delivered 260,990 American-type cars in mid-July, up 29 per cent from 202,966 a year before and a record for the July 11-20 period.

CALI, Colombia, July 24 -- Colombia's President, Misael Pastrana, arrived here today, dedicated the international airport at which he had just landed, and then proceeded to dedicate a superhighway, a colored fountain, a free train, a luxury hotel, a baseball stadium, an Olympic pool, a covered gymnasium as capacious as Madison Square Garden and a bike racing track.

STRATFORD, CONN. JANE ALEXANDER, grimly costumed in black, is acting out her final speech as Lavinia Mannon in Eugene O'Neill's "Mourning Becomes Electra," now playing in repertory here at the American Shakespeare Festival. The audience sits in mesmerized stillness at the end of a four-hour matinee.
