CAIRO, July 25 -- President Anwar el-Sadat has drafted a 10-year program to stimulate economic and social development aimed at creating "a new man" in Egypt.
A young man arrested recently in Madison, Wis., as a marijuana dealer has turned out to be a major theoretician and behind-the-scenes leader of the underground youth movement.

BRUSSELS, July 25 -- International bond prices declined last week as renewed speculation on the future of the West German mark, and, to some degree, the French franc, have shaken loose some sell orders. But the price decline has done nothing to impede the steady flow of new issues.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 25 -- Sta-Still Farms's Better Smile, ridden by Mrs. Sarah Steall, captured one class and finished second and fourth in two others today to score 9 points and win the green working hunter championship of the Old Westburry Horse Show.
Can a poor, good-hearted Italian-American boy from Brooklyn find true love and happiness as a member of one of the American Midwest's most aristocratic families, the Chicago Cubs?
Prompted by a sharp increase in the use of bicycles, the City Department of Transportation is preparing an informational folder containing rules and advice for bicyclists.

PEKING, July 25 -- There is something a little absurd about a man publishing an obituary notice on his own appendix, but for the last 10 days this correspondent has had a chance to learn a little about the professional and political direction of a major Chinese hospital from the inside, and this is a report on how I got there and what I found.

Vida Blue and Chuck Dobson had won 27 games and lost three between them. That's what Manager Dick Williams of the Oakland Athletics served up to the Detroit Tigers yesterday and 55,565 fans, one of the largest crowds of the major league season, went to Tiger Stadium in Detroit.

Mysterious swarming clouds of winged things descended on the East Side around 23d Street yesterday afternoon, pestering residents of Peter Cooper Village and patients at Bellevue Hospital far into the night.
FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, July 25 (UPI) -- A Ford Capri came through today to win the 24-hour Francorchamps tourism car race that was marred by the fatal crash of a Belgian driver, Raymond Mathay.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- The Spingold knockout team championship quarter-finals began here this afternoon with New York represented on all but one of the surviving teams.

ATLANTA, July 25 -- The number of farms operated by Negroes in the United States has decreased in the last two decades from more than half a million to fewer than 100,000, a report by the National Sharecroppers Fund said today.
If you're buying a house, you know you'll pay a legal fee if you hire a lawyer to represent you.

WELLESVILLE, Pa., July 25 -- The Great Pyrenees, a dog of immense size, great majesty and keen intelligence, was bred to guard the flocks in all kinds of weather on the steep mountain slopes of the Pyrenees.

For the third consecutive time, the annual meeting of the World Health Organization produced a political resolution against Israel, sponsored by the Arab and Communist countries. This resolution requested that Israel immediately permit the Arab refugees and displaced persons to return to their homes and charged that the Israelis, as an occupying authority, barred the distribution of medications by the International Committee of the Red Cross (I.C.R.C.) to the inhabitants of the occupied territories.

Art auto belonging to an attache of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations was fire-bombed and slightly damaged early yesterday morning outside the cottage used by the Soviet staff at 127 Beach 27th Street, Far Rockaway, Queens.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 25 (AP) -- A United States Embassy spokesman disclosed that an Air Force sergeant had been arrested in Bangkok on charges that he had conspired to commit espionage with the Soviet Union.

KHARTOUM, July 25 -- Premier Nimeiry, in a news conference today, described in detail his two and a half days of captivity in the Presidential Palace after rebel officers seized power last Monday and his escape in the confusion that followed the loyalist counter-strike on Thursday.

BELGRADE -- The word "convergence" has become fashionable. Since 1968 when the well-known theses of Soviet academician Sakharov appeared, polemics about the convergence of the two systems have not ceased.
MILWAUKEE, July 25 -- Most teams gain their excitement from their proximity to first place, but the Yankees have to settle for lesser thrills.

FORT McPHERSON, Ga., July 25 (UPI) -- Capt. Ernest L. Medina goes on trial tomorrow charged with murdering 102 persons when soldiers under his command swept through the village of Mylai in March, 1968.
HOUSTON, July 25 -- Without a prediction and without his usual flair, Muhammad Ali will oppose Jimmy Ellis tomorrow night at the Astrodome in a 12-round bout containing more mystery than mystique.

Neither the decision of the Supreme Court in the cases of the purloined Pentagon papers nor that of the House of Representatives in the case of the C.B.S. documentary has resolved the fundamental conflict between press freedom, on which the preservation of our democracy rests, and national security, on which the preservation of our nation rests.

THURMONT, Md., July 25 (AP) -- President Nixon, who plans to watch the Apollo 15 lift-off tomorrow morning on television from his mountain retreat here at Camp David, telephoned the three astronauts today to wish them godspeed.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Gardner Ackley, a former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, proposed today a four-part "incomes policy'' to check inflation in the United States, including permanent stand-by authority for the President to impose compulsory wage and price controls.

VIENNA, July 25 -- When the 27th congress of the International Psychoanalytic Association opens here tomorrow, Dr. Leo Rangell, a genial, gregarious New Yorker turned Californian who has been its president for two years, will preside.

The average American tax-payer will have to pay $300 more each year if the United States in the nineteen-seventies is to make social improvements on a scale frequently proposed by those advocating a "reordering of national priorities," according to a New York University economist.

KITZBUEHEL, Austria, July 25 (Reuters) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King and Rosemary Casals of California won the women's doubles title and a new combination of Clark Graebner of New York and Ion Tiriac of Rumania captured the men's crown in the Austrian open tennis championships today.

MOSCOW, July 25 -- After 10 days of studying the startling turn in Chinese-American relations, the Soviet Union has published in Pravda some initial, cautious conclusions for its own people, for its allies and for Peking and Washington.
A member of a motorcycle gang was killed and a second cut and beaten on Staten Island yesterday in what the police said was another chapter in a continuing feud between rival gangs.

The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel producer, reported from Cleveland over the weekend that second-quarter earnings were 73 per cent higher than the same period last year.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 25 -- A firing squad today executed Maj. Farouk Osman Hamadallah, chief aide to Lieut. Col. Babakr al-Nur Osman, the man who would have led the Sudan if a coup last Monday had been successful.

STRATFORD, Conn. -- This is the 17th summer of the American Shakespeare Festival and the third summer that Michael Kahn has been the artistic director. Before he took over Stratford (after several years directing plays off Broadway and in regional theaters including Stratford), the festival had slipped slowly into disrepute.

Senate and House conferees, completing a bill to expand the lending authority of the Export-Import Bank, have agreed to permit the bank to supply credits for shipping American goods to Communist countries including China. President Nixon would, however, retain the power to decide whether to let the bank make particular loans to Communist countries.

Although it's been only a couple of weeks since he joined his old pals from Holiday at Travel Leisure, John S. Connors, the publisher, already has some important announcements to make. One has to do with regional editions and the other is the new ad director to head the beefed-up staff.

RED BLUFF, Calif., July 25 -- Mrs. Jock Roney deftly dipped her spoon into a jar of homemade boysenberry jam, tasted thoughtfully for a few seconds, and went on to the next one. After 14 jars she wrote down her choices, took a sip of tea and started on the blackberry preserves.

WASHINGTON, Monday, July 26 -- The Nixon Administration's chief trouble-shooter in the national railroad labor talks held out hope yesterday of an imminent solution to the dispute that has already shut down four major railroads and threatens to halt 11 more in the next two weeks.

COWDRAY PARK, England, July 25 (AP) -- Joe Barry scored four goals and Billy Linfoot three today to lead the United States to a 9-6 victory over England for the Coronation Cup. It was the first international polo match between the countries since 1939.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 25 -- After 72 hours of festivities, the score at Caesars Palace today was two $100,000 galas and a surprise wedding gown and a plane trip to the Grand Canyon to go, but as William S. Weinberger said, "I can't see why anyone would get excited. It's like this every day."

Ivan Denisovich Shukhov, prisoner S-854, is laying cinder blocks. He's in a rush. It's the end of the day, and it's more than 20 degrees below zero. "Slap on the mortar! Down with the block! Press down! Check! Mortar. Block. Mortar. Block. . . . The boss had said not to worry about the mortar -- chuck it over the wall and push off.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -An amendment to be offered Tuesday in the House of Representatives asks for a sharp increase in a health, education, welfare and labor appropriations bill that already goes substantially beyond the Administration's budget requests.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 25 -- The Apollo 15 astronauts and their complex moon-landing machinery were declared "ready to go" tonight for the scheduled launching tomorrow morning of the 12-day expedition to the foot of the rugged lunar Apennine Mountains.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The United States Embassy in Saigon has informed the State Department that "responsibility for American-fathered illegitimate children" in South Vietnam "has become a matter of serious and continuing concern."

A funeral service will be held Wednesday for Patrolman Robert Denton, who was stabbed to death early Saturday morning outside a grocery in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn after having purchased a package of cigarettes.

Martin W. Goldman, in a recent letter, urges tenant purchases required for conversion of a rent-controlled apartment house to a cooperative be increased from 35 to 51 per cent. Although superficially plausible, this suggestion is a most detrimental proposal which confuses the basic issue.

ACAPULCO, Mexico, July 14 -Thousands of peasants trekking to this Pacific coast resort each year in search of employment and a better life are bringing with them serious social problems that Acapulco is ill-equipped to handle.

Your pointed July 15 editorial on public service jobs recalls that the last systematic survey of unfilled public service jobs (at current levels of staffing), made in 1965 by President Johnson's Automation Commission, identified five million vacant positions in health, education, environmental protection, welfare and home care, public protection, and urban renewal and sanitation.
Housing and Development Commissioner Albert A. Walsh said yesterday that he expected to resume payments this week to contractors for a few rehabilitation projects under the Municipal Loan Program.

After one year, the city's new Health and Hospitals Corporation has received both official praise for management efficiency and criticism from many quarters that none of the gains have trickled down to the sick poor in the wards.
WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 25 -- Peter Revson has probably never shown such exuberance in public.
A 24-year-old service station attendant was found stabbed to death early yesterday outside an all-night gas station in the Bronx. It was his first night on the job.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Allard K. Lowenstein specializes in turning what most people consider lost causes into winners or very close things.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that securities listed on the American Stock Exchange had been included in the Big Board's Block Automation System, an automated network for communicating information on selling big blocks of stock.

DANNEMORA, N. Y., July 25 -- Six members of the New York City Ballet performed here yesterday for a large, enthusiastic audience that seemed generally unfamiliar with the company's art -- the more than 700 maximum-security prisoners at Clinton State Correctional Facility.

"Polygraph interviews," or lie-detector tests, have been administered to about 30 employes of Bonwit Teller, the Fifth Avenue specialty store, as an "experimental step" in the fight against pilferage by store personnel.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 26 -H. T. Sheridan's Over the Counter, a 16-1 outsider, beat the highly regarded Cougar II by a half-length today in winning the $138,150 Sunset Handicap at two miles on the Hollywood Park turf.

District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens announced the appointment yesterday of Anthony V. Lombardino, who has been chief of the criminal divison of the office of the Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, to head a newly appointed organized crime and rackets bureau.
EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 26 -- Northern Light, Gem, Crusader and Appledore II were the winners today in the New York Yacht Club's shortened 18-mile cruise to Martha's Vineyard.
BELGRADE -- What to do? How to live? In what to believe? Is there the smallest hope that in our confused time there is a real answer to these questions?
The United States Environmental Protection Agency has won agreement from Pfizer Inc. to cease dumping industrial sludge into Long Island Sound, it was announced yesterday.

The "road shows" and lobbying activity put on by the Legislative Action Committee of the United States Conference of Mayors appear to be succeeding enough to win emulation. The National Association of Counties has created a Council of Elected County Executives which will try to enlist aid in the solution of suburban problems, as the Mayors' Committee has been doing for the big cities.

POMFRET, Conn., July 26 -A special committee of the United States Catholic Conference Advisory Council has decided that it is not feasible now to create a fully developed national pastoral council to let laymen and priests join bishops in church decision-making.

DETROIT, July 26 -- A report on "The Strengths of Black Families," issued today by the National Urban League, contradicted what it called widely circulated studies saying that Negro families were matriarchal, disorganized, pathological and disintegrating.

Apollo 15 blasted off on schedule yesterday for what is planned to be the most scientifically productive manned trip to the moon that has yet been made. Only two years have passed since Neil Armstrong first set foot on the lunar surface, but already the historic accomplishments of the Apollo 11 crew begin to look as though they belonged to the Model-T era of moon exploration.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday new highs in sales and earnings and a record June 30 backlog for manufacturing orders.

State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer, under investigation for alleged judicial impropriety, met yesterday with his attorney, Bernard Botein, to discuss the possibility of appearing before a Senate subcommittee that is conducting an inquiry into organized crime.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (UPI) -- Cesar Cedeno, who had tied the game in the eighth and 10th innings, singled and scored the go-ahead run in the 15th tonight as the Houston Astros defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-4.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -Following a decade of substantial gains, black people in America in 1970 remained far behind whites in most social and economic areas, a Government report revealed today.
MIAMI, July 26 -- Premier Fidel Castro today ruled out any rapprochement with the United States.
NEW HAVEN, July 26 -- Women have liberated Yale, but they have not yet liberated Mory's, the tavern that puts so much of the ale into Yale.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 26 (AP) -- Huey P. Newton, a Black Panther party co-founder, took the witness stand today, as the defense opened its case, to deny that he had killed an Oakland policeman, John Frey.

A daring, heady ride by Bobby Woodhouse enabled the Pastorale Stables Twist the Axe to take the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday before a crowd of 28,091. The event, a seven-furlong sprint for older horses, attracted a halfdozen contestants and the fans made the Hobeau Farm's Handsome Kid the favorite.
Alvis Rogers of Hollis, Queens, felt he had got a raw deal on his new Chevrolet and he was angry.

Two robbers held 75 to 100 customers at gunpoint yesterday afternoon while their two partners emptied cash registers at the Speedway Supermarket at 840 East New York Avenue in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.
Steel production continued its sharp downward trend last week, falling 3.1 per cent below output the week before. The extremely low operating rate was attributed mainly to market weakness.
The Long Island State Park Commission and the union representing 360 striking lifeguards reached a tentative agreement early today, Lawrence Byrne, president of the union, reported.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 26 -New central bank regulations, reflecting the deterioration of the Chilean escudo, went into effect today raising the price of dollars for Chilean travelers with a parallel rise in the black market for dollars.
City Council President Sanford D. Garelik called on the chairmen of the Council's Finance and Housing Committees yesterday to "take a good hard look" at the city's Municipal Loan Fund.

The New York Telephone Company reported last night that second-quarter net income amounted to $43,562,000, equal to 29 cents a share, or slightly higher than the $42,425,000, or 35 cents a share, earned on fewer shares outstanding in the three months ended June 30, 1970.

The RCA Corporation, the only major American computer manufacturer without an independent marketing organization in Europe, announced yesterday the establishment of a major electronic data processing sales, management and technical operation in England.

Bob Gibson, a pitcher who can be described as being in a class by himself in several respects, established that status in another category last night by beating the New York Mets, 4-0, for the St. Louis Cardinals at Shea Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) -- Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, charged today that President Nixon's welfare proposals might build "a permanent welfare subculture" with as many as 50 million or 100 million persons on relief.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Election year 1972 is beginning to look like one of the most remarkable in history, not so much for who may win as for how victory will be sought. Are we at some turning-point of our politics, after which things will be significantly different?

GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 26 -- Lawyers for Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania appeared to retreat today from a week-long courtroom and press campaign by the Governor against construction of a 307-foot-high commercial observation tower at Gettysburg National Military Park.

Charges of brutality by guards who were accused of using excessive force to quell rioting by inmates at the Queens House of Detention for Men last fall were rejected in Federal Court yesterday as "a gigantic hoax and fraud."
Queens Surrogate John T. Clancy will resign Thursday and touch off a round of political "musical chairs" that will involve a dozen top Queens officeholders in a series of bipartisan agreements.

LONDON, July 26 -- Lord George-Brown, who served as Foreign Secretary when Harold Wilson was Prime Minister, said today that Mr. Wilson is "bound in honor" to accept the negotiated terms for British entry into the European Common Market unless he "never meant the exercise seriously in the first place."
WASHINGTON, July 26 -Negotiations between the nation's railroads and the striking United Transportation Union collapsed today, with no settlement in sight.
PITTSBURGH, July 26 -- Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., reported today that earnings for the second quarter were $3,780,000, or 48 cents a share, on sales of $141,955,000.
Dean Witter Co., Inc., a top-ranking brokerage house and the largest based on the West Coast, announced yesterday preliminary plans to sell its stock to the public.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday approved a "restructuring" of fares on the New Haven Division of the Penn Central that would serve principally to increase the price of 10-trip tickets.
The price of newsprint -the paper on which newspapers are printed -- appeared yesterday to be heading higher, while the price of zinc was definitely raised by at least two producers.
Oil companies' earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30 were mixed, reports showed yesterday.

It comes as a shock to an AngloSaxon who has been resident in Greece for the greater part of the past four and one-half years to learn that a major policy-making committee of the U.S. Government has recommended that the United States should cease to give military and economic aid to Greece until this country returns to a democratic form of government.
Danny Simon, brother of Neil Simon, has written a semi-autobiographical comedy, "Only the Shadow Knows," which will be produced on Broadway in the fall by Zev Bufman.

The Police Department said yesterday that patrolmen, dressed in civilan clothes, were being used on antimugging patrols in all 76 precincts, particularly during the peak crime hours of 6 P.M. to 2 A.M.

VIENNA, July 26 -- Sigmund Freud today received the Austrian and Viennese acclaim denied him in his lifetime as the 27th congress of the International Psychoanalytical Association opened in a former imperial reception hall, in the presence of his 75-year-old daughter, Anna.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -Legislation to rescue the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from impending bankruptcy and to authorize similar rescues, in the future, of other large companies suffered two setbacks in the Senate today.

QUEBEC, July 26 (Canadian Press) -- A grueling, two-hour match between John Alexander of Australia and Frew McMillan of South Africa highlighted the first-round singles play today at the Quebec international tennis open.

LOS ANGELES -- Mrs. Margaret Seeley, a grandmother, has had a full life. She has pursued careers as an actress and a stage manager, was a secretary for 14 years at a movie studio, has made five cross-country trips in her 1958 Plymouth and has traveled to Europe, Africa and Asia.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 26 -- Outside the Hofstra University field house, tireless young autograph-seekers compared signatures today as the New York Jets clumped in from their morning workout.

An electrical engineer, a doorman, a receptionist, a housewife and a half-dozen other civilians turned out with the radio car patrolmen of the 24th Precinct last night and cruised the Upper West Side for two hours of watching their escorts in action.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 -- Duong Van Minh, the retired general who led the 1963 coup d'etat against President Ngo Dinh Diem, announced formally today that he would run against President Nguyen Van Thieu in the Oct. 3 election.
Trading was dull and prices were down on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume drifted to 2,542,160 shares from Friday's 2,782,980. The index was off 0.06 to 25.38.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 -Housing has been one of the few segments of the economy to cheer the Nixon Administration as it looks for signs that the recession is waning. Indeed, housing starts showed surprising strength last year and have continued strong so far this year.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that a study it had sponsored indicated President Nixon's welfare reform plan would discourage relief recipients from working and could add as much as $3billion a year to welfare costs.
PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (UPI) -- Joe Frazier, the heavyweight champion, said he was unimpressed with the bout between Muhammad Ali and Jimmy Ellis.

PARIS, July 26 -- Yves Saint Laurent presented an outrageous collection on the first day of the fall and winter fashion showings here, and everybody's going to copy him. So be prepared for gigantic shoulders, lampshade dresses, stockings with black seams and quilted satin evening jackets.

Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, believes television should not draw unduly optimistic conclusions from the refusal of the House of Representatives to cite Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, for contempt of Congress.

The Norfolk Western Railway, one of four railroads that have been closed by the strike of the United Transportation Union, is "well prepared" for it, according to the railroad's president, John P. Fishwick.

BETHPAGE, L. I., July 26 -The Pentagon sent a 40-man team of Navy investigators here today to begin a threemonth investigation of the costs of three major naval aircraft production programs at the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, including production of the F-14 fighter aircraft.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- President Nixon said "godspeed" today to the Apollo 15 astronauts.

The New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that the cost of member-firm failures might be as much as $20-million higher than anticipated, mainly because of additional expenses connected with the liquidations of Blair
HOUSTON, July 26 -- At one of the moments of highest exhilaration, as the Apollo 15 astronauts set their course toward the moon today, a warning light flashed inklings of serious trouble.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (Reuters) -- The Federal Reserve Bank has proposed that margin regulations in securities transactions, which previously applied only to lenders, be extended to borrowers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 (UPI) -- The United States military command said today that 4,100 American servicemen were pulled out of the war zone last week, reducing American troop strength in Vietnam to 229,200.

DALLAS, July 26 (AP) -- The Texas School Book Depository,I from which were fired the shots that killed President I{en-I nedy in 1963, will be turned into a museum housing more than ]50,000 items associatedI with the slain President, its owner, Audrey Mayhen, said today.

An important facet of President Nixon's foreign aid policy, which in the past has received strong encouragement from some members of Congress, has been the effort to channel more American assistance through multilateral institutions such as the World Bank. The use of international aid agencies serves Mr. Nixon's objective of lowering the United States profile abroad while encouraging other advanced nations to share more fully the burden of promoting international development.

CAPE KENNEDY, July 26 -- The special meaning of the launch to the millions who come to the beach -- the true mystery -- becomes clear and part of the mind forever -in the merest unmeasurable part of a split second.

WASHINGTON, July 26, -Representative Robert H. Steele, the Connecticut Republican who has been at odds with the Nixon Administration over the extent of heroin use in Vietnam, said today that "very substantial progress" had been made in controlling servicemen's use of the drug.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the appointment of a special committee to study the report on the securities industry being prepared by William McChesney Martin Jr.

A blackout in Queens, a telephone failure in and around Bellevue Hospital, hazardous driving and air-traffic delays were the by-products of a thunderstorm here yesterday morning that dumped nearly half an inch of rain in 45 minutes.

Paul D. Townsend, director of marketing of The New York Times, will be leaving "for other business interests," Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher, announced yesterday in a staff memorandum.
FORT MCPHERSON, Ga., July 26 -- The trial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, accused by the Army of responsibility for the Mylai massacre, opened today in a small stuffy courtroom at Third Army Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) -- The Federal Power Commission issued today a three-year preliminary permit to three New England utilities for the proposed Canaan Mountain pumped-storage hydroelectric plant in Connecticut.

Robert J. Kibbee, a vice president of Carnegie-Mellon University and president of the Pittsburgh Board of Education, is scheduled to be named chancellor of the City University today by the Board of Higher Education.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 14 -Monument builders, historians, entertainers, hotel managers and the imperial Government are working at top speed to finish preparations for a royal party in October that promises to be spectacular.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 26 -- Reies Lopez Tijerina returned home today after more than two years in Federal prisons.

The Ford Motor Company realized a 19.3 per cent gain in second-quarter earnings and 26.2 per cent for the half on record sales for both periods, the nation's second largest automotive producer reported from Detroit yesterday.

Remember that scene in "All About Eve" when Anne Baxter, as mousy Eve Harrington, swept up Bette Davis-Margo Channing's costume, held it in front of her and bowed to her as-yet nonexistent audience? It was at that instant that Eve showed her mettle--and soon she was sweeping up everything from Margo: her men, her roles. Now she has even stolen her "Applause."

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday acquitted a former deputy inspector of department charges of giving "evasive answers" to a grand jury investigating alleged payoffs to the police by a convicted gambler, Hugh Mulligan.

Plans for a wing for the Museum of the City of New York are on the drawing board, and a five-year campaign has begun to raise $6.3million for a program of overall expansion and refurbishing and restructuring of the museum's role.
The bald eagle, traditional symbol of the United States, is under imminent threat of extinction -- with the tacit encouragement and active participation of the Department of the Interior.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 26 -- Jesse Philips came back with another Charisma today to record his second consecutive over-all triumph in the Bayview Yacht Club's Mackinac Island sailing race.
Wheat closed mixed, corn higher, oats fractionally higher and soybeans substantially lower on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation has voted to "take whatever steps are necessary" to insure that patients be seen by a physician within 15 minutes of their arrival in an emergency room and within 30 minutes in an outpatient department.

SCHENECTADY -- After fourteen years of technological achievements wholly unprecedented in the history of man -- capped by yesterday's Apollo moon shot -- the United States space program is losing ground to outspoken critics who advocate shifting funds from space to societal programs which appear on the surface to have a more direct and immediate impact on our national economy and well being.

DACCA, Pakistan, July 26 -- Handbills prepared by Bengali separatist guerrillas appeared in Dacca today warning the population to begin evacuation of the city in preparation for a terrorist campaign against the Pakistani Army in East Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -United States monetary reserve assets declined an additional $307-million in June to $13,504,000,000, the Treasury reported today.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 26 -- With his good friend Tucker Frederickson returning, Ernie Koy reverted today to his role as chief substitute among the Giants' running backs.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Tuesday, July 27 -- Three American astronauts, the men of Apollo 15, soared toward the moon today after a spectacular launching that was called the smoothest and most nearly flawless start of any of the nation's lunar adventures.
LISBON, July 26 -- Vice President Agnew conferred today with Premier Marcello Caetano in the last stop of the Vice President's diplomatic world tour.
Macy's has agreed to remove an allegedly bogus "union made" label from a line of imported suits offered at some of its stores, the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America said yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- The semifinal stage on the Spingold knockout team championship began here this afternoon with one team rather short of sleep. WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Democratic party's reform movement, which grew out of the divisive and uproarious 1968 convention in Chicago, may yet succeed in averting similar hostilities in 1972. Or, ironically, it may create new tensions.
