The "most crushing" consideration in his decision not to seek the 1972 Presidential nomination, said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, was the possibility of an assassination attempt.
Thank you for the moral evaluation by Bishop T. Gumbleton of the Vietnam war (Op-Ed July 2).

Much has been written about the Lockheed matter, including your July 23 editorial "The Last Refuge." The proposed legislation is not a bail-out for Lockheed, its management or its stockholders. There would be no justification for this effort if we looked at it in that narrow sense.

NEW ORLEANS, July 26 -Two sheriff's deputies were held as hostages eight hours in the New Orleans jail today by a prisoner group that included several Black Panthers on trial on charges of trying to kill policemen.

During the past several months the news media have brought to the attention of the public the conditions under which children must live when removed from their homes and sent to detention centers by the Family Court.

Emile Griffith, as agile, durable and knowledgeable as ever after 14 years of professional boxing, spoiled the Madison Square Garden debut of Nessim (Max) Cohen of Paris last night before 13,500 fans.
Two of the nation's largest primary-copper producers reported sharp declines yesterday in their second-quarter earnings.

PARIS, July 26 -- As part of efforts to draw European nations closer together, a move is under way to standardize the pitch of orchestras so that the same Beethoven symphony will not be heard in different keys.

A meeting of more than 3,300 postal clerks and letter carriers at Manhattan Center yesterday erupted into a shouting, brawling melee as the workers expressed their dissatisfaction with a new national contract.

MOSCOW, July 26 -- The Soviet authorities have apparently reduced the flow of Jews permitted to emigrate to Israel this month, but the rate continues to exceed last year's, reliable Western sources said today.
Leonard Blackman, former president of the Korvette discount department stores, has joined Sprayregen Co., an investment concern, to start a new subsidiary, Sprayregen Blackman, Inc:

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Now that they've finally attained the .500 level that has frustratingly eluded them for more than two months, the Yankees prefer to think of it not as their final goal of the season but rather as a milestone along the way to a more prestigious plateau.
William (Buddy) Gilmour, the nation's leading harness racing money winner this year, will appear today before a grand jury at the United States Court House in Foley Square.
When Bell Howell announced a couple of weeks back that it had selected N. W. Ayer Son as its new agency it meant that Coordinated Communications, Inc., was once again a bridesmaid.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 26 -- Officials said today that a noted Communist leader had been hanged and that they had captured another, who is to go on trial tomorrow for his role in the abortive leftist coup d'etat last week.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has decided to delay release of any of the Pentagon papers because of "legal" and "security" problems.

NAIROBI, Kenya, July 26 -Crime has become a growing problem and a public preoccupation in Africa, but in most cities few residents are frightened to walk the streets at night or to move freely in any section.
Ten years ago James Benson Irwin was flat on his back in a hospital bed. As a result of a plane crash he had two broken legs, a broken jaw and a brain concussion that had wiped out his memory.

"Coppelia" is by far and away the lightest-weight entry in the select pantheon of popular 19th-century ballets both thematically and choreographically. However, its very fluffiness makes it a specially demanding ballet to perform since it requires substantial stage magnetism to fill its outlines.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. -- An air of happy repose is floating through John Updike's summer cottage here, a human complement to the effortless flight of the seagulls gliding over Menemsha Bay outside.
HOUSTON, July 26 -- The "inevitable fight," as the promoters branded it, produced the inevitable result.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Senate Interior Committee unanimously approved today the establishment of an expanded Gateway National Recreation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor.

CAIRO, July 26 -- President Anwar el-Sadat asked Egypt's political organization tonight for "full powers" for any action he deemed fit against Israel to recover the territories occupied in the six-day war of 1967.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- A growing number of Government-backed loans to private companies and individuals are slipping into default as borrowers are hit by the lagging economy.
Ask David Randolph Scott why we are going back to the moon and his boyish face flushes with excitement as he describes the new and improved features of this trip.

Unlike, it seems, every other astronaut, Alfred Merrill Worden never had much of an interest in flying as a child. In fact, during his school days, the third man aboard Apollo 15 -- the one who won't land on the moon -- was more interested in the piano.
The swarms of tiny, winged insects that mysteriously descended on the East Side around 23d Street Sunday just as mysteriously disappeared yesterday, according to some residents and the police.

HOUSTON, July 26 -- Undertrained and overweight, Muhammad Ali still did what he was supposed to do in the Astrodome tonight. He beat Jimmy Ellis, his one-time sparring partner, just as he had done so often in a thousand rounds of training exercises over the years.

BONN, July 26 -- The West German Government officially expressed "outrage" today over Communist border guards' killing of an East German who tried to escape Saturday night from East to West Berlin across the wall.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that he would propose that the State Department be required to obtain an annual legislative authorization for its appropriations that would be passed upon by the Senate Foreign Relations and House Foreign Affairs Committees.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 26 -- The school-age population joined parents and uncles and peers in flocking to beaches and other vantage areas in greater numbers than expected for the launching today of Apollo 15.

NARITA, Japan, July 26 (Reuters) -- More than 600 policemen and demonstrators were injured today in a 12hour battle for possession of land needed to complete construction of Tokyo's second international airport.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Mounting North Vietnamese and Vietcong attacks on President Nixon's new policy toward China have led some United States Government analysts to conclude that Peking, even if it so desired, would be unable to help settle the Vietnam war except on Hanoi's terms.
William McChesney Martin Jr. has completed a draft of his heralded report on the securities industry. He turned it over yesterday to the committee of Wall Street leaders who had advised him on it.
MOSCOW, July 26 (AP) -- Tigran Petrosian, a Soviet chess grandmaster, won his semifinal match tonight against Viktor Korchnoi in a tournament to pick a challenger for the world chess championship.

In his July 4 letter to the editor David D. Martin has suggested that Government take positive step to limit the size of the American family so as to attain zero population growth, and he recommends the passage of Senator Packwood's bill which would limit to two the number of natural (nonadopted) children that could be claimed by parents on Federal income tax returns.
Roosevelt Hospital has received a gift of $10-million for the treatment and rehabilitation of alcoholics, H. Whitfield Carhart, the president of the West Side institution, announced yesterday.

NEW DELHI, July 26 -- "There's no place to go but up," said one pro-American Indian the other day, referring to the depths into which relations between India and the United States have recently plunged.
NEWARK, July 26 (AP) -Bon Vivant, Inc., whose entire line of canned food was recalled by the Federal Food and Drug Administration, filed today for bankruptcy.
The Treasury's $5.l-billion refinancing operation, which got off to an inauspicious start last Thursday, slowed down even more yesterday.
MOSCOW, July 26 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has published a book on the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.
Texaco, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Howard W. McCall Jr., as a director. Mr. McCall is president and director of the Chemical New York Corporation and Chemical Bank.

MONTAUK, L. I., July 26 -Montauk charter boat captains specializing in bringing big billfsh to gaff are suddenly finding themselves with mates convinced they have just cause to write to Congress over the local bluefish dilemma.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 26 (AP) -- A group of scientists said today that a backup safety system widely used in nuclear reactors was "likely to fail to prevent" a major disaster if an emergency occurred.
CHICAGO, July 26 -- The Continental Casualty Company said here today that it would soon begin selling medical malpractice insurance under an agreement with the American Medical Association.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 (UPI) -- United States helicopters lifted a battalion of Government troops into mountains southeast of the Ashau Valley today. Almost immediate contact with enemy troops was reported.
The trend toward higher prices for newsprint, zinc and aluminum mill products continued yesterday as did lower costs for cadmium.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- The House voted today to support President Nixon's move to give the nearly dormant Subversive Activities Control Board some work in determining whether a score of organizations should be ilsted as subversive.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans warned Congress today that the United States might have a negative balance of trade this year for the first time in this century.
CHICAGO, July 27 -- It was Mug Night at White Sox Park tonight, and New York was mugged as painfully as two Yankees were in the team's last two visits to Chicago.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 27 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union and the premiers of seven other Communist member countries of Comecon, the East European economic alliance, met here this morning to draw up a plan for economic integration that would satisfy both its proponents and opponents.

Two stock brokerage companies, four lawyers and 11 other persons were indicted here yesterday on charges that they took part in a complex conspiracy to obstruct an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
DETROIT, July 27 -- The General Motors Corporation today reported $566.9-million, or $1.97 a share, in second-quarter earnings, up nearly 20 per cent from $472.6-million, or $1.64 a year before.

PEKING, July 27 -- The extraordinary thing about this oldest civilization in the world is that it seems so young. You do not have the feeling here -- so depressing and oppressive in some other parts of the Orient -- of weariness, sickness and death, of old men and women, spent before their time, struggling against hopeless odds.
The stock market dropped steadily yesterday as a falling, dispirited price trend seemed to feed on its own weakness.
Offtrack betting came to Harlem yesterday, but the letters that designated the horses failed to stir as much excitement among the people as the numbers game, the area's favorite pastime.
Following are excerpts from recent addresses delivered by Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, newly appointed chancellor of the City University of New York:
A dance, of journalistic sorts, to Jules Feiffer:
DACCA, Pakistan, July 27 -- Pakistani authorities charged today that an Indian artillery barrage killed five civilians and wounded 13 in the district capital of Comilla in East Pakistan.
A refinery accused of polluting Newtown Creek has agreed to halt discharge of oil and human waste into the stream by next April 12.
Among the graduates of Fairleigh Dickinson's College of Business in May was John Schaffer, a 22-year-old from Elizabeth, N. J., with an eye toward an advertising career. He picked some year for it.

SOUTHBURY, Conn. -- Does anybody need a duck press? Or a live boa constrictor? Coffee from Kenya? A good book? Knitting yarn? Soy beans? A doll house? A bag of penny candy? A watercolor? An antique chair?

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27 (Reuters) -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said tonight that he would not bow out of South Vietnam's presidential election, scheduled to be held Oct. 3, and throw his support behind Duong, Van Minh, the retired general is considered President Nguyen Van Thieu's strongest challenger.
A Soviet scholar described the Arab world to a group of visiting Americans last year as "a very large area close to our borders which cannot be controlled by any power."

In his recent article entitled "Down on the Farm" Tom Wicker points to various loopholes in our tax structure which enable the rich to get richer -- not because they are smarter but because the system tends to be rigged in their favor.

W. Graham Clayton Jr., president of the Southern Railway, disclosed yesterday that, under the industry's mutual aid pact, his 6,000-mile system would collect about $635,000 daily if the strike that closed it 12 days ago lasts a full month.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 27 -- Because the Mets have first call on Shea Stadium, the Jets will have to play out of town during the month of September. However, George Nock will be on exhibit that month in New York at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- The New York Public Service Commission chairman, Joseph C. Swidler, urged Congress today to approve legislation that would encourage the development of a method to obtain natural gas from coal.

CAIRO, July 27 -- A dream of uniting the Arabs from the Atlantic to the Persian Gulf has long been a guiding mystique of Arab intellectuals, yearning for the lost grandeur of Arabic civilization a thousand years ago.
Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, a Pittsburgh educator who was named chancellor of the City University yesterday, has called for a substantial improvement in the quality of the teaching at the university.

WANTAGH, L. I, July 27 -- An eight-week strike by lifeguards at the Robert Moses and Jones Beach State Parks ended today with an agreement by union negotiators and the Long Island State Park Commission.

The Warner-Lambert Company, a diversified drug, consumer-products, scientific and medical- instruments producer, posted record sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30 and raised the quarterly dividend for the 19th consecutive year, Stuart K. Hensley, chairman, reported yesterday.

Representative Herman Badillo charged yesterday that Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Queens Democratic leader, showed "an absolute contempt for the people of Queens" when he made a series of agreements with the Republicans for the election of judges and others there.
Officials of the Long Island Railroad and a union representing 1,600 of its trainmen are to meet in Washington this morning in an attempt to reach agreement on a contract.
The arrest of two burglary suspects in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn last night touched off a fire-setting, brick-throwing disorder by a large group of Puerto Rican residents.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 28 (AP) -- Enemy demolition men stole into an allied base 30 miles north of here in predawn darkness yesterday, blew up four American helicopters and damaged a fifth.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 27 -- After a hard morning workout under a hot sun and their usual modest lunch, the New York Giants gathered in a large classroom at C. W. Post College today and took a quiz.

PARIS, July 27 -- So far, the couturiers here have been conveniently taking sides. Dior stands up for the establishment, Saint Laurent for the protesters and, this morning, Pierre Cardin for the modernists. Hooray for Cardin.

The New York Insurance Department announced yesterday that in an effort to make coverage against vandalism available quickly, it would act in the next 10 days on an industry request for a 39.7 per cent rate increase.

The dispute between Bucharest and Budapest over Nicolai Ceausescu's recent Peking visit, as reported by your news dispatch from Vienna on July 11, is an ominous sign of the fragile state of international relations in the Danube region.

HOUSTON, July 27 -- Muhammad Ali attacked the Internal Revenue Service today for seizing $130,000 as a tax prepayment from his $450,000 guarantee for his 12th-round knockout of Jimmy Ellis at the Astrodome last night.
MOSCOW, July 27 - The 37 members of American Express Tour 410 took a vote yesterday on their last morning in the Soviet Union: Lenin's Tomb or the Kremlin churches.

In the second week of its summer festival, Dance Theater Workshop presented a program of choreographic oddities. These ranged from the mystically still "Light -- Part V" by Kei Takei to the cartoon grotesque "Eulalie/Ulalume" by John Wilson, and all were seen at the American Theater Laboratory on Monday evening.
The General Motors Corporation and the United States Steel Corporation reported sharply improved quarterly profits yesterday.

DETROIT, July 27 -- Frank W. Render 2d, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense, said today that 10 or 12 military officers, from general down to company grade, had been relieved of command, transferred or reprimanded for failure to enforce adequately the regulations aimed to improve race relations or guarantee equal opportunity within the armed services.

The Crompton Knowles Corporation said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the Ciba-Geigy Corporation to acquire that company's Intracolor Corporation subsidiary. The acquisition will be made through a combination of cash and nonvoting preferred stock totaling about $20-million.

With generally favorable Government corn crop development and harvest reports, traders apparently believed there was less risk in selling than in buying and corn futures prices broke more than 5 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
One of the energy centers of filmmaking in the United States lies, not very invitingly, just beyond an orange-walled lobby and through a pair of purple portals.

William B. Camp, the United States Controller of the Currency, approved yesterday the proposed merger of the Connecticut National Bank, Bridgeport, and the First New Haven National Bank. The combined institution would have more than $625-million in assets and 70 offices across the state.

Under a dark, ominous sky that oozed an occasional drop of rain, Mary Travers made her New York debut Monday night at the Wollman Rink in Central Park. Miss Travers has appeared frequently in New York during the last 10 years as the third member of Peter, Paul and Mary.
Most oil industry earnings continued to improve but not spectacularly, according to reports for the quarter and six months released yesterday.

The plea of Secretary of Labor Hodgson for voluntary action by the United Transportation Union and the nation's railroads to arbitrate their long dispute over work rules represents a despairing Administration effort to avoid recourse to Congress once again for emergency legislation to end strikes in this industry. In a real sense, there is nothing to arbitrate. The ingredients for a fair settlement were laid down eight months ago by a Presidential fact-finding board.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration told the Colgate Palmolive Company today that it must not market a new dishwasher detergent in a package resembling a milk carton.
A 16-year-old inmate, who attempted suicide twice in the last month, hanged himself early yesterday in his cell at the Adolescent Remand Shelter on Rikers Island, prison officials reported.
The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday records in operating revenues and net income for the first half. Net income rose by 12.8 per cent on a gain of 17 per cent in operating revenues.
TEL AVIV, July 27 -- Three women were convicted by a military court today in connection with a plot to bomb a dozen crowded hotels during the Easter-Passover season.
DETROIT, July 27 -- A prosperous-looking black man stepped into an elevator in Detroit's newest hotel and said to the lone black passenger, whom he did not know:
About 2,500 people attended the outdoor opening performance of "West Side Story" last night at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center, including Mayor Lindsay.
The city's Human Resources Administrator announced yesterday that 3,000 welfare recipients would be assigned to public-works projects for city agencies in August.

A new musical, "The Ambassadors," based on the Henry James novel. "The Ambassadors," will be presented in London this season by three American producers, Gene Dingenary, Miranda d'Ancona and Nancy Levering. Howard Keel and Danielle Derrieux have been signed for co-starring roles.

HOUSTON, July 27 -- If there was one unanswered question that troubled those who watched the Muhammad Ali-Jimmy Ellis fight in the Astrodome last night, it was this: Why did it take Ali so long to score his knockout? Not until 50 seconds before the final bell of the 12-rounder did the referee mercifully intercede, halting the slaughter of a helpless Ellis.

After a dull morning, stocks on the American Stock Exchange dropped sharply yesterday in a busy afternoon session. The index closed at 25.18, down 0.20, the sharpest decline since June 21. Volume jumped from 2,542,160 shares on Monday to 3,340,210.
Your July 17 editorial "Minority in Rumania" is mischief-making at its worst.

Last weekend's six-hour endurance race at Watkins Glen, N. Y., marked the final appearance of the racing car classified as "Group 5, sports cars," with engines of up to 5 liters displacement. The magnificent Porsche 917K, the Ferrari 512M and other such machines will no longer run in the world manufacturers' championship, the European - American series of 11 endurance races.
PARIS, July 27 -- Fresh worries about the dollar intensified market activity in gold today, lifting the price to about $42 an ounce, the highest level in two years.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 27 -- The $125,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway Aug. 21 appeared today to be in jeopardy. A shortgage of standardbreds, because of an embargo on horses entering France, is at the root of the problem.

LONDON -- An extraordinary political aspect of this era is the ascendancy of the minority leader who, despite absence of clear-cut national backing, audaciously pushes through programs of momentous import. The three outstanding cases in point are U.S. President Nixon, British Prime Minister Heath, and West German Chancellor Willy Brandt.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 27 (AP) -- Angela Davis formally pleaded not guilty today to charges of murder, kidnapping and conspiracy. The judge ordered her trial to begin Sept. 27.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A group of 17 antiwar Congressmen made the first concerted attempt today to use the Pentagon study of the war in Vietnam to attack the Nixon Administration's policies in Indochina.

A 16-year-old girl who was abandoned when she was 7 and has been in child-care institutions most of her life attempted suicide on July 16 at Callagy Hall, a city-operated shelter for troubled and homeless girls.
FAIRHOPE, Ala. -- At 8 o'clock on the morning of Nov. 26, 1921, I was born in the small town of Columbia, Miss. In less than a week my mother had let me for adoption.
QUEBEC, July 27 (Canadian Press) -- Tom Okker of the Netherlands and Roy Emerson and Bob Carmichael of Australia advanced to the second round today at the Quebec international tennis open.

Robinson S. Brown Jr., 54 years old, has been elected chairman of the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, it was announced yesterday in Louisville, Ky. He was formerly executive vice president and director of marketing. He succeeds his cousin, W. L. Lyons Brown, 65, who retired.

BELGRADE -- In the last century Dostoyevsky sought to prove that there exists only one idea without which human life is impossible, and that is the idea of immortality of the soul. In our century Teillard de Chardin took the same view. But in relation to the whole of mankind it is impossible to believe in progress and the future of mankind without belief in the immortality of mankind.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 27 -- The leader of the Socialist party, the largest in Chile's left-wing coalition Government, said today that United States investors should receive no compensation for nationalization of copper mines here.

The first Eisenhower silver dollar to be minted was presented to Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower in a ceremony at the White House. Of limited coinage, the new Ike dollar is only 40 per cent silver and you can't buy one for a dollar.

The State Health Department announced approval yesterday of 27 construction and renovation projects in hospitals and other health facilities here, including the construction of a new $35-million hospital in Manhattan.
NEWARK, July 27 -- Policemen and firemen signed their first contracts with the city today but received no salary increases.
Somewhat sheepishly, Jerry Samuels tied a rubber band round the middle finger of his right hand and attached his whip to it before the eighth race at Aqueduct yesterday.

Tomorrow Entertainment, Inc., the show business subsidiary of General Electric incorporated last December, will produce its first motion picture, "Lamb," in association with Pulsar Productions, Ltd., of London, and Vides Cinematographica SaS of Rome.

State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer declared yesterday that it would be "inappropriate" for him to appear before a Senate subcommittee to answer what he called "baseless charges" that he accepted $50,000 in bribes from a convicted stock manipulator.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Nixon Administration called on the nation's railroads and the striking United Transportation Union today to accept binding arbitration to end their long, bitter contract dispute.

GENEVA, July 27 -- Vast changes that are looming in Japan's economy should mean that this new industrial giant will be shedding the role of bogeyman for the other developed countries in world markets, according to international trade authorities.

The Police Department last night issued a national alarm for a patrolman who is wanted with two other men in the shooting of two Brinks guards and an elevator operator in a Municipal Building holdup that netted $143,000 three weeks ago.

The Administration has run into much heavier Congressional opposition than it expected in its effort to push through a bill authorizing $2 billion in loan guarantees for companies in serious financial trouble, with $250-million earmarked for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

" I guess I should really be buying an odd lot," quipped Donald T. Regan, the chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., shortly before he stepped up yesterday to make the traditional purchase of the first 100 shares of a company new to the New York Stock Exchange.
SEATTLE -- The Pike Place Market is a remnant of another age, another, simpler America. Now it is caught up in a community struggle that is peculiar to the late years of the 20th century.

Grinning all the while, Mayor Lindsay deflected persistent attempts to draw him into conversation yesterday on the rumors that he is about to declare himself a Democrat and, perhaps, a candidate for the Presidential nomination.
The June 29 editorial, ". . . Kafka in Manhattan," described an incident of lack of concern for the public in what was identified as a local Social Security office.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A succession of blue-collar witnesses, mostly union workers in their late forties and fifties, told the Senate Subcommittee on Labor today that they had lost their pension rights.
If the Baltimore Orioles represent the American League in the 1971 World Series, the club's vice president and director of player personnel, Harry Dalton, can take credit for his perspicacity.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- Government investigators reported today that antipoverty programs designed to help minority groups set up their own businesses were only partly successful, largely because of a "lack of managerial competence.''

The word from our Seat of Government yesterday is that Smokey the Bear will not be the only denizen of our woodlands on Civil Service. That world-renowned (but furry) fire-prevention specialist is being joined by Woodsy, an owl, whose message will be "Give a Hoot -- Don't Pollute."
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Civil Service Commission said today that minority group members held 19.6 per cent of Federal jobs last November, up from 19.2 per cent a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate Republican leader, threw his support today behind proposals to put legislative restrictions on the warmaking powers of the Presidency.
The Offtrack Betting Corporation made the first payment yesterday on its $4.8-million loan from the city.

The new chancellor of the City University is fond of reminding his colleagues in higher education of the Ring Lardner story in which a small boy questions his father, who had driven miles in the wrong direction on an automobile trip from Chicago to White Plains.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that about 100,000 men would be drafted in the fiscal year 1972, a decrease of more than 50,000 men from the 1971 fiscal year.

The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, announced yesterday that it would cut its quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share from 60 cents, even though the concern also reported that second-quarter earnings were nearly double the year-earlier level.

LIMA, July 27 -- Chile has a Socialist President and Bolivia has a leftist assembly, but the 33-month-old military Government of Peru has gone farther and faster toward decreeing radical social change than its leftist neighbors while remaining hard to place on the traditional political spectrum.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A Senate subcommittee began looking today into an old and widespread conservation practice that is increasingly drawing the opposition of the new conservationists.

HOUSTON, July 27 -- A brief, successful firing of Apollo 15's main rocket today gave, the three astronauts -- and Mission Control here -- confidence that a flawed electrical switch should not jeopardize the mission's planned landing on the moon.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Republicans' efforts to reform their national convention by including more blacks and other minority group members as delegates are creating more political problems than they are solving.

HOUSTON, July 27 (AP) -- The first television show from the Apollo 15 lunar module Falcon began today like a silent movie filmed in a dark garage, until a hot microphone caught two of the astronauts unawares.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 27 -- Nearly 100 residents of the Hamptons jammed the County Center here today to tell the Suffolk County Legislature that they opposed plans to turn the Suffolk Airport at Westhampton Beach into New York's fourth jetport.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Wednesday, July 28 -- The Omdurman radio announced today that the head of the Sudanese Communist party, Abdel Khalek Mahgoub had been hanged. The announcement came a few hours after the execution was reported of Joseph Garang, a former Sudanese cabinet minister.

Eastern Air Lines reported yesterday a net income of $3.2-million, or 21 cents a share, for the second quarter and a net income of $459,000 for the first six months. Because of preferred dividend requirements, there were no common-share earnings for the half.
A year ago, they were poets. Today, they are songwriters.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 27 (UPI) -- The Orange County chapter of the California Republican Assembly, the oldest party volunteer organization in the state, has voted to censure President Nixon for "betrayal of principles" in his decision to visit Communist China.
VIENNA, July 27 -- Freudians were warned today that "all our theories are going to be carried away by history" unless psychoanalysis is applied to social problems.

The New York Mets finally beat somebody besides themselves last night, and they did it in their long-lost soap-opera style -- four singles that produced a two-run rally in the ninth inning and overturned the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-2.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 27 (AP) -- The State Harness Racing Commission ordered the indefinite suspension today of three men as a result of its continuing investigation into alleged irregularities at Pocono Downs.
Ralph C. Gross, president of the Commerce and Industry Association, warned last night that when public employe unions "have too much power . . . it's bad for the people."

TRENTON, July 27 -- David J. Friedland, the Assembly minority leader, and two other lawyers were suspended from the practice of law today by the State Supreme Court, which found them guiltty of unethical conduct in having charges against an alleged loanshark dropped.

DALAT, South Vietnam, July 23 -- Vietnamese province chiefs and military authorities in the Central Highlands are planning to resume a controversial program of transferring tens of thousands of primitive hill tribesmen out of Communist-controlled areas.
As part of their crackdown on obscenity, plainclothes policemen armed with movie cameras and tape recorders will go into theaters showing allegedly pornographic films and make movies of the movies.
Many small investors say they are up in arms over the commission-rate increases proposed by the New York Stock Exchange for small transactions.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- The Senate Finance Committee opened hearings today on President Nixon's welfare reform plan, and conservative and liberal members alike gave it a hostile reception despite an Administration appeal for speedy action.

The medical unpreparedness in civil defense in the United States is frightening and alarming. The bare fact is that in the event of a nuclear explosion, or an attack by chemical or biological weapons, there are no meaningful stockpiles of critical medical supplies at the local community level for the expected millions of civilian casualties who may linger on for weeks before dying.
A new housing board created by the Legislature at its recent session and authorized to lend $700-million for housing for low-income families was sworn in yesterday at City Hall by Mayor Lindsay.
Although Cal Tjader's quintet is classified as a Latin-jazz group, it would be more accurate to call it a five-man rhythm section.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Diplomatic discussions in preparation for President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Peking are expected to be conducted mainly through the Chinese Embassy in Canada, Nixon Administration officials said privately today.
Rockland County authorities have undertaken an investigation to determine how a county jail prisoner could have received a fatal narcotics overdose while in jail.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- A new anticrime "strike force" of five Federal lawyers went into action today. Justice Department sources said its target was a key figure in crime syndicate infiltration of legitimate financial circles.
SEOUL, South Korea, July 27 -- At least 64 persons were killed in landslides and floods caused by torrential rains that swept the central and southwestern areas of South Korea in the last two days.
Pan American World Airways will no longer promote or take part in safari tours that involve the killing of animals classified by the World Wildlife Fund as "endangered species."
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The World War II baby boom has passed through the nation's public schools, leaving in its wake the worst job market for teachers since the Depression.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Supporters of legislation to rescue the near-bankrupt Lockheed Aircraft Corporation sought and received a breather today after suffering two setbacks in the Senate yesterday.
JERUSALEM, July 27 -- Israel is striving to expand and further profit from her already dominant position as the most scientifically advanced nation in the Middle East.

In spite of the good things in it, "Poems for the Game of Silence" may have an importance beyond its content. For it is another example of that trend away from the use of inherited European forms in poetry, away from the Judeo-Christian subject matter and values and toward a new order of knowledge and a new way of reaching that knowledge.

Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told the Joint Economic Committee last week. "The rules of economics are not working in quite the way they used to." Coming as it did from the economics profession's Great Pragmatist, this was distressing news.

President Nixon's China initiative and other new currents in Washington make it necessary to consider new diplomatic treatment for those countries which may feel a bit out of it all, having run old-fashioned dictatorships, financed by us, while keeping their citizens suitably poor, humble and respectful of authority.

FORT MCPHERSON, Ga., July 27 -- A tentative quorum for the court-martial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, accused by the Army of responsibility for the Mylai massacre, was achieved today with the selection of the fifth juror.

If a society is to be judged by the care it takes of its oldest members, the United States is inviting a harsh appraisal. Figures presented by Senator Percy of Illinois show that one-fourth of all Americans over 65 now live on a poverty-level income and that theirs is the only age group in the country that is getting poorer by the year.

A three-judge special panel sitting in Federal Court in Manhattan took under consideration yesterday the contention of city policemen that their constitutional rigths had been violated by punishment without a hearing after the Jan. 14 to 19 strike.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- For the second time in eight months, the Office of Economic Opportunity lost its director to the White House today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The House passed tonight by a vote of 372 to 25 an appropriations bill that would give the Department of Health, Education and Welfare about $447-million more than requested by the President's proposed budget for the fiscal year 1972.
MONTREAL, July 27 (AP) -- Danny Tucker died in a hospital today of injuries suffered in a junior welterweight bout last night with the Canadian champion, Reynald Cantin.

The Hamburg Savings Bank of Brooklyn announced yesterday the election of Joseph G. Munz as chairman and chief executive officer, Joseph L. Werner as president and Roy C. Schoenhaar as executive vice president.
Maintaining that his "track record speaks for itself," William (Buddy) Gilmour testified for 15 minutes yesterday before a Federal grand jury investigating possible fixed harness races.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Lew Mathe's foursome, which came from behind last night to oust the world champion Aces of Dallas from the Spingold knockout team championship, clashed in the final here today with the defending champions, headed by Joel Stuart.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- James M. Beggs, the Under Secretary of Transportation, expressed confidence today in the Penn Central railroad's "delicate improvement" since it filed for reorganization and said the Nixon Administration would look favorably on new Government loans to advance the railroad's recovery next year.

A distinct difference of opinion has arisen at The Village Voice between the old guard and the new owners over classified masseur and model advertisements, which some contend are simply the offerings of prostitutes.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Eight persons arrested on the Capitol steps May 5 during antiwar demonstrations were acquitted today by a Superior Court jury of disorderly parading and unlawful entry.

The corporate bond market, perhaps taking some perverse satisfaction in the stock market's steep decline yesterday, stopped moving downward during the afternoon and recovered to close little changed from Monday.
A city housing inspector who is also a Republican district leader in the Bronx was arraigned yesterday on charges of conspiracy, extortion, bribe-receiving and official misconduct.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A confidence man from Boston, who turned state's evidence after he was convicted in a securities fraud case, entertained the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee today with tales of stolen and counterfeit securities, loan sharking, credit card swindles, car theft rings and gambling junkets.

MOSCOW, July 27 -- The Soviet Union today began a nationwide protest against the anti-Communist campaign in the Sudan and appealed to the Khartoum authorities to spare the life of Mohammed Abdel Khalek Mahgoub, head of the Communist party.

BELGRADE, July. 28 -- Yugoslavia's outgoing Cabinet asked end - of - session parliamentary approval today for a package of urgent austerity measures designed to curb the country's 14 per cent cost-of-living rise and reduce the payments deficit that has reached nearly $700-million this year.

Philip Rossillo, described by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a bodyguard of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., is a prime suspect in the killing of Jerome A. Johnson, the man the police have said shot Columbo last June 28.

Those tiny flying bugs that descended in swarms on the city last Sunday may have been gnats to some, but to the insect expert at the American Museum of Natural History they turned out to be a species of aphid or plant louse.

NEWARK, July 28 -- Federal District Judge Reynier J. Wortendyke Jr. signed papers here yesterday directing the Securities and Exchange Commission to submit a proposed judgment against Robert L. Vesco, chairman of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., and of the International Controls Corporation, Fairfield, N. J.

FORT McPHERSON, Ga., July 28 -- Five men who believe that the commander of an infantry company need not necessarily be held responsible for the alleged massacre by his soldiers of more than 100 Vietnamese civilians were seated today as the jury in the court-martial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Legislation to give the District of Columbia an elected Mayor and City Council passed the Senate District Committee today, and its backers were confident of Senate approval.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, the former Pentagon researcher who says he gave the Pentagon papers to the press, called on members of Congress today to put their jobs, their power and their careers on the line to end the war in Vietnam.

Kipling -- Just-So Stories Al Gallagher, the San Francisco third baseman, seems to have those six serving-men in abundance. The only child born to his parents after they had waited eight years to have a baby, he was christened Alan Mitchell Edward George Patrick Henry Gallagher.
Man's search for his immortal soul may lead him next to a five-story townhouse at 5 West 73d Street, home of the American Society for Psychical Research.

Chain-store sales in June rose 11.2 per cent, compared to those of year-ago month, according to a survey by The New York Times. Sales for the first six months went ahead of the 1970 half by 9.3 per cent.
City Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin announced yesterday what he called the first arrest resulting from three investigations of the Municipal Loan Fund for slum rehabilitation.
Summer Air of the Darby Dan Farm, under Angel Cordero, moved between horses in the stretch to win the $33,350 Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
After 60 years as a movie man, Arthur L. Mayer has one thing to say about it all. "I still love 'em. Movies are my life, and I'm still at it."

WASHINGTON, July 28 -United States corporations borrowed a record $3-billion abroad last year to permit continuation of a record level of direct investment in foreign countries despite Government controls, the Commerce Department reported today.
The "silent" Presidential campaign to win New York's delegates to the Democratic national convention -- the largest delegation in the 50 states -has started in earnest in the last few weeks.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- Vice President Agnew returned from his round-the-world diplomatic tour of l0 nations today and went to the White House, where President Nixon greeted him with praise.
Throwing caution, not to mention himself, to the winds, Prince Charles, the 22-year-old heir to the British throne, parachuted from a plane 1,200 feet over the English Channel.

The American Can Company announced yesterday the election of Lawrence Lachman to the board of directors. Mr. Lachman is chairman and chief executive officer of Bloomingdale's, a division of Federated Department Stores, Inc. He is a trustee of the Dry Dock Savings Bank and chairman of the New York Better Business Bureau.
LIGONIER, Pa., July 28 -- Those golfing rivals, Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus, are back together as partners. At least they will be for the next four days, but after that . . .?

UAL, Inc., the parent company of United Air Lines, the nation's largest domestic air carrier, managed to operate in the black in the second quarter as a result of the profit made in June, it was reported yesterday by Edward E. Carlson, president.

LIMA, Peru, July 28 -- The military Government of Peru today listed for the first time its long-range social goals -- a sort of cooperative society that would be neither capitalist nor Communist. Simultaneously, it shifted its sights from opponents on the right to the organized, Communist-led left.
LONDON, July 28 -- The Labor party's national executive body voted resoundingly today to oppose British entry into the Common Market on the negotiated terms.

The New York Times Company reported yesterday increased revenues but lower earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30, reflecting mounting costs for salaries, newsprint prices and other operations.
Jim Dawson, a folk singer from Denver now living in New York, is appearing through Sunday at Folk City, 130 West Third Street.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Nixon today named William J. Porter to succeed the ailing chief United States delegate to the Paris peace talks, David K. E. Bruce.

Every moment of light and hope in Northern Ireland seems to be followed inexorably by fresh bloodshed that intensifies the sectarian strife and polarizes further the politics of the volatile province. Discussion of Prime Minister Faulkner's plans for revamping the Stormont Parliament to give the Catholic minority a share in policy-making was halted abruptly by new outbreaks that took the lives of two Catholic youths and two British soldiers.
The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday gains in net income and operating revenues for the first six months.

In an impressive demonstration of bipartisan support for the nation's arts and humanities, a conference committee of the Senate and House has agreed to appropriate $61.21-million for the National Arts and Humanities Endowments in fiscal 1972.

CASPER, Wyo., July 28 -Kevin Dye, a mentally retarded, epileptic 9-year-old boy missing in rugged terrain here for 10 days was found alive and in "remarkably good" condition this morning by a search team in its first hour on the job.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Governor Rockefeller charged today that the Nixon Administration's uncoordinated efforts were causing "confusion and delay" in the battle against water pollution.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 28 (AP) -- United States, Thai and South Vietnamese narcotics agents, working together, have seized a huge quantity of heroin and opium and arrested the leader of a ring supplying drugs to American soldiers in Vietnam.

Four more Canadian newsprint producers announced $8-a-ton price increases yesterday while a fourth said it expected to close down part of its woods operation because of a world oversupply of newsprint.

MARION, Mass., July 28 -- A foul tide and an eight-knot wind that quit brought the New York Yacht Club boats to their knees today as well as causing a number of surprises on the fourth-round of an eight-day cruise.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Officials of the Long Island Railroad and its trainmen union met for six and a half hours today, the threat of a strike on the line having been put off until at least Aug. 9.
LOS ANGELES, July 28 -- A press secretary was sentenced to jail today for refusing to answer a judge's questions about his actions when he worked as a newspaper reporter.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House a compromise bill authorizing $3.3-billion to continue the nation's space program for another year.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- It could happen only to Ron Swoboda.
A study of black families has found that a majority of those in the reproductive age range do not accept the idea that birth control programs are an attempt to eliminate blacks from the population.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 28 -- Mayor Lindsay of New York, described by smiling aides as a "nonpolitical" college lecturer, picked the issue on which President Nixon is thought to be most politically vulnerable -- the economy -- for a sharp attack here tonight.

TRENTON, July 29 -- An independent New Jersey consumer research organization reported today that municipalities, because of technical ignorance and political influence, are selling the public short in franchise agreements with cable television concerns.

Some of Wall Street's money managers -- the men who run mutual funds or otherwise manage assets -have been fuming quietly over implications that they have conflicts of interest if they also are in the brokerage business.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., July 28 -- Three and a half years ago, Frank, the only name he's known by to his customers, bought the Blue Dolphin Restaurant, across from Republic Field.

The Board of Education sent letters yesterday to about 100 headquarters employes, ranging from $100-a-week clerks to $24,000-a-year administrators, informing them that their jobs were being abolished.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP) -- Muhammad Ali has been offered $300,000 for 10 lectures in South Africa Dec. 20 through Jan. 2 and plans to accept if he can obtain a visa to that racially troubled country.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The White House opened the way today to speculation about a rift between President Nixon and Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

Each year parents send nearly eight million youngsters to summer camps across this country with the belief that their children will be constantly protected by trained counselors and live in sanitary and healthful surroundings.
NEW DELHI, July 28 -- The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi moved today to empower parliament to override fundamental rights guaranteed by the Indian Constitution.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A scaled-down version of a jobs bill vetoed last month by President Nixon cleared the House today by a vote of 374 to 27.

Irreverence is occasionally a virtue much to be admired. The New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater is currently doing Shakespeare a power of good and turning Central Park into a place of celebration with its new production of "The Two Gentlemen of Verona."
Mrs. Dianne Markham, a short-order cook from Seattle who doesn't particularly like sandwiches, yesterday was crowned the 1971 Sandwich Queen.

Prostitution is returning steadily to the Times Square area, only three weeks after Mayor Lindsay announced his crackdown on prostitution and pornography in mid-Manhattan "to eliminate the abuses that have tarnished its character."

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 28 -- "I wouldn't want to say too much before the season even began, but right now they're looking so good out there that it scares me," said Walt Michaels, the New York Jets' assistant coach in charge of the linebackers and the defensive backfield.
A melee in which rocks and bottles were thrown at the police by spectators erupted last night near an outdoor concert in Central Park.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -Supporters of legislation to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy won one key test in the Senate today and showed increased strength on another.
PINELAWN, L. I., July 28 -- Patrolman Robert Lee Denton, the eighth New York City patrolman slain this year, was buried today in Long Island National Cemetery.

Congress has a chance, though it is no more than an outside possibility, to save the whale from extermination. The Senate adopted a resolution in June requesting the State Department to seek a ten-year worldwide moratorium on whaling, and now a subcommittee of the House Foreign Affairs Committee is considering similar legislation, which deserves to be adopted promptly and in its strongest form.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -The already-poor United States foreign trade figures worsened further in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

Associations representing New York City gasoline service station operators filed suit in State Supreme Court yesterday to block the imposition of a special cent-a-gallon city tax on leaded gasoline sold here beginning Aug. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, is planning to visit India and Pakistan within two weeks, his office said today.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 28 -Plans for the nation's first rail-air-bus-auto center, to be built at Republic Airport here, were announced today by Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Nixon stepped into the troubled railroad situation today, sending Assistant Secretary of Labor W. J. Usery Jr. to the headquarters of the striking United Transportation Union in Cleveland.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 28 (UPI) -- Jim Osborne of Salt Lake City upset Clark Graebner of New York, 7-6, 6-4, in the second round of the $20,000 Buckeye tennis tournament today.
TEL AVIV, July 28 -- Arab protests mounted in Gaza today as the lsraeli occupation authorities continued to compel residents to leave congested Jabaliya refugee camp north of the town.
State Senator John D. Calandra, the Bronx Republican leader, called yesterday for the ouster of Mayor Lindsay from the Republican party.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A convicted receiver of stolen securities once known as the Paper Hanger disclosed today details of intricate international operations to dispose of stolen and counterfeit stocks and bonds on three continents.
JERSEY CITY, July 28 -- Sister Margaret Murtha entered Hudson County Jail today rather than reveal a conversation she had with a 17-year-old murder suspect.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The United States Board of Parole decided today not to parole the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, Roman Catholic priests imprisoned for destroying draft board records.

NUTLEY, N. J., July 28 -- A desire to refresh her spirit among people and places across the land led a 55-year-old Nutley librarian to journey alone on a motorcycle to San Francisco and back to New Jersey.
Three more steel companies reported yesterday sharp increases in second-quarter earnings, compared with those of the year-earlier period. They were:
Net income of the Standard Oil Company of California in this year's second quarter rose to $127,043,000, or $1.50 a share from $107,401,000, or $1.27 a share, in the second period, a year ago.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., July 28 -- Although he has never played for a team that won a title -- some say he never will -- Fran Tarkenton of the Giants continues to command respect and fear throughout the National Football League.

PARIS, July 28 -- The Paris couture sent in its second team today, most of the big guns having sent off their rockets earlier in the week. Only Givenchy and Courreges among the major houses have not yet shown their wares.

Harald Lander's ballet, "Etudes," serves two useful purposes. By taking ordinary classroom exercises out of the studio and into the theater, it offers a Reader's Digest type of compressed view of the dancer's training that never fails to exert some fascination over the uninitiated.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 -American Airlines, Inc., which in the last 15 months has cut back its payroll by 1,500 employes to about 35,000, expects to lay off 2,000 more during the next five months, unless it begins experiencing an upturn in its traffic, according to Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, executive vice president for finance.
A narcotics raid on the Brooklyn College campus yesterday noon led to the arrest of two women and three men and the seizure of 60 envelopes of heroin.
The corporate bond market, which had been drifting downward for more than a week, rallied yesterday in the face of news that could have been expected to push interest rates higher.

I have followed the exchange of letters between Professor Bishop (June 3) and Stanley Paulson (July 8) on trying ex-servicemen for offenses committed while in uniform.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Not long after he became the United States Ambassador to South Korea, William J. Porter was awakened late at night by an aide knocking at his window.

A recent tournament in Bad Luhahovice, Czechoslovakia, and confined to players from Eastern Europe, was won by the Czech grandmaster Vlastimil Hort, with a score of 11 1/2 out of 15. Grandmaster Laszlo Szabo of Hungary took second with 10 1/2, and there was a tie for third and fourth places between the Soviet grandmaster Vladimir Liberson and the young Czech international master Smejkal, each with 10.

CALI, Colombia, July 28 -- Frank Shorter could not sleep. Not at all. He was exhausted from a hectic day of air travel and settling into new surroundings, but each time he tried to slip into a second world of time and space, shattering sounds stirred him from slumber.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -Trustees of the Penn Central told the Senate today that with modern work rules -- including a basic three-man crew in freight service -- they would never need another Government loan and could be operating the bankrupt railroad profitably as soon as 1973.

LONDON, Thursday, July 29 (AP) -- A British military expert said today that American naval strength is in a serious decline while the Soviet fleet has expanded into a "supernavy" with a greatly increased sphere of influence.
HOUSTON, Thursday, July 29 -The Apollo 15 astronauts overcame a sudden water leak in their command ship early today and coasted closer to the moon.
Prices continued to weaken yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, taking the index down to 25.00, or 0.18 below Tuesday's close. It was the fifth losing session in a row.

A patrolman who is being sought with two other men in a $143,000 robbery at the Municipal Building on July 9 was described yesterday by his colleagues, friends and neighbors as the kind of man "who could do no wrong."

The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue a list yesterday.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 28 (AP) -- Hilton International has been ordered out of Colombia before it could open its 40-story hotel here.
PRESQUE ISLE, Me. -- The road to Ralph Smith's farm cuts across rolling hills that his great-grandfather cleared for farming after the Civil War.
Silver, reflecting gold's strength, was up in price and actively traded yesterday in New York's commodity markets yesterday. Gold has gone up to $42 an ounce in Europe, a two-year high.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -The Government's composite index of "leading indicators" of the economy declined in June, interrupting a steady seven-month rise, the Commerce Department reported today.

Arthur Williams is known to metropolitan fanciers as a devoted Weimaraner breeder who shows his own dogs. He is a former president of the Staten Island Kennel Club and now serves on its board.

SAN JUAN -- The people of Puerto Rico within their relationship to the United States of America have maintained self-determination and freedom of expression at all times. This has been guaranteed by the courts, by Government agencies and by totally free media of communications.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28 (AP) -- The third South Vietnamese sweep in eastern Cambodia within a week, which began early today, reportedly has made only minor contact with the enemy.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 28 -- As a juvenile, Gunner won the Westbury Futurity at Roosevelt Raceway. The following season, Marlu Pride captured the Dexter Cup for sophomores. So neither the Founder's Plate nor the $50,000 bonus that goes to a horse that sweeps the three major local tests for 2, 3 and 4 year olds will be at stake in Saturday night's $101,469.48 Realization Trot at the Nassau County harness racing course.

GRAHAMSVILLE, N. Y., July 28 -- Lou Zanetti was minding his own business last Memorial Day, casting a 15-cent lure on an 8-pound test line into the Catskills' Merriman Dam Reservoir, when suddenly he found himself with problems.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- When the Bureaus of Census and Labor Statistics issued this week their annual thick compendium of statistics about the status of black Americans, many eyes stopped on a single number at the bottom of Table 86.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- Senate-House conferees went along today with President Nixon's desire to put new life in the Subversive Activities Control Board by expanding its role in the investigation of domestic subversion.

ST. FRANCIS, S. D. -- Whenever there is a break in the weather, the teen-agers start running on the Rosebud Sioux Reservation. Indian boys are racing through South Dakota pastures with atavistic dignity and ease, never landing on a cow chip but never seeming to avoid them, speeding but somehow not seeming to hurry.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Eleven prominent conservatives announced today that they had resolved to "suspend" their support of the Nixon Administration to protest its foreign policies.

MOSCOW, July 28 -- Mikhail S. Solomentsev, a national party secretary responsible for heavy industry, was named Premier of the Russian Republic today, replacing Gennadi I. Voronov, who received another job last week.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Deputy Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that he thought the wave of youthful protest was subsiding "because our young people feel they are being heard."

Efforts of the Administration to perpetuate what George W. Ball has called "the myth of executive privilege" in the conduct of foreign affairs have received a setback with the conversion of Senate Minority Leader Hugh Scott. The Pennsylvania Republican has now joined the growing ranks of legislators of both parties who seek to reassert the constitutional role of Congress in the war-making process.

DETROIT, July 28 -- Vernon E. Jordan Jr., who will become executive director of the National Urban League in January, accused the Nixon Administration today of combining "elements of high purpose with an apparent neglect of the deepest needs of poor people and minority groups."

Otto Preminger and Louis Nizer, two stars in different firmaments, will collaborate on a fictionalized two-hour television film based on the trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the executed atom-secret spies.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A married couple from Wantagh, L.I., testified today that despite a combined total of 40 years, service with Columbia Gas Systems, Inc., of New York, neither will be entitled to a pension from the company when they reach retirement age.

CAIRO, July 28 -- President Anwar el-Sadat will fly to Tripoli, Libya, tomorrow to take part in a conference of Arab leaders, it was announced here late tonight. The conference was urged by the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, for coordinated Arab action against the campaign by the Jordanian Army to curb Palestinian guerrillas.

HONG KONG, July 28 -- Premier Chou En-lai has told a group of American graduate students that if diplomatic relations are to be established between the United States and China, Peking must be recognized as the sole legitimate government representing the Chincse people.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Ireland was the first British colony and the first to break free. When the British gave independence to Southern Ireland in 1922, after four years of terrorism and guerrilla warfare, they started down the long road of imperial withdrawal that was to wind through India, Palestine, Kenya and Cyprus.

There are about 350,000 lawyers in the United States with 20,000 more persons admitted to practice each year. Much of our legal theory and structure is built around the fact that large numbers of specialists are available to staff the legal system and act as advisers to the public.

RABAT, Morocco, July 27 -- King Hassan II of Morocco has suggested that fratricidal strife is rending the Arab world because he and other Arab leaders are "not equal to the potentialities that are offered us."
WASHINGTON, July 28 -The Government reported today that the budget for the fiscal year ended June 30 showed a near-record deficit of $23.2-billion.

A barrage of bad news battered the stock market yesterday, shooting holes in individual issues and sending popular averages to their lowest levels in more than five months.

BALTIMORE, July 28 (AP) -- Brooks Robinson of the Baltimore Orioles, the American League third baseman in this year's All-Star Game who is considered one of the finest fielders in the game, committed three errors in one inning tonight during a game against Oakland, won by the Orioles, 3-2, on Frank Robinson's three-run homer in the ninth.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -A sweeping program that would change America's system of measurement from pounds and inches to grams and meters will be proposed tomorrow by Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 28 -- At midnight Tuesday, high-level officials of the New York Giants finally got the call through.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Commerce Department imposed regulations today that ban the sale of flammable sleepwear for children after July, 1973.

MOSCOW, July 28 -- According to Soviet archives just made public, four days before President John F. Kennedy informed the world about the Cuban missile crisis, Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev proposed a meeting with him that Mr. Kennedy first seemed to support but rejected later in the day.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Nixon's approach to Peking, no matter how welcome it may be, was planned in secrecy, decided by Presidential fiat, carried out clandestinely and finally announced only as accomplished fact. Thus, whatever else it was, this grand diplomatic undertaking was another exercise in executive omnipotence.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- A Spingold knockout team championship final notable for slowness, a close finish and a high standard of play ended here in the early hours of this morning in a victory for the defending champions, headed by Joel Stuart of New York.

Mack, Bushnell Edelman, Inc., a two-year-old member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, announced plans yesterday to go public in a 200,000-share offering to be underwritten by J. D. Viner Co., another member firm.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Nixon Administration and Senate conferees were reported today to have worked out a compromise on the amendment on troop withdrawals from Vietnam that they hope will be acceptable to the House conferees and Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28 -- The United States military command has decided to expand its antinarcotics program in South Vietnam to test virtually every serviceman for heroin use, military sources said today.
Computers at the city's off-track betting parlors are still "down" -- but not out.

Steve Carlton pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-3 victory over the New York Mets yesterday and thereby put a dent in one of the backstairs axioms at Shea Stadium: that left-handers who pitch against the Mets do not live to tell about it.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Senate passed today, 76 to 22, a bill to extend the Sugar Quota Act for three more years starting Jan. 1.

HOUSTON, July 28 -- The Apollo 15 astronauts are sailing toward their destination through a sea of moving and contending gravitational fields. As on no previous space flight, the success of their mission depends on accurate analysis of those fields and of their effects.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 28 -- The leadership of the youth wing of the Christian Democratic party resigned today in protest against the opposition tactics of the party's National Council toward the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 28 -- The Sudanese Information Minister said today that more than 1,000 persons still faced possible prosecution for complicity in the short-lived leftist coup d'etat against Premier Gaafar al-Nimeiry last week.

Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson disclosed yesterday that 87 per cent of more than 2,000 food items bought by her department at the city's leading chain supermarkets recently were short-weighted.

An experimental helicopter patrol of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's Long Island Railroad and Penn Central lines has achieved a significant drop in vandalism and other crime, the M.T.A. said yesterday.
The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday price increases on most of its major data-processing systems.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -Administration officials said today that the United States had suspended flights over Communist China by manned SR-71 spy planes and unmanned reconnaissance drones to avoid any incident that might interfere with President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Peking.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, which last week shook up its top management, yesterday announced major changes in its television programing department.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A high White House official said today that the "leaks" earlier this week about possible consideration by President Nixon of a change in the status of the Federal Reserve Board "were not a legitimate expression of Presidential opinion."

AREA A -- Night expeditions by boats chumming along Barnegat Ridge continue to be highly profitable. Most daytime boats, however, to the same area are reporting only fair success. The fluke situation has tapered off in the Spring Lake-Sea Girt region.

PEKING, July 29 -- The Hsinhua News Bulletin, a mimeographed collection of state information in English, is delivered to your door at the Hsin Chiao Hotel here every morning with a quotation from Chairman Mao Tsetung printed in red at the top of the first page.
