WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, countering what it considers secrecy in the executive branch, has moved to suspend all foreign military aid unless the Defense Department supplies its five-year plans for the military assistance program.
State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer asked yesterday to be relieved of his duties pending the conclusion of a court investigation into his judicial conduct.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 -- A number of anti Government candidates won permission today on appeal to run in South Vietnam's lower house elections next month.

Metromedia, Inc., which owns and operates WNEW-TV here, announced yesterday that it had purchased from Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., all issued and outstanding stock of WTCN-TV in Minneapolis-St. Paul. The purchase, for $18-million in cash, is subject to approval by the Federal Communications.
PARIS, July 29 -- David K. E. Bruce retired as chief American delegate to the Vietnam peace talks today in an atmosphere of disappointment and recrimination.
Five persons were reported arrested and one policeman was injured last night when groups of youths threw stones and bottles in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29 -- The Tripoli radio tonight reported the arrival in the Libyan capital of Yasir Arafat, the dominant Palestinian guerrilla leader.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The United States announced today that it was "prepared to undertake discussions" with 10 non-Communist nations on the possibility of sharing its secret technology for producing fissionable uranium-235 for use in atomic power reactors.

Theodore Sorensen's excuse that the Pentagon papers provide the modern citizen with hindsight that was unavailable to those responsible for the Vietnamese escalation [Op-Ed July 13] is another attempt to perpetuate a pernicious myth -- that American leadership was unaware of the idiocy of such involvement.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A compromise aimed at getting immediate Congressional action on legislation to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy fell through tonight after a day of intense negotiations.
LONG BEACH, Calif., July 29 -- The McDonnell-Douglas Corporation today delivered its newest jet aircraft, the DC-10, a wide-bodied, three-engine plane, to American Airlines and United Airlines.

TOKYO, July 29 -- Premier Eisaku Sato has read it. Former Trade Minister Kiichi Miyazawa has read it. Prominent businessmen, critics, professors, rightists, leftists and radical students quote from it, even as they wonder about the author's identity.

The authority of the Pope is now being hotly contested by Dr. Hans Kung. In particular, the selection of a "conservative" as the new bishop of Rotterdam has been depicted by Dr. Kung as a misuse of papal authority. With ever greater urgency, basic questions are now raised.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, proposed today the establishment of an autonomous Cabinet-level agency with broad regulatory powers to protect consumer interests.

The American Textile Manufacturers Institute said yesterday that the Commerce Department's newly issued regulation for children's sleepwear does not meet a requirement in the amended Flammable Fabrics Act for adopting a standard based on findings that are "reasonable, technologically practical and appropriate."

TOKYO, July 29 -- The Foreign Investment Council recommended today that 151 Japanese industries be opened to 100 per cent direct foreign investment and that all but seven industries on a so-called "negative list" be freed for 50 per cent direct foreign investment.

HOUSTON, July 29 -- The mission of Apollo 15 is science -- the close study of a region of the moon offering a major mountain range, the Apennines, and a deep, meandering canyon called the Hadley Rille, and all the features of the largest circular lunar basin, Mare Imbrium.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed a complaint in Federal District Court here against 13 companies and individuals seeking an enjoinment from further violations of Federal securities laws.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Robert Lee Grant, the only black official of the Nixon Administration to criticize Administration policies openly, has been dismissed from his job with the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- The House voted today to appropriate $58.5-million to repay 10 airlines for their investments in the defunct supersonic transport project.

The Gerber Products Company announced yesterday the election of Dan Gerber as chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Gerber will be succeeded as chairman of the board by John C. Suerth, who has been president. Arthur J. Frens has been appointed president and William L. McKinley becomes executive vice president of the baby food company.
A suspended policeman was convicted in Federal Court here last night on a charge of conspiracy to sell cocaine while he was a patrolman in Brooklyn.

Five years ago a young German girl came to New York to become a nurse. She brought luggage and a new portable typewriter. In due course she acquired an apartment, a tape recorder and an assortment of costume jewelry girls dote on.
The Queens Democratic and Republican organizations nominated Judge Louis D. Laurino of the State Court of Claims yesterday to succeed John T. Clancy, who resigned earlier in the day.

Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts announced the grand jury indictments yesterday of three bridgetenders for disabling bridges during the June 7 job action that snarled traffic all over the city.
DETROIT, July 29 -- Two automobile companies, Ford and Chrysler, are planning to raise car prices 5 per cent this fall, or about $200 a car, another sign that inflation is continuing.
Two vice presidents of Allen Co., an investment banking firm, are resigning as directors of REA Express, Inc., because of a conflict of interest with Allen's other transportation holdings.

The United States Board of Parole was accused yesterday of trying to "cripple the voice of dissent" in America by denying early release from prison to the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, Roman Catholic priests serving jail terms for destroying draft board records.
FRESNO, Calif., July 29 (UPI) -- A Federal judge today cleared Fernando Chavez, the 22-year-old son of Cesar Chavez, of charges of refusing induction into military service.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Representative Morris K. Udall charged today that a law firm in which President Nixon was once a partner stood to make "millions of dollars" as bond attorneys for the first issue of United States Postal Service bonds.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today major revisions in one of the key indicators of the economy -- the industrial production index.

Prince of Truth made a trip to Aqueduct from Monmouth Park yesterday and James Tucker's 3-year-old gelding turned the visit into a successful venture. Established the late favorite by the astute members of crowd of 25,438, Prince of Truth contributed to the day's generally satisfactory form picture by winning easily.

Inflation, which is felt daily by virtually all Americans, is far from an exclusively American problem. In fact, the International Monetary Fund pointed out recently that consumer price increases in the industrial countries last year were the steepest since the Korean war boom.
The boards of Societe des Produits Chimiques Pechiney-Saint Gobain and Societe Progil, both controlled by Rhone-Poulenc, S.A., announced merger plans yesterday in Paris.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 29 -- Ann Francis's Sandsablaze captured the stake and finished second in the under-saddle event to score 8 points and win the junior working hunter championship yesterday at the Fairfield Bridle Trails Association horse show at the Fairfield County Hunt Club.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 29 -- Combining luck and perception, the Jets apparently have been twice blessed at their training camp here at Hofstra University.
If the folks at the Museum of Modern Art keep on giving parties in its Sculpture Garden, they're going to spill the beans on one of the few remaining secrets of life in New York City.

Seven New York City Black Panthers, including two of the defendants in the recent bombing conspiracy case here, have been indicted by a Queens County grand jury in the killing of a West Coast Panther official whose bullet-riddled body was found in a party office in Corona on April 17.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that tests had turned up no evidence that chickens given a feed contaminated with an industrial chemical were unsafe to eat.
The standard descent path for a lunar landing has been steepened to a precipitous 25 degrees for Apollo 15 to make sure that the Falcon landing craft has safe clearance over the Apennine mountains.
CALI, Colombia, July 29 -- Dr. Delano Meriwether crouched intently in the starting blocks, counted commands to himself, then bolted quickly down the red Tartan track.

Francis X. Ward, a lieutenant who has been a central figure in the 16-month-old investigation of police corruption here, has been convicted of Police Department charges involving bribery and perjury and has been dismissed from the force without a pension.
The Dance Masters of America, Inc., had the floor at the Statler Hilton here yesterday, and it knew what to do with it: ballet, fox trots, jazz steps, even splits and cartwheels.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 29 -- State Supreme Court Justice Michael M. D'Auria, who was under investigation by the Court on the Judiciary for alleged misconduct, has submitted his resignation.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., July 29 -- Miss Elinor Graham Kaine and Angel A. Penna were married here today at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Donoghue by Justice of the Peace Frank P. deLuca.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Senator James L. Buckley parted company today -- slightly -- with his brother William F. Buckley Jr. and a group of prominent conservatives by reiterating general support for the Nixon Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Amtrak's publicists staged an elaborate production today in honor of the Metroliner's three-millionth passenger and got more, including more trouble, than they had bargained for.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 29 -- President Tito was unanimously re-elected by the Yugoslav parliament today to a five-year term. But he said he might retire before his mandate expired if the group of 22 men who were elected to a new collective presidency of the republic under his chairmanship worked well together.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 29 -- Premier Nimeiry, said today that "I don't want any deterioration in our relationship with the Soviet Union and other socialist countries, but if they want to choose that path we will have no alternative."

PARIS, July 29 -- Hubert de Givenchy ranks up there with Dior as a leading exponent of ladylike clothes. So what do you make of it when he slashes skirts hip-high, opens wedge-shaped necklines almost to the waist and presents a bevy of micromini dresses flecked with sequins?

Registering the sharpest price drop in two months, the American Stock Exchange index closed at 24.72 yesterday, down 0.28 from the previous day. The last time the index fell as much as 0.28 was on May 17.

MANILA, July 29 (AP) -- Pickets of a Filipino union, protected by a court order against police interference, sealed off Clark Air Force Base today and stranded inside hundreds of airmen who live off base.

The highly controversial Tocks Island Dam is to be given a fresh look. It should. Originally conceived as an ideal combination of water conservation, flood control and recreational facility, this project for a 37-mile-long lake in the beautiful Delaware River Valley evoked doubts among some environmentalists soon after it was authorized by Congress a decade ago. Those doubts have grown into fierce opposition.

As a dozen terrified hostages dropped to the sidewalk after being held at gunpoint by five bank robbers, policemen shot and killed one suspect and wounded two others in crossfire yesterday morning on Upper Broadway.

PEKING, July 29 -- Snail fever, a parasitic disease related to the use of human excrement as fertilizer, is China's most serious health problem, according to doctors in Peking's Anti-Imperialist Hospital.

HOUSTON, July 29 -- When the men of Apollo 15 attempt to land on the moon tomorrow, they will be aiming for a relatively small patch of level ground surrounded by towering mountains and a steep-walled canyon some 1,200 feet deep and almost a mile wide.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Bache Co., Inc., was censured today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for allegedly violating the securities laws in connection with its attempts to raise capital for the firm last year and earlier this year.

When Leo Colston, who will be 13 on the 27th, goes to visit his classmate at Brandon Hall in July of 1900, the elegant Maudsley family receives him with that special graciousness reserved for poor but well-bred boys, the sort who live with widowed mothers in small, neat cottages, far enough away so as not to be social embarrassments.

The value of contracts awarded for all kinds of construction projects throughout the country in June totaled $8,076,653,000, a rise of 22 per cent over $6,641,583,000 a year before, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

Not even the glorious ghosts from the past have been able to find resting places in collegiate football's Hall of Fame at Rutgers. It still is a pie in the sky, a hole in the ground, an unfulfilled idea. The immortals already chosen for residence wander in a limbo of sorts while waiting with growing impatience for their heavenly haven to take substance.

This country's worst drug problem -- in terms of number of individuals seriously affected, annual economic loss and similar indices -- is neither heroin nor marijuana nor any other of the drugs newly come to fashion. Rather it is that terrible old and reliable destroyer of lives: alcohol.
A Big Board rule that has provoked controversy for years prevents member firms under most circumstances from buying or selling Big Board shares anywhere but on the floor of the stock exchange.

Starting tonight, New York soccer fans will have one of the biggest weekends of the season, with visits to Yankee Stadium by Santos and the famed Pele, the exciting Bangu team of Brazil and the defending North American Soccer League champion, Rochester Lancers.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Nixon tonight called on officials of the nation's railroads and the striking United Transportation Union to appear at the White House tomorrow morning to discuss the "increasing economic impact arising from the continuation and expansion of the rail strike."

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 29 -- The first black ambassador to South Africa, Joe Kachingwe of Malawi, arrived today and said he believed contact and not isolation was the solution to the racial problems in South Africa.
VAIL, Colo., July 29 -- Leaning against a chalky blackboard, Mayor Lindsay defended the City University of New York's open-enrollment policy today against charges that it was not adequate.

The assistant editor of the National Rifle Association's American Rifleman cites "the proliferation of firearms among private Israeli citizens" [letter July 22] as rebuttal to the antiproliferation article of a faculty member of the Jewish Theological Seminary (Op-Ed July 5). What chutzpa.
The nation's money supply continues to expand at a very rapid pace, despite professed attempts by the Federal Reserve System to curb it, data published by the central bank indicated yesterday.
The police yesterday were seeking a man who entered a building on the City College campus and raped a young art lecturer.

An 80-year-old ballet teacher who danced with the Bolshoi Ballet before the Russian Revolution was mugged in her Carnegie Hall studio on Monday and died two days later of injuries sustained in the attack.

STAPLETON, Neb., July 29 -- From Logan County's modern, low-built brick courthouse, the sign and the American flag on the brand new building of the Bank of Stapleton across the way are barely visible as they peep over the top of the mound of wheat that fills a block on the south end of this town's drowsy Main Street.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 29 -- Senator George McGovern said today that he would introduce a bill calling for "an adequate income for every American'' and for a minimum of $6,500 a year for an urban family of four.
MERRICK, L.I., July 29 (UPI) -- A Manhattan lawyer who was charged last Tuesday with lying to a Manhattan grand jury was found dead today in the garage of his home here.
BABYLON, L. I., July 29 -- Argyle Park with its three placid lakes and tranquil shores has become the favorite nocturnal refuge of many of the young people of Babylon.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

The Union Pacific Corporation, parent of the Union Pacific rail system, hit by a strike two weeks ago by the United Transportation Union, reported second-quarter earnings yesterday of $22.4-million, or $1 a share, up 16.3 per cent from $19.2-million, or 86 cents a share, in comparable quarter of 1970.

JERUSALEM, July 29 -- As the first anniversary of the successful cease-fire along the Suez Canal approaches, what a high official termed "a national debate" appears to be developing on the question whether Israel's rigid negotiating position of the last four years has reached a point of diminishing returns.
Marty Pattin, who once struck out 22 batters in a nine-inning college game, yesterday pitched a four-hit shutout to give the Milwaukee Brewers a 3-0 victory over Boston.
Motorists driving in and out of the metropolitan area this weekend may encounter delays because of construction work at the following points listed by the Automobile Club of New York:
LONDON, July 29 -- Amid an uproar in the House of Commons, the Government announced a severe cutback today in shipbuilding jobs and operations on the Clyde River near Glasgow.

Pornography pushers, pimps, prostitutes and others allied with these businesses will be hit with charges of everything from tax evasion to littering under plans discussed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay's cabinet-level task force established to drive prostitution and pornography out of mid-Manhattan.

It never rains but it pours, all right. The Mets lost for the 20th time in 27 games last night when they were defeated by the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-1, in an eight-inning game that was interrupted by rain three times and took 4 1/2 hours to play.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills proposed today that "every consideration" be given to imposition by the United States of an across-the-board "surcharge" on imports and an equivalent "rebate" on exports as a means of improving the United States balance of trade and hence the over-all balance of international payments.
I am writing as a private citizen who happens to be an employe of the Bronx Children's Psychiatric Hospital.

The Spingold knockout team victory earlier this week was only the fourth time in the 37-year history of the event that a team has successfully defended its title. Stuart, Peter Weichsel, Steve Altman and Gene Neiger, all of New York, and Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn., are also one of the two youngest groups to have won the Spingold.

DACCA, Pakistan, July 29 -- Pakistan's military Government is waiting for what it fears may be a protracted guerrilla war in East Pakistan, and Government strategists are drawing from the writings of Mao Tse-tung and other experts in their plans.
A bodyguard of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. was quoted yesterday as having told Federal agents that the shooting of Colombo last June 28 was planned by "the Gallos."

School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has ordered officials of Community School District 9 in the Bronx to refrain in the future from issuing personnel lists that identify individuals by race or ethnic background in connection with hiring, rehiring or promotion.

MAMARONECK N. Y., July 20 -- Dick Siderowf of the Golf Club of Aspetuck at Easton, Conn., began a quest for a fourth straight Metropolitan amateur championship today by winning two matches by 7 and 6 over the West course at Winged Foot.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 29 -- No kickoffs, no punts, no runbacks and precious few running backs will be seen in the New York Giants' "controlled scrimmage" here Saturday morning, but a crowd of about 8,000 still is expected at the C. W. Post campus to see how a football team prepares for a season.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 29 (AP) -- A type of mosquito that can infect humans with deadly sleeping sickness is reported out of control in California because it has developed immunity to all known pesticides.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 29 -- Acting in line with general budget reductions, the board of trustees of Adelphi University has voted to discontinue intercollegiate football after the 1971 season.
Tax-exempt bond prices, which had advanced for a month, declined this week, pushing The Bond Buyer's yield index higher yesterday for the first time since mid-June.

MORIOKA, Japan, Friday, July 30 (UPI) -- A Japanese self-defense Force F-86 jet fighter and an All-Nippon Airways 727 jetliner carrying 161 persons collided over northern Japan today. The two crewmen of the fighter parachuted to safety, but there were apparently no survivors in the jetliner, officials said.
MOSCOW, July 29 -- The Soviet Union warned Sudanese leaders today against harboring illusions that they could maintain good relations with the Kremlin while cracking down on local Communists.
Stock prices, dropping steadily for the last three sessions, plunged through support levels yesterday to reach a new low since late January.

PARIS, July 29 -- The French Government gave a powerful stimulus to air-cushion rail travel today by deciding to proceed "with the greatest speed" to build a line from Paris to the burgeoning western suburb of Cergy-Pontoise.

Those who think of Italian fiction as a single exercise in realism from Verga to Moravia, with poetic and elegiac interludes by Dino Buzzati and Giorgio Bassani, will find something new, something un-Italian in the writings of Tommaso Landolfi. The characteristics of the stories gathered in "Cancerqueen" are evident enough, but far from easy to convey.

When President Nixon submitted his budget for fiscal 1971 eighteen months ago, he noted that he had "pledged to the American people that I would submit a balanced budget for 1971." Indeed, his new budget showed a $1.3 billion surplus. But this week the Government announced that the actual deficit for fiscal 1971 had climbed to $23.2 billion, the second largest deficit since World War II.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, July 29 -- Representatives of Canada's stock exchanges and investment dealers recommended today that foreign controlled securties houses be permitted to expand only if they eventually become 75 per cent Canadian-owned.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- John S. Nolan, Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury and one of the main architects of the 1969 tax reform bill, has resigned. He will leave the Treasury at the end of August.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation continued its recovery with the second consecutive quarterly profit, according to the mid-year report yesterday of William T. Gossett, chairman, and Dennis C. Stanfill, president.
In the menu below, dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

Former employes of the Municipal Loan Fund for the rehabilitation of slums are being called in for questioning by the city's Department of Investigation as the result of new information supplied by "private citizens who are coming forward," Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin said yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 30 (AP) -- A South Vietnamese task force in eastern Cambodia reported yesterday that it had fought a widespread four-hour battle with enemy forces, the first sizable contact since it began its sweep the day before.

JERSEY CITY, July 29 -- A Superior Court judge ruled today that Thomas J. Whelan and Thomas Flaherty automatically forfeited their offices as Mayor and City Council President here when they were convicted of extortion earlier this month.
"The Museum of Modern Art will be around for a while," prophesies John Hightower, its director for nearly 15 months. "And hopefully," he adds with a small smile, "I will be, too."
Soul folk music? It feels good to run out of pigeonholes sometimes, to encounter a performer who makes categorization difficult.

WASHINGTON, July 29 --The Nixon Administration announced today that it would give 20 cities, including Newark and Paterson, N.J., more money for Model Cities programs and wider latitude in deciding how to use it as a test of the revenue-sharing concept.
Striking telephone workers at a noisy rally here yesterday shouted their opposition to acceptance of a tentative contract with the New York Telephone Company.

Assistant Chief Inspector Sydney C. Cooper, who has the reputation of being the toughest corruption fighter in the Police Department, has been selected to take command of the unit charged with combating graft.
LONDON, July 29 -- Three British experts claimed today to have proved that many examples of Anatolian neolithic pottery in the world's leading museums are fakes.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- For the first time in their 69-year history the Yankees lost tonight to a Latin and Greek scholar who ushers at college basketball games.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A proposal by the Nixon Administration that the United States adopt the metric system caused about as much stir on Capitol Hill today as the first metrication suggestion made to Congress by John Quincy Adams 150 years ago.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- In tomorrow night's first pro football game of the season, matching the College All-Stars and the Baltimore Colts, the player the Giant fans should try to pick out on the television screen is No. 35 wearing blue, white and red stars.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 (AP) -- United States battle casualties in Indochina continued at near-record low levels last week, while South Vietnamese and enemy losses increased, the allied commands reported today.
A 42-year-old father of three pleaded guilty in Bronx Criminal Court yesterday to the murder of a Columbia University secretary whose fiance had originally been charged with the crime.

It must be getting lonely for former President Johnson down there on the ranch on the banks of the Pedernales. He's invited the public to visit him and Mrs. Johnson at the Johnson Library in Austin Sunday afternoon, and the director of the library said they "will be available to meet with visitors and to autograph books and material available at the library."

The El Paso Natural Gas Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the quarter and six months ended June 30. The quarterly report placed operating revenues at $254,148,000 up from $230,079,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (Reuters) -- President Nixon today nominated a career diplomat, Nathaniel Davis, as Ambassador to Chile, replacing Edward M. Korry, who has served four years in the post.

BOURNE, Mass., July 29 -- It was cup-racing time on Buzzards Bay today for the 64 boats in the New York Yacht Club cruise, and all four of the events encountered stiff breezes, the first ones in five days.

DETROIT, July 29 -- When Joseph Kerr, a conductor on the Penn Central Railroad, gets ready for work, he packs a suitcase full of clothes and crams a briefcase with rulebooks weighing three pounds that spell out his job in infinitesimal detail.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that President Lyndon B. Johnson "did not have any plans" to widen the Vietnam war before the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin incident.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The major steel companies have reportedly made their first firm economic offer to the steelworkers union as a strike deadline set for midnight Saturday draws nearer.
BUENOS AIRES, July 29 -- Exchange operations were halted throughout Argentina today after a Cabinet meeting presided over by President Alejandro A. Lanusse.
VIENTIANE, July 29 -- Laotian troops reoccupied the important provincial capital of Saravane yesterday, sources close to the acting Defense Minister, Sisouk Na Champassak, reported today.

YORK, Me. -- I have been reluctant to enter into the scrimmage caused by the publication in The New York Times and other newspapers of the documents procured from Dr. Daniel Ellsberg. This disinclination has been shattered by the news report that my former colleague, Dean Acheson, has injected himself into the controversy.
Mickey Smith, who works for a big Midwestern bookmaker, was in town yesterday and he had plenty to say. You can bet on it.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation's nuclear business will be "a very large profit contributor in 1971 and beyond," John W. Simpson, president of the company's power systems operations. said here yesterday. He reported that its nuclear business made "a significant profit in 1970."
Soybeans were the most active commodity on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, with 16,000 contracts traded. Futures prices were down 1 3/4 to 3 1/2 cents.

CAIRO, Friday, July 30 -- Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, the influential Cairo editor, expressed concern today about a wave of "brutality and violence" that has swept the Arab world in the last several weeks.
A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn yesterday upheld the right of the state to prevent real estate brokers from soliciting home sales in areas where blockbusting tactics are suspected.
Bache Co., Inc., the nation's second largest brokerage house, announced plans yesterday to go public with an offering of 2.5 million shares of its common stock at a maximum price of $25 each.
J. Walter Thompson and Foote, Cone Belding, both of which are on the Big Board, released first-half statements yesterday. The first was up and the second down.

To some who have observed him since his election to the bench here in 1944, State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell David Schweitzer has appeared to be an efficient, dedicated, honest, good-natured, compassionate and highly intelligent judge. To others he has appeared flareboyant, intimidating, cynical, humorless and injudicious.

The Bowater Sales Company, Inc., yesterday joined the growing list of newsprint producers who are raising prices by $8 a ton, effective Nov. 1. The announcement came from the Old Greenwich, Conn., office of the subsidiary of the giant Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd. It said the increase was "essential to cover the increased costs borne by all Bowater mills in North America."

HOUSTON, July 29 -- The astronauts of Apollo 15 swept into an orbit of the moon today -- three excited men seeing a desolate world of craters and rugged mountains below and exclaiming that it was "absolutely overwhelming, absolutely mind-boggling."
Following is the text of a letter dated July 29 from Governor Rockefeller to State Senator John H. Hughes concerning charges of misconduct against Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer:

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, in an opinion that imposed new restrictions on the use of "inside information," held today that investment managers who knowingly receive such information may not legally act upon it.
PARIS, July 29 -- Gold, silver and the "strong" European currencies were in demand in European markets today amid new anxieties over the health of the dollar.

LONDON, July 29 -- A spokesman for the J. Paul Getty Museum of Malibu, Calif., which purchased Titian's 16th-century masterpiece "The Death of Actaeon" here a month ago, said today that Britain had placed a three-month embargo on the painting's leaving the country.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 29 -- At a cost of $2,000 for each, eight colts were kept eligible this morning for the Dexter Cup Trot to be presented at Roosevelt Raceway on Aug. 7. The one-mile event, which will offer a gross purse of $124,249, will be the final major race for 3-year-old trotters before the Hambletonian at Du Quoin, Ill., Sept. 1.

The Labor party's National Executive Committee has voted even more decisively -- sixteen to six -- against British membership in the European Economic Community than had generally been predicted. This margin reflects a measure of success for Harold Wilson's effort to persuade pro-Community colleagues to vote against their convictions in the interests of short-run political advantage and the appearance of party unity.

LONDON -- The mood of Britain vis-a-vis the momentous subject of joining the Common Market is no longer analagous to that of the famous character in the rhyme, out again and in again, Finnegan begin again. Britain stayed out of the market at its inception, which was a very bad mistake, and subsequently was twice kept out by de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -President Nixon's special consultant on narcotics and dangerous drugs told Senate investigators today that 5.5 per cent of servicemen tested in South Vietnam had shown indications of heroin addiction.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 30 -Persons arriving here from Amman, Jordan, said today that Jordan had reinforced her forces along the northern border with Syria.

EAGLE'S NEST, Colo., July 30 -- More than 500 people rode the swaying metal gondolas of a ski lift to a symposium today on this 10,000-foothigh peak above the tourist village of Vail, many of the visitors drawn by the celebrity status of one of their number, New York City's Mayor Lindsay.
PRAGUE, July 30 -- Eastern Europe's trade bloc, the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, has reportedly agreed on a complex plan for economic integration, including a convertible currency.

CANTON, Ohio, July 30 -President Nixon canceled a trip to California tomorrow to address 1,600 influential Californians because, the White House said, he respected complaints from the press that his remarks would be off the record.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 30 -- Diplomatic sources said today that the Sudanese Government had asked Soviet experts in the Sudan in recent days to restrict or suspend their activities.
Television viewers will be able to watch the Apollo 15 astronauts on their explorations of the moon, if all goes well.

Eight New York black theater groups have banded together for the purpose of "institutionalizing black theater'' and in the hope of "obtaining a more equitable share of funding by non-Federal and Federal agencies," it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Government lost today its attempt to have a major environmental law suit shifted from Washingtan to Alaska.

It's always the right time of year to get in shape, the problem usually is getting around to doing something about it. Some women find exercises a bore. Others candidly admit that they are too lazy for strenuous routines.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Senate passed today with no dissenting votes a $21.1-billion appropriations bill for labor, health, education and welfare programs that is more than a billion dollars over last year's figure.
BLOOMINGDALE, Minn., July 30 -- Even seeing wasn't believing tonight.
HOUSTON, July 30 -- The outbreak of Venezuelan equine encephalomyelitis that has alarmed the United States horse industry, may have been confined to Texas.
Two men were arrested early yesterday morning and $209,600 of Mexican currency stolen from a South Bronx printing plant was recovered as detectives ended a threeweek surveillance of the suspects.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -"In this labor business," says I. W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers of America, "you have to be a fair fisherman. You have to have the ability to sit back and wait for a bite."

WASHINGTON. July 30 -- A high official of the United Steelworkers of America said today that steel companies had made "a very stingy offer" for a new contract but that "prayerfully" a settlement could still be reached before a strike deadline set for midnight tomorrow.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30 -- Dzemal Bijedic, a 54-year-old Bosnian, was sworn in today as Yugoslavia's new Premier. He pledged his Government to a policy of long-term sacrifices to end inflation and stabilize the economy.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -The House of Representatives approved tonight, by the unexpectedly small margin of three votes, a compromise version of legislation aimed at preventing the bankruptcy of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

HOUSTON, July 30 -- A group of independent oil and gas exploration companies has proposed stricter controls by the Securities and Exchange Commission of their outside financing as one way to attract more investors into oil and gas wildcatting.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 30 -- George Sauer visited the New York Jets' training camp last night. But to his former teammates' dismay, he did not stay.

Metropolitan-area postal workers, who are not satisfied with the recently negotiated national postal agreement, are seeking recognition on an area basis that would enable them to bargain separately.

Theoretically they still have it, but Councilman Matthew J. Troy, that county's Democratic leader, is -- with full Republican assistance -- making it more of a mockery than Carmine De Sapio in his palmiest days ever tried to make it in Manhattan.

JERUSALEM, July 30 -Premier Golda Meir conferred here for more than three hours today with Joseph J. Sisco, the United States Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, and they decided to continue their far-reaching discussions early next week.

Sixteen companies -- the most in one week for many months -ventured to offer their stock to the public for the first time this week: As a result, trading activity picked up a bit in the new-issue market, but prices tended to decline.
PITTSBURGH, July 30 -- A Federal judge awarded $4,998 bounty today to three citizens who had furnished river pollution information to the United States Attorney.
The deluge and violent thunderstorms -- with a tornado or two -- that struck the metropolitan area would not have happened if the elements had followed the traditional rules of weather maps.

MAHOPAC, N. Y., July 30 -This little Putnam County village was still buzzing today about a freak local tornado that swept a 30-yard-wide swath through it last evening, leveling trees and causing scattered property damage.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -House and Senate conferees broke the deadlock that has stalled the draft extension bill for the last month by reaching agreement today on a compromise version of the Senate's Vietnam troop withdrawal amendment.
Youths residing in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn told the police yesterday that excessive use of force to break up crowds had kindled a series of rock-throwing rampages in the area this week.
George A. Hirsch, who helped found New York magazine three years ago, has resigned as publisher and president in an apparent disagreement with its editor, Clay S. Felker.

TRIPOLI, Libya, July 30 -- A truncated conference of five Arab heads of state and Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, opened and closed here today. It threatened "practical measures" against Jordan for seeking "to liquidate" the Palestinian commando movement, but fell short of proposing immediate sanctions.

It is the considered view of at least half the governors of the United States that the current railroad strikes are having a "critical to disastrous" impact on the economy. The language may sound alarmist, but it would be foolish to belittle the effect of these strike actions, which have already shut down ten of the country's railroads.
SOUTHSEA, England, July 30 -- Edward Heath went to sea today in a beautiful mahogany yacht, the first Prime Minister to play a part in a big ocean race.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills, the Arkansas Democrat and powerful chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, had terse and tongue-in-cheek answers to questions at the National Press Club.

Investors who have been accustomed to the closing of the New York Stock Exchange each afternoon at 3:30 may be interested to learn they can have many of their trades executed until 4 o'clock in another market.
BERLIN, July 30 -- The Big Four met again today on Berlin without making substantial progress.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Prices received by farmers for raw products remained steady in July for the second straight month but averaged one per cent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department announced today.

State Supreme Court Justice Darwin M. Telesford refused yesterday to delay the collection of a new cent-a-gallon city tax on gasoline containing lead that is scheduled to go into effect at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Another reported crime against Vietnamese nationals by members of the Americal Division has come to light here in records of the United States Court of Military Appeals.
Wheat was fractionally higher, corn and soybeans mixed and oats fractionally lower at the close of trading yesterday at the Chicago Board of Trade.
VIENNA, July 30 -- Anna Freud suggested at a congress of psychoanalysts here today that her father's theory of aggression was still unproved.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined again yesterday. The index closed at 24.61, off 0.11. For the week the decline totaled 0.83, a sharp drop.
The lunar rover, the 460pound wire-wheeled vehicle rigged to unfold this morning from the side of the Apollo 15 landing craft, gives American space men a mobility never available before.

A sectional Swiss team championship begins today at the New York Hilton under the auspices of the Greater New York Bridge Association. Sessions begin at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. today and 1 P.M. and 7 P.M. tomorrow. Teams may compete for one day only.
LONDON, July 30 (AP) -Jerome Kern's 1927 musical "Show Boat" was revived at the Adelphi Theater last night, and today the critics agreed it's likely to stay for years.

Patrolman John R. Crocker, who was being sought in connection with a $143,000 robbery and shooting in the Municipal Building on July 9, surrendered yesterday at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Productivity in the entire private economy rose much less rapidly in the second quarter of this year than in the first quarter, the Labor Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -The Democratic Rules Commission finished drafting revised regulations for the 1972 convention today by adding a new loyalty requirement for delegates.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- President Nixon today named Air Force 1, his official airplane, Spirit of '76 in honor of the national bicentennial celebration of United States independence.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Earl Morrall, the 37-year-old quarterback who was a College AllStar back in 1956, threw three touchdown passes tonight to help the Baltimore Coils, the National Football League champions, beat the current edition of the All-Stars, 24-17, before 52,289 fans at Soldier Field.

The offtrack bettor had good news yesterday. OTB Corporation computers were back in operation for the first time in eight racing days and a full variety of betting will be available when action shifts to Saratoga Monday.
Richard Moore, who jumped bail last winter in the Black Panther conspiracy trial here, was charged with attempted murder yesterday in the machinegun shooting of two policemen last May 19.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 (UPI) -- A Pan American 747 with 212 persons aboard hit a runway light on take-off today, injuring 26 persons in the worst accident for the large jetliners since they went into service 18 months ago.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The House has passed a $4.57-billion public works bill but has rejected an amendment cutting off funds for an underground nuclear explosion this fall in the Aleutian Islands.

Pinchbeck, a name given most base-metal imitations of gold made before 1860, is attracting the interest of collectors more concerned with acquiring fascinating design than precious metal.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. -- In the spectacular Yosemite Valley, beneath tumbling waterfalls and soaring granite cliffs that were carved and polished by glacial ice two million years ago, the American tourist is learning to live for a while without the automobile.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., received a basic patent this week for a gas laser that is already in wide use by industry and government. The carbon dioxide laser, as it is known, creates an invisible beam of radiation that can be made powerful enough to burn holes through steel plates.
BUENOS AIRES, July 30 -- A significant new devaluation of the Argentine peso and measures that limit imports, foreign travel, and the flight of dollars went into effect today.

HOUSTON, July 30 -- In addition to the many spectacular and complex scientific studies that Apollo 15 is scheduled to carry out, there are a number of smaller, simpler experiments that, while not an important part of the mission, may prove just as fascinating.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 30 -- The New York Yacht Club cruise made its annual run from the Cape Cod Canal to Marblehead today, and many of the boats probably wish they hadn't.

Robert D. Timpany, the Federal trustee of the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey, filed a reorganization plan yesterday for that 592-mile carrier with the Federal District Court in Newark. WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The White House finally denied today, without ambiguity, that President Nixon was considering any change in the size or status of the Federal Reserve Board.
DETROIT, July 30 (UPI) -Ron Perranoski, "fireman of the year" with Billy Martin's Minnesota Twins in 1969, was acquired today by the Tigers to help fill Detroit's need for relief pitching.

A 30-year-old Desana Indian from an upper tributary of the Amazon on the Colombian-Brazilian frontier, he had drifted up to the capital city of Bogota via Roman Catholic missionary schools, a preparation for the priesthood and a stint in the army. His eclectic training and his life in a city that despised everything Indian violated his sense of identity.

LONDON, July 30 -- In March, 1960, a Soviet biochemist interested in the process of aging, Jaures Medvedev, had a letter from California. HOUSTON, July 30 -- Largescale exploration of the earth only became possible after the invention of the compass and other navigational tools. Now, for the first time, exploration of the moon's surface has similarly become dependent on such devices.

Possibly as few as 6,000 New York City welfare recipients -less than 1 per cent of the total number of people on welfare here -- are actually employable at this time, a study by a social services organization has tentatively found.

WEST HAVEN, Conn., July 30 (UPI) -- Control of the Connecticut Senate has been left in Democratic hands following Representative John D. Prete's victory over Alex Botte, a Republican, in a special election yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -A Federal judge condemned today the use of an electrical gadget purported to be a cureall, but he permitted the Church of Scientology to continue to use the instrument in its religious practices.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit rescinded today its order that excluded Chinese pupils from plans to integrate San Francisco's 95 elementary schools.

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., a holding company that derives nearly all its income from majority interests in its publicly owned subsidiaries, had an operating profit in the second quarter and first half this year before extraordinary charges. Getaway day at Aqueduct today will have as its feature race the Tidal Handicap, a 1 1/8mile turf test listed for its eighth running. Thoroughbred activity in this state then will shift to Saratoga for the regular 24-day meeting from Monday through Aug. 28.

Retail toy buyers in New York have just received their first look at Big Bird, Oscar the Grouch and Cookie Monster -- characters they may never have heard of before but which are already well-known to 8 million children throughout the country.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 31 -Caesar Kimmel's Chevron Flight established himself as the season's big 2-year-old today by winning the $117,550 Sapling Stakes on a sloppy track at rain-swept Monmouth Park.

WASHINGTON -- Vice President Agnew, theorized conservative columnist James J. Kilpatrick the other day, is a sort of Mount Everest to liberals. They like to criticize him "because he is there." TORONTO, Aug. 1 -- The Ontario Legislature gave final passage last week to a bill to prevent foreigners from buying more than a 25 per cent interest in wholesale distributors of magazines and paperback books in Canada's most populous province.
DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 1 -- Pakistan's airliners do not get hijacked or sabotaged. A typical half-hour flight within strife-torn East Pakistan shows why.

PLAINFIELD, N. J. -- Mrs. Linda North sat in her kitchen -- a room empty except for a stove, refrigerator and a secondhand table with two old chairs -- and explained why poverty in the metropolitan suburbs is so often "quiet," "hidden" or "voiceless."

DUBLIN -- Like the rest of the world Ireland has been having its environmental problems. Untreated sewerage has been pumped into one of the lakes of Killarney and it is not now altogether safe to bathe at Sandymount Strand because Dublin Bay is considered "an area of high pollu tion,"

SEATTLE, Aug. 1 -- A drug that is widely prescribed for minor intestinal upsets has apparently caused thousands of its users to suffer severe damage to eye muscles and nerves, a medical journal has warned physicians.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 31 -- The Venezuelan Congress which is unusual in Latin America in that it dictates its wishes to the executive branch of Government, is preparing legislation to nationalize all natural gas resources in the country.

Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that he was pressing to put a previously shelved transit-aid package before the State Legislature at a special session this year.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 1 -Whatever the outside world may think of the international activities of Col. Muammar elQaddafi last month no serious criticism is audible here or in Egypt and the Sudan, which are his friends and beneficiaries.

Two of the four Beatles, the rock group that came out of Liverpool to make musical history in the nineteen-sixties, were reunited on stage for the first time in more than four years yesterday. Over 40,000 people acclaimed them at two sold-out concerts at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of East Pakistani refugees.
AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 1 -This quiet city of 13,000 citizens has always been dominated by its institutions of higher learning.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1 -- The United States and South Vietnam have decided to start paying the highest cash rewards of the war -- up to the equivalent of $11,000 -- for information leading to the capture of certain key leaders of the Vietcong's political underground.

WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 1 -The John F. Kennedy Presidential Library has opened virtually the entire official White House files -- except for secret papers -- spanning the years of the Kennedy Administration, from Jan. 20, 1961, to Nov. 22, 1963.
Wilbur Wood, whose left-handed knuckleball is more tiresome to the opposition than to himself, boasted repeatedly this season that he could pitch both games of a double-header.
ADENAU, Germany, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Jackie Stewart of Scotland all but clinched the world driving championship today by winning the German Grand Prix in record time.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Pope Paul VI praised the "genius, skill and daring" of America's Apollo 15 moon exploration today and disclosed that the three astronauts had sent him a message of thanks for his good wishes to them.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 1 -- Mrs. Anita Fording of Cohoes, N. Y., and Mrs. Shirley Johnson of Cape Girardeau, Mo., looked surprised when a newsman asked them about the Apollo astronauts on the moon. They said they were not interested.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- The Post Office said today that Apollo 15 astronauts planned to cancel a new United States stamp on the moon tomorrow and that it would then go on sale immediately at Cape Kennedy, Fla., Huntsville, Ala., and Houston.

The Wells Fargo Bank, San Francisco, has reached a tentative agreement to acquire a 50 per cent interest in the Allegemeine Deutsch Credit-Anstalt, a Berlin-based bank, with assets of about $85-million.
Five policemen were injured early yesterday when they tried to arrest several drag racers in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

The Rev. William Lombardy of St. Mary's Church in the Bronx is, in his spare time -- what he has of it -- one of America's strongest grandmasters. Though he has played no tournament chess lately, he has given a few exhibitions of simultaneous play.

PEKING, Aug. 1 -- Despite President Nixon's recent efforts to establish normal relations with China, powerful officials of the People's Liberation Army are mounting a campaign for total withdrawal of United States troops not only from Taiwan and Vietnam but also from Korea, Japan the Philippines and Thailand.
The New York Mets, who were happy to flee from July, stumbled into August yesterday and found no relief.

The two Apollo astronauts were scheduled to make their last trip across the lunar surface today. They were originally scheduled to begin their final excursion at 3:24 A.M., but the time was delayed as the astronauts ran behind in most of their activities.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1 -- Senator George McGovern campaigned through the paper-mill towns and family farms of Wisconsin this weekend, pressing his few but important advantages in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
William C. Wahl has been elected a corporate group vice president and president of General Foods International, General Foods Corporation announced over the weekend.

CLEVELAND Aug. 1 (AP) -- Gabe Paul, president and general manager of the Cleveland Indians, said today the club was starting a grievance procedure against Sam McDowell. The ace left-handed pitcher was suspended yesterday for not reporting for games and is demanding to be declared a free agent.

Your July 26 news story about the Rikers Island Reformatory again reveals the city administration's perversion of justice and retribution. The story deals extensively with the reformatory and the alleged denial of adequate training and rehabilitation to youthful offenders, and their subjection to "empty days and useless work."

MONT TREMBLANT, Quebec, Aug. 1 -- On the 60th lap, with 10 laps to go, Mark Donohue got the "EZ" sign from his car owner, Roger Penske, at the time donohue's factory Javelin was beyond challenge from the Bud Moore Mustang driven by George Follmer.
CALI, Colombia, Aug. 1 -- Marty Liquori made it look easy tonight en route to a gold medal in the 1,500-meter run at the Pan-American Games.

The July 20 letter from Peter M. Schwartz concerning the conditions at the Central Park Zoo describes the inadequacies but neglects the measures already taken toward improvement of the zoo's educational potential.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The United States command pulled seven more Army units out of combat today, cutting American troop strength in Vietnam by 2,990 men. The withdrawal was the biggest in a month.
CRESTWOOD, Mo. -- It is very hot in middle America these days, and Henry Crews worries a lot about his grass.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- For years Jerome Robbins has been negotiating with Britain's Royal Ballet. Indeed, years ago, his famous version of "Les Noces" was planned for the Royal Ballet, but got lost in transit.

The enormous progress made by the United States manned space program in just two years has been amply demonstrated by Falcon's stay on the lunar surface. Astronauts Scott and Irwin have already accomplished many times as much useful work as did their pioneering predecessors during all of Apollo ll's stayin July, 1969.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Mortgage loan delinquencies at savings and loan associations remained low during the second quarter, despite continued inflation and substantial unemployment, the United States Savings and Loan League announced today.
PRAGUE, Aug. 1 -- Premier Lubomir Strougal has disclosed that the new economic integration plan drafted in Bucharest will include a "collective currency'' for Eastern Europe.

CALI, Colombia, Aug. 1 -- The United States invented the game of basketball, but Cuba borrowed the ingredients for success today and scored a stunning 73-69 upset of the men's team in the sixth Pan-American Games.

Everybody's crazy over horses. Well, almost everybody. Last year 45 million racing fans cheered on the thoroughbreds in 28 states across the country and wagered a total of $4.-billion.

When Virgil Thomson and Gertrude Stein wrote their second opera, "The Mother of Us All," 24 years ago, they were well ahead of their time. Important artist usually are.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- Dr. Pyotr L. Kapitsa, the Soviet physicist, says civilization is threatened by the increase in wealth and leisure time in advanced industrial countries. He advocates a more liberal education that would turn out independent-minded, creative thinkers able to cope with the new life style of the future.

There is a heady atmosphere in the chancelleries of Europe this summer. The feeling everywhere is: Europe is entering a new era.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Richard (Rick) Spears of the Orange County Golf Club at Middletown, in his next-to-last tournament before turning professional, won the Metropolitan Amateur championship today. But their years of political power were alike in one profoundly depressing sense. Both created deep disillusionment among the naturally optimistic reformist elements in their societies.

United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr., yesterday urged people boating or fishing during the summer to help his office track down sources of pollution in the Hudson River and its tributaries.

Almost unnoticed except by two decades of students, Lucas Hoving rounded out 20 active years at Connecticut College's American Dance Festival over the weekend. All the evidence suggests that this is the most productive scientific expedition ever carried out in space. Even before the astronauts' own return, the information they have sent back has already forced reconsideration of some key ideas about the natural history of the moon.

The nation's savings and loan associations had a net increase in deposits of $1.3-billion in June, the smallest monthly increase so far this year, the National League of Insured Savings Associations reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 2 (UPI) -Tax collections for the first third of the state's fiscal year were about $118 - million behind last year's level, the Tax Department said today.
